A panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit reversed, holding that the life sentence was so grossly disproportionate to the defendant's offenses as to constitute cruel and unusual punishment (568 F2d 1193), but on rehearing by the Court of Appeals sitting en banc, the panel's opinion was vacated and the District Court's denial of habeas corpus relief was affirmed (587 F2d 651).

After falling behind in their mortgage payments to a bank, which had loaned them $ 68,250 for the purchase of their principal residence in Texas, a husband and wife filed a petition for relief under Chapter 13 of the Bankruptcy Code (11 USCS 1301 et seq.) in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Northern District of Texas. The bank filed a proof of claim with the Bankruptcy Court for $ 71,335 in principal, interest, and fees owed on the note which the mortgage secured. Relying on 506(a) of the Bankruptcy Code (11 USCS 506(a))--which provides that an allowed claim secured by a lien on the debtor's property is a secured claim to the extent of the value of the creditor's interest in the property and is an unsecured claim to the extent the claim exceeds the value of the creditor's interest in the property--the debtors (1) valued the residence at $ 23,500 in their Chapter 13 plan and proposed to make payments pursuant to the mortgage contract up to only that amount plus prepetition arrearages; and (2) proposed to treat the remainder of the bank's claim as unsecured. Under the debtors' proposed plan, unsecured creditors were to receive nothing. The bank and the Chapter 13 trustee, objecting to the plan, argued that the debtors' proposed bifurcation of the bank's claim into a secured claim for $ 23,500 and an effectively worthless unsecured claim modified the bank's rights as a homestead mortgagee in violation of 11 USCS 1322(b)(2), which provides that a Chapter 13 plan may "modify the rights of holders of secured claims, other than a claim secured only by a security interest in real property that is the debtor's principal residence." Agreeing with the bank and the trustee, the Bankruptcy Court denied confirmation of the debtors' Chapter 13 plan. On appeal, the United States District Court for the Northern District of Texas (129 BR 98) and the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit (968 F2d 483) both affirmed.

The first count of a criminal complaint charged a motorist with violation of the California Vehicle Code's provision against passing another vehicle without maintaining a safe distance, and the second count of the complaint charged him with failing to comply with the provisions of the "hit and run" statute, requiring the driver of a motor vehicle involved in an accident resulting in damage to any property to stop at the scene and give his name and address. Both charges arose out of the same accident, and the defendant's demurrer to the second count, asserting violation of his privilege against self-incrimination, was overruled by a California Justice Court. The defendant then sought a writ of prohibition from the Superior Court of Mendocino County, California, to restrain prosecution of the second count. The Superior Court issued the writ, and the Supreme Court of California ultimately affirmed, holding that the privilege against self- incrimination was applicable to a motorist, such as the defendant, who reasonably believed that compliance with the statute would result in a substantial risk of self-incrimination. The California Supreme Court also held that in the case of such a motorist, the hit-and-run statute should be limited by a restriction preventing use in subsequent criminal prosecutions, arising from the motorist's conduct, of information disclosed under the statute, and the fruits of such information, but the court concluded that it would be unfair to punish the defendant for failure to comply with the statute, since he could have had no knowledge that use restrictions would be imposed by the courts (71 Cal 2d 1039, 80 Cal Rptr 553, 458 P2d 465).

Pursuant to a Berkeley, California, ordinance which placed a limitation of $ 250 on contributions to committees formed to support or oppose ballot measures, the city fair campaign practices commission ordered an unincorporated association formed to oppose a particular ballot measure to pay into the city treasury the amount of contributions it received in excess of the permitted amount. Two weeks before the election, the association sought and obtained from the Superior Court, Alameda County, a temporary restraining order prohibiting enforcement of the ordinance. Following the ballot measure's defeat, the Superior Court granted the association's motion for summary judgment, declaring that the ordinance was invalid on its face because it violated the state constitution and the First Amendment of the Federal Constitution, and the California Court of Appeal, First District, affirmed that conclusion (160 Cal Rptr 448). The Supreme Court of California reversed, concluding that the ordinance furthered compelling governmental interests because it ensured that special interest groups could not corrupt the initiative process by spending large amounts to support or oppose a ballot measure and that the ordinance accomplished its goal by the least restrictive means available (27 Cal3d 819, 614 P2d 742, 167 Cal Rptr 84).

In a Florida state court action brought for separate maintenance by the wife of the scion of a wealthy family, the husband counterclaimed for divorce on grounds of extreme cruelty and adultery by the wife. The divorce court granted the husband's counterclaim, but its judgment was ambiguous and did not specify that the basis for the judgment was either of the two grounds alleged in the counterclaim. After a news magazine publisher printed an article reporting that the wife and her husband had been divorced on the basis of the wife's extreme cruelty and adultery, the divorcee brought a libel action in a Florida state court, and the Supreme Court of Florida ultimately upheld a judgment against the publisher (305 So 2d 172).

In a Florida state court, the accused was convicted of murder and sentenced to death. There was no suggestion that he was incompetent at the time of his offense, at trial, or at sentencing. Later, however, he began to manifest changes in behavior, indicating a mental disorder. At his attorneys' request, two psychiatrists examined him, one of whom concluded that he was not competent to suffer execution. His counsel then invoked the procedures of Florida law governing the determination of the competency of a condemned inmate. Following such procedures, the Governor of Florida appointed a panel of three psychiatrists to evaluate whether the accused had the mental capacity to understand the nature of the death penalty and the reasons why it was imposed on him. The Governor specifically directed that during the evaluation, the accused's and the state's attorneys should not participate in any adversarial manner. The members of the panel together interviewed the accused for about 30 minutes, and while they differed on their diagnoses, they agreed that the accused understood his situation and the nature of the death penalty. The accused's attorneys then tried unsuccessfully to submit to the Governor some other materials, including the reports of the psychiatrists who had examined the accused at his counsel's request. The Governor announced his decision when, without any explanation or statement, he signed a death warrant for the accused's execution. The accused's attorneys, after unsuccessfully seeking a hearing in state court to determine his competency to suffer execution (451 So 2d 471), filed a petition for habeas corpus in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida, seeking an evidentiary hearing on the question of his sanity, and proferring the conflicting findings of the Governor-appointed panel and subsequent challenges to their methods by other psychiatrists. The District Court denied the petition without a hearing, and the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit affirmed, holding that the Florida procedures for determining the competency of condemned prisoners met minimum standards required by procedural due process (752 F2d 526).

MuAn Arizona criminal defendant was charged with first-degree murder, based in part on evidence that (1) he had been found driving the victim's car and using the victim's credit cards, and (2) other items belonging to the victim had been found in a rental car abandoned by the defendant. After the defendant's initial conviction was set aside by the Supreme Court of Arizona (142 Ariz 619, 691 P2d 710), the defendant was retried on theories of both premeditated murder and felony-murder, either of which, under the trial court's instructions to the jury, would constitute first-degree murder. The defense, contending that the circumstantial evidence proved at most that the defendant was a thief, requested an instruction on theft as a lesser included offense. The trial court refused this request, but did instruct the jury on second-degree murder, and further advised them that all 12 jurors had to agree on a verdict. The defendant was then convicted of first-degree murder and sentenced to death. In affirming the defendant's conviction and sentence against various challenges, the Supreme Court of Arizona held that the trial court (1) had not erred in failing to require the jury to agree on a single theory of first-degree murder, since first-degree murder is one offense under state law regardless of whether it occurs as premeditated murder or felony-murder, and (2) had not committed plain error in failing to instruct the jury on the lesser included offense of robbery (168 Ariz 411, 788 P2d 1162).

The plaintiffs' spouses, a Navy flight instructor and her student, were killed during training exercises when their Navy airplane, banking sharply to avoid another airplane, crashed and burned. At the trial of the plaintiffs' product liability suit against the companies that had manufactured and serviced the decedents' airplane, the only seriously disputed question was whether pilot error or equipment malfunction had caused the crash. Having initially determined that an investigative report prepared pursuant to authority granted in the Manual of the Judge Advocate General (the JAG Report) was sufficiently trustworthy to be admissible, the trial judge admitted, over the plaintiffs' objection, most of the JAG Report's "opinions," including a paragraph opining that pilot error was the most probable cause of the crash. One of the plaintiffs, who was himself a Navy flight instructor, had, some 6 months after the crash, written a detailed letter based on his own investigation in which he took issue with some of the JAG Report's findings and outlined his theory that equipment malfunction had been the most probable primary cause of the crash. At trial, after that plaintiff admitted on direct examination as an adverse witness that he had made certain statements in his letter arguably implicating pilot error as the cause of the crash, his counsel attempted to ask him on cross-examination whether he had not also said in the letter that the most probable primary cause of the crash had been loss of engine power. However, before the plaintiff answered, the court sustained a defense objection on the ground that the question asked for the plaintiff's opinion; further questioning along this line was cut off. After the jury returned a verdict for the defendants, a panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit reversed and remanded for a new trial (784 F2d 1523). Accepting the argument that Rule 803(8)(C) of the Federal Rules of Evidence, which excepts investigatory reports from the hearsay rule, did not encompass evaluative conclusions or opinions, the Court of Appeals held that the "conclusions" contained in the JAG Report should have been excluded. Citing Rules 106 (partially codifying the common-law rule of completeness) and 801(d)(1)(B) (relating to the nonhearsay status of prior consistent statements) of the Federal Rules of Evidence, the Court of Appeals also held that it had been reversible error for the trial court to have prohibited cross-examination regarding additional portions of the plaintiff's letter that would have put in context the admissions elicited from him on direct examination. On rehearing en banc, the Court of Appeals upheld the panel's judgment (827 F2d 1498).

Two citizens and qualified voters in Georgia's Fifth Congressional District, which has a population of 823,680 as contrasted with the 394,312 population of the average Georgia congressional district, brought suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Georgia against the Georgia governor and secretary of state for a judgment declaring invalid the Georgia congressional districting statute and enjoining the defendants from conducting elections under it. The District Court, sitting as a three-judge court, dismissed the case for nonjusticiability and want of equity. (206 F Supp 276.)

The defendant, who had sold heroin to undercover federal agents pursuant to arrangements made by a government informant, was convicted of a federal narcotics offense upon trial in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri, the trial court having refused to give the defendant's requested instruction that if it was found, as contended by the defendant, that the narcotics had been supplied to him by the informant, the defendant must be acquitted as a matter of law, regardless of any predisposition of the defendant to commit the offense charged. On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit affirmed, rejecting the argument of the defendant, who conceded that he was predisposed to commit the offense, that if the jury found that the narcotics had been supplied by the informant, the defendant should have been acquitted (507 F2d 832).

In March 1992, a party commenced an action in the Court of Common Pleas in Summit County, Ohio against a corporation and a guarantor of the corporation's performance under two commercial leases. The corporation filed a Chapter 11 bankruptcy petition in May 1992 in the Southern District of New York. In September 1992, the guarantor's successor in interest filed notices of removal in the United States District and Bankruptcy Courts for the Northern District of Ohio. The removal was based on a provision of the bankruptcy removal statute, 28 USCS 1452(a), and a provision of the general federal removal statute, 28 USCS 1441(a). The Ohio Bankruptcy Court, in which all proceedings were consolidated, (1) concluded that the action had been timely removed under 1441; and (2) granted a motion to transfer venue to the Southern District of New York. On appeal, the Ohio District Court (1) found that the removal was untimely under 1441(a) and 1452(a); (2) concluded that the Bankruptcy Court lacked jurisdiction over the case; and (3) effectively remanded the case to state court. On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit (1) determined that the general statutory provision governing the reviewability of Federal District Court orders remanding removed cases to state court, 28 USCS 1447(d), and a provision of the bankruptcy removal statute, 28 USCS 1452(b), barred appellate review of the Ohio District Court's remand order; and (2) dismissed the appeal for lack of jurisdiction.

The father sought to have his son returned to Chile from the United States, where he had been taken by respondent mother. Chilean courts had granted the mother daily care and control of the child and had awarded visitation rights to the father. Under Chilean law, the father had a ne exeat right to consent before the mother could take the child out of Chile. The court of appeals held that the ne exeat right was not a "right of custody" under the Convention and that the Convention's return remedy was therefore not authorized. The Supreme Court disagreed, holding that the father's joint right to decide the child's country of residence was a right of custody within the meaning of Convention art. 5(a). The father's ne exeat right gave him the right to determine the child's place of residence by ensuring that the child could not live outside Chile and also gave the father rights relating to the care of the person of the child. To have interpreted the Convention as not providing a return remedy for removal of a child in violation of a ne exeat right would have run counter to the Convention's purpose of deterring parents from seeking a friendlier forum for deciding custody disputes.

After having been arrested and charged with selling marijuana to a local narcotics bureau informant, the two defendants were given the Miranda warnings, but remained silent. At their separate trials in the Common Pleas Court of Tuscarawas County, Ohio, the defendants testified that they had been framed by narcotics agents. For the purpose of impeaching the defendants' testimony, the prosecutor cross-examined them about their failure to tell the frame story at the time of their arrests. Defense counsel's timely objections to the prosecutor's questions were overruled by the trial court, and the defendants admitted their post-arrest silence. They were convicted of the offenses charged. On their separate appeals, the Court of Appeals, Fifth District, Tuscarawas County, affirmed the convictions, and the Ohio Supreme Court denied further review.

Each of the three petitioners was Negro, was convicted in a state court, and was sentenced to death after a trial by a jury which, under applicable state statutes, had discretion to determine whether or not to impose the death penalty. One petitioner was convicted of murder, and his death sentence was upheld by the Georgia Supreme Court (225 Ga 253, 167 SE2d 628). The second petitioner was convicted of rape, and his death sentence was upheld by the Georgia Supreme Court (225 Ga 790, 171 SE2d 501). And the third petitioner was convicted of rape, and his death sentence was upheld by the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals (447 SW2d 932).

No. 242 is a suit brought by employees in a New York state court to recover damages for breach of a collective bargaining contract, and removed to the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York by the defendant employer on the ground of diversity of citizenship. The employees' right to recover, denied by the District Court (185 F Supp 441), was sustained by a divided panel of the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit (288 F2d 99), in an opinion by a judge of the Court of Claims sitting by designation of the Chief Justice of the United States under 28 USC 293(a). No. 481 is a criminal prosecution instituted in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia and resulting in a conviction affirmed by the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. (111 App DC 238, 296 F2d 360.) The trial was presided over by a retired judge of the Court of Customs and Patent Appeals sitting by similar designation. In both cases the United States Supreme Court granted certiorari, limited to the question whether the judgment in either was vitiated by the respective participation of the judges mentioned above. Answering this question in the negative, the United States Supreme Court affirmed the judgments below. However, the Court could not agree upon an opinion.

The defendant was tried in the Corporation Court of Austin, Texas, and found guilty of violating a statute which made it unlawful to be drunk in a public place. Upon appeal and trial de novo in the County Court at Law No. 1 of Travis County, Texas, the defendant asserted that to punish him criminally would be cruel and unusual punishment, contrary to the Eighth Amendment as applied to the states under the Fourteenth Amendment, since the defendant was afflicted with the disease of chronic alcoholism and his appearance in public was not of his own volition. The County Court, ruling as a matter of law that chronic alcoholism was not a defense to the charge and finding the defendant guilty, entered findings of fact that chronic alcoholism is a disease which destroys the afflicted person's will power to resist constant, excessive consumption of alcohol, that a chronic alcoholic does not appear in public by his own volition but under a compulsion symptomatic of the disease, and that the defendant was afflicted with the disease of chronic alcoholism.

In 1970, Congress enacted Title X of the Public Health Service Act (42 USCS 300--300a-41). The Act authorizes the Secretary of Health and Human Services to make grants to, and enter into contracts with, public or nonprofit private entities to assist in family planning projects. Under 1008 of the Act (42 USCS 300a-6), it is provided that "[n]one of the funds appropriated under this subchapter shall be used in programs where abortion is a method of family planning." In 1988, the Secretary promulgated new regulations ( 42 CFR 59.2, 59.8, 59.9, and 59.10), which specified that projects receiving Title X funds (1) may not provide counseling concerning the use of abortion, or referral for abortion, as a method of family planning; (2) may not engage in activities that encourage, promote, or advocate abortion as a method of family planning; and (3) must be organized so that they are physically and financially separate from prohibited abortion activities. After the regulations had been promulgated, but before they had been applied, several Title X grantees and doctors who supervised Title X funds filed two separate actions against the Secretary in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, in which actions the grantees and doctors challenged the regulations on the grounds that the regulations (1) were not authorized by Title X, (2) violated the rights of Title X health care providers and Title X clients under the Federal Constitution's First Amendment, and (3) violated the rights of Title X clients under the Federal Constitution's Fifth Amendment. Following consolidation of the actions, the District Court granted summary judgment in favor of the Secretary (690 F Supp 1261). On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, affirming, ruled that the regulations (1) were a permissible construction of Title X, (2) did not impermissibly burden a woman's right to an abortion, and (3) did not constitute a facial violation of the First Amendment rights of health care providers or of women (889 F2d 401).

The issue presented by this case was whether the owner and operator of community antenna television (CATV) systems, which carried, as part of the programing received from the several television stations whose signals were provided to customers of the systems, copyrighted motion pictures for which the stations, but not the CATV systems, were licensed by the copyright holder, infringed the latter's exclusive performance rights under the Copyright Act of 1909 (17 USC 1 et seq.). The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York ruled in favor of the copyright holder (255 F Supp 177), and the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit affirmed (377 F2d 872).

An American citizen, who was also a citizen of Japan under Japanese law, and who resided in Japan during World War II, registered there in a family census register; on the strength of this entry, he had his name removed as an alien in a police station, changed his registration at a university from American to Japanese, and obtained employment as an interpreter with a Japanese private corporation, where he maltreated American prisoners of war there employed. After Japan's surrender he applied to the United States consul for registration as an American citizen and obtained a passport for his return to the United States. There he was convicted of treason, despite his protestations that, while residing in Japan, he had renounced his American citizenship.

In 1992, a police officer in Milwaukee approached a 1981 two-door Oldsmobile with California license plates in a motel parking lot--a car that was arguably characteristic of one typically used by drug couriers--and asked the two men inside the car whether they had any illegal drugs or contraband. The men said they did not, but they consented to a search of the car. A second officer, conducting the search without having obtained a warrant, discovered cocaine inside an interior panel. The men were arrested on drug charges. In pretrial motions to suppress the cocaine evidence, it was alleged that the officers had violated the men's rights under the Federal Constitution's Fourth Amendment by detaining the men in the parking lot and by searching inside the panel without a warrant. A United States Magistrate Judge concluded that the circumstances had given the officers reasonable suspicion to stop and question the men, but not probable cause to conduct a warrantless search. The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin--adopting the Magistrate Judge's recommendation with respect to reasonable suspicion, but not the reasoning as to probable cause--ruled that the cocaine need not be excluded, and the men were convicted. The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, reviewing deferentially the District Court's determinations of reasonable suspicion and probable cause, (1) said that the determinations would be reversed only upon a finding of "clear error"; and (2) found no clear error in the reasonable-suspicion analysis and affirmed that determination; but (3) vacated the District Court's judgments of conviction and remanded the case for a determination as to probable cause (16 F3d 714). On remand, the District Court ruled that probable cause had supported the search. The Court of Appeals, finding that this determination was not clearly erroneous, affirmed (52 F3d 328, 1995 US App LEXIS 9069).

Following the denial of a pretrial motion to suppress, the prosecution, at defendant's trial in the Court of Common Pleas of Cuyahoga County on a charge of carrying a concealed weapon, introduced in evidence a revolver seized from defendant by a police officer after the officer observed the unusual conduct of defendant and two other men and, concluding that these men contemplated a daylight robbery, stopped and frisked them, thereby discovering guns. The Ohio Court of Appeals for the Eighth Judicial District, Cuyahoga County, affirmed. (5 Ohio App 2d 122, 34 Ohio Ops 2d 237, 214 NE2d 114.) The Supreme Court of Ohio dismissed defendant's appeal on the ground that no substantial constitutional question was involved.

Before a Florida robbery trial, the defendant filed two motions. The first sought a protective order excusing him from the requirements, under a Florida rule of criminal procedure, that he furnish the prosecuting attorney in advance of trial with the names and addresses of any alibi witnesses and information as to the place where he was claiming to have been. He objected to the disclosure requirements on the ground that the rule compelled him to be a witness against himself in violation of his Fifth and Fourteenth Amendment rights. His second motion sought to impanel a 12-man jury instead of the 6-man jury provided by Florida statute in all but capital cases. Both motions were denied, and the defendant was convicted as charged and was sentenced to life imprisonment. The Florida District Court of Appeal affirmed, rejecting the defendant's claims that his Fifth and Sixth Amendment rights had been violated (224 So 2d 406).

The EPA argued that the Clean Air Act (CAA) did not authorize the EPA to address global climate change and that, in any event, executive policy specifically addressing global warming warranted the EPA's refusal to regulate in such area. The U.S. Supreme Court first held that petitioners had standing to challenge EPA's denial of their rulemaking petition since at least one petitioner state properly asserted a concrete injury from the potential further loss of its coastal land, much of which was owned by the state, from rising sea levels caused by climate change. Further, because greenhouse gases were clearly within the CAA's broad definition of an air pollutant, the EPA had the statutory authority to regulate the emission of such gases from new motor vehicles, and there was no showing of any congressional intent to bar the EPA from addressing global warming. Also, it was undisputed that global warming threatened serious harms, and policy considerations were irrelevant to the EPA's statutory mandate to determine whether the greenhouse gases contributed to global warming and whether motor vehicle emissions of such gases actually or potentially endangered public health or welfare.

A criminal defendant was found by a Louisiana trial court to have been insane at the time of the offense, and accordingly the court ruled that he was not guilty by reason of insanity. The person was committed to a psychiatric facility until such time as doctors recommended that he be released, and until further order of the court. When the superintendent of the facility and a three-member panel at the facility recommended that the person be conditionally discharged, the trial judge appointed a commission of two doctors, who reported that the person was in remission from mental illness, but that he had an antisocial personality, and that this condition was not a mental disease but was untreatable. One of the doctors testified that the person had been involved in several altercations at the facility and that the doctor would not feel comfortable in certifying that the person would not be a danger to himself or to other people. After it was stipulated that the other doctor would have given essentially the same testimony, the court ruled that the person was dangerous to himself and to others and ordered him returned to the facility. The Court of Appeals of Louisiana refused supervisory writs. The Supreme Court of Louisiana, affirming, held that (1) neither the due process clause nor the equal protection clause of the Federal Constitution's Fourteenth Amendment was violated by a Louisiana statutory provision under which an insanity acquittee who has been committed to a mental hospital, but whose release from the hospital has been recommended by a hospital review panel, may be returned to the hospital after a court hearing, regardless of whether the acquittee is then mentally ill, if the acquittee fails to prove that the acquittee is not dangerous; and (2) the person had not carried the burden of proving that he was not dangerous (563 So 2d 1138).

Contrary to the employees' argument, 28 U.S.C.S. ¬¨√ü 1453(c) did not deprive the U.S. Supreme Court of jurisdiction to review a case. "Principal place of business" under ¬¨√ü 1332(c)(1) referred to where a corporation's officers directed, controlled, and coordinated the corporation's activities, a "nerve center." It would normally be a corporation's headquarters--provided it was not simply an office for board meetings. The "nerve center" was a single place. A more general business activities test led to incorrectly measuring the amount of business activities in a state. The simple "nerve center" jurisdictional rule promoted predictability. The "nerve center" approach was simple to apply, comparatively speaking. Section 1332(c)(1)'s legislative history suggested "principal place of business" was not to be interpreted to be complex. The employer's unchallenged declaration suggested its center of direction, control, and coordination, its "nerve center," and its corporate headquarters, were one and the same, located in New Jersey. But, the employees would have a fair opportunity to litigate that issue on remand.  [***1030]

In 1977, the Kansas City, Missouri, School District, the school board, and the children of two school board members brought suit in the United States District Court for the Western District of Missouri against the state of Missouri, various suburban school districts, and other defendants for allegedly causing and perpetuating racial segregation in the schools of the city's metropolitan area. The District Court, having dismissed the case against the suburban school districts and realigned the city district as a nominal defendant, determined that the state and the city district had operated a segregated school system within the city district (593 F Supp 1485). In 1985, the District Court (1) determined that segregation had caused a systemwide reduction in student achievement in the city district's schools; (2) identified 25 schools within the city district that had enrollments of 90 percent or more black students; and (3) ordered a wide range of remedial "quality education" programs for all students in the city district's schools (639 F Supp 19). In 1986, the District Court adopted a comprehensive magnet school program in order to draw nonminority students from private schools and the suburban districts into city district schools. In 1987 and subsequently, the District Court ordered salary assistance that was eventually extended to virtually all of the city district's instructional and noninstructional employees. The costs of these and other desegregation programs ordered by the District Court for the city district ultimately approached an annual cost of $ 200 million. The District Court's authority to order the city district to levy taxes to fund the desegregation programs was ultimately upheld in 1990 by the United States Supreme Court (495 US 33, 109 L Ed 2d 31, 110 S Ct 1651), but a major share of the programs' costs was paid by the state. In 1992, the District Court ordered the state to continue to fund the quality education programs, on the ground that student achievement levels were still at or below national norms at many grade levels. In 1993, the District Court--noting that its salary ruling was grounded in remedying the vestiges of segregation by improving the city district's desegregative attractiveness--entered orders requiring the state to pay for across-the-board salary increases and to continue funding the quality education programs. A panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit affirmed (11 F3d 755, 13 F3d 1170), and the Court of Appeals denied rehearing en banc (19 F3d 393).

A taxpayer, a public utility engaged in the production and sale of electric energy, used its own transportation equipment and employees in the construction of and additions to its capital facilities. On its books, in accordance with methods prescribed by the Federal Power Commission and the Idaho Public Utilities Commission, the taxpayer capitalized the construction- related depreciation, but for income tax purposes that depreciation increment was claimed as a deduction under 26 USCS 167(a). The Commissioner of Internal Revenue disallowed this deduction, and was upheld by the United States Tax Court (29 TCM 383), but the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit reversed (477 F2d 688).

An alien entered the United States illegally and was taken by smugglers to a house in Escondido, California. Six days later, in exchange for his not having to pay the smugglers for bringing him across the border, the alien agreed to drive himself and five other passengers to Los Angeles. During the course of this drive, the alien and three of his passengers were apprehended by the United States Border Patrol. Following their arrest, the alien and the other passengers were interviewed by criminal investigators. The alien and his three passengers admitted that they were illegally in the country and all of the passengers identified the alien as the driver of the car. An Assistant United States Attorney concluded that the passengers possessed no evidence material to the prosecution or defense of the alien-defendant for transporting illegal aliens, and two of the passengers were deported to Mexico, while the third was detained to provide a non-hearsay basis for establishing that the defendant had transported an illegal alien in violation of 8 USCS 1324(a)(2). On trial in the United States District Court for the Southern District of California, the defendant moved to dismiss the indictment, claiming that the government's deportation of two of the passengers violated his Fifth Amendment right to due process of law and his Sixth Amendment right to compulsory process for obtaining favorable witnesses, claiming that the deportation had deprived him of the opportunity to interview the two remaining passengers to determine whether they could aid in his defense. The District Court denied the defendant's motion and, following a bench trial on stipulated evidence, found the defendant guilty as charged. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit reversed the conviction holding that the government violated the Fifth and Sixth Amendments when it deported the alien witnesses before counsel had an opportunity to interview them (647 F2d 72).

Physicians who provide abortion services brought a class action in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois challenging the constitutionality of an Illinois abortion law and seeking declaratory and injunctive relief. A pediatrician moved to intervene as a party defendant and to be appointed guardian ad litem for fetuses who survive abortion, based on his conscientious objection to abortions and on his status as a pediatrician and as a parent of an unemancipated minor daughter. The District Court granted the motion, without indicating whether the intervention was permissive or as of right. Ultimately, the District Court permanently enjoined the enforcement of certain provisions of the law which impose criminal liability on physicians for violating prescribed standards of care for performing abortions and the requirements for furnishing a patient with particular abortion-related information (579 F Supp 464). The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit affirmed and also permanently enjoined the enforcement of another provision (749 F2d 452). The pediatrician filed a notice of appeal to the United States Supreme Court and a jurisdictional statement. The state of Illinois did not appeal, but filed a "letter of interest" with the Supreme Court under Supreme Court Rule 10.4, stating in the letter that the state's interest was identical to that advanced by it in the lower courts and was essentially coterminous with the pediatrician's position.

Under the standard of proof established by the United States Supreme Court in Batson v Kentucky (1986) 476 US 79, 90 L Ed 2d 69, 106 S Ct 1712, if a state criminal defendant makes a prima facie showing that a prosecutor, in violation of the equal protection clause of the Federal Constitution's Fourteenth Amendment, has exercised peremptory challenges on the basis of race, then the burden shifts to the prosecutor to articulate a race-neutral explanation for striking the jurors in question. In a criminal trial in the New York Supreme Court, Kings County, defense counsel objected that the prosecutor had used peremptory challenges to exclude allegedly Latino--that is, Hispanic--potential jurors. With respect to two of the challenged venirepersons, one of whom was Latino while the other's Latino status was uncertain, the prosecutor offered an explanation to the effect that while he would have no motive to exclude Latinos from the jury, as the alleged victims and the prosecutor's proposed main witnesses were Latinos, he was supposedly not certain whether the two venirepersons in question would have accepted an interpreter as the final arbiter of what was said by Spanish-speaking witnesses. The trial court rejected the defense claims, and the defendant was eventually convicted of attempted murder and criminal possession of a weapon. On appeal, the New York Supreme Court, Appellate Division, in affirming, expressed the view that the prosecutor had offered race-neutral explanations for the peremptory challenges, which explanations were sufficient to rebut the defendant's prima facie case (140 App Div 2d 543, 528 NYS2d 625). On appeal, the Court of Appeals of New York, in affirming, (1) deferred to the factual findings of the lower New York courts; and (2) ruled that the prosecutor had offered a legitimate basis for challenging the individuals in question (75 NYS2d 350, 553 NYS2d 85, 552 NE2d 621).

The projects involved placing sand along beaches seaward from the mean high-water line, which was the boundary between the state's submerged land and the owners' properties. The corporation contended that the state's ownership of the new dry land to seaward deprived the owners of their rights to accretion and a water boundary, and that the state court's decision was a taking of the owners' properties. While their was no consensus concerning whether a judicial decision could effect a taking, or whether it was even necessary to address the issue, the U.S. Supreme Court unanimously held that there was no taking of the owners' property rights. Since the change in the mean high-water line resulted from a relatively sudden avulsion, rather than a gradual accretion, the newly exposed land remained property of the state and the previous mean high-water line remained the boundary between the properties of the state and the owners. Thus, prior to the state court's decision the owners had no rights to future accretions and to contact with the water superior to the state's right to fill in its submerged land, and any further seaward accretion became property of the state.

These consolidated cases presented the question whether the United States Supreme Court's decision in Duren v Missouri, 439 US 357, 58 L Ed 2d 579, 99 S Ct 664--holding that a Missouri statute's exemption of women from jury service on request which resulted in underrepresentation of women on juries violated the Sixth Amendment--should be applied retroactively. Retroactive application was sought by several Missouri criminal defendants whose timely motions to quash their petit jury panels were denied by the state trial courts. On the basis of State v Duren (556 SW2d 11), which was later reversed by the Supreme Court in Duren v Missouri, the convictions of the defendants were affirmed (556 SW2d 25, 556 SW2d 35, 559 SW2d 749, 560 SW2d 283, 564 SW2d 328).

A Seventh-Day Adventist was discharged by her employer for her refusal to work on Saturday, the Sabbath Day of her faith, and was refused unemployment compensation by the South Carolina Employment Security Commission on the ground that her refusal to work Saturdays, causing other employers to refuse to hire her, disqualified her for failure to accept suitable work. The commission's finding was sustained by the Court of Common Pleas for Spartanburg County. The South Carolina Supreme Court affirmed on the ground that disqualifying the Seventh-Day Adventist from unemployment compensation did not restrict her religious freedom. (240 SC 286, 125 SE2d 737.)

A state court prisoner initiated habeas corpus proceedings in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Iowa, alleging that the introduction of certain incriminating evidence against him in a state murder prosecution had violated his constitutional right to the assistance of counsel. The challenged evidence was based on disclosures made by the prisoner to police officers in the absence of his attorney. The prisoner, on the advice by telephone of his counsel in Des Moines, Iowa, surrendered to police officials in Davenport, Iowa, and was booked on the charge of abducting a 10-year-old girl in Des Moines. The prisoner was then advised by his Des Moines attorney, by telephone, that Des Moines police officers would be driving to Davenport to pick him up, and that the prisoner should not talk to the officers about the girl until after consulting with the attorney upon his return to Des Moines. It was agreed between the attorney and Des Moines officials that the officers would not question the prisoner during the trip. In the meantime, the prisoner was arraigned before a judge in Davenport on the abduction charge, was advised of his Miranda rights, and was committed to jail. Before leaving the courtroom, the prisoner conferred with another lawyer, who advised him not to make any statements until consulting with his attorney back in Des Moines. When the Des Moines officers arrived in Davenport, one of them repeated the Miranda warnings to the prisoner and was reminded by his Davenport attorney that the prisoner was not to be questioned about the disappearance of the girl until after he had consulted with his attorney in Des Moines. During the trip to Des Moines, the prisoner did not express a willingness to be interrogated in the absence of an attorney, but rather stated several times that he would tell the whole story after seeing his attorney in Des Moines. However, one of the officers sought to obtain incriminating evidence from the prisoner by telling him that they should stop and locate the girl's body because her parents were entitled to a "Christian burial" for the girl, who had been taken from them on Christmas Eve. The prisoner subsequently made several incriminating disclosures, and then directed the officers to the body. Notwithstanding his objections to the admission of evidence resulting from those disclosures, the prisoner was tried and convicted for first degree murder, and the conviction was affirmed by the Iowa Supreme Court. The prisoner's petition in Federal District Court for a writ of habeas corpus was granted on the ground that as a matter of law, the evidence in question had been wrongly admitted at trial (375 F Supp 170), and the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit affirmed (509 F2d 227).

A member of the Colville Indian Tribe was charged in the Superior Court of Okanogan County, Washington, with burglary committed in the south half of the Colville Indian Reservation. After conviction upon his plea of guilty to the offense of attempted burglary, he filed a petition for a writ of habeas corpus in the Supreme Court of Washington, urging that the crime of burglary was committed in "Indian country," as defined in 18 USC 1151, and that burglary committed by an Indian in Indian country is an offense within the exclusive jurisdiction of the United States under 18 USC 1153. The petition was denied by the State Supreme Court on the ground that the land on which the burglary was committed was no longer an Indian reservation. (55 Wash 2d 109, 346 P2d 669.)

Sections 4 and 5 of the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992, 47 USCS 534 and 535 (the "must-carry" provisions), generally require cable operators to carry the signals of specified numbers, based on cable system size, of local commercial television stations ( 4) and local noncommercial educational television stations ( 5). Soon after the Act became law, a number of cable programmers and cable operators filed five separate actions in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia against the Federal Government, in which actions the cable entities challenged the constitutionality of the must-carry provisions. Additional parties intervened. A three-judge District Court, which convened as required under the Act to hear any civil action challenging the constitutionality of the must-carry provisions, consolidated the actions. The District Court, granting summary judgment in favor of the government and the intervenor-defendants, expressed the view that the must-carry provisions were consistent with the Federal Constitution's First Amendment under an intermediate standard of scrutiny, since (1) the preservation of local broadcasting was an important governmental interest; and (2) the must-carry provisions were sufficiently tailored to serve that interest (819 F Supp 32).
The issue before the Supreme Court was the constitutionality of the disclosure provisions of the Federal Lobbying Act (2 USC 261 et seq.).

Petitioners' powerplants were subject to the Clean Water Act, 33 U.S.C.S. _ 1251 et seq., because they had cooling water intake structures that threatened aquatic organisms. Respondents, environmental groups and various States, challenged the EPA's Phase II rules under 40 C.F.R. _ 125.94 that applied to existing facilities. The EPA expressly declined to mandate closed-cycle cooling systems in part because of the cost. The Second Circuit held that the EPA was not permitted to use cost-benefit analysis in determining the content of regulations promulgated under _ 1326(b). The Court, however, held that the EPA permissibly relied on cost-benefit analysis in setting the national performance standards under _ 125.94(b) and in providing for cost-benefit variances from those standards under _ 125.94(a)(5). Considering _ 1326(b)'s text, and comparing it with the text and statutory factors applicable to parallel provisions under 33 U.S.C.S. __ 1311, 1314, and 1316, prompted the Court's conclusion that it was well within the bounds of reasonable interpretation for the EPA to conclude that cost-benefit analysis was not categorically forbidden.

An electrician, who alleged that his small cell lung cancer was promoted by on-the-job exposure to polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) and to furans and dioxins (some PCB derivatives), sued in a Georgia state court the manufacturers of the products through which the exposure had occurred. After the manufacturers removed the case to the United States District Court for the Northern District of Georgia, the District Court--in excluding the proffered scientific testimony of the electrician's experts indicating a link between exposure to PCBs and small cell lung cancer, and in granting the manufacturers' summary judgment motion--expressed the view that (1) there was no genuine issue as to whether the electrician had been exposed to furans and dioxins, and (2) the expert testimony did not rise above subjective belief or unsupported speculation (864 F. Supp 1310). The United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit, in reversing the District Court's judgment, expressed the view that (1) the Court of Appeals would apply a particularly stringent standard of review to a trial judge's exclusion of expert testimony, and (2) under that standard, the District Court had erred in excluding the testimony of the electrician's experts (78 F.3d 524).

Two Indiana police officers suspected a mother in the shooting and wounding of her two sons, under a theory that the mother had multiple personalities. When the officers wanted to interview the mother under hypnosis, they consulted a deputy prosecutor, who told them that they could proceed. The officers, interpreting the mother's resulting statements under hypnosis as supporting their theory, again sought the advice of the deputy prosecutor, who told the officers that they probably had probable cause to arrest the mother, whereupon she was arrested. At a probable cause hearing the next day to obtain a search warrant, (1) one of the officers testified, in response to the deputy prosecutor's questioning, that the mother had confessed; (2) neither the officer nor the deputy prosecutor told the judge that the "confession" had been obtained under hypnosis or that the mother had otherwise denied the shooting; and (3) the judge issued a search warrant. The mother was charged under Indiana law with the attempted murder of her sons, but the trial judge granted the mother's pretrial motion to suppress the statements under hypnosis, and, as a result, the prosecutor's office dropped all charges against the mother. The mother then filed a damages action against various defendants, including the deputy prosecutor, in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Indiana, and claimed that the defendants were liable under 42 USCS 1983 for alleged violations of her rights under the Federal Constitution's Fourth, Fifth, and Fourteenth Amendments. The mother settled with several of the defendants, but, when her case proceeded to trial against the deputy prosecutor, the District Court granted him a directed verdict on the ground that he was absolutely immune for his conduct. On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, in affirming, expressed the view that (1) the deputy prosecutor was absolutely immune for his role in the probable cause hearing; and (2) a prosecutor should be afforded absolute immunity for giving legal advice to police officers about the legality of their prospective investigative conduct (894 F2d 949).

A union officer, appearing as a witness before a subcommittee of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, refused to answer questions as to past Communist Party membership of certain persons, objecting to the questions on the ground of lack of pertinency to the subject under inquiry by the subcommittee. In a prosecution in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, he was convicted of violating the statute providing for criminal punishment of witnesses before congressional committees who refuse to answer any question pertinent to the question under inquiry, and the conviction was affirmed by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit (98 App DC 190, 233 F2d 681).

At a general election, the voters of Arkansas adopted a state constitutional amendment which included a ballot-access restriction that prohibited (1) the appearance on the ballot for election to the United States House of Representatives from Arkansas of the name of anyone who had been elected to three or more terms as a member of the House from Arkansas, and (2) the appearance on the ballot for election to the United States Senate from Arkansas of the name of anyone who had been elected to two or more terms as a member of the Senate from Arkansas. Before the amendment became effective, an Arkansas resident sought a declaratory judgment that the ballot-access restriction violated the Federal Constitution. The Circuit Court for Pulaski County, Arkansas entered a judgment to the effect that the ballot-access restriction violated the Federal Constitution's Article I, which contains qualifications clauses that provide age, United States citizenship, and state residency qualifications for (1) United States Representatives in Art I, 2, cl 2, and (2) United States Senators in Art I, 3, cl 3. The Arkansas Supreme Court affirmed the judgment of the Circuit Court (316 Ark 251, 873 SW2d 349).

Pursuant to the Federal Constitution's Indian commerce clause (Art I, 8, cl 3), which grants the Federal Government authority over Indian commerce, Congress passed the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act (25 USCS 2701 et seq.) in order to provide a statutory basis for the operation and regulation of gaming by Indian tribes. The Act, under 25 USCS 2710(d)(3), imposed on a state a duty to negotiate in good faith with an Indian tribe toward the formation between the tribe and the state of a compact concerning gaming activities by the tribe in the state. Moreover, the Act, under 25 USCS 2710(d)(7), authorized a tribe to bring suit in a federal court against a state in order to compel performance of the state's duty to negotiate in good faith. The Seminole Indian Tribe sued the state of Florida--which had not consented to be sued--and its governor, alleging that the state and the governor had violated the 2710(d)(3) requirement of good-faith negotiation. After the United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida denied a motion by the state and the governor for dismissal on the basis that the suit violated the state's sovereign immunity from suit in federal court (801 F Supp 655), the state and the governor took an interlocutory appeal of the District Court's decision. The United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit, reversing the District Court's judgment and remanding to the District Court with directions to dismiss the suit, expressed the view that the Court of Appeals had no jurisdiction over the suit, because (1) the Indian commerce clause did not grant Congress the power to abrogate a state's immunity, under the Constitution's Eleventh Amendment, from suit in federal court, and (2) the doctrine of Ex parte Young (1908) 209 US 123, 52 L Ed 714, 28 S Ct 441--which held that state officials may be sued in federal court for injunctive relief in order to prevent a continuing violation of federal law--was not available with respect to the governor (11 F3d 1016).

The Endangered Species Act of 1973 (16 USCS 1531 et seq.) contains a variety of protections designed to save from extinction species that the Secretary of the Interior designates as endangered or threatened. The Act includes (1) in 5 (16 USCS 1534), land-acquisition authority; (2) in 7 (16 USCS 1536), a directive to federal agencies to avoid destruction or modification of critical habitat; and (3) in 11(a)(1) and 11(b)(1) (16 USCS 1540(a)(1) and 1540(b)(1)), some civil and criminal penalties for violating the Act or its implementing regulations. In addition, 9(a)(1)(B) of the Act (16 USCS 1538(a)(1)(B)) generally makes it unlawful for any person to "take" any endangered or threatened species of fish or wildlife, although 10(a)(1)(B) of the Act (16 USCS 1539(a)(1)(B))--which Congress added by amendment in 1982--authorizes the Secretary to grant a permit for any taking otherwise prohibited by 9(a)(1)(B) if such taking is incidental to, and not the purpose of, the carrying out of an otherwise lawful activity. The term "take" is defined in 3(19) of the Act (16 USCS 1532(19)) to mean to harass, harm, pursue, hunt, shoot, wound, kill, trap, capture, or collect, or to attempt to engage in any such conduct. Provisions such as 4 and 11(f) of the Act (16 USCS 1533 and 1540(f)) delegate interpretive and administrative power to the Secretary. A case arose as to the validity of 50 CFR 17.3, a regulation which (1) was originally promulgated by the Secretary in 1975, and (2) provides that "harm" in the Act's definition of "take" means an act which actually kills or injures wildlife and that such act may include "significant habitat modification or degradation where it actually kills or injures wildlife" by significantly impairing essential behavioral patterns, including breeding, feeding, or sheltering. In the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, some small landowners, logging companies, families dependent on the forest products industries in the Pacific Northwest and in the Southeast, and organizations representing their interests (1) brought a declaratory judgment action against federal officials including the Secretary; (2) included a facial challenge to the statutory validity of 17.3; and (3) alleged that the application of 17.3 to the red-cockaded woodpecker, an endangered species, and to the northern spotted owl, a threatened species, had injured the plaintiffs economically. The District Court (1) granted a motion by the defendant officials for summary judgment; (2) denied a motion by the plaintiffs for summary judgment; and (3) expressed the view that Congress intended an expansive interpretation of the statutory term "take" that encompassed habitat modification (806 F Supp 279). On appeal, a panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit initially affirmed (303 US App DC 42, 1 F3d 1). On rehearing, however, the panel (1) reversed in pertinent part; and (2) expressed the view that 17.3 was invalid in defining "harm" to include habitat modification (305 US App DC 110, 17 F3d 1463). The Court of Appeals then denied rehearing en banc (308 US App DC 128, 30 F 3d 190).

Landowners who owned contiguous tracts of land Nebraska and Colorado on which a well physically located on the Nebraska tract pumped ground water for irrigation of both the Nebraska Colorado tracts failed to apply for a permit required by Nebraska law which, among other things, stated that Nebraska would not provide a permit for the withdrawal of ground water for the use in another state if that state did not grant reciprocal rights to withdraw and transport ground water into Nebraska. The state of Colorado did not provide for reciprocity for the use of ground water. Nebraska brought an action to enjoin the landowners from transferring the water across the border without a permit in the District Court of Chase County, Nebraska, which granted an injunction, rejecting the defense that the statute imposed an undue burden on interstate commerce. The Supreme Court of Nebraska affirmed, holding that ground water is not a marketable item freely transferable for value among private parties and therefore is not an article of commerce (208 Neb 703, 305 NW2d 614).

A group comprised of licensed physicians and one physician-assistant practicing in Montana brought against the attorney general of Montana an action challenging, under the Federal Constitution, a Montana statute that restricted the performance of abortions to licensed physicians. The United States District Court for the District of Montana, expressing the view that the practitioners had not established any likelihood of prevailing on their claim that the law imposed an undue burden concerning abortion rights, denied the practitioners' motion for a preliminary injunction (906 F Supp 961). The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, expressing the view that the practitioners had shown a fair chance of success on the merits of their claim and thus had met the threshold requirement for injunctive relief, vacated the District Court judgment and remanded with instructions to determine whether entry of a preliminary injunction was ultimately warranted (94 F3d 566). On remand, the District Court (1) entered an injunction pending appeal pursuant to Rule 62(c) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, and (2) postponed a hearing on the preliminary injunction motion until the United States Supreme Court's disposition of the state attorney general's certiorari petition.

In 1968, a diversified holding company acquired about 65% of the stock of a bank. As a result of federal legislation, enacted in 1970, pertaining to bank holding companies, the holding company, in 1971, filed a notice of divestiture and began trying to sell its bank stock. Because the bank had made a series of bad loans, selling the bank stock proved difficult. While trying to sell its bank stock, the holding company, in response to the concerns of federal regulators that the bank was not adequately capitalized, bought additional shares of the bank's stock. By 1974, the holding company more than tripled the number of shares it owned in the bank, although its percentage interest remained relatively stable. In 1975, the holding company was finally able to sell most of its bank stock. On its federal income tax return for 1975, the holding company claimed a deduction for an ordinary loss resulting from the sale of the bank stock. The Commissioner of Internal Revenue disallowed the ordinary loss deduction, ruling that the loss incurred was a capital loss rather than an ordinary loss and was therefore subject to the capital loss limitations of the Internal Revenue Code. The holding company challenged this determination in the United States Tax Court, which held that bank stock purchased by the holding company through 1972 was purchased with a substantial investment purpose and was thus a "capital asset" within the meaning of 26 USCS 1221, so that, when sold, it gave rise to a capital loss, while bank stock purchased by the holding company after 1972 was held for a business purpose, without any substantial investment motive, and was thus an ordinary asset whose sale gave rise to an ordinary loss (83 TC 640). On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit reversed in part, holding that, regardless of the purpose for which it was acquired, all of the bank stock sold in 1975 (1) was included within the general definition of "capital asset" in 1221, (2) fell outside any of the specific statutory exceptions to this definition, and (3) was thus subject to capital-loss treatment (800 F2d 215).

Colorado permits its citizens to place propositions on the ballot through an initiative process. Under state law, (1) each initiative measure must be submitted to state officials for the preparation of an approved draft, (2) proponents of the measure must obtain the necessary signatures on an initiative petition within 6 months after the preparation of the draft, (3) it is a crime to forge a signature on a petition, to make false or misleading statements relating to a petition, or to pay someone to sign a petition, and (4) persons who circulate petitions for signatures must sign affidavits attesting to the validity of each signature. In addition, state law made it a felony to pay any person, corporation, or association to circulate an initiative petition. In 1984, proponents of an amendment to the Colorado Constitution that would have removed motor carriers from the jurisdiction of the state public utilities commission brought an action under 42 USCS 1983 against state officials. In the action, the proponents sought a declaration that the prohibition against the use of paid circulators violated the proponents' rights under the Federal Constitution's First and Fourteenth Amendments. The District Court upheld the prohibition, and a panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit affirmed, but on rehearing en banc, the Court of Appeals reversed, on the grounds that (1) the prohibition impeded the proponents' opportunity to disseminate their views to the public, and (2) various justifications asserted by the state were inadequate to support the prohibition (828 F2d 1446).

The petitioner applied some 9 months after his induction into the Army for a discharge as a conscientious objector, but was denied such status on the grounds that his professed beliefs had become fixed prior to entering the service and that his opposition to war was not truly based upon his religious beliefs. Thereafter, the petitioner applied to the Army Board for Correction of Military Records (ABCMR) for administrative review of that determination, and he also commenced a habeas corpus proceeding in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California, claiming that the Army's denial of his conscientious objector application was without basis in fact. The District Court declined at that time to consider the merits of the petition, but it did retain jurisdiction pending a decision by the ABCMR, and enjoined Army authorities from requiring the petitioner to participate in activities or training beyond his current noncombatant duties. After attempts to win a stay of a redeployment order had been rejected both by the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit and by Mr. Justice Douglas, acting as Circuit Justice (396 US 1233, 24 L Ed 2d 482, 90 S Ct 497), the petitioner reported to Fort Lewis, Washington, as he had been ordered to do, but refused to obey an order to board a plane for Vietnam, as a result of which failure the petitioner was charged with wilful disobedience of a lawful command of a superior commissioned officer, and was convicted of that offense by a court- martial. While the court-martial charges were pending, the ABCMR rejected the petitioner's application for relief, and thereafter, on the government's motion at a show cause hearing, the District Court entered an order deferring consideration of the habeas corpus petition until final determination of the criminal charge then pending in the military court system, which order was affirmed by the Court of Appeals (435 F2d 299).

The plaintiff, a private university which refused to admit Negroes as students, instituted an action in the United States District Court for the District of South Carolina, seeking to enjoin the Internal Revenue Service--pursuant to its decision to no longer allow tax-exempt status under 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1954 (26 USCS 501(c)(3)) for private schools maintaining racially discriminatory admissions policies--from revoking its ruling letter declaring that the plaintiff qualified for tax-exempt status, and from withdrawing advance assurance to the plaintiff's donors that contributions to the plaintiff would constitute charitable deductions for the donors under 26 USCS 170(c)(2). The plaintiff contended that the Service's threatened action was outside its lawful authority and would violate the plaintiff's First Amendment, due process, and equal protection rights. The District Court granted a preliminary injunction against the Service pending a decision on the merits, holding that the suit was not precluded by the Anti-Injunction Act of the Internal Revenue Code of 1954 (26 USCS 7421(a)), which provides in general that no suit for the purpose of restraining the assessment or collection of any tax shall be maintained in any court by any person, whether or not such person is the person against whom such tax was assessed (341 F Supp 277). The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit reversed, holding that the suit was barred by the Anti-Injunction Act (472 F2d 903, reh den 476 F2d 259).

The Duval County, Florida sheriff's department prepared a report on a sexual assault. The report, which identified the victim by her full name, was placed in the department's pressroom. Although the department did not restrict access either to the pressroom or to the reports made available therein, the room contained signs to the effect that the names of rape victims were not matters of public record and were not to be published. A reporter-trainee for a weekly newspaper copied the police report verbatim, including the victim's full name, and a reporter for the newspaper prepared an article, derived entirely from the copied police report, which again included the victim's full name. The newspaper published the article in violation of its own internal policy of not publishing the names of sexual offense victims. The victim, claiming emotional distress, filed suit in the Circuit Court of Duval County against the sheriff's department and the newspaper. The victim alleged that the newspaper had violated a Florida statute that made it unlawful to publish in any instrument of mass communication the name of the victim of a sexual offense. The department reached a pretrial settlement with the victim, but following a trial, the newspaper was found negligent and the victim was awarded compensatory and punitive damages. The District Court of Appeal of Florida, First District, affirmed (499 So 2d 883), and the Supreme Court of Florida denied review.

Two drug rehabilitation counselors, both of whom were members of the Native American Church, were fired from their jobs with a private corporation in Oregon because they had ingested peyote, a hallucinogenic drug, for sacramental purposes at a ceremony of the Church. The counselors applied to the Employment Division of Oregon's Department of Human Resources for unemployment compensation, but the department's Employment Appeals Board ultimately denied their applications on the ground that the counselors had been discharged for misconduct connected with work. The Oregon Court of Appeals, reversing the board's decisions, (1) held that the denial of benefits to persons who were discharged for engaging in a religious act constituted an unjustified burden on the right of free exercise of religion, and (2) remanded the cases to the board for further findings as to the religious nature of the counselors' acts (75 Or App 764, 707 P2d 1274, 709 P2d 246). The Supreme Court of Oregon, holding that such further findings were unnecessary and that the counselors were entitled to payment of unemployment benefits, affirmed both judgments as modified (301 Or 209, 221, 721 P2d 445, 451). On certiorari, the United States Supreme Court (1) noted that the Oregon Supreme Court had not decided whether the counselors' sacramental use of peyote was in fact proscribed by Oregon's controlled substance law, and that this issue was a matter of dispute between the parties, (2) determined that it would not be appropriate, given this uncertainty, for the United States Supreme Court to decide whether the practice was protected by the Federal Constitution, and accordingly (3) vacated the Oregon Supreme Court's judgment and remanded the case for further proceedings (485 US 660, 99 L Ed 2d 753, 108 S Ct 1444). On remand, the Oregon Supreme Court held that (1) the Oregon statute made no exception for the sacramental use of peyote, (2) the counselors' use of peyote thus fell within the prohibition of the statute, (3) the prohibition of the practice at issue was not valid under the free exercise clause of the Federal Constitution's First Amendment, and (4) the counselors could not be denied unemployment benefits for having engaged in that practice (307 Or 68, 763 P2d 146).

Upon trial in an Oregon state court, the defendant was convicted of second degree murder, and the Supreme Court of Oregon affirmed the conviction (245 Or 4, 418 P2d 841). The defendant filed a petition for a writ of habeas corpus in the United States District Court for the District of Oregon, asserting that (1) his constitutional right to confrontation, guaranteed by the Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments, had been violated by prosecutorial misconduct in that the prosecutor had included in his opening statement a summary of testimony that he expected to receive from a person who had been indicted with the accused and had pleaded guilty, but who later asserted his privilege against self-incrimination when called as a witness by the prosecutor, (2) his confession to the police should not have been admitted in evidence, since his right to counsel was violated when the police continued the questioning after he said that he thought he should get a lawyer before he talked any more, (3) alternatively, the confession should have been excluded as being involuntary, and (4) his clothing, which had been seized by the police upon searching his duffel bag after they had arrested the defendant's cousin, who had possession of the duffel bag and consented to the search, should not have been admitted in evidence. The District Court granted the writ, but the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit reversed (388 F2d 777).

During a joint trial of Evans and Bruton in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri on a federal charge of armed postal robbery, at which Evans did not testify, a postal inspector testified to Evans' oral confession that Evans and Bruton had committed the robbery. The court instructed the jury that although Evans' confession was competent evidence against Evans, it was inadmissible hearsay against Bruton and must be disregarded in determining Bruton's guilt or innocence. Both were convicted. The United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit set aside Evans' conviction on the grounds that his admissions to the postal inspector were tainted by the poison of his prior unconstitutional confession, but affirmed Bruton's conviction because of the trial court's limiting instructions. (375 F2d 355.)

The Commission found that the council member violated Nevada's Ethics in Government Law by failing to abstain from voting on a hotel/casino project because he had a disqualifying conflict of interest under the catchall provision. The United States Supreme Court determined that the recusal provision of the Ethics in Government Law was not unconstitutionally overbroad under the First Amendment because legislators lacked a personal First Amendment right to vote on any given matter. A legislator's vote was not protected speech, because, inter alia, (1) the belief that recusal rules violated legislators' First Amendment rights was inconsistent with early congressional enactments and long-standing state traditions, (2) a legislator's vote was the commitment of his apportioned share of the legislature's power to the passage or defeat of a particular proposal and the legislative power thus committed was not personal to the legislator but belonged to the people, (3) the fact that a nonsymbolic act was the product of a deeply held personal belief did not transform action into First Amendment speech, and (4) a legislator had no right to use official powers for expressive purposes.

In 1984, a 4-year-old boy in Winnebago County, Wisconsin, was severely beaten by his natural father. The resulting brain damage was so great that the boy was expected to spend the rest of his life in an institution for the profoundly retarded. The boy and his mother brought suit under 42 USCS 1983 in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin against the county, its department of social services (DSS), and various individual DSS employees. The complaint alleged that the county, the DSS, and the individual employees had deprived the boy of his liberty without due process of law, in violation of his rights under the due process clause of the Federal Constitution's Fourteenth Amendment, by failing to intervene to protect him against a risk of violence of which they knew or should have known. The evidence showed that the county first received a report that the boy might be a victim of child abuse in January 1982. A year later, the boy was hospitalized with multiple bruises and abrasions. The DSS obtained an order from a juvenile court which placed the boy in the temporary custody of the hospital. On the recommendation of a "child protection team," consisting of a pediatrician, a psychologist, a police detective, the county's lawyer, several DSS caseworkers, and various hospital personnel, the juvenile court dismissed the case and returned the boy to the custody of his father, who promised to cooperate with the DSS. During 1983, the boy was hospitalized twice for suspicious injuries, and a DSS caseworker who made monthly visits to the boy's home recorded in her files her continuing suspicions of child abuse, but the DSS took no action. The District Court, holding that a state agency's failure to render protective services to persons within its jurisdiction does not violate the due process clause, dismissed the boy's claim. The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit affirmed, holding that (1) the due process clause does not require a state or local governmental entity to protect its citizens from private violence, and (2) the causal connection between the county's conduct and the boy's injuries was too attenuated to establish a deprivation of constitutional rights actionable under 1983 (812 F2d 298).

Before trial in the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts on an indictment charging the defendant with refusing to submit to military induction, the defendant moved to dismiss the indictment on the grounds that (1) the government's military involvement in Vietnam violated international law, (2) he reasonably believed that involvement to be illegal, and (3) the Military Selective Service Act and its regulations were unconstitutional because the procedures followed by local boards lacked due process and because compulsory conscription during peacetime was unnecessary and stifling to fundamental personal liberties. The District Court denied the motion (294 F Supp 511, 515).
