This evidence included the identity of a man seen running into the alley after the murder and stopping near the garage where Fuller's body had already been found; the statement of a passerby who claimed to hear groans coming from a closed garage; and evidence tending to impeach witnesses Eleby, Jacobs, and Thomas. The D. C. Superior Court rejected petitioners' Brady claims, finding that the withheld evidence was not material. The D. C. Court of Appeals affirmed.

A dealer in sugar products, acquitted of conspiring with another to defraud the United States by presenting false invoices of sales to agencies exempt from sugar rationing, for the purpose of obtaining an additional allotment, was indicted for the substantive offense. Since the invoices were prepared and presented by the alleged co-conspirator, the dealer was answerable only as an accessory.

A provision of the Airport and Airway Improvement Act of 1982 (49 USCS Appx 1513(d)(1)) forbids a state or its subdivisions to levy or collect an ad valorem property tax on air carrier transportation property at a rate that exceeds the rate applicable to commercial and industrial property in the same assessment jurisdiction. However, 49 USCS Appx 1513(d)(3) provides that this prohibition does not apply to an "in lieu tax which is wholly utilized for airport and aeronautical purposes." Four airline companies operating in South Dakota challenged that state's flight property tax, alleging that the tax violated the Act because most other personal property was not taxed. The proceeds of the South Dakota tax, which is imposed on a portion of the value of certain aircraft, are allocated by statute to the airports regularly used by the airlines, and the tax is applied to the exclusion of any other tax on the airlines' property. The four airlines unsuccessfully sued the appropriate county commissions for a refund of taxes paid after the effective date of the Act. The airlines also appealed their property tax assessment to South Dakota's State Board of Equalization, which denied the appeal. All of these lawsuits were consolidated in the Circuit Court for the Sixth Judicial District in Hughes County, South Dakota, which held that the flight property tax was permitted under 49 USCS Appx 1513(d)(3). On appeal, the Supreme Court of South Dakota expressed disagreement with the conclusion that the tax was authorized under 1513(d)(3) as an "in lieu tax," but it affirmed on an alternate ground (372 NW2d 106).

An Army officer, a physician, refused to obey orders to train Special Forces aide men, and made public statements urging Negro enlisted men not to go to Viet Nam if ordered to do so, and characterizing Special Forces personnel as liars, thieves, killers of peasants, and murderers of women and children. Thereupon the officer was convicted by a general court-martial of violations of (1) Article 90 of the Uniform Code of Military Justice (10 USCS 890), for wilfully disobeying a lawful command of a superior officer, (2) Article 133 of the Code (10 USCS 933), for "conduct unbecoming an officer or gentleman," and (3) Article 134 of the Code (10 USCS 934), for "disorders and neglects to the prejudice of good order and discipline in the armed forces" not otherwise specifically mentioned in the Code. After exhausting avenues of relief under military law, the officer sought federal habeas corpus relief in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania, which denied relief. The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit reversed, holding that Articles 133 and 134 of the Uniform Code of Military Justice were void for vagueness, even though the officer's conduct fell within military authorities' construction of the Articles' coverage (478 F2d 772).

In an anti-trust suit a consent decree was entered directing the formation of two new companies, one to take over the motion-picture production and distribution assets, and the other the theater assets, of an existing corporation, which was to be dissolved upon the formation of the new companies. The decree provided that the owner of 24 per cent of the stock of the dissolved corporation may "either" sell his stock in one or the other of the two newly formed companies, "or" deposit such stock with a court-designated trustee. After the stockholder had chosen the latter alternative, the district court, without evidence or facts, amended the decree by ordering a compulsory sale.

These two, consolidated cases presented the question whether federal courts have discretion to exceed the $ 30-per-day limit for expert witness fee awards prescribed by 28 USCS 1821. In the first case (No. 86-322), after a verdict was directed in favor of the defendant in an antitrust action brought in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana, the defendant sought reimbursement of its litigation expenses, including substantial expert witness fees. The District Court (1) held that Rule 54(d) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure granted it discretion to exceed the $ 30-per-day limit for witness fee awards prescribed by 1821, and (2) awarded the defendant over $ 86,000 for its expert witness fees (102 FRD 73). En banc, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit reversed and held that the limit of 1821 controlled (790 F2d 1193). In the second case (No. 86-328), after a judgment on the merits was entered in favor of the defendant in an employment discrimination action brought in the United States District Court for the Nothern District of Mississippi, the District Court declined to order the plaintiff to reimburse the defendant for expert witness fees in excess of the $ 30-per-day limit prescribed by 1821. En banc, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit affirmed the District Court decision and held that the 1821 limit was dispositive (790 F2d 1174).

Under the General Allotment Act of 1887 (25 USCS 331 et seq.)--which governs the allotment to Indians of agricultural and grazing lands located on Indian reservations under an arrangement whereby the United States retains title to the allotted lands in trust for the benefit of the allottees--the federal government, by 1935, allotted to individual Indians all of the land located on a reservation which had been established in the state of Washington for the Quinault Tribe. Several decades later, over 1,000 individual allottees of land on the Quinault Reservation, the Quinault Tribe, which itself held some allotments, and an unincorporated association, which had been formed to promote the interests of the Quinault Reservation allottees, brought actions against the United States in the United States Court of Claims, seeking to recover money damages from the federal government for its alleged mismanagement of timber resources on the allotted lands in breach of a fiduciary duty owed to allottees by the United States under the General Allotment Act. Denying the United States' motion to dismiss the Consolidated actions on the asserted ground that the federal government had not waived its sovereign immunity with respect to the claims raised, the Court of Claims ruled that government mismanagement of the kind alleged in the action breaches the federal government's fiduciary duty under the General Allotment Act, and that the Act provides Indian allottees with a cause of action for money damages against the United States for breaches of such duty (219 Ct Cl ____, 591 F2d 1300).

The defendant railroads, together with the other defendants, conducted a publicity campaign against the plaintiffs--truckers--designed to foster the adoption and retention of laws and law-enforcement practices destructive of the trucking business. In that campaign the so-called third- party technique--giving propaganda actually circulated by a party in interest the appearance of being spontaneous declarations of independent groups--was used. In the truckers' action charging that the defendants had conspired to restrain trade in and monopolize the long-distance freight business in violation of 1 and 2 of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act, the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania decided in favor of the plaintiffs. (155 F Supp 768, 166 F Supp 163.) The Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit affirmed, one judge dissenting. (273 F2d 218.)

In accordance with the then-prevailing rulings of the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, royalties received by the taxpayer-wife on patents transferred by her to a corporation were reported by her as ordinary income in the 1952 joint federal income tax return filed by her and her husband in 1953, in which year the last payment of the taxes due was made. Under the statute of limitations governing a claim for refund of such taxes, the claim was barred in 1956. In that year Congress amended the 1939 Internal Revenue Code by adding 117(q), made applicable to tax years beginning after May 31, 1950, and providing that royalties of the kind received by the taxpayer should be taxed as capital gains rather than as ordinary income. In reliance on this amendment, the taxpayers, on June 23, 1958, filed a claim for a pro tanto refund of their 1952 income taxes, and, no action having been taken on the claim, commenced the present refund suit in the United States Court of Claims. Rejecting the defense of the United States that the suit was barred by limitations, the Court of Claims entered judgment for the taxpayers. (150 Ct Cl 814, 280 F2d 829.)

In these two, consolidated cases, the major questions presented were whether a writ of habeas corpus ad prosequendum, issued by a Federal District Court to state prison authorities to secure the presence of a state prisoner in the federal court to stand trial on federal criminal charges, constituted either a "detainer" or a "written request for temporary custody" within the meaning of the Interstate Agreement on Detainers (see 18 USCS App)--which prescribes procedures by which a member state (including the United States) may obtain for trial a prisoner incarcerated in another member jurisdiction by filing a "detainer" and a "request" for temporary custody. In the first case (No. 76-1596), the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York issued writs of habeas corpus ad prosequendum to New York prison authorities to secure the presence of two state prisoners for arraignment on federal criminal charges. After the prisoners pleaded not guilty, and after their trial dates were set, the District Court, because of overcrowded federal facilities, directed that the prisoners be returned to their respective state prisons to await their federal trials. Subsequently, the District Court granted the prisoners' motions to dismiss the indictments, holding that the Agreement governed their removal from state custody by means of the writs of habeas corpus ad prosequendum, and that the government had violated the Agreement's requirement that a prisoner must be tried in the receiving state before being returned to the sending state (414 F Supp 358). The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit affirmed, holding that a writ of habeas corpus ad prosequendum was a "detainer" entitling a prisoner to the protections provided by the Agreement (544 F2d 588). In the second case (No. 77-52), the United States filed a detainer with Massachusetts officials while a prisoner was being held on Massachusetts charges. After his conviction on the Massachusetts charges, and after the prisoner had been indicted on the federal charges, the prisoner was produced from Massachusetts for arraignment in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York pursuant to a writ of habeas corpus ad prosequendum. After the prisoner pleaded not guilty to the federal charges, and after a trial date was set, the trial was postponed several times, at the government's request or on the court's own initiative, until approximately 17 months after the prisoner had been produced under the ad prosequendum writ. The District Court denied the prisoner's motions to dismiss the indictment on speedy trial grounds, and a jury trial resulted in the prisoner's conviction. On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit reversed, holding that (1) since the government had filed a detainer, triggering the Agreement's provisions, the ad prosequendum writ constituted a "written request for temporary custody" under the Agreement, and (2) the federal indictment should have been dismissed, since the government had violated the Agreement's requirement that trial must be commenced within 120 days of the prisoner's arrival in the receiving state (550 F2d 732).

Each of the taxpayers involved received, and reported in his income tax return for the year of the receipt, a salary from a closely held corporation in which he was both an officer and a stockholder. After the end of that year the Commissioner disallowed the deduction by the corporations of parts of the salaries as exceeding reasonable compensation, and determined that the taxpayers were liable as transferees for the corporate deficiencies. The issue was whether the excessive part of the salary should be excluded from taxable income in the year of receipt, as contended by the taxpayers, or whether an adjustment should be made in the year of payment of the transferee liability, as contended by the government.

The Agricultural Marketing Agreement Act of 1937 (AMAA), which was enacted to stabilize prices for agricultural commodities, regulates only "handlers," i.e., "processors, associations of producers, and others engaged in the handling" of covered agricultural commodities, 7 U. S. C. ¬ß608c(1). Any handler that violates the Secretary of Agriculture's marketing orders may be subject to civil and criminal penalties. ¬ß¬ß608a(5), 608a(6), and 608c(14). One such order, the California Raisin Marketing Order (Marketing Order or Order), established a Raisin Administrative Committee (RAC), which recommends setting up annual reserve pools of raisins that are not to be sold on the open domestic market, and which recommends what portion of a particular year's production should be included in the pool. The Order also requires handlers to pay assessments to help cover the RAC's administrative costs. Petitioners, California raisin growers, started a business that processed more than 3 million pounds of raisins from their farm and 60 other farms during the two crop years. When they refused to surrender the requisite portions of raisins to the reserve, the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) began administrative proceedings, alleging that petitioners were handlers who were required to retain raisins in reserve and pay assessments. Petitioners countered that as producers, they were not subject to the Order. They also raised an affirmative defense that the Order violated the Fifth Amendment's prohibition against taking property without just compensation. An Administrative Law Judge found that petitioners were handlers, found that they had violated the AMAA and the Marketing Order, and rejected their takings defense. On appeal, a judicial officer agreed that petitioners were handlers who had violated the Marketing Order, imposed fines and civil penalties, and declined to address the takings claim. Petitioners sought review in the Federal District Court. Granting summary judgment to the USDA, it found that substantial evidence supported the agency's determination that petitioners were handlers rather than producers, and it rejected petitioners' takings claim. The Ninth Circuit affirmed. It agreed that petitioners were handlers subject to the Marketing Order, but concluded that it lacked jurisdiction to resolve the takings claim, which they should have raised in the Court of Federal Claims. It recognized that when a handler raises a takings defense, Court of Federal Claims Tucker Act jurisdiction gives way to the AMAA's comprehensive remedial scheme, see 7 U. S. C. ¬ß608c(15), but found that petitioners had brought the takings claim in their capacity as producers.

The issue before the Supreme Court was the validity of the provisions of school desegregation plans entitling a student, solely on the basis of his own race and the racial composition of the school to which he had been assigned by virtue of the plan, to transfer from such school, where he would be in the racial minority, back to his former segregated school, where his race would be in the majority. There was no provision whereby a student might transfer upon request to a school in which his race was in a minority, unless he qualified for a "good cause" transfer. The transfer plans were approved in the case of petitioner Goss by the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Tennessee (186 F Supp 559) and by the Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit (301 F2d 164), and in the case of petitioner Maxwell by the United States District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee and by the Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit (301 F2d 828).

A Tennessee cotton merchant entered into a contract with a Mississippi cotton farmer for the purchase of the farmer's future crop, to be delivered to the merchant's account at a local warehouse, and when the farmer failed to perform, the merchant instituted an action for damages and injunctive relief in the Chancery Court, Quitman County, Mississippi. The contract had been negotiated on the Tennessee merchant's behalf by an independent Mississippi broker who, while not authorized to execute contracts for the merchant, followed the practice of telephoning the necessary information to the merchant at its Tennessee office, where a contract was prepared and signed by the merchant and forwarded to the broker to obtain the farmer's signature. The Tennessee merchant had no office or warehouse in Mississippi, and no employees soliciting business or otherwise operating in the state on a regular basis; and the cotton purchased by the merchant in Mississippi was delivered to a local warehouse for sorting and classifying prior to its shipment in interstate or foreign commerce under the merchant's contracts for sale of the cotton to customers outside the state. The trial court entered judgment for the merchant, but the Supreme Court of Mississippi reversed, holding that (1) pursuant to a Mississippi statute, the suit could not be maintained in the state courts because of the Tennessee merchant's failure to obtain a certificate of authority to qualify to do business in the state, and (2) the merchant's transactions with Mississippi farmers were wholly intrastate in nature, since they were complete upon delivery of the cotton at the local warehouse, it being irrelevant that the merchant might subsequently sell the cotton in interstate commerce (276 So 2d 678).

The petition for rehearing is granted and the order denying the petition for writ of certiorari, 389 U.S. 835, is set aside. The petition for a writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit is vacated and the case is remanded to that court for further consideration in light of Bruton v. United States, 391 U.S. 123. See Roberts v. Russell, ante, p. 293.

A collective bargaining agreement between a longshoremen's union and employing stevedores provided "straight time hourly rates" for work done within a prescribed 44-hour time schedule, and "overtime hourly rates" for all work outside the straight time hours, with no differential for work in excess of 40 hours, the longshoremen working a varying and irregular number of hours throughout the work week.

After observing a car which was speeding and which had a cracked windshield, both of which were traffic violations, police officers directed the driver to stop the car. While the driver left the car and provided one officer with a registration certificate and proof of insurance, but stated that he had no driver's license, the other officer opened the left door of the car and checked the door jamb for the vehicle identification number, and when the officer did not find the number on the door jamb, he reached into the car to move some papers, obscuring the area of the dashboard where the number was located, and in doing so, he saw the handle of a gun protruding from underneath the driver's seat. The officer seized the gun, and the driver was promptly arrested. After a motion to suppress the gun as evidence was denied, the driver was convicted, in the Supreme Court of Bronx County, New York, for illegal possession of a weapon. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, First Department, affirmed the conviction without opinion (97 App Div 2d 741, 468 NYS2d 892), but the New York Court of Appeals reversed, holding (1) that a police officer's nonconsensual entry into an individual's car to determine the vehicle identification number violates the Federal and New York Constitutions where it is based solely on a stop for a traffic infraction; (2) that the Fourth Amendment protects people from unreasonable government intrusions into their legitimate expectations of privacy; (3) that the area underneath the seat of a car is one which a person legitimately expects to remain private; and (4) that in the present case, the officer's intrusion into the car in an effort to learn the vehicle identification number was not justified by the traffic violations which had occurred, in the absence of reason to suspect that the car was stolen (63 NY2d 491, 483 NYS2d 181, 472 NE2d 1009).

A passenger was injured when an unarmed Oklahoma county deputy pulled the passenger from a truck which had been stopped after a police chase. The passenger filed a Federal District Court suit which included a claim that the county, on the basis of the county sheriff's prior decision to hire the deputy--and more specifically, on the basis of the sheriff's allegedly inadequate screening of the deputy's background--ought to be held liable under 42 USCS 1983 for the deputy's alleged use of excessive force on the passenger. Before trial, counsel for the county stipulated that the sheriff had been the policymaker for the county in regard to the sheriff's department. At trial, the sheriff's own testimony indicated that he had made only a limited screening of the deputy's background, while there was evidence that this background had included a misdemeanor conviction for assault and battery and various other misdemeanor convictions. The District Court denied two motions by the county, at the close of the passenger's case and at the close of all of the evidence, for judgment as a matter of law. Also, the District Court instructed the jury that with respect to the county's liability, the passenger had to prove that the sheriff's inadequate screening of the deputy's background was so likely to result in violations of constitutional rights that the sheriff could reasonably be said to have been deliberately indifferent to the passenger's constitutional needs. The jury, through answers to special interrogatories, concluded that (1) the deputy had arrested the passenger with excessive force, and (2) the county's hiring policy, in the case of the deputy as "instituted" by the sheriff as the county's policymaker, had been so inadequate as to amount to deliberate indifference to the passenger's constitutional needs. The District Court entered judgment for the passenger on the issue of the county's liability. On appeal, a panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit initially concluded that (1) the jury's verdict ought to stand, and (2) the judgment ought to be affirmed (53 F.3d 1410). On rehearing en banc, the Court of Appeals, in reaching the same conclusion, expressed the view that the county had properly been found liable under 1983 on the basis of the sheriff's decision to hire the deputy (67 F.3d 1174).

An inmate in a local jail, who had supposedly slipped on a pillow negligently left on a stairway by a corrections officer, filed suit, in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia, for alleged violations of his constitutional rights, claiming that the officer had negligently deprived him of his liberty interest in freedom from bodily injury, and that this deprivation was without due process of law because the officer claimed that he would be entitled to a defense of sovereign immunity in a state tort action. The District Court granted the officer's motion for summary judgment. A panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit affirmed, finding that the inmate would not be deprived of a meaningful opportunity to present his case in state court even if the officer could make out a defense of sovereign immunity (720 F2d 792). On rehearing en banc, the Court of Appeals again affirmed, holding that the negligent infliction of bodily injury does not constitute a deprivation of any interest protected by the due process clause, and that the inmate had an adequate remedy in state court, since the ministerial nature of the officer's duties would have precluded him from successfutly defending on the ground of sovereign immunity (748 F2d 229).

Under 26 USCS 3121(a), the annual ceiling on wages subject to the Social Security tax portion of Federal Insurance Contributions Act (FICA) (26 USCS 3101 et seq.) tax is established by defining "wages" to exclude any remuneration paid to an individual by an employer during a calendar year that exceeds remuneration equal to the contribution and benefit base paid to such individual by such employer during the calendar year with respect to which such contribution and benefit base is effective. Under 26 USCS 3306(b)(1), annual wages subject to Federal Unemployment Tax Act (FUTA) (26 USCS 3301 et seq.) tax are similarly limited, by excluding from "wages" any remuneration paid to an individual by an employer during a calendar year that exceeds an annual ceiling. Both the ceilings and the tax rates for the Social Security tax portion of FICA and for FUTA taxes increased between the years 1987 and 1994. In addition, the ceiling for the Medicare portion of FICA taxes was abolished during that time period. Under a grievance settlement, a professional baseball team, in 1994, paid several players salary damages for 1986 and 1987, which damages were characterized by both the team and the Federal Government as back wages. After the team paid the additional FICA and FUTA taxes that resulted from applying the 1994 FICA and FUTA ceilings and rates to the damages, the team, asserting that the 1986 and 1987 FICA and FUTA ceilings and rates were applicable to the damages, sought a refund of the additional tax payments. The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) denied the refund claim. Subsequently, the team brought a refund action in a Federal District Court, which ordered the government to pay the refund. The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit affirmed (215 F3d 1325, reported in full 2000 US App LEXIS 9984).

In March 1996, an alien, who had been admitted to the United States as a lawful permanent resident, pled guilty to selling a controlled substance in violation of Connecticut law. His subsequent conviction on this charge made him deportable. At the time of his conviction, the alien would have been eligible, under 212(c) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (8 USCS 1182(c)), for waiver of deportation at the discretion of the United States Attorney General. However, by the time removal proceedings were commenced against the accused, 212(c) had been repealed and, in effect, had been replaced by legislation, under the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996 (110 Stat 1214) and the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 (110 Stat 3009-546), that, in the Attorney General's view, did not give the Attorney General discretion to waive deportation of aliens such as the alien in question. The alien, in a petition for a federal writ of habeas corpus, alleged that, because he pled guilty before 212(c) was repealed and the new legislation went into effect, the new legislation did not apply to him. A Federal District Court accepted jurisdiction of the alien's habeas corpus application and determined that the new legislation did not apply to the alien. The United States Courts of Appeals for the Second Circuit affirmed (229 F3d 406).

A woman who had been a student at a Virginia university (1) filed suit in the United States District Court for the Western District of Virginia against defendants including two male individuals; and (2) alleged, among other matters, that (a) she had been raped by the two individuals while she and they had been attending the university, and (b) this attack violated 42 USCS 13981, which provided a federal civil remedy for the victims of gender-motivated violence. The United States intervened to defend 13981's validity under the Federal Constitution. Although the District Court decided that the complaint stated a claim against the two alleged attackers under 13981, the District Court, in dismissing the complaint, reasoned that Congress lacked authority to enact 13981 under either the Constitution's commerce clause (Art I, 8, cl 3) or 5 of the Constitution's Fourteenth Amendment (935 F Supp 779). A panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit initially reversed the District Court (132 F3d 949). However, on rehearing en banc, the Court of Appeals, among other matters, instead affirmed the District Court's determination that Congress lacked authority under the Constitution to enact 13981's civil remedy (169 F3d 820).

A debtor filed a petition for relief under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code (11 USCS 1101-1174) in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Western District of Missouri, listing as a dischargeable debt a judgment previously entered against him for fraud in connection with the sale of corporate securities. The judgment creditors filed a complaint in the bankruptcy proceeding requesting a determination that their claim against the debtor based on the fraud judgment was exempt from discharge in bankruptcy pursuant to 11 USCS 523(a), which provides that certain types of debt are excepted from discharge in bankruptcy and which specifies, in 11 USCS 523(a)(2)(A), that a discharge in bankruptcy does not discharge an individual from any debt to the extent that such debt is obtained by "actual fraud." After the judgment creditors introduced portions of the record in the fraud case, the Bankruptcy Court found that all the elements required to establish actual fraud under 523 had been proved and that the doctrine of collateral estoppel required a holding that the debt was therefore not dischargeable, notwithstanding the debtor's contention that collateral estoppel did not apply inasmuch as the jury instructions in the fraud trial merely required that fraud be proved by a preponderance of the evidence, whereas 523 requires proof by clear and convincing evidence (73 BR 26). The United States District Court for the Western District of Missouri affirmed. On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit reversed, holding that 523 requires proof by clear and convincing evidence, at least in fraud cases (881 F2d 579).

In a suit for damages under the Federal Employers' Liability Act for the death of a railroad employee, held that there was no evidence in the record, nor any inference which reasonably could be drawn from the evidence, when viewed in a light most favorable to plaintiff, which could sustain a recovery.

In connection with a divorce decree, a California court awarded custody of the parties' two daughters to the wife, but a California court later modified the decree by awarding custody to the husband. After securing a California warrrant to obtain custody of the daughters, the husband, with his father and without the consent of the wife, picked up the daughters in Louisiana, where they had been living with the wife, and brought them back to California. Based on the wife's affidavit, a Louisiana prosecuting attorney filed an information charging the husband and his father with violating a Louisiana kidnapping statute. After the Governor of Louisiana formally notified the Governor of California of the kidnapping charges and demanded that the husband and his father be delivered up for trial, a California Superior Court issued a writ of habeas corpus to block the extradition warrants. A California Court of Appeal issued a writ of mandate on the ground that the Superior Court had abused its discretion in blocking extradition. The California Supreme Court reversed, finding that the California custody decrees had been properly considered by the Superior Court, and concluding that (1) under the full faith and credit provisions of the Parental Kidnaping Prevention Act of 1980 (28 USCS 1738A), the California decrees conclusively established that the husband was the lawful custodian of his daughters at the time he and his father took them from Louisiana to California, and (2) under Louisiana law, the lawful custodian could not be guilty of kidnapping children in his custody (41 Cal 3d 758, 716 P2d 991).

At issue in the case was whether 18 U.S.C.S. ¬¨√ü 2250 applied to sex offenders whose interstate travel occurred prior to the Sex Offender Registration and Notification Act's (SORNA) effective date and, if so, whether the statute ran afoul of the U.S. Constitution's prohibition on ex post facto laws. The Supreme Court found that, by its terms, the first element of ¬¨√ü 2250(a) could have only been satisfied when a person was required to register under SORNA. Once a person became subject to SORNA's registration requirements, which could have occurred only after the statute's effective date, that person could have been convicted under ¬¨√ü 2250 if he thereafter traveled and then failed to register. The statutory context strongly supported a forward-looking construction of "travels." Congress intended ¬¨√ü 2250 to do exactly what it said: to subject to federal prosecution sex offenders who eluded SORNA's registration requirements by traveling in interstate commerce. Liability under ¬¨√ü 2250 could not have been predicated on pre-SORNA travel. Defendant relocated prior to SORNA's enactment. The Supreme Court did not address the ex post facto question.

The Biologics Price Competition and Innovation Act of 2009 (BPCIA or Act) provides an abbreviated pathway for obtaining Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approval of a drug that is biosimilar to an already licensed biological product (reference product). 42 U. S. C. ¬ß262(k). It also provides procedures for resolving patent disputes between biosimilar manufacturers (applicants) and manufacturers of reference products (sponsors). ¬ß262(). The Act treats the mere submission of a biosimilar application as an "artificial" act of infringement, enabling parties to bring patent infringement actions at certain points in the application process even if the applicant has not committed a traditional act of patent infringement. See 35 U. S. C. ¬ß¬ß271(e)(2)(C)(i), (ii). Under ¬ß262(l)(2)(A), an applicant seeking FDA approval of a biosimilar must provide its application and manufacturing information to the sponsor within 20 days of the date the FDA notifies the applicant that it has accepted the application for review. This triggers an exchange of information between the applicant and sponsor designed to create lists of relevant patents and flesh out potential legal arguments. ¬ß262(l)(3). The BPCIA then channels the parties into two phases of patent litigation. In the first, the parties collaborate to identify patents on the lists for immediate litigation. The second phase-triggered when the applicant, pursuant to ¬ß262(l)(8)(A), gives the sponsor notice at least 180 days before commercially marketing the biosimilar-involves any listed patents not litigated in the first phase. The applicant has substantial control over the timing and scope of both phases of litigation. Failure to comply with these procedural requirements may lead to two consequences relevant here. Under ¬ß262()(9)(C), if an applicant fails to provide its application and manufacturing information to the sponsor under ¬ß262()(2)(A), then the sponsor, but not the applicant, may immediately bring an action "for a declaration of infringement, validity, or enforceability of any patent that claims the biological product or a use of the biological product." And under ¬ß262()(9)(B), if an applicant provides the application and manufacturing information but fails to complete a subsequent step in the process, the sponsor, but not the applicant, may bring a declaratory-judgment action with respect to any patent included on the sponsor's list of relevant patents. Neupogen is a filgrastim product marketed by Amgen, which claims to hold patents on methods of manufacturing and using filgrastim. Sandoz sought FDA approval to market a biosimilar filgrastim product under the brand name Zarxio, with Neupogen as the reference product. A day after the FDA informed Sandoz that its application had been accepted for review, Sandoz notified Amgen that it had submitted an application and that it intended to market Zarxio immediately upon receiving FDA approval. It later informed Amgen that it did not intend to provide the application and manufacturing information required by ¬ß262()(2)(A) and that Amgen could sue immediately for infringement under ¬ß262()(9)(C). Amgen sued Sandoz for patent infringement and also asserted that Sandoz engaged in "unlawful" conduct in violation of California's unfair competition law. This latter claim was predicated on two alleged violations of the BPCIA: Sandoz's failure to provide its application and manufacturing information under ¬ß262()(2)(A), and its provision of notice of commercial marketing under ¬ß262()(8)(A) prior to obtaining licensure from the FDA. Amgen sought injunctions to enforce both BPCIA requirements. Sandoz counterclaimed for declaratory judgments that the asserted patent was invalid and not infringed and that it had not violated the BPCIA. While the case was pending, the FDA licensed Zarxio, and Sandoz provided Amgen a further notice of commercial marketing. The District Court subsequently granted partial judgment on the pleadings to Sandoz on its BPCIA counterclaims and dismissed Amgen's unfair competition claims with prejudice. The Federal Circuit affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded. The court affirmed the dismissal of Amgen's state-law claim based on Sandoz's alleged violation of ¬ß262()(2)(A), holding that Sandoz did not violate the BPCIA in failing to disclose its application and manufacturing information and that the BPCIA provides the exclusive remedies for failure to comply with this requirement. The court also held that under ¬ß262(l)(8)(A) an applicant must provide notice of commercial marketing after obtaining licensure, and that this requirement is mandatory. It thus enjoined Sandoz from marketing Zarxio until 180 days after the date it provided its second notice.

The Federal Government brought an in rem civil forfeiture action in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida against a single-family residence, located in the district, which allegedly had been purchased with the proceeds of narcotics trafficking, so as to be subject to forfeiture under 511(a)(6) of the Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act of 1970 (21 USCS 881(a)(6)). A bank filed a claim asserting a lien interest in the residence and thereafter agreed to a sale of the residence. The proceeds of the sale were retained by the United States Marshal pending disposition of the case. After a trial on the merits, the District Court entered a judgment denying the bank's claim with prejudice and forfeiting the proceeds to the United States. The bank filed a timely notice of appeal to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit, but did not post a supersedeas bond or file a motion to stay execution of the judgment. At the Government's request, the Marshal transferred the proceeds of the sale to the Assets Forfeiture Fund of the United States Treasury. The Government then moved to dismiss the appeal for want of jurisdiction, and this motion was granted by the Court of Appeals, which held that the removal of the proceeds of the sale from the district terminated the District Court's in rem jurisdiction (932 F2d 1433).

A ship's officer sought recovery from the government for polio which the officer alleged he had contracted as a result of the government's negligence in creating conditions aboard ship whereby he contracted the disease, and negligence in the treatment thereof. The District Court found that the government was negligent in respect to the condition of the ship, and, on appeal, the Court of Appeals reversed on the ground that this negligence was not shown to have proximately caused the polio.

A group of unincorporated Wisconsin townships filed suit against an adjacent city in the United States District Court for the Western District of Wisconsin, alleging that the city had violated the Sherman Act (15 USCS 1 et seq.) by acquiring a monopoly over sewage treatment in the area and providing that service only to areas which were willing to be annexed by the city and to use its sewage collection services rather than those of the towns. The District Court ruled in favor of the city, pointing to a Wisconsin law which authorized cities providing sewage services to limit the unincorporated areas covered by their service unless ordered by the state to service certain areas, and holding that the city's conduct fell within the "state action" exemption from the federal antitrust laws. The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit affirmed (700 F2d 376).

The present case involved the constitutionality of a Florida statute entitled "Uniform Law to Secure the Attendance of Witnesses from Within or Without a State in Criminal Proceedings." A request made under this statute by New York authorities that respondent be given into their custody to the transported to New York to testify in a grand jury proceeding there was refused by the Circuit Court of Dade County, Florida, on the ground, among others, that the statute violated the United States Constitution. (9 Fla Supp 153.) The Supreme Court of Florida affirmed. (100 So 2d 149.)

The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, as amended (ADA) (42 USCS 12101 et seq.) is made inapplicable to very small businesses by 42 USCS 12111(5), which provides that the ADA applies to only employers that have 15 or more employees. A bookkeeper, whose employment at a medical clinic--which was a professional corporation owned by four physician-shareholders who practiced medicine at the clinic and constituted its board of directors--had been terminated, brought, against the clinic, an action alleging unlawful discrimination on the basis of disability in violation of the ADA. The United States District Court for the District of Oregon, adopting a magistrate judge's findings and recommendation, granted the clinic's motion for summary judgment, which was based on an assertion that the clinic had fewer than 15 employees, where the accuracy of this assertion depended on whether the four shareholder-directors were counted as employees (2000 US Dist LEXIS 8574). A divided panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit reversed (271 F3d 903).

The Immigration and Nationality Act provides the framework for acquisition of U. S. citizenship from birth by a child born abroad, when one parent is a U. S. citizen and the other a citizen of another nation. Applicable to married couples, the main rule in effect at the time here relevant, 8 U. S. C. ¬ß1401(a)(7) (1958 ed.), required the U. S.-citizen parent to have ten years‚Äô physical presence in the United States prior to the child‚Äôs birth, ‚Äúat least five of which were after attaining‚Äù age 14. The rule is made applicable to unwed U. S.-citizen fathers by ¬ß1409(a), but ¬ß1409(c) creates an exception for an unwed U. S.-citizen mother, whose citizenship can be transmitted to a child born abroad if she has lived continuously in the United States for just one year prior to the child‚Äôs birth. Respondent Luis Ram√≥n Morales-Santana, who has lived in the United States since he was 13, asserts U. S. citizenship at birth based on the U. S. citizenship of his biological father, Jos√© Morales. Jos√© moved to the Dominican Republic 20 days short of his 19th birthday, therefore failing to satisfy ¬ß1401(a)(7)‚Äôs requirement of five years‚Äô physical presence after age 14. There, he lived with the Dominican woman who gave birth to Morales-Santana. Jos√© accepted parental responsibility and included Morales-Santana in his household; he married Morales-Santana‚Äôs mother and his name was then added to hers on Morales-Santana‚Äôs birth certificate. In 2000, the Government sought to remove Morales-Santana based on several criminal convictions, ranking him as alien because, at his time of birth, his father did not satisfy the requirement of five years‚Äô physical presence after age 14. An immigration judge rejected MoralesSantana‚Äôs citizenship claim and ordered his removal. Morales¬≠ Santana later moved to reopen the proceedings, asserting that the Government‚Äôs refusal to recognize that he derived citizenship from his U. S.-citizen father violated the Constitution‚Äôs equal protection guarantee. The Board of Immigration Appeals denied the motion, but the Second Circuit reversed. Relying on this Court‚Äôs post-1970 construction of the equal protection principle as it bears on genderbased classifications, the court held unconstitutional the differential treatment of unwed mothers and fathers. To cure this infirmity, the Court of Appeals held that Morales-Santana derived citizenship through his father, just as he would were his mother the U. S. citizen.

A Montana statute provides that, subject to certain restrictions, the State Board of Pardons (parole board) "shall release on parole ... any person confined in the Montana state prison ... when in its opinion there is reasonable probability that the prisoner can be released without detriment to the prisoner or to the community." The statute further provides that a prisoner "shall be placed on parole only when the board believes that he is able and willing to fulfill the obligations of a law-abiding citizen." Two inmates of the Montana state prison, after being denied parole, filed an action in the United States District Court for the District of Montana under 42 USCS 1983 on behalf of a class of all present and future inmates of the state prison who were or might become eligible for parole. Seeking declaratory and injunctive relief as well as compensatory damages, the complaint alleged that the parole board violated the inmates' rights under the Fourteenth Amendment's due process clause by (1) failing to apply statutorily mandated criteria in determining inmates' eligibility for parole, and (2) failing to explain adequately its reasons for denial of parole. The District Court dismissed the action, holding that the inmates were not entitled to due process protections in connection with the board's denial of parole, since the board's discretion was too broad to provide a prisoner with a constitutionally protected liberty interest in parole release. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit reversed, holding that (1) the statute's use of the mandatory term "shall" indicated that under the statute, the board may not deny parole once it determines that harm is not probable, and (2) the provisions of the Montana statute were comparable to those of a Nebraska statute that was held in Greenholtz v Nebraska Penal Inmates, 442 US 1, 60 L Ed 2d 668, 99 S Ct 2100, to create an expectancy of release and thus a liberty interest (792 F2d 1404).
One convicted for contempt of Congress fled the United States after the Supreme Court had granted his petition for writ of certiorari and after his cause had been submitted on the merits.

In a patent infringement suit by a research company in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, the defendant, a radio and television set manufacturer, counterclaimed for treble damages and injunctive relief, alleging antitrust violations consisting of both misuse of the research company's patents and a conspiracy in restraint of trade by the research company, its parent corporation, and Canadian, English, and Australian patent pools. Holding that the research company had misused its patents, the District Court awarded the manufacturer treble damages and injunctive relief against the research company; and further holding that the research company and its parent corporation had conspired in restraint of trade, the District Court, relying upon a pretrial stipulation that the research company and its parent corporation were to be considered as an entity for purposes of the litigation, awarded the manufacturer treble damages and injunctive relief against both the research company and its parent corporation (239 F Supp 51). On appeal, the Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, affirming the treble damage award for patent misuse, but otherwise reversing the judgment of the District Court, (1) held that the District Court lacked jurisdiction over the research company's parent corporation, and that the stipulation relied upon by the District Court was an insufficient basis for entering judgment against the parent corporation, (2) modified in certain respects the District Court's injunction against patent misuse, (3) held that the manufacturer had failed to prove that it had sustained damage as a result of the conspiracy in restraint of trade, and (4) struck the injunction against the research company's participation in conspiracies restricting the manufacturer's trade in foreign markets (388 F2d 25).

Two paraplegics who used wheelchairs for mobility--a criminal defendant and a certified court reporter--filed, in a Federal District Court, an action for damages and equitable relief, alleging that Tennessee and a number of its counties had denied them physical access to the state court system in violation of Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA) (42 USCS __ 12131 et seq.), which, in 42 USCS _ 12132, prohibited any qualified individual with a disability from, by reason of such disability, being excluded from participation in, or denied the benefits of the services, programs, or activities of, a public entity, or being subjected to discrimination by any such entity.

In the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado, a jury found that defendant indirectly infringed plaintiff's patent and partially breached the parties' contract. Damages were assessed for breach of contract and indirect infringement. After denying defendant's motion for judgment as a matter of law (JMOL), the district court doubled the infringement award for willful infringement and issued a permanent injunction. Defendant appealed.

A state prisoner, convicted in the Dade County, Florida, Criminal Court of two felonies, filed, after an unsuccessful appeal from the judgment of conviction, a petition for habeas corpus in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida, alleging that his confinement was unlawful because the state trial court had denied his motions to dismiss the chosen jurors and for a change of venue, these motions being based on the ground that through pretrial publicity, the jurors were aware of his prior criminal record or certain facts about the crime charged. The District Court denied relief (363 F Supp 1224), and the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit affirmed (495 F2d 553).

Petitioner Montgomery was 17 years old in 1963, when he killed a deputy sheriff in Louisiana. The jury returned a verdict of "guilty without capital punishment," which carried an automatic sentence of life without parole. Nearly 50 years after Montgomery was taken into custody, this Court decided that mandatory life without parole for juvenile homicide offenders violates the Eighth Amendment's prohibition on "' cruel and unusual punishments.' "Miller v. Alabama, 567 U. S. ____.Montgomery sought state collateral relief, arguing that Miller rendered his mandatory Hie-without-parole sentence ilegal. The trial court denied his motion, and his application for a supervisory writ was denied by the Louisiana Supreme Court, which had previously held that Miller does not have retroactive effect in cases on state collateral review.

A judgment of probation, suspending imposition of sentence, was entered against the defendant in his absence and was void for that reason. Nearly two years later, after defendant had violated the terms of his probation, a formal judgment sentencing him to prison and setting aside the judgment of probation was entered. Defendant's motion to vacate this sentence was denied by the United States District Court for the District of Minnesota. Petitioner's further motion for leave to appeal in forma pauperis was denied, without opinion, by the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. After the Supreme Court of the United States had granted certiorari, the defendant was released from prison.

The plaintiffs in nine actions which were tried together in the Southern District of New York appeal from the dismissal of their complaints which alleged violations of the antitrust laws and sought treble damages from the Carvel Corporation, a New York corporation which manufactures dairy and primarily soft ice cream products, ‚àö¬∂[**2]‚àö¬∂ its subsidiary organizations, certain of its individual officers and attorneys, and a number of its suppliers. The plaintiffs, former and present individual operators of Carvel franchise outlets in Massachusetts, Connecticut and Pennsylvania, also charged the Carvel defendants with fraudulent misrepresentations in the franchise negotiations.

An employee who was represented by a union under a collective bargaining agreement, one provision of which prohibited an employee's wrongful discharge or discharge without just cause, was discharged by her employer on grounds that she had filed a false worker's compensation claim. Pursuant to a mandatory arbitration procedure under the collective bargaining agreement, the union filed a grievance on the employee's behalf, in which the union denied that the employee's worker's compensation claim had been false, and the arbitrator eventually ordered the employee's reinstatement with backpay. Subsequent to the filing of the grievance, the employee also filed a state court action against her employer in the Illinois Circuit Court for Williamson County, alleging that she had been discharged for exercising her rights under the Illinois worker's compensation statute, under which compensatory and punitive damages for an employer's retaliatory discharge could be recovered. The action was removed on grounds of diversity of citizenship to the United States District Court for the Southern District of Illinois, where the employer moved to dismiss on grounds that the District Court lacked subject matter jurisdiction of the employee's retaliatory discharge claim, on grounds that the claim--insofar as it sought a state law remedy for a right governed by the collective bargaining agreement covering the employee--was pre-empted by 301(a) of the Labor Management Relations Act of 1947 (29 USCS 185(a)). The District Court, concluding that the retaliatory discharge claim was "inextricably intertwined" with the provision in the collective bargaining agreement prohibiting wrongful discharge, granted the employer's motion and dismissed the employee's complaint (618 F Supp 1448). The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit affirmed, agreeing that the retaliatory discharge claim was pre-empted by 301 (823 F2d 1031).

Two defendants were charged with federal drug offenses in the United States District Court for the District of South Carolina. The prosecutions arose after a truck driven by one of the defendants was stopped by a highway patrol officer working with an agent of the Drug Enforcement Administration and detained for about 15 minutes until the agent, who had pursued the other defendant in another vehicle, arrived on the scene and within 5 minutes determined that the truck contained material resembling marijuana. Subsequent chemical tests showed that the material was in fact marijuana. The District Court denied a motion to suppress the contraband and the defendants were convicted. The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit reversed, concluding that the investigative stops failed to meet the requirement of brevity and that the length of the detentions transformed them into de facto arrests without probable cause (712 F2d 65).

Petitioners Reichle and Doyle were members of a Secret Service detail protecting Vice President Richard Cheney while he greeted members of the public at a shopping mall. Agent Doyle overheard respondent Howards, who was speaking into his cell phone, state that he ‚Äúwas going to ask [the Vice President] how many kids he‚Äôs killed today.‚Äù Doyle and other agents observed Howards enter the line to meet the Vice President, tell the Vice President that his ‚Äúpolicies in Iraq are disgusting,‚Äù and touch the Vice President‚Äôs shoulder as the Vice President was leaving. After being briefed by Doyle, Agent Reichle interviewed and then arrested Howards, who was charged with harassment. After that charge was dismissed, Howards brought an action against petitioners and others under 42 U. S. C. ¬ß1983 and Bivens v. Six Unknown Fed. Narcotics Agents, 403 U. S. 388. Howards claimed that he was arrested and searched without probable cause, in violation of the Fourth Amendment, and that the arrest violated the First Amendment because it was made in retaliation for Howards‚Äô criticism of the Vice President. Petitioners moved for summary judgment on the ground that they were entitled to qualified immunity, but the Federal District Court denied the motion. On appeal, the Tenth Circuit reversed the immunity ruling with respect to the Fourth Amendment claim because petitioners had probable cause to arrest Howards, but the court affirmed with regard to the First Amendment claim. In doing so, the court rejected petitioners‚Äô argument that, under Hartman v. Moore, 547 U. S. 250, probable cause to arrest defeats a First Amendment retaliatory arrest claim. It concluded instead that Hartman applied only to retaliatory prosecution claims and thus did not upset prior Tenth Circuit precedent holding that a retaliatory arrest violates the First Amendment even if supported by probable cause

Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of Maryland. We noted probable jurisdiction n1 and set the case for oral argument with Williams v. Illinois, ante, p. 235, decided today. However, Maryland has recently enacted legislation n2 dealing directly with the issue presented, and our holding in Williams, that an indigent may not be imprisoned beyond the maximum term specified by statute solely because of his failure to pay a fine and court costs, may shed further light on the question raised here. We therefore vacate the judgment and remand the case to the District Court for reconsideration in light of the intervening legislation and our holding in Williams v. Illinois, supra.

The present action was brought by the United States in the United States District Court for the Southern District of California for the purpose of revoking petitioner's naturalization decree on the ground that it had been procured by concealment of a material fact or by wilful misrepresentation within the meaning of 340(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952. The complaint was based on the ground, among others, that petitioner had procured his naturalization by concealing a record of arrests. The District Court canceled petitioner's naturalization, finding that he had concealed and misrepresented three matters, his arrests, his membership in the Communist Party, and his allegiance. The Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit affirmed, reaching only the question of the concealment of the arrests. (270 F2d 179.)

Various natural gas producers applied to the Federal Power Commission for permanent certificates to sell gas produced in three Texas gulf coast districts. The Commission conditionally certificated the proposed sales. (31 FPC 623, 34 FPC 897.) On an appeal to the Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit concerning one of the districts, it was held proper for the Commission, in setting in-line prices, to take account of prices at which gas had been sold under temporary certificates, but it was held that the Commission had no power to order refunds of amounts collected by producers in the past under temporary certificates which contained no refund conditions and had not been appealed. (370 F2d 181; 376 F2d 578.) On appeal to the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia concerning the other two districts, it was held that the Commission, in setting in-line prices, had erred in giving weight to the price of sales under temporary certificates, and that the Commission had also erred in reserving to later proceedings the question whether there was a public need for the gas which was to be sold. (126 App DC 26, 373 F2d 816.)

Two Federal District Courts appointed commissions under Rule 71A(h) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure to determine the issue of just compensation in eminent domain proceedings. In No. 65, the District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma gave no instructions to the commissioners and adopted the commission's reports, which contained conclusory findings of the damages assessed, but which did not indicate the process or reasoning used by the commission in assessing damages. The Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit affirmed, stating that the awards were within the range of the conflicting testimony taken by the commission. (306 F2d 39.) In No. 79, the District Court for the Middle District of Georgia instructed the commission as to the applicable law and the filing of reports, and adopted the commission's reports, which contained conclusory findings of the damages assessed without indicating the commission's reasoning, and which, in some instances, assessed damages in excess of the highest estimates of the expert witnesses, including the landowners' experts. The Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit remanded for resubmission to the commission, on the ground that the reports did not indicate the evidence adopted by the commission in assessing damages. (310 F2d 775.)

In consolidated actions in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California, conscientious objectors who, upon completion of alternative civilian service, had been denied educational benefits under the Veterans' Readjustment Benefits Act of 1966 (38 USCS 1651-1697) by the Veterans' Administration, sought declaratory, injunctive, and mandamus relief, contending that the Act's restriction of benefits to veterans who had served on active duty unconstitutionally discriminated against conscientious objectors and infringed the religion clauses of the First Amendment. Granting the government's motion to dismiss, the District Court held that (1) the court lacked jurisdiction of the action because of the prohibition of 38 USCS 211(a) against judicial review of decisions of the Administrator of Veterans Affairs on questions of law or fact under any law administered by the Veterans' Administration providing for veterans' benefits, and (2) the plaintiffs' constitutional challenges were insubstantial and without merit (339 F Supp 913). The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit affirmed the dismissal on the ground of the jurisdictional bar of 38 USCS 211(a) (467 F2d 479).

The motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded for consideration in light of Coppedge v. United States, ante, p. 438.

In a suit for a declaratory judgment and an injunction instituted by a licensee under a patent-licensing agreement, the District Court sustained the validity of a condition requiring the licensee to assign improvement patents to the licensor.

The judges of the United States District Court for the Southern District of California adopted a districtwide policy permitting the use of full restraints‚Äîhandcuffs connected to a waist chain, with legs shack- led‚Äîon most in-custody defendants produced in court for nonjury proceedings by the United States Marshals Service. Respondents Jasmin Morales, Rene Sanchez-Gomez, Moises Patricio-Guzman, and Mark Ring challenged the use of such restraints in their respective cases and the restraint policy as a whole. The District Court denied their challenges, and respondents appealed to the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Before that court could issue a decision, re- spondents‚Äô underlying criminal cases ended. The court‚Äîviewing the case as a ‚Äúfunctional class action‚Äù involving ‚Äúclass-like claims‚Äù seek- ing ‚Äúclass-like relief,‚Äù 859 F. 3d 649, 655, 657‚Äì658‚Äîheld that this Court‚Äôs civil class action precedents saved the case from mootness. On the merits, the Court of Appeals held the policy unconstitutional.

A personal holding company entered into a purchase agreement with a corporation under which the holding company received debentures convertible into more than ten per cent of the corporation's outstanding common stock, thus making the company a beneficial owner of the corporation for purposes of 16(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (15 USCS 78p(b)), which authorizes a corporation to recover for itself the profits realized by a beneficial owner of more than ten per cent of its shares from a purchase and sale, or sale and purchase, of its stock within a six-month period. Having acquired and disposed of the securities within six months, the holding company brought suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California, seeking a declaration that it was not liable to the corporation under 16(b), and the District Court granted summary judgment for the holding company (331 F Supp 787). On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit affirmed on the basis of the exemptive provision of 16(b), which provides that 16(b) is not to be construed to cover any transaction where the beneficial owner was not such both "at the time of the purchase and sale, or the sale and purchase," the court deciding that although the holding company became a beneficial owner of the corporation by acquiring the debentures, it was not a beneficial owner "at the time of the purchase," since in a purchase-sale sequence the last-quoted phrase had to be construed to mean prior to the time when the decision to purchase was made (506 F2d 601).
Gasoline bought in the United States by a Canadian corporation for export to Canada and shipped by rail to Detroit was stored there in tanks for 15 months before it was shipped to Canada by water.

Under Tennessee law, first-degree murder requires proof of premeditation and deliberation, while second-degree murder requires proof of malice. At a Tennessee trial in which the accused was eventually convicted of first-degree murder of one victim and second-degree murder of another, the trial court, when defining "malice," instructed the jury that all homicides "are presumed to be malicious" in the absence of evidence which would rebut the implied presumption. After the accused's argument that the jury instructions had impermissibly shifted the burden of proof as to malice was rejected on direct appeal, the accused sought habeas corpus relief on the same grounds in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee. The District Court held that (1) the malice instruction had violated the accused's right to have his guilt proved beyond a reasonable doubt, as defined in Sandstrom v Montana (1979) 442 US 510, 61 L Ed 2d 39, 99 S Ct 2450; and (2) the error could not be deemed harmless because the accused at trial had relied upon a mens rea defense in contesting his guilt (611 F Supp 294). On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit affirmed, (1) agreeing that the malice instruction was unconstitutional under Sandstrom v Montana; and (2) expressing the view that because the accused contested malice at his trial, an erroneous burden-shifting instruction could not be deemed "harmless" (unpublished opinion; judgment reported at 762 F2d 1006).

Petitioner, a stevedoring company engaged by a carrier to load cargo aboard a ship, negligently caused damage to a package of cargo shipped by respondents. Respondents thereupon instituted a tort action in the United States District Court for the District of Maryland to recover the damage, and petitioner's answer asserted, inter alia, that its liability was limited to $ 500 by the limitation of liability provisions of the Carriage of Goods by Sea Act and by the parallel provisions of the bill of lading to which the shipper and carrier were parties. The District Court held that respondents were entitled to recover the full amount of their damages from petitioner (145 F Supp 554), and rendered judgment for respondents for that amount (155 F Supp 296). The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit affirmed (256 F2d 946).

Harry Mitts drank bourbon until he became intoxicated and then shot and killed an African American man, while speaking racial epithets. During the police shoot-out that followed, Mitts shot and killed one police officer and wounded two others before being apprehended. At trial, Mitts did not contest the evidence proving that he had killed two men, but he instead attempted to establish that he was too intoxicated to form the required intent to kill. After a penalty hearing, the jury recommended the death penalty on both aggravated murder counts and terms of imprisonment for the attempted murders. The trial court sentenced Mitts to death for the aggravated murders and to terms of imprisonment for the attempted murders. The Ohio Court of Appeals affirmed Mitts' convictions and sentences, and the Ohio Supreme Court affirmed the convictions and sentences and denied rehearing, ruling that the trial court should have instructed the jury to merge duplicative death penalty specifications, but holding that the error did not influence the jury and was resolved by re-weighing on appeal. Mitts filed a petition for a writ of habeas corpus. A federal judge in Cleveland affirmed the sentence, but the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit decided to vacate.

Under 1561(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1954 (26 USCS 1561(a)), as it formerly read, a "controlled group of corporations" was limited to a single corporate surtax exemption. Section 1563(a)(2) of the Code (26 USCS 1563(a)(2)) provides that a "controlled group of corporations" includes a "brother-sister controlled group," defined as "[t]wo or more corporations if 5 or fewer persons ... own ... stock possessing (A) at least 80 percent of the total combined voting power ... or at least 80 percent of the total value ... of each corporation, and (B) more than 50 percent of the total combined voting power ... or more than 50 percent of the total value ... of each corporation, taking into account the stock ownership of each such person only to the extent such stock ownership is identical with respect to each such corporation," and a Treasury Regulation ( 26 CFR 1.1563-1(a)(3)) interpreting that statutory provision states that the term "brother-sister controlled group" means two or more corporations if the same five or fewer persons own "singly or in combination" the two prescribed percentages of voting power or total value. A fertilizer corporation--77.49 percent of whose stock was owned by an individual who held 87.5 percent of the voting power of another corporation, and the remaining 22.51 percent of whose stock was owned by an unrelated individual who owned no stock in the second corporation--did not claim a full surtax exemption on its tax returns, believing that the Treasury regulation barred such a claim. However, the corporation subsequently filed timely claims for refunds, asserting that it and the other corporation were not members of a controlled group and that it was therefore entitled to a full surtax exemption for each taxable year. The Internal Revenue Service disallowed the claims, and the corporation brought a suit for a refund in the United States Court of Claims. The Court of Claims held that two corporations did not constitute a brother-sister controlled group within the meaning of 1563(a)(2), that the Treasury regulation was invalid to the extent that it took into account, with respect to the 80-percent requirement, stock held by a shareholder who owns stock in only one corporation of the controlled group, and that the corporation was therefore entitled to a refund (634 F2d 497).

In two separate incidents, officers of a Texas county's narcotics unit, executing search warrants, supposedly made forcible entries into private homes in fruitless searches for evidence of narcotics activity, in the course of which the officers allegedly shot two dogs to death in one home and assaulted the homeowner in the other. In an action under 42 USCS 1983 in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Texas against some local officials in their official capacity, the county, two cities, and the narcotics unit, the homeowners asserted that (1) the officers' conduct had violated the Federal Constitution's Fourth Amendment, and (2) the municipalities were liable for these violations due to their alleged failure adequately to train the officers involved on the proper manner to execute search warrants and to respond when confronted by family dogs. The complaint alleged no underlying facts other than the events of the searches to support the assertion that the municipalities had adopted policies, customs, and practices condoning the officers' conduct. The District Court held that the conclusionary allegations of the complaint as to inadequate training did not meet the "heightened pleading standard" required for such claims under decisions of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, and accordingly dismissed all claims against all of the defendants (755 F Supp 726). The Court of Appeals, affirming, held that the complaint was insufficient because it failed to state any facts with respect to the adequacy or inadequacy of police training (954 F2d 1054).

18 USCS 1302 prohibits the mailing of publications containing either any advertising for any lottery, gift enterprise, or scheme in which prizes were offered based in whole or in part upon lot or chance, or any list of prizes awarded by means of any such lottery, gift enterprise, or scheme. An organization which represented a state's newspaper publishers filed an action in the United States District Court for the District of Minnesota against the United States Postal Service, seeking to bar the enforcement of 1302 against its member newspapers, based on the Federal Constitution's First Amendment and the due process clause of the Fifth Amendment, with respect to gaming activities run for fundraising purposes by nonprofit charities in conformity with state law. The District Court ruled that 1302's restriction on the mailing of advertisements was constitutional, but granted a permanent injunction against the Postal Service from further enforcement of the restrictions in 1302 and its implementing regulations as to the mailing of prize lists (677 F Supp 1400). The Postal Service appealed the injunction ruling on prize lists, the organization cross-appealed the ruling on advertisements, and the United States Supreme Court noted probable jurisdiction of both appeals. Thereafter, (1) Congress passed two laws affecting the coverage of 1302, (2) both parties agreed to dismiss the cross appeal, (3) the Postal Service conceded that 1302 did not apply to the noncommercial publishing of prize lists, and (4) the organization stated its willingness to forgo any further claim to the declaratory and equitable relief sought in its complaint.

The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Arkansas, in a case in which the constitutionality of an Arkansas statute affecting the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People was challenged, referred to the state courts questions as to construction of the statute under attack. On appeal, the United States Supreme Court, in a per curiam opinion reflecting the views of six members of the court, vacated the District Court's judgment, and remanded the case for consideration in light of Harrison v National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, 360 US 167, 3 L ed 2d 1152, 79 S Ct 1025.

During the war the government requisitioned pepper from a company which had accumulated a large supply of pepper, expecting to hold it for sale when the prices went up and basing its policy on the fairly regular cyclical fluctuations of pepper prices over a period of about 75 years. The government's offer to pay the ceiling price established under the Emergency Price Control Act was rejected by the company. The Court of Claims fixed the compensation at a price higher than the ceiling price, taking into consideration (1) the "retention value" arising from the owner's right, expressly recognized by 4(d) of the act, to hold the property until restrictions on its dispositions are removed; and (2) the cost of the pepper to the owner, which exceeded the ceiling price.

In an action in the nature of mandamus instituted in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, persons whose applications for oil and gas leases in the Kenai National Moose Range in Alaska were rejected by the Department of the Interior, on the ground that the lands had been leased to prior applicants, asserted that the prior applications were ineffective because the lands were closed to leasing by virtue of Executive Order No. 8979 and Public Land Order No. 487, when the prior applications were filed. The District Court dismissed the complaint, but the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia reversed. (116 App DC 379, 324 F2d 411.)

In Wainwright v Witt (1985) 469 US 412, 83 L Ed 2d 841, 105 S Ct 844, a federal habeas corpus case which involved determining when prospective jurors may be excused for cause because of their views concerning the death penalty, the United States Supreme Court held that under 28 USCS 2254(d), federal courts must accord a presumption of correctness to state courts' findings of juror bias. An accused was convicted in a Georgia trial court on charges including murder and was sentenced to death after the trial court, over the accused's objection, had excused for cause five jurors who had expressed reservations about the death penalty. The Supreme Court of Georgia, in affirming, expressed the view that Wainwright v Witt was "controlling authority" for a rule that appellate courts must defer to trial courts' findings of fact concerning juror bias (266 Ga 439, 469 S.E.2d 129).

Petitioner Merck Sharp & Dohme Corp. manufactures Fosamax, a drug that treats and prevents osteoporosis in postmenopausal women.
