The accused therefore moved the District Court to hold his pending federal habeas corpus petition in abeyance, while he presented his unexhausted claims to the South Dakota courts. The District Court (1) granted the motion, and (2) issued a stay conditioned upon the accused's commencing (as he did) state-court exhaustion proceedings.

After a National Guardsman had been awarded a life-time government pension as a result of injuries he sustained during training when the egress life-support system of his fighter aircraft malfunctioned during a mid-air emergency, the serviceman brought a personal injury action in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri against the United States and the subcontractor on a contract between the United States and another, which subcontractor had manufactured the aircraft's ejectment system according to the government's specifications and with components supplied by the government. The subcontractor cross-claimed against the United States for indemnity as to any sums it would be required to pay to the serviceman, charging that the government was primarily responsible for the serviceman's injuries. The United States moved for summary judgment against the serviceman, claiming that the government could not be held liable for injuries sustained incident to military service under the Federal Tort Claims Act (28 USCS 2674), and also moved for dismissal of the subcontractor's cross-claim, asserting that an indemnity action by a third party for moneys paid to military personnel who could not recover directly from the United States could not be brought. The District Court granted the government's motions, dismissing the serviceman's and subcontractor's claims against the government (395 F Supp 52). The United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit affirmed (536 F2d 765).

A union member who assaulted the local's business manager in a job referral dispute was charged with violating the local's constitutional provision against attempting to create dissension or working against the union's interest and harmony, and the local's bylaw against threatening or using force against any union officer to prevent him from properly discharging the duties of his office. A local committee found him "guilty as charged," the local membership approved and voted him suspended indefinitely, and the international denied his appeal. Thereafter, he sued the international in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Alabama for consequential and punitive damages. The District Court instructed the jury that there was no evidence that the member violated the union's constitution, and since the union tribunals had returned only a general verdict on the two charges, the member had been deprived of the "full and fair hearing" guaranteed by 101(a)(5)(C) of the Labor-Management Reporting and Disclosure Act (29 USC 411(a) (5)(C)). The jury awarded damages of $ 152,150, and the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit affirmed (420 F2d 485).

The motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded for further consideration in light of Sanders v. United States, 373 U.S. 1: When brought before the United States District Court for the Northern District of California on a charge of robbery of a federally insured bank, the accused, appearing without counsel, waived the right to the assistance of counsel and the right to proceed by indictment, and pleaded guilty to the charge. He was given a 15-year sentence. Subsequently he filed a motion under 28 USC 2255 to vacate and set aside his sentence on the grounds that the indictment was invalid, that he was denied the assistance of counsel, and that the sentencing court had allowed him to be coerced into entering a plea without counsel and without knowledge of the charges lodged against him. He also applied for a writ of habeas corpus ad testificandum requiring prison authorities to produce him before the court to testify in support of his motion. The sentencing court denied both the motion and the application without a hearing, for the reason that the motion alleged bare conclusions unsupported by facts. The prisoner then filed a second motion under 28 USC 2255, alleging that at the time of the conviction and sentence he was mentally incompetent as a result of narcotics administered to him while he was being held in a county jail pending trial. The sentencing court denied this motion without a hearing on the grounds that (1) there was no reason why the prisoner could not have raised the issue of mental incompetency at the time of the first motion, and (2) the prisoner's allegations were without merit in fact. The Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit affirmed on the first of these grounds. (297 F2d 735.)

In 2016, petitioner Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts, Inc. (AWF) licensed to Cond√© Nast for $10,000 an image of ‚ÄúOrange Prince‚Äù‚Äîan orange silkscreen portrait of the musician Prince created by pop artist Andy Warhol‚Äîto appear on the cover of a magazine commemorating Prince. Orange Prince is one of 16 works now known as the Prince Series that Warhol derived from a copyrighted photograph taken in 1981 by respondent Lynn Goldsmith, a professional photographer. Goldsmith had been commissioned by Newsweek in 1981 to photograph a then ‚Äúup and coming‚Äù musician named Prince Rogers Nelson, after which Newsweek published one of Goldsmith‚Äôs photos along with an article about Prince. Years later, Goldsmith granted a limited license to Vanity Fair for use of one of her Prince photos as an ‚Äúartist reference for an illustration.‚Äù The terms of the license included that the use would be for ‚Äúone time‚Äù only. Vanity Fair hired Warhol to create the illustration, and Warhol used Goldsmith‚Äôs photo to create a purple silkscreen portrait of Prince, which appeared with an article about Prince in Vanity Fair‚Äôs November 1984 issue. The magazine credited Goldsmith for the ‚Äúsource photograph‚Äù and paid her $400. After Prince died in 2016, Vanity Fair‚Äôs parent company (Cond√© Nast) asked AWF about reusing the 1984 Vanity Fair image for a special edition magazine that would commemorate Prince. When Cond√© Nast learned about the other Prince Series images, it opted instead to purchase a license from AWF to publish Orange Prince. Goldsmith did not know about the Prince Series until 2016, when she saw Orange Prince on the cover of Cond√© Nast‚Äôs magazine. Goldsmith notified AWF of her belief that it had infringed her copyright. AWF then sued Goldsmith for a declaratory judgment of noninfringement or, in the alternative, fair use. Goldsmith counterclaimed for infringement. The District Court considered the four fair use factors in 17 U. S. C. ¬ß107 and granted AWF summary judgment on its defense of fair use. The Court of Appeals reversed, finding that all four fair use factors favored Goldsmith. In this Court, the sole question presented is whether the first fair use factor, ‚Äúthe purpose and character of the use, including whether such use is of a commercial nature or is for nonprofit educational purposes,‚Äù ¬ß107(1), weighs in favor of AWF‚Äôs recent commercial licensing to Cond√© Nast.

After the Navy decided to construct several weapons storage structures capable of storing nuclear weapons, an action was brought in the United States District Court for the District of Hawaii, seeking an injunction against the building of such new facilities until an environmental impact statement had been filed by the Navy pursuant to 102(2)(C) of the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 (42 USCS 4332(2)(C)), regarding the environmental impact of nuclear weapons storage on the area surrounding the new facilities. The District Court held that the Navy was not required to file an environmental impact statement, even though the construction and operation of such facilities was "major federal action" under the National Environmental Policy Act (42 USCS 4321 et seq.), because, given certain national security provisions of the Atomic Energy Act (42 USCS 2011 et seq.) and the Navy's own regulations concerning nuclear weapons, the Navy had complied with the Act "to the fullest extent possible" (468 F Supp 190). The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit reversed, holding that 102(2)(C) of the Environmental Policy Act requires the Navy to prepare and release to the public a "Hypothetical Environmental Impact Statement" with regard to the operation of a facility capable of storing nuclear weapons (643 F2d 569).

After the owner of a poultry packaging and processing plant in Maine closed the plant and laid off most of its employees, the Maine Director of the Bureau of Labor Standards commenced an action in a Maine Superior Court to enforce the provisions of a state statute requiring certain employers, in the event of a plant closing, to provide a one-time severance payment to employees not covered by an express contract providing for severance pay. The Superior Court granted the Director's motion for summary judgment, holding that the plant owner was liable for severance pay under the statute. The Supreme Judicial Court of Maine affirmed, holding that (1) the statute was not pre-empted by the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (29 USCS 1001 et seq.) (ERISA), because ERISA pre-empted only benefit plans created by employers or employee organizations, while the severance pay liability in the present case resulted from the operation of the state statute, and (2) the statute was not pre-empted by the National Labor Relations Act (29 USCS 157 et seq.) (NLRA), because the state statute applied equally to union and nonunion employees and reflected the state's substantial interest in protecting Maine citizens from the economic dislocation that accompanies large-scale plant closings (510 A2d 1054).

Petitioners, two national labor organizations, brought an action in the District Court under Judicial Code _ 274d against members of the First and Fourth Divisions of the National Railroad Adjustment Board, seeking a declaratory judgment to the effect that the First Division has jurisdiction under the Railway Labor Act of disputes involving yardmasters. Another national labor organization and two railroad companies were allowed to intervene.

An individual (1) was indicted by an Ohio grand jury on charges of aggravated murder and aggravated robbery, (2) pleaded guilty, and (3) was sentenced to life imprisonment, with parole possible after 30 years. On direct appeal, the individual challenged only the length of the minimum sentence, without success. After unsuccessfully pursuing state postconviction relief, the individual petitioned the Ohio Court of Appeals to reopen his direct appeal on the asserted ground that his original appellate counsel had been constitutionally ineffective in failing to challenge the sufficiency of the evidence. However, the Court of Appeals dismissed the application on the ground that the individual had not shown good cause for failing to file such a petition within the 90-day period established by a state appellate rule. The Supreme Court of Ohio affirmed. The individual thereafter filed a petition for a writ of habeas corpus in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Ohio, which petition alleged in part that (1) the evidence supporting his plea and sentence was insufficient in violation of the Federal Constitution's Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments, and (2) his former counsel had been constitutionally ineffective in failing to raise that claim on direct appeal. The District Court (1) determined that--while the sufficiency claim had been procedurally defaulted--the ineffective-assistance-of-counsel claim (a) could excuse that default, and (b) was not itself barred from review, because the state appellate rule had not been consistently applied by state courts; and (2) granted the petition, conditioned on the state courts reopening direct appeal of the sufficiency claim. On cross-appeals, the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit (1) expressed the view that the ineffective-assistance-of-counsel claim could serve as cause to excuse the procedural default of the sufficiency claim, regardless of whether the ineffective-assistance-of-counsel claim had been procedurally defaulted; and (2) ordered that the writ be issued, conditioned on the state courts granting the individual a new culpability hearing (163 F.3d 938).

A criminal defendant convicted of murder in a Michigan trial court appealed his conviction to the Michigan Court of Appeals on the ground that the trial court's instruction to the jury on implying malice was erroneous under a previous state court decision which held under state law that malice should not be implied from the fact that a weapon was used. The Michigan Court of Appeals affirmed his conviction, and the Michigan Supreme Court, on review of the record, denied the defendant's request for relief. The defendant then filed a petition for a writ of habeas corpus pursuant to 28 USCS 2254 in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan, alleging that the state trial court's instruction on malice was unconstitutional. The District Court held that the instruction violated his due process rights by unconstitutionally shifting the burden of proof as to malice to the defendant, being inconsistent with the presumption of innocence, and that the defendant had exhausted available state court remedies, as required by 28 USCS 2254(b) and (c), since his conviction had been reviewed by both the Michigan Court of Appeals and the Michigan Supreme Court (504 F Supp 1135). The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit affirmed, holding that the defendant's claim had been properly exhausted in the state courts, because the defendant had presented to the Michigan Court of Appeals the facts on which he based his federal claim, and the defendant's reliance on the previous state court decision was sufficient to present the state court with the substance of his due process challenge to the malice instruction being asserted in the habeas corpus proceedings (664 F2d 610).

During the early morning hours of New Year‚Äôs Eve, 2008, police sergeant Jeffrey Cotton fired three bullets at Robert Tolan; one of those bullets hit its target and punctured Tolan‚Äôs right lung. At the time of the shooting, Tolan was unarmed on his parents‚Äô front porch about 15 to 20 feet away from Cotton. Tolan sued, alleging that Cotton had exercised excessive force in violation of the Fourth Amendment. The District Court granted summary judgment to Cotton, and the Fifth Circuit affirmed, reasoning that regardless of whether Cotton used excessive force, he was entitled to qualified immunity because he did not violate any clearly established right. 713 F. 3d 299 (2013). In articulating the factual context of the case, the Fifth Circuit failed to adhere to the axiom that in ruling on a motion for summary judgment, ‚Äú[t]he evidence of the nonmovant is to be believed, and all justifiable inferences are to be drawn in his favor.‚Äù Anderson v. Liberty Lobby, Inc., 477 U. S. 242, 255 (1986). For that reason, we vacate its decision and remand the case for further proceedings consistent with this opinion

The Medicaid Act (42 USCS 1396-1396s) establishes a program through which the Federal Government provides financial assistance to states for the provision of medical care to needy individuals. To participate in the program, a state must submit for the approval of the United States Secretary of Health and Human Services a comprehensive plan that contains a scheme for reimbursing health care providers for medical services provided to medicaid patients. Under 42 USCS 1396a(a)(13)(A), also known as the Boren amendment, a reimbursement scheme must provide for reimbursement through the use of rates "which the State finds, and makes assurances satisfactory to the Secretary [of Health and Human Services], are reasonable and adequate to meet the costs which must be incurred by efficiently and economically operated facilities." The state of Virginia's medicaid plan was approved by the Secretary in 1982 and again in 1986 after an amendment was made. In 1986, an association of hospitals operating in Virginia filed suit under 42 USCS 1983 in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia against several state officials. The association alleged that Virginia's medicaid plan violated the Medicaid Act because the reimbursement rates for health care providers were not reasonable and adequate to meet the economically and efficiently incurred costs of providing care to medicaid patients in hospitals, and did not assure access to inpatient care. The association sought declaratory and injunctive relief, including an order requiring the promulgation of a new state medicaid plan with new reimbursement rates and, in the interim, the reimbursement of medicaid providers at rates commensurate with payments under the medicare program. The governor and other defendants filed a motion to dismiss, or in the alternative a motion for summary judgment, on the ground that 1983 did not afford a cause of action to challenge the state's compliance with the Medicaid Act. The District Court denied the motion, and the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit affirmed, concluding that health care providers may sue state officials under 1983 for declaratory and injunctive relief to insure compliance with the Medicaid Act (868 F2d 653).

Orders of the California Public Utilities Commission allocating to certain railroads 50 per cent of the costs of railroad grade separation improvements were challenged by the railroads as violating the Federal Constitution because the allocation was not based upon the benefits accruing to railroad property as result of the improvements, and thus amounted to a taking of property without due process of law. In addition, the orders were alleged to place an unconstitutional burden upon interstate commerce.

Under the Fair Labor Standards Act (29 USC 201 et seq.) workers in a battery plant must be paid as a part of their "principal" activities for the time incident to changing clothes at the beginning of the shift and showering at the end, where they must make extensive use of dangerously caustic and toxic materials, and are compelled by circumstances, including vital considerations of health and hygiene, to change clothes and to shower in facilities which state law requires their employer to provide; these activities are not "preliminary" or "postliminary" activities within the meaning of 4(a)(2) of the Portal-to-Portal Act (29 USC 254(a)(2)), providing that the employer's liability under the Fair Labor Standards Act does not extend to "activities which are preliminary to or postliminary to" an employee's "principal activity or activities."

Several years after a decision upholding the Federal Power Commission's refusal to assert jurisdiction over natural gas sales under certain contracts, the Commission asserted jurisdiction over natural gas sales under new contracts between the same parties, where the gas sold under the new contracts was commingled with gas destined for out-of-state resale. (30 FPC 200.) The United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit reversed on the grounds that the sales were beyond the Commission's jurisdiction and the parties were collaterally estopped by the previous decision from relitigating the question. (334 F2d 404.)

In an action brought by the widows of passengers killed in the crash, outside of Louisiana's territorial waters, of a helicopter used in connection with oil drilling operations, the United States District Court for the Western District of Louisiana accepted admiralty jurisdiction, found that the deaths were caused by the negligence of the operating company, and awarded damages equal to the pecuniary loss suffered by the two families. The District Court held, however, that the law did not authorize recovery for the two families' loss of society (360 F Supp 1140). On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit reversed, holding that the families were entitled to claim damages for loss of society (545 F2d 422).

A jury convicted one charged with first degree murder, but recommended life imprisonment, acting pursuant to a statute making, where life imprisonment has been recommended by the jury, the imposition of the death penalty discretionary with the judge. The judge, however, imposed the death sentence by reason of additional information obtained by him concerning the background and character of the convicted person, which could not have been brought to the attention of the jury, and which he narrated in imposing sentence. The accuracy of the judge's statements were not challenged by the convicted person or his counsel, nor was the judge asked to disregard or to afford a chance to refute or discredit any of them.

The issue presented is whether the districting plan adopted by the State of Alabama for its 2022 congressional elections likely violated ¬ß2 of the Voting Rights Act, 52 U. S. C. ¬ß10301. As originally enacted in 1965, ¬ß2 of the Act tracked the language of the Fifteenth Amendment, providing that ‚Äú[t]he right of citizens of the United States to vote shall not be denied or abridged . . . on account of race, color, or previous condition of servitude.‚Äù In City of Mobile v. Bolden, 446 U. S. 55, this Court held that the Fifteenth Amendment‚Äîand thus ¬ß2‚Äîprohibits States from acting with a ‚Äúracially discriminatory motivation‚Äù or an ‚Äúinvidious purpose‚Äù to discriminate, but it does not prohibit laws that are discriminatory only in effect. Id., at 61‚Äì65 (plurality opinion). Criticism followed, with many viewing Mobile‚Äôs intent test as not sufficiently protective of voting rights. But others believed that adoption of an effects test would inevitably require a focus on proportionality, calling voting laws into question whenever a minority group won fewer seats in the legislature than its share of the population. Congress ultimately resolved this debate in 1982, reaching a bipartisan compromise that amended ¬ß2 to incorporate both an effects test and a robust disclaimer that ‚Äúnothing‚Äù in ¬ß2 ‚Äúestablishes a right to have members of a protected class elected in numbers equal to their proportion in the population.‚Äù ¬ß10301(b). In 1992, ¬ß2 litigation challenging the State of Alabama‚Äôs then-existing districting map resulted in the State‚Äôs first majority-black district and, subsequently, the State‚Äôs first black Representative since 1877. Alabama‚Äôs congressional map has remained remarkably similar since that litigation. Following the 2020 decennial census, a group of plaintiffs led by Alabama legislator Bobby Singleton sued the State, arguing that the State‚Äôs population growth rendered the existing congressional map malapportioned and racially gerrymandered in violation of the Equal Protection Clause. While litigation was proceeding, the Alabama Legislature‚Äôs Committee on Reapportionment drew a new districting map that would reflect the distribution of the prior decade‚Äôs population growth across the State. The resulting map largely resembled the 2011 map on which it was based and similarly produced only one district in which black voters constituted a majority. That new map was signed into law as HB1. Three groups of Alabama citizens brought suit seeking to stop Alabama‚Äôs Secretary of State from conducting congressional elections under HB1. One group (Caster plaintiffs) challenged HB1 as invalid under ¬ß2. Another group (Milligan plaintiffs) brought claims under ¬ß2 and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment. And a third group (the Singleton plaintiffs) amended the complaint in their ongoing litigation to challenge HB1 as a racial gerrymander under the Equal Protection Clause. A three-judge District Court was convened, and the Singleton and Milligan actions were consolidated before that District Court for purposes of preliminary injunction proceedings, while Caster proceeded before one of the judges on a parallel track. After an extensive hearing, the District Court concluded in a 227-page opinion that the question whether HB1 likely violated ¬ß2 was not ‚Äúclose.‚Äù The Court preliminarily enjoined Alabama from using HB1 in forthcoming elections. The same relief was ordered in Caster.

An Indian tribe filed a suit in the United States District Court for the District of Montana challenging the application of several Montana taxes to the tribe's royalty interests in oil and gas produced under leases granted to non-Indian lessees in accordance with the Indian Mineral Leasing Act of 1938 (25 USCS 396a et seq.). The District Court granted the state's motion for summary judgment, holding that the state taxes were authorized by the Act of May 29, 1924, ch 210, 43 Stat. 244, and that the 1938 Act did not repeal this authorization. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, on rehearing en banc, reversed in part and remanded (729 F2d 1192).

Upon learning that the Republic of Nigeria was interested in contracting for a construction project on an air force base in Nigeria, the chief executive officer (CEO) of a New Jersey corporation made arrangements for a Nigerian citizen to endeavor to secure the contract for the corporation. It was agreed that if the corporation secured the contract, the corporation would funnel a percentage of the contract price as a bribe to officials of the Nigerian government though the payment of a "commission" to Panamanian entities which the Nigerian citizen controlled. Both the payment and the receipt of bribes in connection with the award of a government contract were prohibited by Nigerian law. The corporation was awarded the contract, and the bribes were paid. A Pennsylvania corporation, which had been an unsuccessful bidder for the contract, learned of the "commission" and brought the matter to the attention of American and Nigerian officials. The New Jersey corporation and its CEO were eventually charged with violations of a federal corrupt practices statute, and both pleaded guilty. The Pennsylvania corporation subsequently brought an action in the United States District Court for the District of New Jersey against the New Jersey corporation, its CEO, the Nigerian citizen, and others, in which action the Pennsylvania corporation sought damages under various federal and state statutes. The defendants moved to dismiss the complaint, on the ground that the action was barred by the act of state doctrine. In response to the District Court's request, the United States Department of State submitted to the court a letter in which the State Department's legal advisor addressed the question of the applicability of the act of state doctrine to the Pennsylvania corporation's action. The District Court, treating the defendants' motion to dismiss the action as a motion for summary judgment and granting the motion, concluded that the act of state doctrine was applicable if the inquiry presented for judicial determination included the motivation of a sovereign act which would result in embarrassment to the sovereign or constitute interference in the conduct of foreign policy of the United States (659 F Supp 1381). On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, reversing, ruled that the defendants had not met their burden of showing that the case should not go forward, in light of the view expressed by the State Department in its letter to the District Court that the interests of the executive branch of the Federal Government would not be harmed by prosecution of the action (847 F2d 1052).

Immigrant migrant farmworkers instituted an action against certain farm labor contractors in a California Superior Court, alleging that the defendants had refused continued employment to the plaintiffs because of a surplus of labor resulting from the defendants' violation of a California statute which provides that no employer shall knowingly employ an alien who is not entitled to lawful residence in the country if such employment would have an adverse effect on lawful resident workers. The Superior Court dismissed the complaint, holding that the statute was unconstitutional as encroaching upon the comprehensive scheme of the Immigration and Nationality Act (8 USCS 1101 et seq.), enacted by Congress in the exercise of its exclusive power over immigration. The Court of Appeals of California, Second Appellate District, affirmed (40 Cal App 3d 976, 115 Cal Rptr 444).

Corporate stockholders brought a derivative suit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, contending, inter alia, that the defendant directors had converted assets of the corporation and that the defendant brokers had extracted excessive fees from the corporation. The stockholders requested that the defendants "account for and pay to the Corporation for their profits and gains and its losses." The stockholders also demanded a jury trial on the corporation's claims. The District Court denied the defendants' motion to strike the jury trial demand (275 F Supp 569), but the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit reversed, holding that a derivative action was entirely equitable in nature and that no jury was available to try any part of it (403 F2d 909).

After a trial had commenced in a Tennessee court on an indictment charging the defendant and his codefendant with armed robbery by the use of a "pistol," the trial court granted, over the defendants' objection, the state's motion for a directed verdict of acquittal on the ground that the indictment erroneously specified the use of a pistol, whereas, in fact, a rifle had been used. Thereafter the defendants were tried and convicted upon trial in the Criminal Court, Montgomery County, Tennessee, on a new indictment based on the same robbery but specifying the use of a "rifle," the trial court overruling a plea of double jeopardy. The Tennessee Court of Criminal Appeals sustained the double jeopardy plea on appeal, but the Supreme Court of Tennessee reversed, holding that the reindictment and retrial of the defendants were not barred on double jeopardy grounds (224 Tenn 712, 462 SW2d 491).

The defendants were convicted by a jury in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York of conspiring to import and conceal heroin in violation of the federal narcotics laws. An important part of the government's evidence consisted of tape recordings of conversations among several of the defendants in a hotel room, the tapes being made by federal officers in the adjoining room by means of an electronic recording device which did not physically intrude into the defendants' room. Because there was no "trespass" or "actual intrusion into a constitutionally protected area," the District Court and the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit rejected the defendants' argument that this evidence was inadmissible because the eavesdropping had violated their rights under the Fourth Amendment, and the Court of Appeals affirmed the conviction. (384 F2d 889.)

In a contested case, the Mayor of Monroeville, Ohio, convicted an accused of two traffic offenses and fined him $ 50 for each offense, acting pursuant to Ohio statutory provisions authorizing mayors to sit as judges in cases of ordinance violations and certain traffic offenses. The conviction was sustained by the Ohio Court of Appeals for Huron County (21 Ohio App 2d 17, 50 Ohio Ops 2d 16, 254 NE2d 375) and by the Ohio Supreme Court (27 Ohio St 2d 179, 56 Ohio Ops 2d 110, 271 NE2d 757).

Under the Older Workers Benefit Protection Act (OWBPA) (29 USCS 626(f)), (1) an individual may not waive any right or claim under the Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA) (29 USCS 621 et seq.) unless the waiver is knowing and voluntary, and (2) a waiver may not be considered knowing and voluntary without satisfying various enumerated minimum requirements. A Louisiana power plant employee, pursuant to a termination agreement, signed a release of all claims against her employer. In consideration for the release, the employee received severance pay in installments. The release did not comply with the requirements for a release under the OWBPA in at least three respects, in that (1) the employer did not give the employee enough time to consider her options, (2) the employer did not give the employee 7 days after she signed the release to change her mind, and (3) the release made no specific reference to claims under the ADEA. The employee filed an age discrimination charge with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, which dismissed the charge on the merits but issued a right-to-sue letter. The employee, alleging constructive discharge on the basis of her age in violation of the ADEA and state law, filed suit against the employer in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana. The employer moved for summary judgment on the ground that the employee had ratified the defective release by failing to return or offer to return the monies that she had received. The District Court, agreeing, entered summary judgment for the employer (20 EBC 2772, 73 BNA FEP Cas 984). The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit affirmed (112 F3d 787, 1996 US App LEXIS 41288, 1996 US App LEXIS 41679).

Petitioner attorneys represented respondent Minton in a federal patent infringement suit. The District Court declared Minton's patent invalid under the "on sale" bar since he had leased his interactive securities trading system to a securities brokerage "more than one year prior to the date of the [patent] application." 35 U. S. C. ¬ß102(b). In a motion for reconsideration, Minton argued for the first time that the lease was part of ongoing testing, and therefore fell within the "experimental use" exception to the on-sale bar. The District Court denied the motion and the Federal Circuit affirmed, concluding that the District Court had appropriately held that argument waived. Convinced that his attorneys' failure to timely raise the argument cost him the lawsuit and led to the invalidation of his patent, Minton brought a legal malpractice action in Texas state court. His former attorneys argued that Minton's infringement claims would have failed even if the experimental-use argument had been timely raised, and the trial court agreed. On appeal, Minton claimed that the federal district courts had exclusive jurisdiction over claims like his under 28 U. S. C. ¬ß1338(a), which provides for exclusive federal jurisdiction over any case "arising under any Act of Congress relating to patents." Minton argued that the state trial court had therefore lacked jurisdiction, and he should be able to start over with his malpractice suit in federal court. Applying the test of Grable & Sons Metal Products, Inc. v. Darue Engineering & Mfg., 545 U. S. 308, the Texas Court of Appeals rejected Minton's argument, proceeded to the merits, and determined that Minton had failed to establish experimental use. The Texas Supreme Court reversed, concluding that the case properly belonged in federal court because the success of Minton's malpractice claim relied upon a question of federal patent law.
The judgment is reversed. Russell v. United States, 369 U.S. 749.

The plaintiff, a court clerk, brought the present action in the West Virginia Circuit Court, Wyoming County, alleging that during his re-election campaign he was libeled by editorials, critical of his official conduct, which appeared in defendant's newspaper. The jury returned a verdict for plaintiff and the West Virginia Supreme Court of Appeals denied defendant's application for appellate review.

An action for wrongful death occurring in Utah was brought under the Utah wrongful death statute in a federal court in Illinois, where jurisdiction was based on diversity of citizenship. The court dismissed the action in reliance upon an Illinois statute which provided that no action should be brought in that state for death occurring outside Illinois, if service of process may be had in the state in which death occurred. The case of Hughes v. Fetter, 341 US 609, 95 L ed 1212, 71 S Ct 980, in which a like Wisconsin statute was held to violate the full faith and credit clause, was distinguished by the court on the ground that the latter statute operated as an absolute bar to an action based on a wrongful death statute of a sister state, while the Illinois statute excluded only actions which could be effectively litigated in the state in which they arose.

The United States brought, in the United States District Court for the Western District of Washington, the instant civil antitrust action to challenge a proposed merger between two commercial banks. The acquiring bank is a large, nationally chartered bank with its principal office in Seattle, Washington, and the acquired or target bank is a medium-sized, state- chartered bank with headquarters in Spokane at the opposite end of the state. The United States based its case exclusively on the potential competition doctrine under 7 of the Clayton Act (15 USCS 18), which prohibits corporate mergers the effect of which "may be substantially to lessen competition." The United States contended that if the merger is prohibited, the acquiring bank will find an alternate and more competitive means for entering the Spokane area and that the acquired bank will ultimately develop by internal expansion or mergers with smaller banks into an actual competitor of the acquiring bank and other large banks in sections of the state outside Spokane. The government further submitted that the merger will terminate the alleged procompetitive influence that the acquiring bank presently exerts over Spokane banks due to the potential for its entry into that market. The District Court rendered judgment against the government (1973-1 Trade Cases 74,496).

A retired county sheriff's department employee filed a complaint with the EEOC, claiming that he received a lower pension because he became disabled after, instead of before, age 55, when he became eligible for retirement. Under Kentucky's special retirement plan for workers in hazardous positions, if the employee had become disabled before becoming eligible for retirement, additional years of service would have been imputed to him under Ky. Rev. Stat. Ann. _ 16.582(5)(a) (2003) for purposes of calculating his pension; instead, the employee's pension was based only on his actual years of service. The Supreme Court held that the difference in treatment of workers in light of their pension status was not "actually motivated" by age and did not violate the ADEA. It was permissible under 29 U.S.C.S. _ 623(l)(1)(A)(i) to condition pension eligibility upon age. Pension status was analytically distinct from age and did not serve as a proxy for age in the Kentucky retirement plan. The plan sought to treat disabled workers as if they had worked until the point at which they would have been eligible for a normal pension; the disparity in treatment turned only upon pension eligibility.

In proceedings instituted by an insurance company in the District Court of Edwards County, Kansas, for the foreclosure of a mortgage held by the company on certain Kansas real estate, the company joined the United States in its capacity as junior mortgagee. At the foreclosure sale, the insurance company bought in the property for the amount of its own judgment. Thereafter the United States instituted proceedings to redeem the property pursuant to 28 USC 2410(c), providing that when the United States is joined in a foreclosure proceeding under 2410 and a sale is held to satisfy a lien prior to that of the United States, "the United States shall have one year from the date of sale within which to redeem." The District Court denied relief and the Supreme Court of Kansas affirmed (185 Kan 274, 341 P2d 1002), holding that the United States' action was barred by the provisions of state law granting the mortgagor the exclusive right to redeem his property during a period of 12 months following the date of a foreclosure sale.

A Mississippi franchise tax measured by the value of capital used, invested or employed within the state was held by five members of the Court, without concurrence on the grounds of decision, not unconstitutionally to burden interstate commerce in the case of an interstate natural gas pipeline company a portion of whose line passed through the state but which did no local business therein.

With respect to some provisions of the Federal Power Act, as amended (FPA) (16 USCS 824 et seq.), 16 USCS 824(b) provided that the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) had jurisdiction over "the transmission of electric energy in interstate commerce" and "the sale of electric energy at wholesale in interstate commerce." However, 824(b) also provided that FERC had no jurisdiction over facilities used for the generation of electric energy, over facilities used in local distribution or only for the transmission of electric energy in intrastate commerce, or over facilities for the transmission of electric energy consumed wholly by the transmitter. Moreover, 16 USCS 824(a) generally provided that federal regulation was to extend to only those matters which were not subject to regulation by the states.

Under 514(a) of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) (29 USCS 1144(a)), state laws that relate to employee benefit plans are pre-empted by ERISA. A California statute, which required contractors who were awarded public works contracts to pay their workers not less than the prevailing wage rate for similar work in the locality in which the public work was performed, allowed public works contractors to pay to an apprentice trained in an apprenticeship program approved under the National Apprenticeship Act, as amended (29 USCS 50), an apprentice wage rate that was less than the prevailing journeyman wage rate. A subcontractor working at a county facility (1) hired apprentices through an unapproved joint apprenticeship training committee program that had been created pursuant to a collective bargaining agreement, and (2) paid the apprentices the apprentice wage rate provided in the bargaining agreement. After a state agency ordered the county to withhold certain moneys from the general contractor because of the subcontractor's failure to pay the prevailing journeyman rate to the apprentices from the unapproved program, the contractors, arguing that with respect to the training program the state's prevailing wage statute was pre-empted under 514(a), filed suit to prevent interference with payment under the subcontract. The United States District Court for the Northern District of California, expressing the view that pre-emption was forestalled by ERISA's saving clause, 514(d) (29 USCS 1144(d)), entered summary judgment against the contractors (778 F. Supp 1522). The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit--expressing the view that the training program was (1) an employee benefit program to which the prevailing wage statute related, and (2) not preserved by 514(d)--reversed the District Court judgment (57 F.3d 712).

Petitioner Wright, a longshoreman, was subject to a collective-bargaining agreement (CBA) and a Longshore Seniority Plan, both of which contained an arbitration clause. When respondents refused to employ him following his settlement of a claim for permanent disability benefits for job-related injuries, Wright filed this suit, alleging discrimination in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA). The District Court dismissed the case without prejudice because Wright had failed to pursue the arbitration procedure provided by the CBA. The Fourth Circuit affirmed.

he case at hand involved the promulgation by the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA), an agency within the Department of Transportation, of certain application and safety-monitoring regulations that would allow some cross-border operations by Mexican-domiciled motor carriers to occur, where (1) even though 49 USCS _ 13902(a)(1) generally mandated that the FMCSA register any qualified motor carrier, a moratorium on new FMCSA grants of operating authority for Mexican-domiciled  [***61]  motor carriers initially had been imposed, and later had been extended, pursuant to 49 USCS _ 10922(l); (2) subsequently, the President of the United States, in asserted fulfillment of the North American Free Trade Agreement (32 ILM 605), had expressed an intention to lift the moratorium; and (3) in May 2001, the FMCSA had initially published for comment the proposed regulations in question. Congress then enacted _ 350 of the Department of Transportation and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2002 (note following 49 USCS _ 13902), which provided (in conditions later extended to appropriations for fiscal years 2003 and 2004) that no funds appropriated under the 2002 Act could be obligated or expended to review or to process any application by a Mexican-domiciled motor carrier for authority to operate in the interior of the United States until the FMCSA implemented specific application and safety-monitoring requirements for such carriers. In January 2002, the FMCSA issued a FONSI, which--on the basis of an Environmental Assessment released the same day--concluded that no EIS was needed concerning the proposed regulations. In March 2002, the FMCSA (1) issued the application and safety-monitoring regulations as interim rules with a delayed effective date; and (2) in some accompanying materials, said that a full CAA conformity review was not required. The FMCSA, in its analysis under both NEPA and the CAA, did not consider any emissions attributable to the increased presence of Mexican-domiciled motor carriers within the United States. In November 2002, the President lifted the moratorium on qualified Mexican-domiciled motor carriers.

An individual was convicted of murder in Superior Court, Bleckley County, Georgia, and a sentencing jury imposed the death penalty after finding three aggravating circumstances set forth in the Georgia death penalty statute. On direct appeal, the Supreme Court of Georgia affirmed, setting aside the second statutory aggravating circumstance found by the jury, but upholding the death sentence on the ground that in the case under review the evidence supported the jury's findings of the other statutory aggravating circumstances, so that the death sentence was not impaired (237 Ga 259, 227 SE2d 261). After exhausting his state post-conviction remedies, the prisoner applied for a writ of habeas corpus in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Georgia. The District Court denied relief, but the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit reversed the District Court's denial of habeas corpus relief insofar as it left standing the prisoner's death sentence and remanded for further proceedings (631 F2d 397, mod 648 F2d 446). On certiorari, the United States Supreme Court certified to the Supreme Court of Georgia the question what were the premises of state law that supported the conclusion that the death sentence in the case was not impaired by the invalidity of one of the statutory aggravating circumstances found by the jury (456 US 410, 72 L Ed 2d 222, 102 S Ct 1856). The Supreme Court of Georgia, in response to the certified question, explained the state law premises for its treatment of aggravating circumstances and then why the failure of the second aggravating circumstance did not invalidate the prisoner's death sentence (250 Ga 97, 297 SE2d 1).

Under 28 USC 2253, which requires, as a prerequisite of an appeal from a final order in a habeas corpus proceeding instituted by a state prisoner, that "the justice or judge who rendered the order or a circuit justice or judge" issue a certificate of probable cause, a Court of Appeals has jurisdiction to entertain an application for such a certificate, addressed to that court instead of to a judge or judges thereof.

Asparagus growers and an association of asparagus processors in Michigan sued a producers' association which had been accredited under the Michigan Agricultural Marketing and Bargaining Act as the sole sales and bargaining representative for Michigan asparagus producers, seeking a declaratory judgment that those provisions of the Michigan Act requiring that commodity producers pay a service fee to any association accredited as the exclusive bargaining agent for all producers of that particular commodity, and abide by the terms of the contracts which the association negotiated with processors, regardless of whether they chose to become members of the association, were pre-empted by the Federal Agricultural Fair Practices Act of 1967 (7 USCS 2301 et seq.). The Michigan Supreme Court held that the Michigan Act was constitutional (416 Mich 706, 332 NW2d 134).

An organization of private individuals and the United States each filed suit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania to compel the state of Pennsylvania to implement a vehicle emission inspection and maintenance program (I/M program) as required by the Clean Air Act (42 USCS 7410). Pursuant to a consent decree, the state agreed to establish an I/M program for 10 counties in two metropolitan areas in the state. Under the decree, the state transportation department was required to seek legislation instituting a franchise I/M program, and if such legislation was not approved, the transportation department was to promulgate regulations allowing the state to certify a number of private garage facilities to perform the inspections. Implementation of the I/M program did not proceed smoothly, and the factual developments which followed the entry of the consent decree included the following: (1) after the transportation department published the proposed regulations, the state legislature having earlier failed to enact a franchise system, the organization continued to monitor the state's performance under the consent decree and submitted comments on the regulations; (2) after the state legislature enacted a statute prohibiting the expenditure of state funds by the executive branch for the implementation of the I/M program, the organization successfully opposed the state's motion to stay implementation of the consent decree, the Federal District Court ordering the United States Secretary of Transportation to refrain from approving any projects, or awarding any grants, for highways in the two areas covered by the consent decree, with certain exceptions (533 F Supp 869), and on appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit affirmed (678 F2d 460); and (3) the organization participated in hearings before the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) at which the state unsuccessfully sought the EPA's approval of an I/M program covering a smaller geographic area. The organization then sought attorneys' fees and costs for the work performed after the issuance of the consent decree. The Federal District Court awarded attorneys' fees and costs to the organization and, overruling the state's objections that the organization was seeking compensation for work done in only tangentially related state and federal administrative proceedings, held that the organization was entitled to such compensation for its work in monitoring the state's performance under the consent decree and commenting on the state's proposed regulations and for its participation in the hearings before the EPA; also, the District Court increased the "lodestar" amounts--the result of multiplying the number of hours reasonably necessary to perform the legal services for which compensation was sought by a reasonable hourly rate for the attorney providing the services (this rate being based on the court's determination of the attorney's reputation and status and the type of activity for which the attorney was seeking compensation)--with respect to the organization's work in opposing the state's motion to stay implementation of the consent decree, to reflect the low likelihood of success the organization faced in that stage of the litigation and the high quality of representation provided in that stage. The Court of Appeals affirmed and held that (1) the work of counsel in monitoring the state's performance under the consent decree, commenting on the state transportation department's regulations, and participating in the EPA hearings was useful and necessary for securing full enforcement of the decree; and (2) with respect to the adjustment of the lodestar amounts, the evidence showed that the success of counsel was exceptional, and that the quality of the service rendered was superior to that which one should reasonably expect in light of the hourly rates charged (762 F2d 272).

These two consolidated cases presented issues as to the validity of the state of Washington's business and occupation (B & O) tax on business activities within the state, including manufacturing and wholesale selling. In the first case (No. 85-2006), 71 commercial enterprises filed 53 separate actions in the Thurston County Superior Court for refunds of B & O taxes paid to the state. The enterprises challenged the state's "multiple activities" exemption, under which local manufacturers were exempted from the manufacturing tax for the portion of their output that was subject to the wholesale tax, in other words, for their in-state sales, but sales by local manufacturers to out-of-state purchasers remained subject to the manufacturing tax. The Superior Court joined the actions, found that the exemption did not violate the Federal Constitution's commerce clause (Art I, 8, cl 3), and granted the state taxation department's motion for summary judgment. The Supreme Court of Washington affirmed (105 Wash 2d 328, 715 P2d 128). In the second case (No. 85-1963), an out-of-state manufacturer sued in the Superior Court for a refund of B & O taxes paid for its wholesaling activities within Washington, on the grounds that its business did not have a sufficient nexus with Washington to justify the collection of the tax, and that the tax was not fairly apportioned to reflect the amount of business conducted in the state. This manufacturer had no office, property, or employees in Washington but solicited business in the state under the direction of out-of-state executives and an in-state independent contractor. The Superior Court denied the tax refund, holding that (1) the manufacturer had a sufficient nexus with the state, since the manufacturer's in-state sales representatives helped the manufacturer establish and maintain its market in the state, and (2) the tax was fairly apportioned. The Washington Supreme Court affirmed (105 Wash 2d 318, 715 P2d 123).

Appellants brought an action in the District Court for the District of Vermont challenging the constitutionality of various provisions of the customs laws and seeking other relief including damages. A three-judge court was convened, and it held that it had jurisdiction under the Tucker Act (28 USCS 1346(a)(2)), rejected appellants constitutional claims, enjoined appellees from applying the customs laws except as construed by the court, declined to remit appellants' fines and returned the question of damages to the single-judge District Court (370 F Supp 312).

In 1938, a 17-year-old Negro of limited education and mental capacity, after expressly disavowing a desire for counsel, pleaded guilty in the Circuit Court of Kalamazoo County, Michigan, to a charge of murder. He was sentenced to solitary confinement at hard labor for life. In 1950, he filed a delayed motion for a new trial in the Circuit Court, asserting constitutional invalidity of his conviction and sentence because he did not have the assistance of counsel at the time of his plea and sentence.

Medicaid is a cooperative federal-state program that provides medical care to needy individuals. To qualify for federal funds, a State must submit its Medicaid plan and any amendments to the federal agency that administers the program, the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS). Before approving a plan or amendments, CMS conducts a review to determine whether they comply with federal requirements. Federal law requires state plans or amendments to "assure that payments are consistent with efficiency, economy, and quality of care and are sufficient to enlist enough providers" to make Medicaid "care and services" available. 42 U. S. C. ¬ß1396a(a)(30)(A). After California enacted three statutes reducing the State's payments to various Medicaid providers, the State submitted plan amendments to CMS. Before the agency finished its review, Medicaid providers and beneficiaries sought, in a series of cases, to enjoin the rate reductions on the ground that they were pre-empted by federal Medicaid law. In seven decisions, the Ninth Circuit ultimately affirmed or ordered preliminary injunctions preventing the State from implementing its statutes. The court (1) held that the providers and beneficiaries could bring a Supremacy Clause action; (2) essentially accepted their claim that the State did not show that its amended plan would provide sufficient services; (3) held that the amendments thus conflicted with ¬ß1396a(a)(30)(A); and (4) held that the federal statute pre-empted the new state laws. In the meantime, agency officials disapproved the amendments, and California sought further administrative review. The cases were in this posture when the Court granted certiorari to decide whether respondents could mount a Supremacy Clause challenge. After oral argument, CMS approved several of the State's amendments, and the State withdrew its requests for approval of the remainder.

In 1971, the Internal Revenue Service assessed a deficiency against a company for failing to withhold federal income taxes in 1963 with respect to lunch expense reimbursements made to employees who were on company travel but not away overnight. Section 3401(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1954 (26 USCS 3401(a)) defines "wages" for purposes of withholding federal income tax as including all remuneration for services performed by an employee for his employer. The employer paid the deficiency and filed a claim for a refund. When no action was taken on the claim within six months, the employer instituted a suit to recover the amount paid in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Illinois, which held that the lunch expense reimbursements did not constitute wages subject to withholding (405 F Supp 748). The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit reversed (540 F2d 300).

In September 2017, the President issued Proclamation No. 9645, seeking to improve vetting procedures for foreign nationals traveling to the United States by identifying ongoing deficiencies in the information needed to assess whether nationals of particular countries present a security threat. The Proclamation placed entry restrictions on the nationals of eight foreign states whose systems for managing and sharing information about their nationals the President deemed inadequate. Foreign states were selected for inclusion based on a review undertaken pursuant to one of the President's earlier Executive Orders. As part of that review, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), in consultation with the State Department and intelligence agencies, developed an information and risk assessment ‚Äúbaseline.‚Äù DHS then collected and evaluated data for all foreign governments, identifying those having deficient information-sharing practices and presenting national security concerns, as well as other countries ‚Äúat risk‚Äù of failing to meet the baseline. After a 50‚Äìday period during which the State Department made diplomatic efforts to encourage foreign governments to improve their practices, the Acting Secretary of Homeland Security concluded that eight countries‚ÄîChad, Iran, Iraq, Libya, North Korea, Syria, Venezuela, and Yemen‚Äîremained deficient. She recommended entry restrictions for certain nationals from all of those countries but Iraq, which had a close cooperative relationship with the U.S. She also recommended including Somalia, which met the information-sharing component of the baseline standards but had other special risk factors, such as a significant terrorist presence. After consulting with multiple Cabinet members, the President adopted the recommendations and issued the Proclamation. Invoking his authority under 8 U.S.C. ¬ß¬ß 1182(f) and 1185(a), he determined that certain restrictions were necessary to ‚Äúprevent the entry of those foreign nationals about **2400 whom the United States Government lacks sufficient information‚Äù and ‚Äúelicit improved identity-management and information-sharing protocols and practices from foreign governments.‚Äù The Proclamation imposes a range of entry restrictions that vary based on the ‚Äúdistinct circumstances‚Äù in each of the eight countries. It exempts lawful permanent residents and provides *668 case-by-case waivers under certain circumstances. It also directs DHS to assess on a continuing basis whether the restrictions should be modified or continued, and to report to the President every 180 days. At the completion of the first such review period, the President determined that Chad had sufficiently improved its practices, and he accordingly lifted restrictions on its nationals.
Plaintiffs‚Äîthe State of Hawaii, three individuals with foreign relatives affected by the entry suspension, and the Muslim Association of Hawaii‚Äîargue that the Proclamation violates the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) and the Establishment Clause. The District Court granted a nationwide preliminary injunction barring enforcement of the restrictions. The Ninth Circuit affirmed, concluding that the Proclamation contravened two provisions of the INA: ¬ß 1182(f), which authorizes the President to ‚Äúsuspend the entry of all aliens or any class of aliens‚Äù whenever he ‚Äúfinds‚Äù that their entry ‚Äúwould be detrimental to the interests of the United States,‚Äù and ¬ß 1152(a)(1)(A), which provides that ‚Äúno person shall ... be discriminated against in the issuance of an immigrant visa because of the person's race, sex, nationality, place of birth, or place of residence.‚Äù The court did not reach the Establishment Clause claim.

A federal court imposing multiple prison sentences typically has discretion to run the sentences concurrently or consecutively. See 18 U. S. C. ¬ß3584. An exception exists in ¬ß924(c), which provides that ‚Äúno term of imprisonment imposed on a person under this subsection shall run concurrently with any other term of imprisonment.‚Äù ¬ß924(c)(1)(D)(ii). Here, the Court considers whether ¬ß924(c)‚Äôs bar on concurrent sentences extends to a sentence imposed under a different subsection, ¬ß924(j). Petitioner Efrain Lora was convicted of the federal crime of aiding and abetting a violation of ¬ß924(j)(1), which penalizes ‚Äúa person who, in the course of a violation of subsection (c), causes the death of a person through the use of a firearm,‚Äù where ‚Äúthe killing is a murder.‚Äù A violation of subsection (c) occurs when a person ‚Äúuses or carries a firearm‚Äù ‚Äúduring and in relation to any crime of violence or drug trafficking crime,‚Äù or ‚Äúpossesses a firearm‚Äù ‚Äúin furtherance of any such crime.‚Äù ¬ß924(c)(1)(A). Lora was also convicted of a second federal crime, conspiring to distribute drugs. At sentencing, the District Court concluded that it lacked discretion to run the sentences for Lora‚Äôs two convictions concurrently, because ¬ß924(c)(1)(D)(ii)‚Äôs bar on concurrent sentences governs ¬ß924(j) sentences. The District Court sentenced Lora to consecutive terms of imprisonment for the drug-distribution-conspiracy count and the ¬ß924(j) count. The Court of Appeals affirmed.

One charged in the Municipal Court for the District of Columbia with making checks with intent to defraud was found not guilty by reason of insanity, despite the fact that he maintained that he was mentally responsible when the alleged offenses were committed. He was thereafter confined in a mental hospital by authority of 24-301(d) of the District of Columbia Code, which provides that if any person tried for an offense is acquitted solely on the ground that he was insane at the time of its commission, the court shall order such person confined in a mental hospital. He instituted habeas corpus proceedings in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, which directed his release from custody unless civil commitment proceedings should be begun within 10 days of the court's order. The Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit reversed. (109 App DC 404, 288 F2d 388.)

A Jacksonville, Florida ordinance required that 10 percent of the amount spent on city contracts be set aside each fiscal year for "minority business enterprises" (MBEs), where (1) an MBE was defined as a business whose ownership was at least 51 percent minority or female, and (2) a "minority" was defined as a person who was black, Spanish-speaking, Oriental, Indian, Eskimo, Aleut, or handicapped. A local chapter of a construction contractors' association, most of whose members did not qualify as MBEs, brought against the city and its mayor an action, pursuant to 42 USCS 1983, in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief based on an allegation that many chapter members would have bid on designated set-aside contracts but for the restrictions imposed by the MBE ordinance in violation of the equal protection clause of the Federal Constitution's Fourteenth Amendment. The District Court entered a summary judgment for the association. On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit, holding that the association lacked standing to challenge the MBE ordinance, vacated the District Court judgment and remanded the case with instructions to dismiss the association's complaint without prejudice (951 F2d 1217). After the United States Supreme Court granted certiorari, the city repealed the MBE ordinance and replaced it with a new ordinance that reserved certain contracts for the exclusive competition of black- and female-owned businesses. Subsequently, the Supreme Court denied a motion by the city and the mayor to dismiss the case as moot (506 US 1031, 121 L Ed 2d 681, 113 S Ct 808).

The defendants were convicted, in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, for defrauding and conspiring to defraud a union pension fund, and their convictions were affirmed by the Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. (367 F2d 698.) In response to the defendants' petition requesting the United States Supreme Court to grant certiorari, the Solicitor General voluntarily informed the Supreme Court that FBI agents had, by trespass, installed electronic eavesdropping equipment in the office of a person who was not one of the defendants, that they had recorded a conversation between such person and one of the defendants, and that the contents of the recording were available to government attorneys involved in the prosecution. The Solicitor General also informed the court that the information obtained through this electronic eavesdropping was not introduced into evidence at trial, that it was never the basis of any investigative lead, and that it was in part already known, through such defendant's own statements, to government attorneys, and there was apparently no direct intrusion into attorney-client discussions.

Acting pursuant to 407(a) of the Social Security Act (42 USCS 607(a))--which delegates to the Secretary of Health, Education, and Welfare the power to prescribe standards for determining what constitutes "unemployment" for purposes of the right to benefits under the Aid to Families with Dependent Children-Unemployed Fathers (AFDC-UF) program--the Secretary promulgated a regulation authorizing states participating in the AFDC-UF program, within their discretion, to exclude from the definition of an unemployed father one "whose unemployment results from participation in a labor dispute or who is unemployed by reason of conduct or circumstances which result or would result in disqualification for unemployment compensation under the State's unemployment compensation law" ( 45 CFR 233.100(a)(1)(ii)). Thereafter, Maryland officials moved that the United States District Court for the District of Maryland dissolve its injunction that had been granted in an action to restrain enforcement of a rule of the Maryland Department of Employment and Social Services under which AFDC-UF benefits could be denied to families where the father was out of work for reasons disqualifying him for state unemployment insurance compensation. Denying the motion, the District Court held that the federal regulation was in conflict with 407(a) of the Social Security Act (379 F Supp 78). Subsequently, appeals were taken to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, where the case was consolidated with an appeal in a similar case in which the United States District Court for the District of Maryland had also held that the federal regulation was invalid insofar as it authorized a state to deny AFDC-UF benefits to fathers who had voluntarily quit their previous jobs (384 F Supp 1274). The Court of Appeals affirmed in an unpublished decision adopting the respective District Court opinions (see 529 F2d 514, 515).

An armed robbery in Ohio left a victim dead and the victim's husband wounded. An accused admitted to participating in the robbery and to shooting the husband, but denied shooting the victim. The accused agreed to plead guilty to aggravated murder and attempted aggravated murder, and the state dropped other charges against him. With respect to the aggravated murder charge, the accused pleaded guilty to one of three capital specifications and was thus eligible for the death penalty. In an Ohio Court of Common Pleas, a contested penalty hearing was held in which the accused's principal mitigation argument was that (1) he had participated in the plot only at the urging and under the influence of an alleged accomplice, and (2) the accomplice had fired the fatal shots at the victim. Nevertheless, the court sentenced the accused to death. Subsequently, the accomplice was tried in the same court. Although the prosecutor claimed that the accomplice was the principal offender in the murder, the accomplice argued that the same prosecutor had taken a contrary position in the accused's case. A jury sentenced the accomplice to life imprisonment.

A railroad employee brought an action in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia for injuries sustained in the derailment of a four-wheel motor track car carrying maintenance workers and towing a four-wheel hand push truck. The first cause of action was based on negligence of the defendant railroad, and a second cause of action alleged that the plaintiff's injuries were proximately caused by defendant's violations of the Safety Appliance Acts, specifically, in that the motor car was not equipped with a power driving-wheel brake and the push truck was not equipped with any brakes. The District Court rendered judgment for the plaintiff. The defendant appealed as to the second cause of action concerning the applicability of the Safety Appliance Acts.

Subchapter S of the Internal Revenue Code (26 USCS 1361-1379) allows small corporations to attribute corporate income, losses, deductions, and credits to individual shareholders by means of a pass-through system. On February 1, 1980, a Subchapter S corporation filed, for the tax year of December 26, 1978 to November 30, 1979, a federal income tax return on which the corporation reported a loss deduction and an investment tax credit. On April 15, 1980, a shareholder in the corporation filed, for 1979, a federal income tax return on which the shareholder, pursuant to Subchapter S, claimed a pro rata share of the deduction and credit reported by the corporation. The generally applicable limitations period established by 6501(a) of the Code (26 USCS 6501(a))--providing that the Internal Revenue Service may assess tax deficiencies within 3 years from the date the return is filed--may be extended under 6501(c)(4) of the Code (26 USCS 6501(c)(4)). No extension was obtained with respect to the corporate return, but in March 1983, the shareholder agreed to an extension with respect to his return. In 1987, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue determined that the loss deduction and credit reported by the corporation were erroneous and sent a notice of deficiency to the shareholder based on the pro rata loss deduction and credit he had claimed on his return. Rejecting the shareholder's contention that the Commissioner's claim was time barred because the disallowance was based on an error in the corporation's return, for which the 3-year assessment period had lapsed, the United States Tax Court found for the Commissioner. The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit (1) held that, where a tax deficiency is assessed against a shareholder in a Subchapter S corporation, the filing date of the shareholder's return is the relevant date for purposes of 6501(a), and (2) affirmed the Tax Court judgment (952 F2d 675).

The United States District Court for the Northern District of California dismissed, for failure to state a claim warranting relief, a complaint by 16 individuals seeking intervention on their own behalf and on behalf of all persons similarly situated in a pending employment discrimination action, which was in the process of settlement by the original parties. The District Court had not certified a class at the time of the dismissal. A notice of appeal of the dismissal was filed in the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, but, due to a clerical error by a secretary employed by an attorney, omitted one individual's name. The Court of Appeals reversed and remanded the case to the District Court for further proceedings, in an order which also omitted the individual's name. On remand, the opposing party moved for partial summary judgment against the individual whose name had been omitted, on the ground that the District Court's prior judgment of dismissal was final as to the individual by virtue of his failure to appeal. The District Court granted the motion, but left open the question whether the individual could participate in the litigation as a member of a class, should a class be properly certified, and the Court of Appeals affirmed, holding that unless a party is named in the notice of appeal, a federal appellate court does not have jurisdiction over him, pursuant to Rule 3(c) of the Federal Rules of Appellate Procedure (807 F2d 178).

An Administrative Law Judge of the United States Department of Labor rejected the contention of a widow of an employee in the District of Columbia that her death benefits under the District of Columbia Workmen's Compensation Act should include employer contributions to union trust funds for health and welfare, pensions, and training as part of the weekly wage upon which benefits are calculated. The District of Columbia Act incorporates the provisions of the Longshoremen's and Harbor Workers' Compensation Act (33 USCS 901 et seq.) which defines "wages," under 2(13) (33 USCS 902(13)). The Benefits Review Board of the United States Department of Labor affirmed, reasoning that only values that are readily identifiable and calculable may be included in the determination of wages. The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit reversed, holding that the benefits at issue were readily identifiable and calculable, and that the trustees of the union funds were a channel by which the companies provided fringe benefits. (216 US App DC 50, 670 F2d 208).

The United States filed a complaint in condemnation in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Texas. Shortly thereafter, the government filed a notice of lis pendens, notifying the public of the institution of the condemnation proceeding. The District Court referred the matter to a special commission to ascertain the compensation due the landowner. On the day that the trial began before the commission, the parties stipulated that "today is the date of taking." After hearing competing testimony pertaining to the fair market value of the land, the commission entered a report recommending compensation in a specified amount. After a hearing on both parties' objections to the report, the District Court entered judgment awarding the landowner compensation in the amount recommended by the commission, plus interest at 6 percent for the period from the date the complaint was filed to the date the government deposited the adjudicated value of the land with the court (520 F Supp 75). The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit reversed and remanded for reconsideration of the value of the property (696 F2d 351).

After earlier proceedings in a private antitrust action, wherein the United States Supreme Court entered a mandate directing entry of judgment for the plaintiff (395 US 642, 23 L Ed 2d 599, 89 S Ct 1871), the plaintiff filed an application in the United States District Court for the District of Oregon for allowance of attorneys' fees for services performed during the appellate stages of the litigation, both in the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit and in the Supreme Court. The District Court denied the application, ruling that the allowance of such attorneys' fees was not authorized under 4 of the Clayton Act, which provides for recovery of treble damages "and the cost of suit, including a reasonable attorney's fee." The Court of Appeals on the plaintiff's appeal and on his simultaneously filed applications for such attorneys' fees, concluded that the Supreme Court's mandate, by not mentioning attorneys' fees, precluded an award of such fees.

An indigent woman who unsuccessfully sought to obtain a nontherapeutic abortion in one of two city-owned public hospitals in St. Louis, Missouri, brought a civil rights class action under 42 USCS 1983 in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri, alleging that the hospital's refusal to provide the abortion violated her constitutional rights. Ultimately, the District Court ruled against the plaintiff, but the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit reversed, holding that the provision of publicly financed hospital services for childbirth but not for elective abortions, pursuant to a policy determination of the Mayor of St. Louis prohibiting the performance of abortions in city hospitals except when there was a threat of genuine physiological injury or death to the mother, constituted invidious discrimination violative of equal protection under the Fourteenth Amendment (515 F2d 541).

While defendant, Stanley Edward Kelley, was proceeding west on River Road in Pima County, Arizona, his vehicle crossed the center line for a brief moment. He was observed by a deputy county sheriff, who, suspecting that defendant was driving while intoxicated, turned his car around and proceeded after defendant's car.
