On appeal, the Federal Circuit vacated the judgment, holding that patent applicants can introduce new evidence in ¬ß145 proceedings, subject only to the limitations in the Federal Rules of Evidence and the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. It also reaffirmed its precedent that when new, conflicting evidence is introduced, the district court must make de novo findings to take such evidence into account.

In 1985, a Virginia statute prohibiting the sale to juveniles of sexual or sadomasochistic materials which are "harmful to juveniles" was amended by adding a provision making it a crime "to knowingly display for commercial purpose in a manner whereby juveniles may examine and peruse" such materials, even if the materials are not actually sold to any juvenile. The term "harmful to juveniles" was defined elsewhere in the statute. Approximately two weeks after the effective date of the 1985 amendment, and prior to any enforcement action thereunder, several booksellers filed suit under 42 USCS 1983 in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia. The booksellers, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief against the enforcement of the 1985 amendment, alleged that the amendment was facially invalid for overbreadth, in that it unconstitutionally burdened adult book buyers' access to nonobscene materials under the First Amendment of the Federal Constitution. The defendants, who included local officials and the Commonwealth of Virginia, challenged the booksellers' reading of the amendment's reach, arguing that it extended only to "borderline obscenity." Based upon the direct testimony of booksellers who stated that the 1985 amendment might apply to between 30 and 50 percent of their inventory, and based upon the District Court's own review of a number of books which the booksellers introduced into evidence as examples of material believed to be covered by the 1985 amendment--and notwithstanding the booksellers' testimony that they were unfamiliar with the portion of the law defining "harmful to juveniles"--the District Court found as a factual matter that the 1985 amendment covered between 5 and 25 percent of a typical bookseller's inventory, concluded as a matter of law that the amendment was overbroad, and permanently enjoined its enforcement (617 F Supp 699). On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit affirmed as to the unconstitutional overbreadth of the 1985 amendment, while acknowledging that "little specific evidence" had been presented in the District Court as to what percentage of a booksellers' inventory might be subject to the amendment's restrictions (802 F2d 691).

The respondent, a tenured corrections officer, was discharged without a pretermination hearing; at a post-termination hearing the Public Employee Relations Board decided that the dismissal was proper as a matter of state law. On appeal, the Oregon Supreme Court reversed. Relying on its decision in Tupper v. Fairview Hospital & Training Center, 276 Ore. 657, 556 P. 2d 1340 (1976), ‚àö¬∂[**470]‚àö¬∂ the court concluded that procedural due process required that a tenured employee receive notice of the charges against him and the proposed sanction, as wel as an opportunity to respond, before being discharged. It further held that respondent was entitled to backpay and other benefits from the time of his discharge until such time as a proper termination hearing is ‚àö¬∂[***307]‚àö¬∂ held, even though the discharge had been upheld at the post-termination hearing. n1

Section 7005 of the Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1985 (49 USCS Appx 1682a) directs the United States Secretary of Transportation to establish a system of user fees to cover the costs of administering programs under the Natural Gas Pipeline Safety Act of 1968 (NGPSA) (49 USCS Appx 1671 et seq.) and the Hazardous Liquid Pipeline Safety Act of 1979 (HLPSA) (49 USCS 2001 et seq.), which fees are to be collected annually from operators of pipeline facilities subject to NGPSA and HLPSA. As specified in 7005, the fee schedule is to be "based on the usage" of such facilities, "in reasonable relationship to volume-miles, miles, revenues, or an appropriate combination thereof." After soliciting industry comment, the Secretary established a set of fee schedules based on pipeline miles. A company which owned and operated pipelines subject to HLPSA (1) paid, under protest, the fees assessed against it under those schedules, and (2) filed an action for declaratory and injunctive relief against the Secretary in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma. On cross motions for summary judgment, the United States Magistrate assigned to the case recommended that 7005 be struck down as an invalid delegation to the Secretary of Congress' taxing power under the Federal Constitution (Art I, 8, cl 1), and the District Court adopted these recommendations.

Under 4A1.2, 4B1.1, and 4B1.2(c) of the Federal Sentencing Guidelines (18 USCS Appx), (1) a "career offender," defined as one with at least two prior felony convictions for violent or drug-related crimes, is subject to particularly severe punishment, (2) convictions that are "related" to one another count as a single prior felony conviction, and (3) prior convictions are related to one another when they were consolidated for sentencing. The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit has ruled that convictions that were not formally consolidated for sentencing may be considered functionally consolidated, for purposes of the Guidelines, if the convictions were factually or logically related and sentencing was joint. In the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin, a defendant--who had four prior felony convictions in state court for gas-station robberies and one for a drug offense--pleaded guilty to federal charges of armed bank robbery. At sentencing, the defendant contended that her drug conviction had been consolidated for sentencing with the robbery convictions--which the prosecution conceded were "related" to each other--as the defendant argued that (1) the robberies allegedly had been motivated by her drug habit; (2) the drugs had been found in her home by police searching for evidence of the robberies; and (3) the same state-court judge had (a) heard arguments about sentencing in all five cases in a single proceeding, (b) issued sentences in all five cases at the same time, and (c) ordered that the drug sentence run concurrently with the sentences for robbery. The District Court, however, ruled that the robbery and drug cases had not been consolidated, either formally or functionally, as the District Court placed greater weight on the circumstances that (1) the robbery and drug offenses had been charged in separate indictments and handled by different prosecutors, both at trial and before the sentencing court; (2) the defendant's guilty plea on the drug charge had been heard in a separate proceeding; and (3) the robbery and drug sentences had been issued in separate judgments. The Court of Appeals, deciding to review the District Court's decision deferentially rather than de novo, affirmed (201 F3d 937).

Defendants' convictions, in the United States District Court for the District of Connecticut, of possession, custody, and control of an unregistered still, in violation of 26 USC 5601(a)(1), were reversed by the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit on the grounds that the trial court, in instructing the jury, read the provision of 5601(b)(1), authorizing an inference of guilt from defendants' unexplained presence at the site of the still, and that the instruction, and the statutory inference embodied therein, violated the due process clause of the Fifth Amendment. (330 F2d 566.)

The plaintiff, a member of a Louisiana local of the plumbers union, attempted to secure a job with a construction company in Dallas, Texas, on a particular bank construction project. The company's hiring on this project was done through union referral. Plaintiff was unable to obtain such a referral from the business agent of the defendant Dallas local of the plumbers union, even after the agent had accepted plaintiff's clearance card from the Louisiana local and after the company's foreman on the project had asked the business agent to have plaintiff sent over. The plaintiff brought the present suit against the union in a Texas state court, seeking damages under state law for defendant's refusal to refer him to the company. The defendant challenged the state court's jurisdiction, asserting that the subject matter of the suit was within the exclusive jurisdiction of the National Labor Relations Board. After protracted litigation the plaintiff recovered a judgment in the trial court. The Texas Court of Civil Appeals affirmed, rejecting defendant's pre-emption argument. (355 SW2d 729.) The Supreme Court of Texas denied a writ of error.

Canadian railroads transporting asbestos from the Province of Quebec to points in Vermont joined with American railroads, which transported the asbestos from there to other points in the United States, in the publication of joint through rates available to consignees in the northeastern United States, which were substantially lower than the combination through rates available to consignees in the southern United States. After hearings, the Interstate Commerce Commission found that the higher combination rates to complainants in the South were violative of 49 USC 1(5) and 3(1), and directed railroads engaged in transportation within the United States to cease participation in this transportation practice. (303 ICC 743.) A three-judge United States District Court for the District of Vermont set aside the Commission's order. (182 F Supp 516.)

Based primarily on evidence taken at a hearing concluded in 1955, which tended to prove that an organization's executive director was a Communist Party member, the Subversive Activities Control Board ordered in 1960 that the organization register as a "Communist-front" organization under 7 of the Subversive Activities Control Act, although the executive director had died in 1959 and the record disclosed no evidence of the organization's activities after his death. The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit affirmed. (117 App DC 393, 331 F2d 53.)

The present controversy arises from a long-standing dispute between the coastal states and the federal government over their respective rights to exploit the oil and other natural resources of off-shore submerged lands. In United States v California (1947) 332 US 19, 91 L ed 1889, 67 S Ct 1658, the Supreme Court of the United States held that, as against California, the United States possessed paramount rights in such lands underlying the Pacific Ocean seaward of the low-water mark on the coast of California and outside of inland waters. In 1950, the Court made like holdings with respect to submerged lands in the Gulf of Mexico similarly lying off the coasts of Louisiana and Texas. United States v Louisiana, 339 US 699, 94 L ed 1216, 70 S Ct 914; United States v Texas, 339 US 707, 94 L ed 1221, 70 S Ct 918. By the Submerged Lands Act of 1953 (43 USC 1301 et seq.) the United States relinquished to the coastal states all of its rights in all lands beneath navigable waters within a three-mile limit and, in excess of that limit, within state boundaries as they existed at the time a state became a member of the Union, or as theretofore approved by Congress. The limit of the grant was three leagues. The United States, invoking the original jurisdiction of the Supreme Court of the United States, brought the present suit against Louisiana, Texas, Mississippi, Alabama, and Florida, seeking, among other relief, a declaration that it was entitled to exclusive possession over the lands, minerals, etc., underlying the waters of the Gulf of Mexico more than three geographic miles seaward from the coast of each state. The defendant states claimed a right to the submerged lands within three leagues of their coast, Alabama filing a cross bill to establish such right. The claim of Florida is discussed in an opinion appearing p. 1096, infra. The present opinion deals with the claims of Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama.

In Anders v California (1967) 386 US 738, 18 L Ed 2d 493, 87 S Ct 1396, the United States Supreme Court, in holding that California's then existing procedure for handling potentially frivolous criminal appeals by convicted indigents violated the Federal Constitution's Fourteenth Amendment, set out what would be an acceptable procedure for treating such appeals, under which procedure (1) counsel who finds an appeal to be frivolous should so advise the appellate court and request permission to withdraw, (2) counsel's request must be accompanied by a brief referring to anything in the record that might arguably support the appeal, and (3) the court then decided whether the case is frivolous. Subsequently, the California Supreme Court adopted a new procedure, under which (1) counsel (a) upon concluding that an appeal would be frivolous, filed a brief with the appellate court that summarized the procedural and factual history of the case, (b) attests that counsel has reviewed the record, explained counsel's evaluation of the case to the client, provided the client with a copy of the brief, and informed the client of the client's right to file a pro se supplemental brief, (c) requests that the court independently examine the record for arguable issues, (d) neither explicitly states a conclusion that an appeal would be frivolous nor requests leave to withdraw, (e) is silent on the merits of the case, and (f) expresses counsel's availability to brief any issues on which the court might desire briefing; and (2) the appellate court must conduct a review of the entire record. An accused who, after representing himself at a California state court trial, had been convicted of murder and grand theft, received appointed counsel on appeal. Counsel, concluding that an appeal would be frivolous, filed a brief that complied with the new California procedure, and the accused filed a pro se supplemental brief. After the California Court of Appeal affirmed the accused's conviction, the California Supreme Court denied the accused's petition for review. The accused filed, in the United States District Court for the Central District of California pursuant to 28 USCS 2254, a writ of habeas corpus alleging, among other things, that the accused had been denied effective assistance of appellate counsel because counsel's brief filed in accordance with the new California procedure failed to comply with the procedure set forth in Anders v California. The District Court, in agreeing with the accused's allegation, ordered California to either grant the accused a new trial within 30 days or release him from custody. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit agreed with the District Court on the Anders issue, but remanded for the District Court to consider the accused's 11 claims of trial error, reasoning that if the accused prevailed on any of these claims, then it would be unnecessary to order the California Court of Appeal to grant a new direct appeal (152 F3d 1062).

An individual who had purchased 50 percent of the stock in a closely held liquor import company and assumed a role in the management of the firm brought suit against the previous sole owner and others, alleging violations of the antifraud provisions of the federal securities laws. The United States District Court granted summary judgment for the defendants, holding that the stock in question was not a "security" within the meaning of the securities laws under the "sale of business" doctrine. The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit reversed (737 F2d 320).

The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act of 1976 (RCRA) is a comprehensive environmental statute that empowers the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to regulate hazardous waste in accordance with the rigorous safeguards and waste management procedures of Subtitle C (42 USCS 6921-6934), while nonhazardous wastes are regulated much more loosely under Subtitle D (42 USCS 6941-6949). The city of Chicago owned and operated a municipal incinerator that burned solid waste and recovered energy, leaving a residue of ash. In 1988, an environmental organization (1) filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against the city and its mayor under RCRA's citizen suit provision (42 USCS 6972); and (2) alleged that the city and the mayor were violating provisions of RCRA and of implementing EPA regulations. While it was uncontested that with respect to the incinerator ash, the city and the mayor had not adhered to Subtitle C's requirements, the city and the mayor contended that the ash was exempted from those requirements by 3001(i) of the Solid Waste Disposal Act (42 USCS 6921(i))--an RCRA provision which had been added in a 1984 amendment as a clarification of a household waste exclusion from regulation, after the EPA had issued some 1980 regulations involving such an exclusion. The District Court agreed with the contention of the city and the mayor (727 F Supp 419) and subsequently granted a motion by the city and the mayor for summary judgment. On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, in 1991, reversed on the ground that the ash generated from the incinerators of municipal resource recovery facilities was subject to regulation as a hazardous waste under Subtitle C 48 F2d 345). In 1992, the Administrator of EPA issued a memorandum expressing the agency's view to the effect that pursuant to 3001(i), municipal waste combustion ash was exempt from hazardous waste regulation under Subtitle C. Thereafter, the United States Supreme Court granted certiorari, vacated the Court of Appeals' judgment, and remanded the case to the Court of Appeals for further consideration in light of the EPA memorandum (506 US ____, 121 L Ed 2d 426, 113 S Ct 486). On remand, however, the Court of Appeals reinstated its previous opinion, expressing the view that because the statute's plain language was dispositive, the EPA memorandum did not affect the Court of Appeals' analysis (985 F2d 303).

Under 5 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 (42 USCS 1973c), some states and their political subdivisions may not implement any change in a voting qualification, prerequisite, standard, practice, or procedure unless the state or subdivision first obtains either (1) administrative preclearance of that change from the United States Attorney General, or (2) judicial preclearance from the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. Bossier Parish, Louisiana, was a jurisdiction subject to the 5 preclearance requirements. In order to equalize the population distribution among the 12 electoral districts for the parish's school board, the board, in 1992, adopted a redistricting plan which had been recently adopted by the Bossier Parish police jury--the parish's primary governing body--to govern the jury's own elections. This plan, for which the jury had obtained the Attorney General's preclearance, likewise contained 12 districts. None of the districts in the board's existing plan or in the jury plan contained a majority of black residents. In adopting the jury plan, the board rejected an alternative 12-district plan that would have included two districts each containing a majority of voting-age black residents. The Attorney General (1) objected to the board's use of the jury plan on the basis of new information not previously available, that is, the alternative plan; (2) asserted that the board's redistricting plan violated 2 of the Voting Rights Act (42 USCS 1973) by unnecessarily limiting the opportunity for minority voters to elect their candidates of choice; and (3) concluded that the board's plan warranted a denial of preclearance. The board filed a preclearance action in the District Court against the Attorney General. The District Court, in granting preclearance, said that the District Court would not (1) deny preclearance of a proposed voting change under 5 simply because the change violated 2, or (2) permit 2 evidence to prove discriminatory purpose under 5 (907 F Supp 434). The United States Supreme Court, in vacating the District Court's judgment and in remanding the case for further proceedings, held that (1) a proposed voting change could not be denied preclearance simply because the change violated 2; and (2) evidence of a dilutive but nonretrogressive effect forbidden by 2 could, in some circumstances, be relevant to whether a plan was enacted with a retrogressive purpose forbidden by 5 (520 US 471, 137 L Ed 2d 730, 117 S Ct 1491). On remand, the District Court, in again granting preclearance, (1) expressed the view that retrogressive intent had not been established, but (2) left open the question, which the Supreme Court had left open on remand, as to whether the 5 purpose inquiry extended beyond the search for retrogressive intent (7 F Supp 2d 29).

No recovery is allowed in actions under death act for loss of 2 minor sons of administrator, where they were drowned while trapping on defendant's land without permission or consideration and there is no claim defendant was guilty of gross negligence or wilful and wanton misconduct in the maintenance of chemical ponds for disposal of waste products incident to sugar-beet processing operation

As of 1996, South Carolina law provided that (1) capital jurors at the sentencing phase of a trial were to decide first whether the state had proved beyond a reasonable doubt the existence of any statutory aggravating circumstance; (2) if the jury failed to agree unanimously on the presence of a statutory aggravator, then the trial judge was to sentence the defendant to either life imprisonment or a mandatory minimum 30-year prison term; and (3) if the jury unanimously found a statutory aggravator, then the jury was to recommend either a death sentence or life imprisonment without the possibility of parole. A South Carolina trial court jury found a defendant guilty of a 1997 murder and other crimes. During the trial's sentencing phase, the judge refused--on the ground that the defendant's future dangerousness had not been argued--to instruct the jury that a life sentence would carry no possibility of parole. Instead, the judge told the jury that "life imprisonment means until the death of the defendant." The judge also refused to allow defense counsel to state plainly in his closing argument that a life sentence in South Carolina carried no possibility of parole. Accordingly, defense counsel's closing argument stated merely that if the defendant's life was spared, the defendant would "die in prison" after "spend[ing] his natural life there." During sentencing deliberations, the jury asked the judge whether, and under what circumstances, someone convicted of murder could become eligible for parole. The judge responded that parole eligibility or ineligibility was not for the jury's consideration. The jury, unanimously finding an aggravating factor beyond a reasonable doubt, recommended a death sentence, which the judge imposed. The Supreme Court of South Carolina, in affirming, (1) acknowledged that when a defendant's future dangerousness is at issue and the only available alternative sentence to the death penalty is life imprisonment without parole, due process entitles the defendant to inform the jury that the defendant is parole ineligible; but (2) reasoned that this rule was inapplicable in the case at hand, for when the jury began its deliberations, there was a potential alternative--a mandatory minimum 30-year sentence--to death or life without the possibility of parole (340 SC 291, 531 SE2d 524).

Section 5 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965, as amended (42 USCS _ 1973c), requires that a covered jurisdiction's change in a voting "standard, practice, or procedure" must be precleared, either by the United States Attorney General or by the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, in order to ensure that the change "does not have the purpose and will not have the effect of denying or abridging the right to vote on account of race or color." For such purposes, the United States Supreme Court has generally held that the determination whether such a change should be precleared depends on whether the change would lead to a "retrogression" in the position of racial minorities with respect to their effective exercise of the electoral franchise. Georgia was a covered jurisdiction for _ 5 purposes. After the 1990 census, there were some redistricting disputes involving Georgia's United States House of Representatives seats and the seats in the two houses of the state's legislature. Eventually, among other dispositions, the state's 1997 plan for redistricting the state's senate was precleared. After the 2000 census, there were again redistricting disputes. In 2001, the state enacted a new redistricting plan for the state's senate. Subsequently, the state (1) filed a preclearance suit in the District Court for the District of Columbia; and (2) sought a declaratory judgment that several redistricting plans, including the 2001 state-senate plan, did not violate _ 5. The United States, through its Attorney General, opposed preclearance of the 2001 plan and argued that the plan's changes to three state-senate  [***429]  districts--in each of which the plan assertedly reduced the percentage of black voting-age population to just over 50 percent--unlawfully reduced the ability of black voters to elect candidates of their choice. Eventually, the District Court, in pertinent part, denied _ 5 preclearance for the 2001 plan, as the court expressed the view that (1) the three districts in question were retrogressive, for in each of those districts, a lesser opportunity existed for a black candidate of choice to win election under the new plan than under the benchmark 1997 plan; and (2) Georgia had "failed to present any . . . evidence" that the retrogression in those three districts would be offset by gains in other districts (195 F Supp 2d 25).

The explosion of a bomb which had been sent through the mail killed two persons and injured a third person. After the defendant was tried in a Washington state court for the murder of one of the persons, the jury decided that the defendant was not the person who had mailed the bomb, and the jury therefore acquitted the defendant. The state subsequently prosecuted the defendant for the murder of the other person killed by the bomb and for the assault of the person injured by the bomb. Rejecting the defendant's pleas of former jeopardy and collateral estoppel, the Supreme Court of Washington held that since a letter which had been excluded at the first trial, and which allegedly had been written by the defendant and contained threats against the lives of two of the victims of the explosion, would be admissible at the second trial, the issue of the identity of the person who had mailed the bomb had not been fully litigated at the first trial, and the doctrine of collateral estoppel did not bar a subsequent trial at which litigation of the issue of identity would be complete (78 Wash 2d 894, 480 P2d 484).

A collective labor contract between a union and a publisher contained a clause incorporating the general laws of the union not in conflict with the contract or with federal or state law ("General Laws" clause); the contract further provided that the employer's mail-room foremen must be members of the union and should do the hiring ("Foreman" clause). Upon a charge of nonunion employees that foremen discriminated in favor of union men, the National Labor Relations Board concluded that the union and the employer had violated the provisions of the National Labor Relations Act which prohibit discrimination in regard to hire or tenure of employment to encourage or discourage membership in any labor organization. (122 NLRB 818.) The remedial order of the board contained various provisions, including a direction that all employees in the mail rooms be reimbursed for dues and assessments paid the union for a specified period. The board proceeded on the theory that the contract constituted a per se violation of the statutory provisions, and also that the employer and the union had in fact maintained and enforced unlawful union security and preferential hiring practices in the mail rooms. Upon the board's petition for enforcement of its order, the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit refused enforcement. (279 F2d 323.)

Petitioners brought suits against the Collector of Internal Revenue for refunds of social security taxes. In one of the suits several band leaders were permitted to intervene as defendants. Judgments for the petitioners in the District Court were reversed by the Circuit Court of Appeals.

This case represents the latest conflict between Texas gaming officials and the Ysleta del Sur Pueblo Indian Tribe. In 1968, Congress recognized the Ysleta del Sur Pueblo as an Indian tribe and assigned its trust responsibilities for the Tribe to Texas. 82 Stat. 93. In 1983, Texas renounced its trust responsibilities as inconsistent with the State‚Äôs Constitution. The State also expressed opposition to any new federal trust legislation that did not permit the State to apply its own gaming laws on tribal lands. Congress restored the Tribe‚Äôs federal trust status in 1987 when it adopted the Ysleta del Sur and Alabama and Coushatta Indian Tribes of Texas Restoration Act. 101 Stat. 666. The Restoration Act also ‚Äúprohibited‚Äù as a matter of federal law ‚Äú[a]ll gaming activities which are prohibited by the laws of the State of Texas.‚Äù Id., at 668. Shortly thereafter, Congress adopted its own comprehensive Indian gaming legislation: the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act (IGRA). IGRA established rules for separate classes of games. As relevant here, IGRA permitted Tribes to offer so-called class II games‚Äîlike bingo‚Äîin States that ‚Äúpermi[t] such gaming for any purpose by any person, organization or entity.‚Äù 25 U. S. C. ¬ß2710(b)(1)(A). IGRA allowed Tribes to offer class III games‚Äîlike blackjack and baccarat‚Äîbut only pursuant to negotiated tribal/state compacts. ¬ß2703(8). Pursuant to IGRA, the Tribe sought to negotiate a compact with Texas to offer class III games. Texas refused, arguing that the Restoration Act displaced IGRA and required the Tribe to follow all of the State‚Äôs gaming laws on tribal lands. In subsequent federal litigation, the District Court held that Texas violated IGRA by failing to negotiate in good faith. The Fifth Circuit reversed, holding that the Restoration Act‚Äôs directions superseded IGRA‚Äôs and guaranteed that the entirety of ‚ÄúTexas‚Äô gaming laws and regulations‚Äù would ‚Äúoperate as surrogate federal law on the Tribe‚Äôs reservation.‚Äù 36 F. 3d 1325, 1326, 1334 (Ysleta I). In 2016, the Tribe began to offer bingo, including ‚Äúelectronic bingo‚Äù machines, on the view that IGRA treats bingo as a class II game for which no state permission is required so long as the State permits the game to be played on some terms by some persons. The State then sought to shut down all of the Tribe‚Äôs bingo operations. Bound by Ysleta I, the District Court sided with Texas and enjoined the Tribe‚Äôs bingo operations, but the court stayed the injunction pending appeal. The Fifth Circuit reaffirmed Ysleta I and held that the Tribe‚Äôs bingo operations were impermissible because they did not conform to Texas‚Äôs bingo regulations.

Several voters from Winston County, Mississippi, filed an action in the Chancery Court of Winston County, seeking to enforce a neglected state statute passed in 1964, which prescribed the composition and election procedures for members of boards of trustees of all municipal separate school districts. The statute also prescribed a separate procedure, applicable only to Winston County. The Chancery Court dismissed the voters' complaint, holding that the statute violated Mississippi's constitutional bar against local legislation. The Supreme Court of Mississippi reversed, striking only the specific reference which limited application of the special election procedure to Winston County, upholding the remainder of the statute, and remanding to the Chancery Court for further proceedings not inconsistent with its opinion (365 So 2d 947). Certain local county officials then filed a petition for rehearing, in which they argued for the first time that the Chancery Court could not implement the reformed statute until the change had been precleared with the Attorney General of the United States pursuant to 5 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 (42 USCS 1973c). The Supreme Court of Mississippi denied the petition without comment and the United States Supreme Court denied certiorari (60 L Ed 2d 1049). On remand, the Chancery Court ordered an election pursuant to the redacted statute and, agreeing that the changes in election procedure fell within 5, directed that local officials submit the election plan to the Attorney General for preclearance. The Attorney General objected to the plan, arguing that the procedure requiring a runoff between the two leading candidates absent any candidate's receiving a majority of the vote had a discriminatory effect. The Chancery Court then ordered that its decree calling for an election remain in force subject to compliance with the Act. The voters again appealed to the Supreme Court of Mississippi, which observed that its prior decision was the law of the case and held that the Chancery Court properly enforced the law requiring runoffs but improperly conditioned the election on compliance with the Voting Rights Act (399 So 2d 1356).

In each of these cases, an employer allegedly fired a long-time employee simply for being homosexual or transgender. Clayton County, Geor- gia, fired Gerald Bostock for conduct “unbecoming” a county employee shortly after he began participating in a gay recreational softball league. Altitude Express fired Donald Zarda days after he mentioned being gay. And R. G. & G. R. Harris Funeral Homes fired Aimee Ste- phens, who presented as a male when she was hired, after she in- formed her employer that she planned to “live and work full-time as a woman.” Each employee sued, alleging sex discrimination under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The Eleventh Circuit held that Title VII does not prohibit employers from firing employees for being gay and so Mr. Bostock’s suit could be dismissed as a matter of law. The Second and Sixth Circuits, however, allowed the claims of Mr. Zarda and Ms. Stephens, respectively, to proceed.
Held: An employer who fires an individual merely for being gay or transgender violates Title VII. Pp. 4–33.

An employee of the Nevada human resources department sought leave to care for his ailing wife under the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) (29 USCS _ 2601 et seq.), which (1) in 29 USCS _ 2612(a)(1)(C), entitled some private and public employees to unpaid leave of up to 12 workweeks per 12-month period to care for a family member who had a serious health condition; (2) in 29 USCS _ 2617(a)(2), enabled employees to seek damages "against any employer (including a public agency) in any Federal or State court of competent jurisdiction;" and (3) in 29 USCS _ 2611(4)(A)(iii), defined "public agency" to include state governments, their agencies, and their political subdivisions. The department granted the employee the full 12 weeks of FMLA leave, but eventually informed him that he had exhausted the 12 weeks and had to return to work. He failed to return and was terminated. The employee brought in the United States District Court for the District of Nevada, against the department and two of its officers, a suit seeking damages and injunctive and declaratory relief for, among other things, violation of _ 2612(a)(1)(C). The District Court granted the department and the officers summary judgment on the grounds that (1) the FMLA claim was barred by the state's immunity, under the Federal Constitution's Eleventh Amendment, from suit in federal court; and (2) the employee's rights under the Constitution's Fourteenth Amendment had not been violated. The employee appealed, and, after the United States intervened to defend  [***954]  the applicability of the FMLA to the states, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit reversed (273 F3d 844).

A purported class action was instituted in the United States District Court for the Southern District of West Virginia challenging the constitutionality of a West Virginia statute requiring that in order to perfect an appeal from a judgment by a justice of the peace in a civil case, a defendant must post bond in a penalty double the amount of the adverse judgment. The action was instituted against a justice of the peace and a creditor by a debtor who was unable to post the requisite bond for an appeal from a judgment which the creditor had obtained against the debtor in the justice's court. The District Court upheld the challenged statute.

In an action instituted in the Circuit Court, Wayne County, Michigan, a corporation engaged in operating federally licensed steam vessels in interstate commerce sought to enjoin the enforcement against it of provisions of the Smoke Abatement Code of the City of Detroit, under which the corporation's steam vessels could not, without undergoing structural alteration, perform necessary cleaning of their fires within the city. The Circuit Court refused to grant relief, and the Supreme Court of Michigan affirmed (355 Mich 227, 93 NW2d 888).

Former federal probationary employees who had been discharged from federal employment without being afforded a prior agency hearing, applied for unemployment compensation through the New York State Department of Labor, which was an agent of the United States in administering the Unemployment Compensation for Federal Employees Program (5 USCS 8501 et seq.), and which denied unemployment compensation on the basis of ex parte findings of the federal employing agencies as to the reasons for the employees' discharges from federal employment. Thereupon, the employees instituted a class action against the State and Federal Departments of Labor, and the employees' former federal employing agencies, in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, claiming that a hearing prior to denial of unemployment compensation was required by the federal statutes, and that the state agency's denial of a hearing violated due process and equal protection under the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments. The three-judge District Court dismissed the suit, holding that the federal statutes did not require either a state or federal hearing, and that the denial of a hearing by the state agency did not violate due process or equal protection (347 F Supp 1158).

The plaintiff, an alien who was originally admitted to the United States for permanent residence in 1952, and has been there continuously since except for a visit of "about a couple hours" duration to Mexico in 1956, was ordered to be deported on the ground that at the time of his 1956 return he was excludible under 212(a)(4) of the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952 as an alien "afflicted with psychopathic personality." After his appeal to the Board of Immigration Appeals was dismissed, he brought the present action in the United States District Court for the Southern District of California for declaratory judgment and review of the administrative action. The District Court granted the government's motion for summary judgment. On appeal, however, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit set aside the deportation order, holding that as applied to plaintiff, 212(a)(4) was unconstitutionally vague. (302 F2d 652.)

The plaintiff, who had been convicted in a state criminal prosecution, later filed suit in the United States District Court for the District of South Carolina under 42 USCS 1983 against an undercover agent for, and the head of, a state law enforcement agency, asserting that the agent and the agency head had deprived him of certain constitutional rights. The action was based on the claim that the participation of the undercover agent--who, like the plaintiff, had been arrested for vandalizing a Selective Service office--in two pretrial conferences between the plaintiff and the plaintiff's attorney, at their request, and the agent's representation that he would not be a prosecution witness, whereas he later testified for the state, had deprived the plaintiff of his right to the effective assistance of counsel guaranteed by the Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments, and had deprived him of a fair trial in violation of the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment. The District Court found for the defendants, but the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit reversed (528 F2d 483).

A corporation which has availed itself of statutory permission to report as income from instalment sales only that proportion of the instalment payments actually received in the tax year which the gross profit to be realized when payment is completed bears to the total contract price, may, though otherwise reporting income on an accrual basis, properly be required to exclude from invested capital, defined by statute as including "accumulated earnings and profits as of the beginning of" the taxable year, the amount of profits not yet converted into cash through the collection of future instalments in computing the deduction to be made in ascertaining income subject to excess profits tax, of an amount equal to 8 per cent of the taxpayer's invested capital for the taxable year.

A bank holding company incorporated and maintaining its principal place of business in New York sought approval from the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System to operate an investment management subsidiary in Florida. The Board rejected the application on the ground that it would conflict with a Florida statute prohibiting a bank, trust company, or bank holding company whose operations are principally conducted outside the state from owning or controlling a business within that state that sells investment advisory services (59 Fed Res Bull 364). The holding company and its subsidiary subsequently filed an action seeking declaratory and injunctive relief in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Florida, alleging, among other things, that the statute violated the commerce clause of the United States Constitution (Art I, 8, cl 3) and that the commerce clause was also violated as a result of the joint operation of the statute with another Florida statute which prohibited all corporations except state-chartered banks and national banks having their operations in the state from performing specified fiduciary functions. A three-judge court was convened and ultimately held that the challenged portions of the two statutes violated the commerce clause and that the federal Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 (12 USCS 1841 et seq.) did not foster or permit the types of discrimination against out-of-state bank holding companies reflected in the Florida statutes (461 F Supp 1187).

The issue in the present case concerned the validity and construction of the Narcotic Control Act of 1956 (18 USC 1406), in so far as this act legislates immunity from prosecution for a witness compelled under the act by court order to testify before a federal grand jury investigating violations of the federal narcotics laws. The petitioner, while serving a 5-year sentence for a federal narcotics offense, was directed by court order pursuant to 1406 to answer questions before a federal grand jury, but nevertheless refused to testify, primarily on the ground that 1406 did not grant him immunity from state prosecution, or, of it could be construed as granting such immunity, was unconstitutional. He was adjudged in contempt by the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York (170 F Supp 592), and his conviction was affirmed by the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit (273 F2d 234).

Under the federal Medicare program, qualified providers of health care services are eligible for reimbursement from the Secretary of Health and Human Services for the reasonable cost of providing covered services to Medicare beneficiaries. As part of the reimbursement procedure, the provider is required to submit a cost report at year's end to a fiscal intermediary, which is usually a private insurance company acting as the Secretary's agent. In 1979, the Secretary promulgated a regulation which instituted a new method for apportioning malpractice insurance premium costs associated with a provider's care of Medicare patients, for purposes of determining the provider's reimbursement under the Medicare program. Subsequently, two providers, in submitting the required cost reports for 1980 to the fiscal intermediary, complied with the 1979 regulation, disclosing their Medicare-related malpractice insurance costs but claiming reimbursement for only that portion allowable under the regulation. The fiscal intermediary which reviewed the providers' cost reports issued a notice of program reimbursement to each. The providers later filed a request for a hearing before the Provider Reimbursement Review Board (the Board), in which they challenged the validity of the 1979 regulation and sought reimbursement for malpractice costs pursuant to the method of calculating such costs in effect prior to the promulgation of the regulation. The Board ruled that, insofar as the providers had effected a "self-disallowance" of the malpractice costs which they had disclosed but not claimed on the cost reports, the providers had made no claim for reimbursement of the additional malpractice costs to the fiscal intermediary, and hence the Board lacked jurisdiction over the providers' appeal from the fiscal intermediary's final determination, pursuant to 42 USCS 1395oo. The providers then filed an action against the Secretary in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Ohio, which determined that the Board erred in concluding that it had no jurisdiction to review the providers' claims for reimbursement of their self-disallowed costs (609 F Supp 1360). On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit reversed, holding that circuit precedent required the conclusion that the Board had properly refused to exercise jurisdiction under the circumstances (810 F2d 558).

In 2000, the Maine legislature enacted a statute that established a program to reduce prescription drug prices for Maine residents. The program, which was open to all residents, was primarily intended to enable uninsured residents to buy prescription drugs from retail pharmacies at discounts that were approximately equal the rebates available to Medicaid participants under the Medicaid Act (42 USCS __ 1396 et seq.). Under the program, the state would attempt to negotiate rebates with drug manufacturers to fund reduced prices for drugs offered to program participants. If a manufacturer refused to enter into such a rebate agreement, then the state would generally subject the manufacturer's Medicaid sales to a "prior authorization" procedure that required state approval to qualify a prescription for reimbursement. An association of nonresident drug manufacturers, challenging the Maine program before the program's commencement date, claimed that the program (1) was pre-empted by the Medicaid Act, and (2) violated the Federal Constitution's commerce clause (Art I, _ 8, cl 3). Without resolving any factual issues, the United States District Court for the District of Maine, on the basis of a finding that the program was pre-empted by the Medicaid Act, entered a preliminary injunction preventing the state statute's implementation. The United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit (1) determined that the association's evidence was insufficient to support a preliminary injunction on the basis of asserted pre-emption; (2) found no violation  [***890]  of the commerce clause; and (3) vacated the temporary injunction, but stayed the Court of Appeals' mandate pending review of the case by the United States Supreme Court (249 F3d 66).

Under 29 USCS 623(f)(2), age-based employment decisions taken pursuant to the terms of any bona fide employee benefit plan, such as a retirement, pension, or insurance plan, which is not a subterfuge to evade the purposes of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 (ADEA) (29 USCS 621 et seq.) are exempt from the prohibitions of the ADEA, which forbids arbitrary discrimination by public and private employers against employees on account of age. Before the ADEA was made applicable to the states in 1974, the state of Ohio established for state and local government employees a retirement plan under which retirees receive either age-and-service benefits or disability benefits, employees are required to be under 60 years of age upon retirement to qualify for disability benefits, and once an individual retires on either age-and-service or disability benefits, he or she continues to receive that type of benefit throughout retirement, regardless of age. In 1976, the plan was amended to provide that disability payments would in no event constitute less than 30 percent of a disability retiree's final average salary, but no such floor was applied to age-and-service payments. An employee who was covered by the plan and who, because she was no longer able to perform adequately in any employment capacity, retired in 1985 at the age of 61 was denied disability retirement benefits because of her age and was instead granted age-and-service retirement benefits amounting to $ 158.50 per month. The employee, who would have received some $ 355 per month had she been permitted to receive disability benefits subject to the 30-percent floor, filed an age discrimination charge against the plan with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) and filed suit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Ohio, claiming that the refusal to grant her application for disability benefits violated the ADEA. The District Court granted summary judgment in favor of the employee, holding that, because the retirement plan's reduction in available benefits at age 60 was not shown to be justified by considerations of increased cost, the plan was not entitled to claim the protection of the 623(f)(2) exemption. The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, holding that the 623(f)(2) exemption is available only to those retirement plans that can provide age-related cost justifications or a substantial business purpose for any age-based reduction in benefits, affirmed the District Court's judgment (848 F2d 692).

After a Federal District Court dismissed an employment discrimination claim, the employee appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The employer moved for dismissal of the appeal and for sanctions. The employer argued that the appeal was frivolous in light of the Court of Appeals' prior decisions holding that 101 of the Civil Rights Act of 1991 (amending 42 USCS 1981) did not apply to cases, such as the present case, that arose before 101's enactment. In an order dated September 30, 1992, the Court of Appeals granted the employer's motion, dismissed the appeal, and imposed a $ 500 sanction on the employee's attorney.

Shipowners whose employees were not organized and whose vessel was picketed by two affiliated unions while it was being unloaded, causing dock employees to refuse to continue with the unloading, obtained in a Minnesota state court a permanent injunction against such picketing. The Supreme Court of Minnesota affirmed, holding that the two unions were not "labor organizations" within the meaning of 8(b) of the amended National Labor Relations Act (29 USC 158(b)) and that consequently the lower court was not deprived of jurisdiction of the case on the ground that it was within the exclusive jurisdiction of the National Labor Relations Board. (260 Minn 1, 108 NW2d 627.)

In an unfair labor practice proceeding an employer challenged the jurisdiction of the National Labor Relations Board upon the ground that the regional director of the complaining union had not filed a noncommunist affidavit as required of each "officer" of the union by 9(h) of the National Labor Relations Act. The Board rejected this contention on two grounds: (1) the compliance status of a union was a matter of administrative determination, and not one to be litigated in the unfair labor practice proceeding; (2) the employer's allegations, if true, did not establish that the regional director was an "officer" of the union, the Board proceeding on the theory that a union "officer" was a person occupying a position identified as an office in the union's constitution.

A meeting hall, the only available meeting place in a company-owned town, was erected by the company on the understanding that only a certain fraternal organization might use it; it was not connected with the company's business operations nor was its use open to employees because of their employment. The permission to use the meeting hall, freely given by the fraternal organization to those who needed it, was also given to a union organizer, but the employer rescinded the permission granted because of anti-union bias, manifested also by other acts.

EMW Women‚Äôs Surgical Center and two of its doctors filed a federal suit seeking to enjoin enforcement of Kentucky House Bill 454, legislation regulating the abortion procedure known as dilation and evacuation. Named defendants in EMW‚Äôs lawsuit included two Commonwealth officials, the attorney general and the cabinet secretary for Health and Family Services. EMW agreed to dismiss claims against the attorney general without prejudice. The stipulation of dismissal specified that the attorney general‚Äôs office reserved ‚Äúall rights, claims, and defenses . . . in any appeals arising out of this action‚Äù and agreed to be bound by ‚Äúany final judgment . . . subject to any modification, reversal or vacation of the judgment on appeal.‚Äù App. 28‚Äì30. The secretary remained in the case and defended the challenged law. After a bench trial, the District Court held that HB 454 unconstitutionally burdens a woman‚Äôs right to an abortion and issued a permanent injunction against the law‚Äôs enforcement. The secretary filed a notice of appeal. While the appeal was pending, Kentucky elected a new attorney general, petitioner Daniel Cameron, and elected the former attorney general, Andrew Beshear, Governor. Governor Beshear appointed a new secretary for Health and Family Services who continued the defense of HB 454 on appeal. Prior to oral argument before the Sixth Circuit, Attorney General Cameron entered an appearance as counsel for the new secretary. A divided Sixth Circuit panel affirmed the District Court‚Äôs judgment. The secretary then informed the attorney general‚Äôs office that the secretary would not file a petition for rehearing en banc or a petition for a writ of certiorari challenging the Sixth Circuit panel‚Äôs decision. Two days later, the attorney general moved to withdraw as counsel for the secretary and to intervene as a party on the Commonwealth‚Äôs behalf. The secretary did not oppose that motion, but respondents did. The attorney general also filed a petition for rehearing en banc within the 14-day deadline for an existing party to seek rehearing. The Sixth Circuit denied the attorney general‚Äôs motion to intervene. This Court granted certiorari limited to the question whether the Sixth Circuit should have permitted the attorney general to intervene

A corporate taxpayer exchanged its $ 50 face value 5 percent sinking fund debentures for its outstanding 47,059 shares of $ 50 par, 5 percent cumulative preferred stock. On the day of the exchange, the preferred was redeemable at $ 51 per share plus accrued dividends of $ 10 per share, but on the over-the- counter market, the midpoint between the bid and offering quotations for the preferred was $ 33. The National Stock Summary showed 100 shares wanted on two days within two weeks before the exchange, and 100 shares offered. On its federal income tax returns for that fiscal year and the nine subsequent fiscal years, the corporation claimed an interest deduction measured by the $ 17 difference between the $ 33 market value of the stock and the $ 50 face value of the bonds, amortized on a straight-line basis over the 18-year life of the bonds, with an addition each year for the unamortized discount on any bonds currently repurchased or redeemed. The Commissioner of Internal Revenue disallowed the deductions and the Tax Court upheld the Commissioner (57 T Ct 46), but the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit reversed (472 F2d 796).

In the late 19th century, Utah Lake, a navigable body of water, was included within the boundaries of Utah Territory. After a portion of the Sundry Appropriations Act of 1888 ("the 1888 Act") (25 Stat 505) authorized the United States to select and reserve federal land as sites for reservoirs, the Federal Government in 1889 took several actions--whose nature and effect were to be disputed--with respect to Utah Lake. In a portion of the Sundry Appropriations Act of 1890 ("the 1890 Act") (predecessor to 43 USCS 662), Congress repealed the 1888 Act's reservoir-site provisions, but added that reservoir sites previously located or selected under the 1888 Act would remain segregated and reserved from entry or settlement. The Utah Enabling Act of 1894 (28 Stat 107) provided that Utah was to be admitted into the Union on an equal footing with the original states. Subsequently, Utah was admitted to statehood, and entered the Union in 1896. In 1976, a bureau of the Federal Government issued oil and gas leases for the lands underlying Utah Lake. The state of Utah then brought suit against the United States in the United States District Court for the District of Utah, and sought a judgment that the state, rather than the Federal Government, had title to the bed of Utah lake. The District Court, however, granted a summary judgment in favor of the United States, expressing the view that (1) as part of an 1889 reservoir-site selection, the United States had withdrawn the bed of Utah Lake pursuant to the 1888 Act; (2) because of this prior withdrawal, title to the lakebed did not pass to Utah, which otherwise would have been permitted, on an equal footing with the original states, to obtain title to the lands under navigable waters within the state upon Utah's entry into the Union; and (3) federal title to the bed of Utah Lake was not affected by Congress' subsequent passage of the Submerged Lands Act (43 USCS 1301 et seq.), which relinquished to the states title to some, but not all, federal submerged lands (624 F Supp 622). On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit affirmed, (1) reaching similar conclusions as to reservoir-site selection, the equal footing doctrine, and the Submerged Lands Act; and (2) adding that the reservior-site selection was not affected by the 1890 Act, a provision as to reservoir sites in an 1891 act (predecessor to 43 USCS 663), or a provision as to reservoir sites in an 1897 act (predecessor to 43 USCS 664) (780 F2d 1515).

Acting within the provisions of a Texas venue statute, a receiver for a Texas insurance company in liquidation in the Ninety-eighth District Court of Travis County, Texas, brought suit in that court against two national banks and 143 other parties, alleging a conspiracy to defraud the insurance company. Each national bank filed a plea of privilege asserting that it was located in Dallas County, Texas, and therefore was immune from suit in Travis County by virtue of Revised Statutes 5198, which is now incorporated in 12 USC 94, and provides that suits against a national bank may be had in any state or county court in the county in which the bank is located having jurisdiction in similar cases. The pleas were overruled, but the Austin Court of Civil Appeals of the Third Supreme Judicial District reversed. (331 SW2d 349.) The Supreme Court of Texas reversed the judgment of the Court of Civil Appeals and affirmed the judgment of the trial court on the grounds that (1) 94, being permissive and not mandatory, does not prohibit a suit against a national bank when a state venue statute expressly permits it, and (2) 94 has been repealed. (161 Tex 349, 341 SW2d 161.)

The lower court applied an improper standard of review to the state court's decision where it blamed counsel for abandoning the not guilty by reason of insanity defense because there was nothing to lose by pursuing it. However, it was not an unreasonable application of clearly established federal law for a state court to decline to apply a specific legal rule that had not been squarely established by the United States Supreme Court. The Court had never established anything akin to the nothing to lose standard for evaluating Strickland claims. Under the doubly deferential judicial review that applied to a Strickland claim evaluated under the _ 2254(d)(1) standard, the prisoner's ineffective assistance of counsel claim failed as it was not unreasonable for the state court to conclude that his defense counsel's performance was not deficient when he counseled the prisoner to abandon a claim that stood almost no chance of success. Case law did not require defense counsel to pursue every claim or defense, regardless of its merit, viability, or realistic chance for success. Thus, the denial of the ineffective assistance of counsel claim did not violate clearly established federal law.

An owner of patents commenced in a federal court in Illinois an action against the distributor of infringing devices manufactured by a Pennsylvania corporation. Subsequently the manufacturer began in a federal court in Delaware an action against the patent owner for a declaration that the patents were invalid. Thereafter the patent owner joined the manufacturer as a defendant in the Illinois action.

Neither declaratory nor injunctive relief should be granted to an air carrier in an action seeking to prevent, on the ground that the Civil Aeronautics Board has exclusive jurisdiction, a state public utilities commission from exercising its claimed jurisdiction over rates charged by the carrier for transportation between points on the mainland and an island, both parts of the same state, but separated by the high seas.

A judgment of the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit was vacated, and the case remanded to that court, on the ground stated in the headnote below.  A judgment of a Court of Appeals will be vacated and the case remanded to that court, where the Solicitor General so suggests in the light of the present practice of the Court of Appeals to appoint an attorney in all cases on direct appeal where the trial judge's certificate of bad faith is attacked.

In an action against the United States to recover damages under the Federal Tort Claims Act (28 USC 1346, 2671 et seq.) for injuries resulting from the negligent operation of a government automobile by a government employee, the United States filed a third-party complaint, asking that if it should be held liable to the plaintiff, it should have indemnity from the employee.

The present action was instituted by Negro school children to test the constitutionality of the Alabama School Placement Law of 1955, the material provisions of which appear in the headnote, infra. The United States District Court for the Northern District of Alabama held that the act was not invalid upon its face, in view of the presumption that it would be administered in a constitutional manner by the admission of qualified pupils upon a basis of individual merit without regard to their race or color. (162 F Supp 372.)

Vorchheimer claimed that the school‚àö√ßs basis for the denial of her admission, her gender, was a violation of her rights under the Fourteenth Amendment.She argued in a class action suit that the single-sex institutions of Central High and Girls High (the only academic high schools in Philadelphia) were unequal in reputation, facilities and fundin

The facts admitted by an accused, in pleading guilty to kidnapping his estranged wife, supported, under some statutes of the state of Washington, a maximum prison sentence of 53 months. However, the judge, after hearing the wife's description of the kidnapping, imposed--on the basis of other state statutes allowing in some cases an "exceptional sentence" exceeding the general statutory limit--a 90-month prison sentence on the ground that the accused had acted with "deliberate cruelty," which was a statutorily enumerated ground for an enhanced sentence in a domestic-violence case.

A railroad whose line west of Kankakee, Illinois, roughly parallels the Illinois River, and which competes with bargelines for the transportation of corn and corn products, applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission for an order permitting a departure from the long and short haul provisions of 4 of the Interstate Commerce Act by allowing the railroad to give a 17-cent credit per hundred pounds, against the 23-cent charge per hundred pounds for shipments of milled-in-transit corn from western points to Kankakee, to shippers who reshipped to the east over the railroad. The Commission permitted the rate to continue, refusing to consider the arguments of the Chicago Board of Trade and a competing bargeline that the rate violated 3(1) and 3(4) of the statute and the National Transportation Policy. (310 ICC 437.) A three-judge United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois dismissed the bargeline's complaint in a suit to set aside the order. (209 F Supp 744.)

The petitioner in the present habeas corpus proceeding was convicted of murder in an Indiana trial court and sentenced to death. After his conviction was affirmed on appeal, the defendant, represented by the Public Defender, filed a petition for a writ of error coram nobis in the state trial court, which was denied. He then requested the Public Defender to represent him in perfecting an appeal to the Indiana Supreme Court. This request was refused because of the Public Defender's stated belief that an appeal would be unsuccessful. The petitioner's application to a state trial court for a free transcript of the coram nobis hearing and the appointment of counsel to perfect an appeal was denied. The state procedure was in accordance with Indiana law under which only the Public Defender can procure a free transcript of the hearing for the indigent, and the indigent cannot procure a transcript for himself and appeal pro se, nor can he secure the appointment of another lawyer for that purpose. The petitioner then instituted the present habeas corpus proceedings in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Indiana. The District Court granted relief on the ground that Indiana had deprived the petitioner of a right secured by the Fourteenth Amendment by refusing him appellate review of the denial of coram nobis solely because of his poverty. (196 F Supp 484.) The Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit affirmed. (302 F2d 537.)

In 1994, the Missouri legislature enacted a statute to restrict the permissible amounts of monetary contributions to candidates for state office. The statute took effect in 1995, after a ballot initiative with even stricter contribution limits--although approved by 74 percent of Missouri voters--had been invalidated as violative of the Federal Constitution's First Amendment by the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, which had nevertheless noted alleged improprieties with respect to contributions to Missouri political figures (72 F3d 633, cert den 518 US 1033, 135 L Ed 2d 1094, 116 S Ct 2579). The statute provided, among other matters, that (1) with respect to elections for statewide offices, including state auditor, the amount of contributions made by or accepted from any person other than the candidate was not to exceed 1,000; (2) contributions to candidates for some other state offices were to be limited to as little as 250; and (3) the statutory dollar amounts were to be adjusted each even-numbered year by taking into account the consumer price index. Thus, as of 1998, the limit was adjusted to 1,075 for contributions to candidates for statewide office, while the limit on contributions to candidates for some other state offices was adjusted to 275. A political action committee (PAC) gave a candidate for state auditor 1,025 in 1997 and another 50 in 1998. The PAC, alleging that it would have contributed more to the candidate's campaign but for the limitation--and the candidate, alleging that he could campaign effectively only with more generous contributions than those allowed by the statute--brought suit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri against various Missouri officials to enjoin enforcement of the statute as assertedly violating the Federal Constitution's First and Fourteenth Amendments. The District Court, in granting summary judgment in favor of the officials, (1) cited evidence including (a) an affidavit from a Missouri state senator--the co-chair of the legislature's campaign finance reform committee at the time that the contribution limits were enacted--who said that large contributions had the real potential to buy votes, and (b) newspaper reports supporting inferences of impropriety with respect to contributions to Missouri political figures; (2) found adequate support for the statute in the proposition that large contributions raised suspicions of influence peddling that tended to undermine citizens' confidence in the integrity of government; and (3) concluded that the case was controlled by Buckley v Valeo (1976) 424 US 1, 46 L Ed 2d 659, 96 S Ct 612, in which the United States Supreme Court had upheld the constitutionality of a federal statute establishing a 1,000 limitation on contributions to any single candidate for federal office (5 F Supp 2d 734). However, the Court of Appeals (1) enjoined enforcement of the law pending appeal (151 F3d 763); and (2) ultimately reversed and ordered a remand, as the Court of Appeals reasoned in part that Missouri's claim of a compelling interest in avoiding the corruption or the perception of corruption with respect to large campaign contributions was insufficient by itself to satisfy the requisite strict scrutiny (161 F3d 519, reh, en banc, den 1999 US App LEXIS 5241).

Congress passed the Natural Gas Act in 1938 to regulate the transportation and sale of natural gas in interstate commerce. To build an interstate pipeline, a natural gas company must obtain from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission a certificate reflecting that such construction ‚Äúis or will be required by the present or future public convenience and necessity.‚Äù 15 U. S. C. ¬ß717f(e). As originally enacted, the NGA did not provide a mechanism for certificate holders to secure property rights necessary to build pipelines, often leaving certificate holders with only an illusory right to build. Congress remedied this defect in 1947 by amending the NGA to authorize certificate holders to exercise the federal eminent domain power, thereby ensuring that certificates of public convenience and necessity could be given effect. See ¬ß717f(h). FERC granted petitioner PennEast Pipeline Co. a certificate of public convenience and necessity authorizing construction of a 116-mile pipeline from Pennsylvania to New Jersey. Several parties, including respondent New Jersey, petitioned for review of FERC‚Äôs order in the D. C. Circuit. The D. C. Circuit has held those proceedings in abeyance pending resolution of this case. PennEast filed various complaints in Federal District Court in New Jersey seeking to exercise the federal eminent domain power under ¬ß717f(h) to obtain rights-of-way along the pipeline route approved by FERC. As relevant here, PennEast sought to condemn parcels of land in which either New Jersey or the New Jersey Conservation Foundation asserts a property interest. New Jersey moved to dismiss PennEast‚Äôs complaints on sovereign immunity grounds. The District Court denied the motion, and it granted PennEast‚Äôs requests for a condemnation order and preliminary injunctive relief. The Third Circuit vacated the District Court‚Äôs order insofar as it awarded PennEast relief with respect to New Jersey‚Äôs property interests. The Third Circuit concluded that because ¬ß717f(h) did not clearly delegate to certificate holders the Federal Government‚Äôs ability to sue nonconsenting States, PennEast was not authorized to condemn New Jersey‚Äôs property.

The present action was brought in the District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania by the petitioner against the individual respondent and the corporate respondent (and two other defendants not involved in the appellate proceeding) to recover the value of bearer bonds issued by the Home Owners' Loan Corporation and allegedly stolen from their owner, the petitioner, and presented for collection by the individual respondent to and cashed by the corporate respondent in 1948. The bonds were due to mature on May 1, 1952, but pursuant to their terms, had been called on or about May 1, 1944. The questions material for the decision were (1) whether the bonds were overdue; (2) whether the burden of proof was on the petitioner to show notice and lack of good faith on the part of the respondents or on the respondents to show good faith on their part; and (3) whether the respondents acted in good faith.

Having been discharged from the Army and issued discharge certificates in form other than "honorable," petitioners separately instituted proceedings in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia seeking (1) judgments declaring that the Secretary of the Army, in effecting the discharges and issuing the discharge certificates after taking into account preinduction activities of petitioners rather than basing his action exclusively upon their military record, acted in excess of his powers, and (2) that the District Court direct the Secretary of the Army to issue them "honorable" discharge certificates. The District Court denied the relief sought, and the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit affirmed ( No. 80, 100 App DC 190, 243 F2d 613; No. 141, 100 App DC 256, 243 F2d 834).

A petition for mandamus was filed in the Court of Common Pleas of Ohio, challenging the validity of an Ohio statute which required signatures on a nominating petition for an independent candidate for the United States House of Representatives from 7 percent of the number of voters in the district who had voted in the last gubernatorial election. The petitioner, whose nominating petition bore only a little over one percent of the required voters' signatures, sought to compel the placing of his name on the ballot for the November 1968 election, urging the unconstitutionality of any percentage requirement in excess of one percent which the state had imposed prior to enactment of the 7 percent rule in 1952. The Court of Common Pleas, without passing on the merits, denied the writ of mandamus, ruling that the petitioner had not established a clear legal right to the extraordinary remedy under Ohio law. The Ohio Court of Appeals for the Eighth Judicial District affirmed, and the Supreme Court of Ohio dismissed the petitioner's appeal for want of a substantial constitutional question. Thereafter the election was held and the controlling statute was amended to reduce the signature requirement from 7 percent to 4 percent.

An amendment of the Georgia Constitution revoked an exemption from taxation granted to a Georgia corporation by a provision of the act under which it was incorporated. Injunctive and declaratory relief against the state revenue commissioner, who was threatening to collect ad valorem taxes from the corporation, was denied by the state courts solely on the ground that the action was, in effect, an unconsented suit against the state. Plaintiff's suit for injunctive relief in a federal district court was dismissed on the same ground.

In Ford v. Wainwright, 477 U.S. 399, 106 S.Ct. 2595, 91 L.Ed.2d 335, this Court held that the Eighth Amendment's ban on cruel and unusual punishments precludes executing a prisoner who has ‚Äúlost his sanity‚Äù after sentencing. Id., at 406, 106 S.Ct. 2595. And in Panetti v. Quarterman, 551 U.S. 930, 127 S.Ct. 2842, 168 L.Ed.2d 662, the Court set out the appropriate competency standard: A State may not execute a prisoner whose ‚Äúmental state is so distorted by a mental illness‚Äù that he lacks a ‚Äúrational understanding‚Äù of ‚Äúthe State's rationale for [his] execution.‚Äù Id., at 958‚Äì959, 127 S.Ct. 2842.
Petitioner Vernon Madison was found guilty of capital murder and sentenced to death. While awaiting execution, he suffered a series of strokes and was diagnosed with vascular dementia. In 2016, Madison petitioned the state trial court for a stay of execution on the ground that he was mentally incompetent, stressing that he could not recollect committing the crime for which he had been sentenced to die. Alabama responded that Madison had a rational understanding of the reasons for his execution, even assuming he had no memory of committing his crime. And more broadly, the State claimed that Madison failed to implicate Ford and Panetti because both decisions concerned themselves with gross delusions, which Madison did not have. Following a competency hearing, the trial court found Madison competent to be executed. On federal habeas review, this Court summarily reversed the Eleventh Circuit's grant of relief, holding that, under the ‚Äúdemanding‚Äù and ‚Äúdeferential standard‚Äù of the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996 (AEDPA), ‚Äú[n]either Panetti nor Ford ‚Äòclearly established‚Äô that a prisoner is incompetent to be executed‚Äù because of a simple failure to remember his crime. Dunn v. Madison, 583 U. S. ‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì, ‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì, 138 S.Ct. 9, 11‚Äì12, 199 L.Ed.2d 243. But the Court ‚Äúexpress[ed] no view‚Äù on the question of Madison's competency outside of the AEDPA context. Id., at ‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì, 138 S.Ct. at 12. When Alabama set a 2018 execution date, Madison returned to state court, arguing once more that his mental condition precluded the State from going forward. The state court again found Madison mentally competent.

The trustees of a fund that administered an employee benefit plan covered by the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) (29 USCS 1001 et seq.) brought against New York state health department officials an action alleging that a state statute that imposed a tax on medical centers' gross receipts from patient services "related to" the fund within the meaning of 514(a) of ERISA (29 USCS 1144(a))--which provides that ERISA supersedes state laws insofar as they relate to any employee benefit plan covered by ERISA--and was therefore pre-empted as applied to the two medical centers that the fund owned and operated in the state.
