After the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York denied the fund's request for a refund of the gross receipts tax that the fund had paid and for an injunction preventing future assessments of the tax against the fund, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, reversing the District Court judgment, expressed the view that the tax related to the fund, in that the tax reduced the amount of fund assets that otherwise would have been available for plan members' benefits (27 F3d 823). On certiorari, the United States Supreme Court (1) vacated the judgment of the Court of Appeals, and (2) remanded for further consideration in light of the Supreme Court's opinion in New York State Conference of Blue Cross & Blue Shield Plans v Travelers Ins. Co. (1995) 514 US 645, 131 L Ed 2d 695, 115 S Ct 1671, which held that 514(a) did not pre-empt a New York statute that imposed surcharges n hospitals' commercially insured patients (514 US 1094, 131 L Ed 2d 742, 115 S Ct 1819). On remand, the Court of Appeals, reinstating its original judgment, expressed the view that Travelers case involved only an indirect economic influence on the decisions of ERISA plan administrators, whereas the gross receipts tax depleted the fund's assets directly (74 F3d 28).

After an adult bookstore located in a borough's commercial zone introduced a coin-operated mechanism which permitted customers to watch a live dancer, usually nude, performing behind a glass panel, complaints were filed against the bookstore operators charging that the exhibition of live dancing violated the borough's zoning ordinance which governed uses permitted in a commercial zone. The bookstore operators were found guilty in a municipal court, and were also found guilty on appeal in the Camden, New Jersey, County Court. In response to the bookstore operators' defense based on the First and Fourteenth Amendments, the court recognized that live nude dancing was protected by the First Amendment, but ruled that First Amendment guarantees were not involved. The Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division, affirmed the bookstore operators' convictions, and the Supreme Court of New Jersey denied further review.

A writ of certiorari granted to review a judgment of the Supreme Court of South Carolina was dismissed on the grounds appearing in the headnote, infra. (235 SC 356, 111 SE2d 657.) Prosecution for homicide. The General Sessions Court of Dillon County, T. B. Greneker, J., entered judgment of conviction and defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, Moss, J., held that under circumstances refusing motion for continuance made upon call of case for trial was not erroneous and circumstances surrounding alleged confessions of defendant presented a jury issue as to voluntariness of confessions.

On December 17, 2009, the Ninth Circuit Judicial Council issued a news release indicating that it had approved a pilot program for the limited use of cameras in federal district courts within the circuit. On December 21, a coalition of media companies requested permission from the District Court to televise the trial challenging Proposition 8 which amended the California Constitution to provide that only marriage between a man and a woman was valid. Two days later, the District Court indicated on its Web site that it had amended N.D. Cal. Civ. R. 77-3, which had previously banned the recording or broadcast of court proceedings. On January 9, 2010, defendant-intervenors filed their application for a stay of the District Court's order pending resolution of forthcoming petitions for the writs of certiorari and mandamus. A bench trial began on January 11, 2010. The Court concluded that the District Court's amendment of its local rules to broadcast the trial likely did not comply with federal law and that defendant-intervenors demonstrated that irreparable harm would likely have resulted from the District Court's actions. No harm was alleged if the trial was not broadcast.

Having filed notice of a lien for state unemployment compensation taxes under Jones Ill. Stat. Ann., 1944, _ 45.154, creating a lien "upon all the personal property" of an employer "used by him in connection with his . . . business," the state Director of Labor brought suit in a state court to enforce the lien, alleging that the employer was insolvent and that a creditor had obtained judgment and execution against him subsequent to the filing of notice of the lien. The court enjoined all creditors from interfering with the employer's property and appointed a receiver, who took charge of all his assets. Thereafter, the Collector of Internal Revenue filed claims on behalf of the United States for federal social security taxes under _ 1400 of the Internal Revenue Code and an intervening petition alleging that the debtor was insolvent and claiming priority of payment. The receiver liquidated all of the debtor's assets and realized less than enough to satisfy the claims of creditors.

A federal prisoner, while confined in a county jail pending trial, committed suicide by hanging himself with a noose fashioned from a bandage which had been applied to a laceration on his arm. The laceration had occurred when the prisoner had previously attempted to commit suicide by slashing veins in his arm. After the prisoner's death, his parents sued the United States for damages under the Federal Tort Claims Act, alleging that negligence on the part of government agents and employees had proximately caused the death. Awarding the plaintiffs a judgment for damages, the United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas held that employees of the county jail were negligent in providing inadequate surveillance of the prisoner, that the deputy United States marshal who had arrested the prisoner was negligent in failing to make specific arrangements for constant surveillance of the prisoner, and that the United States was bound by the negligent acts of both the county jail employees and the deputy marshal (334 F Supp 322). The Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit reversed, holding that since the county jail was a "contractor with the United States" and therefore fell within an exclusion from the coverage of the Federal Tort Claims Act, the United States could not be held liable for the negligence of the county jail employees, and that since there was no support in the record for holding that the deputy marshal had any power or authority to control any of the internal functions of the county jail, the deputy marshal violated no duty of safekeeping with respect to the prisoner (459 F2d 408, 463 F2d 1340).

The Civil Aeronautics Act provides that orders of the Civil Aeronautics Board which grant or deny applications by citizens to engage in overseas and foreign air transportation shall be subject to the approval of the President.

A corporation which was organized under Delaware law and which had its principal office in Connecticut initiated a cash tender offer for all outstanding shares of an Illinois corporation by filing a certain schedule with the Securities and Exchange Commission in order to comply with the Williams Act (15 USCS 78m(d)-(e) and 78n(d)-(f)). The corporation did not comply with the Illinois business takeover statute--which required that a takeover offer be registered with the Secretary of State if Illinois shareholder owned 10 percent or more of the target company and instead filed an action in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, asking for a declaratory judgment that the Illinois statute was preempted by the Williams Act and violated the commerce clause of the United States Constitution (Art I, 8, cl 3). The corporation also sought a temporary restraining order and an injunction prohibiting the Illinois Secretary of State from enforcing the Illinois statute. The District Court issued a preliminary injunction prohibiting enforcement of the statute against the tender offer, and the corporation then published its tender offer. Subsequently the District Court entered final judgment, declaring that the Illinois statute was preempted by the Williams Act and violated the commerce clause, and permanently enjoined enforcement of the statute against the corporation. The corporation and the target company then entered into an agreement whereby the corporation's tender offer and an offer made by the target company were withdrawn, under which agreement the corporation was either to make a tender offer at a certain price per share or decide not to acquire the target company. The corporation subsequently announced its decision not to make a tender offer. The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit affirmed, agreeing with the District Court that several provisions of the Illinois statute were preempted by the Williams Act and that it unduly burdened interstate commerce in violation of the commerce clause (633 F2d 486).

A complaint in a suit brought in a state court under the Federal Employers' Liability Act charged that the defendant's negligence caused the deceased to perform additional work of the same kind as he normally performed. It was not alleged that this additional work contained any hazards other than those usual to the occupation. The state court sustained a demurrer to the complaint on the ground that the injury did not result proximately, in whole or in part, from the defendant's negligence.

The holder of a United States patent brought a patent infringement suit in the United States District Court for the District of Oregon against a Canadian corporation, predicating venue on the provision of 28 USCS 1391(d) that "an alien may be sued in any district." The court dismissed the complaint on the ground of improper venue, holding that 28 USCS 1400(b) is the exclusive provision governing venue in patent infringement litigation. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit reversed (442 F2d 420).

State departments of motor vehicles (DMVs) required drivers and automobile owners to provide personal information--which may have included a person's name, address, telephone number, vehicle description, Social Security number, medical information, and photograph--as a condition of obtaining a driver's license or registering an automobile. Congress, finding that many states, in turn, sold this personal information to individuals and businesses, enacted the Driver's Privacy Protection Act (DPPA) (18 USCS 2721-2725), which (1) generally prohibited any state DMV, or officer, employee, or contractor thereof, from knowingly disclosing or otherwise making available to any person or entity personal information about any individual obtained by the department in connection with a motor vehicle record; (2) provided that (a) the ban on disclosure of personal information did not apply if drivers had consented to the release of their data, and (b) the prohibition of nonconsensual disclosures was subject to a number of statutory exceptions; (3) regulated the resale and redisclosure of drivers' personal information by private persons who obtained that information from a state DMV; and (4) established several penalties to be imposed on states and private actors that failed to comply with the DPPA's requirements. South Carolina law--under which the information contained in the state's DMV records was available to any person or entity that filled out a form listing the requester's name and address and stating that the information would not be used for telephone solicitation--conflicted with the DPPA. South Carolina and its attorney general filed suit in the United States District Court for the District of South Carolina, and alleged that the DPPA violated the Federal Constitution's Tenth and Eleventh Amendments. The District Court (1) concluded that the DPPA was incompatible with the principles of federalism inherent in the Constitution's division of power between the states and the Federal Government, (2) granted summary judgment for South Carolina, and (3) permanently enjoined the DPPA's enforcement against South Carolina and its officers (972 F Supp 977). The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit affirmed the decision of the District Court (155 F3d 453).

The plaintiff, a special consultant in the United States Public Health Service, was twice cleared from charges of disloyalty by the loyalty board of the agency employing him. Thereafter the Loyalty Review Board, on its own motion, conducted a "post-audit" of the agency board's determination and found that there was a reasonable doubt as to plaintiff's loyalty. This determination was based on information supplied by informants whose identity was not disclosed to the plaintiff, and, as to some informants, was not known even to the Board; the information given by these informants had not been given under oath. The chairman of the Board advised plaintiff that he had been barred from the federal service for a period of three years. The plaintiff brought suit, in which the principal relief sought was a declaration that his removal and debarment from federal employment were invalid. He contended that the action taken against him was in violation of Executive Order No. 9835, which established the Loyalty Review Board, and in violation of the Constitution of the United States in that he was denied any opportunity to confront and cross-examine his secret accusers.

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) proposed a rule in 2011 regarding ‚Äúcooling water intake structures‚Äù used to cool industrial equipment. 76 Fed. Reg. 22174. Because aquatic wildlife can become trapped in these intake structures and die, the Endangered Species Act of 1973 required the EPA to consult with the U. S. Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) and National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS) (together, the Services) before proceeding. Following this required consultation, the Services prepare an official ‚Äúbiological opinion‚Äù (known as a ‚Äújeopardy‚Äù or ‚Äúno jeopardy‚Äù biological opinion) addressing whether the agency‚Äôs proposal will jeopardize the existence of threatened or endangered species. 50 CFR ¬ß402.14(h)(1)(iv). Issuance of a ‚Äújeopardy‚Äù biological opinion here would require the EPA either to implement certain alternatives proposed by the Services, to terminate the action altogether, or to seek an exemption. 16 U. S. C. ¬ß¬ß1536(b)(4), (g), 1538(a). After consulting with the Services, the EPA made changes to its proposed rule, and the Services received the revised version in November 2013. Staff members at NMFS and FWS soon completed draft biological opinions concluding that the November 2013 proposed rule was likely to jeopardize certain species. Staff members sent these drafts to the relevant decisionmakers within each agency, but decisionmakers at the Services neither approved the drafts nor sent them to the EPA. The Services instead shelved the draft opinions and agreed with the EPA to extend the period of consultation. After these continued discussions, the EPA sent the Services a revised proposed rule in March 2014 that differed significantly from the 2013 version. Satisfied that the revised rule was unlikely to harm any protected species, the Services issued a joint final ‚Äúno jeopardy‚Äù biological opinion. The EPA issued its final rule that same day. Respondent Sierra Club, an environmental organization, submitted requests under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) for records related to the Services‚Äô consultations with the EPA. As relevant here, the Services invoked the deliberative process privilege to prevent disclosure of the draft biological opinions analyzing the EPA‚Äôs 2013 proposed rule. The Sierra Club sued to obtain these withheld documents, and the Ninth Circuit held that the draft biological opinions were not privileged because even though labeled as drafts, the draft opinions represented the Services‚Äô final opinion regarding the EPA‚Äôs 2013 proposed rule.

Prior to acquiring through merger various railroad lines, including the line on which the plaintiffs were employees, the defendant railroad entered into an agreement with several labor unions for the protection of the employees on the railroad lines which were to be acquired. The agreement provided that the employees of these lines would not be adversely affected in their employment as a result of the merger, and specific provisions were included for compensation of those employees, including the plaintiffs, whose postmerger earnings would be lower than their premerger earnings. In its order approving the merger, the Interstate Commerce Commission stated that the agreement respecting the rights of the employees was made pursuant to and in conformity with 5(2)(f) of the Interstate Commerce Act, which provides that as a condition to the Commission's approval of a railroad merger, the Commission shall require a fair and equitable arrangement to protect the interests of the employees affected by the merger, and that in the order of approval of the merger, the Commission shall include terms and conditions providing that the merger will not result in such employees being in a worse position with respect to their employment. After the merger went into effect, the plaintiffs were not paid the compensation promised, and when they were about to obtain arbitration, their union and the defendant entered into a new agreement which reduced substantially the compensation payable to the plaintiffs. The union refused to arbitrate the plaintiffs' claim that they were entitled to the compensation provided under the premerger agreement, and the plaintiffs then sued for damages in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Ohio. The District Court held the postmerger agreement invalid and upheld the plaintiffs' right of action (287 F Supp 221, 309 F Supp 575). The Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit affirmed (436 F2d 841).

The Telecommunications Act of 1996 requires incumbent local exchange carriers (LECs)‚Äîi.e., providers of local telephone service‚Äîto share their physical networks with competitive LECs at cost-based rates in two ways relevant here. First, 47 U. S. C. ¬ß251(c)(3) requires an incumbent LEC to lease ‚Äúon an unbundled basis‚Äù‚Äîi.e., a la carte‚Äînetwork elements specified by the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to allow a competitor to create its own network without having to build every element from scratch. In identifying those elements, the FCC must consider whether access is ‚Äúnecessary‚Äù and whether failing to provide it would ‚Äúimpair‚Äù the competitor‚Äôs provision of service. ¬ß251(d)(2). Second, ¬ß251(c)(2) mandates that incumbent LECs ‚Äúprovide ‚Ä¶ interconnection‚Äù between their networks and competitive LECs‚Äô to ensure that a competitor‚Äôs customers can call the incumbent‚Äôs customers, and vice versa. The interconnection duty is independent of the unbundling rules and not subject to impairment analysis. In 2003, the FCC issued its Triennial Review Order deciding, contrary to previous orders, that ¬ß251(c)(3) did not require an incumbent LEC to provide a competitive LEC with cost-based unbundled access to existing ‚Äúentrance facilities‚Äù‚Äîi.e., transmission facilities (typically wires or cables) that connect the two LECs‚Äô networks‚Äîbecause such facilities are not network elements at all. The FCC noted, however, that entrance facilities are used for both interconnection and backhauling, and it emphasized that its order did not alter incumbent LECs‚Äô ¬ß251(c)(2) obligation to provide for interconnection. Thus, the practical effect of the order was only that incumbent LECs were not obligated to unbundle entrance facilities for backhauling purposes. In 2005, following D. C. Circuit review, the FCC issued its Triennial Review Remand Order. The FCC retreated from the view that entrance facilities are not network elements, but adhered to its previous position that cost-based unbundled access to such facilities need not be provided under ¬ß251(c)(3). Treating entrance facilities as network elements, the FCC concluded that competitive LECs are not impaired without access to such facilities. The FCC again emphasized that competitive LECs‚Äô ¬ß251(c)(2) right to obtain interconnection had not been altered. In the Remand Order‚Äôs wake, respondent AT&T notified competitive LECs that it would no longer provide entrance facilities at cost-based rates for either backhauling or interconnection, but would instead charge higher rates. Competitive LECs complained to the Michigan Public Service Commission that AT&T was unlawfully abrogating their ¬ß251(c)(2) right to cost-based interconnection. The Michigan Public Service Commission agreed and ordered AT&T to continue providing entrance facilities for interconnection at cost-based rates. AT&T challenged the ruling. Relying on the Remand Order, the Federal District Court ruled in AT&T‚Äôs favor. The Sixth Circuit affirmed, declining to defer to the FCC‚Äôs argument that the order did not change incumbent LECs‚Äô interconnection obligations, including the obligation to lease entrance facilities for interconnection.

A tenth grade student left school without permission and, with four other students, consumed alcohol and became intoxicated. When he returned to school later that day to go on a band trip, he was notified that he was suspended from school. At a hearing before the local school board, the board voted to expel all five students for the remainder of the semester. The student immediately sought injunctive relief under 42 USCS 1983 in the United States District Court forthe Western District of Arkansas, which decided that the school board had violated the student's right to substantive due process. The District Court found that the board had acted under one of its rules, which provides for mandatory suspension of students who, on school premises, use, sell, are under the influence of, or possess narcotics or other hallucinogenics, drugs, or controlled substances, and concluded that alcohol is not included in any of these categories and that, therefore, the board had acted unreasonably by suspending the student under the rule. The United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit affirmed (662 F2d 1263).

Inter partes review authorizes the United States Patent and Trademark Office **1368 (PTO) to reconsider and cancel an already-issued patent claim in limited circumstances. See 35 U.S.C. ¬ß¬ß 311‚Äì319. Any person who is not the owner of the patent may petition for review. ¬ß 311(a). If review is instituted, the process entitles the petitioner and the patent owner to conduct certain discovery, ¬ß 316(a)(5); to file affidavits, declarations, and written memoranda, ¬ß 316(a)(8); and to receive an oral hearing before the Patent Trial and Appeal Board, ¬ß 316(a)(10). A final decision by the Board is subject to Federal Circuit review. ¬ß¬ß 318, 319.
Petitioner Oil States Energy Services, LLC, obtained a patent relating to technology for protecting wellhead equipment used in hydraulic fracturing. It sued respondent Greene's Energy Group, LLC, in Federal District Court for infringement. Greene's Energy challenged the patent's validity in the District Court and also petitioned the PTO for inter partes review. Both proceedings progressed in parallel. The District Court issued a claim-construction order favoring Oil States, while the Board issued a decision concluding that Oil States' claims were unpatentable. Oil States appealed to the Federal Circuit. In addition to its patentability arguments, it challenged the constitutionality of inter partes review, arguing that actions to revoke a patent must be tried in an Article III court before a jury. While the case was pending, the Federal Circuit issued a decision in a separate case, rejecting the same constitutional arguments raised by Oil States. The court then summarily affirmed the Board's decision in this case.

An individual was convicted of murder in Superior Court, Bleckley County, Georgia, and the sentencing jury imposed the death penalty after finding three aggravating circumstances set forth in the Georgia death penalty statute. On direct appeal, the Supreme Court of Georgia affirmed, setting aside the second statutory aggravating circumstance found by the jury, but upholding the death sentence on the ground that in the case under review the evidence supported the jury's findings of the other statutory aggravating circumstances, so that the death sentence was not impaired (237 Ga 259, 227 SE2d 261). After exhausting his state post-conviction remedies, the prisoner applied for a writ of habeas corpus in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Georgia. The District Court denied relief, but the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit reversed the District Court's denial of habeas corpus relief insofar as it left standing the prisoner's death sentence and remanded for further proceedings (631 F2d 397, modified 648 F2d 446).

The Supreme Court of Louisiana having disbarred an attorney who had committed a forgery, notwithstanding that it was conceded that he was, at the time of the forgery, suffering from some degree of insanity, the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana ordered that the attorney be stricken from its rolls, and the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit affirmed the order (228 F2d 617).

Challenging the constitutionality of provisions of Pennsylvania statutes governing the admission and commitment of a person 18 years of age or younger to a state mental health institution upon parental consent over the objection of such juvenile, five individuals who alleged that they were being held at a state mental health facility and that they had been admitted or committed pursuant to the challenged provisions, brought an action on behalf of themselves and a class in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania. The District Court determined that the action was maintainable as a class action under Rule 23 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure on behalf of "all persons eighteen years of age or younger who have been, are or may be admitted or committed to mental health facilities in Pennsylvania pursuant to the challenged provisions," notwithstanding that after the commencement of the action, state regulations had been promulgated which accorded significant procedural protection to those juveniles 13 years of age and older in regard to their admission and commitment to mental institutions. Thereafter, the District Court held that the challenged provisions violated the Fourteenth Amendment's due process clause (402 F Supp 1039).

A military doctor who was working at a United States Army hospital in Italy served as attending physician to an Army sergeant's wife during the delivery of the couple's son. In 1987, the couple filed a federal diversity suit against the doctor in the United States District Court for the Central District of California and alleged that the doctor's negligence during the delivery caused the son to be born with massive brain damage. The Federal Government (1) sought to have itself substituted for the doctor as the defendant pursuant to the Gonzalez Act, which provides, in 10 USCS 1089(a), that, in suits against military medical personnel for torts committed within the scope of their employment, (a) the Federal Government is to be substituted as the defendant, and (b) the suit is to proceed against the Federal Government under the Federal Tort Claims Act (FTCA) (28 USCS 2671 et seq.); and (2) argued that action should be dismissed, because (a) the action had arisen overseas, and (b) therefore, Federal Government liability was precluded by the FTCA's exception (28 USCS 2680(k)) excluding recovery for injuries sustained abroad. The District Court granted the Federal Government's motion for substitution and dismissed the action. While the couple's appeal was pending, Congress enacted the Federal Employees Liability Reform and Tort Compensation Act of 1988 (the 1988 Act), which (1) was made applicable to all proceedings pending on the date of enactment; and (2) generally provided, in 28 USCS 2679(b)(1), that the remedy against the United States under the FTCA is exclusive of any other civil action or proceeding for money damages by persons injured by Federal Government employees acting within the scope of their employment. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, however, in reversing and remanding, expressed the view that neither the Gonzalez Act nor the 1988 Act required the Federal Government's substitution as the defendant in the case at hand or otherwise immunized the doctor in question from liability, because (1) the Gonzalez Act (a) made the FTCA the exclusive remedy only for malpractice committed by stateside military medical personnel, and (b) left foreign-based military medical personnel like the doctor subject to malpractice liability; and (2) the 1988 Act's exclusive remedy (a) applied only when the FTCA in fact provided a remedy, and (b) thus, did not apply in the case at hand, as a result of 2680(k)'s exclusion of any FTCA remedy (885 F2d 650).

In January 2019, the Department of Homeland Security began to implement the Migrant Protection Protocols (MPP). Under MPP, certain non-Mexican nationals arriving by land from Mexico were returned to Mexico to await the results of their removal proceedings under section 1229a of the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA). MPP was implemented pursuant to a provision of the INA that applies to aliens ‚Äúarriving on land . . . from a foreign territory contiguous to the United States‚Äù and provides that the Secretary of Homeland Security ‚Äúmay return the alien to that territory pending a proceeding under section 1229a.‚Äù 8 U. S. C. ¬ß1225(b)(2)(C). Following a change in Presidential administrations, the Biden administration announced that it would suspend the program, and on June 1, 2021, the Secretary of Homeland Security issued a memorandum officially terminating it. The States of Texas and Missouri (respondents) brought suit in the Northern District of Texas against the Secretary and others, asserting that the June 1 Memorandum violated the INA and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA). The District Court entered judgment for respondents. The court first concluded that terminating MPP would violate the INA, reasoning that section 1225 of the INA ‚Äúprovides the government two options‚Äù with respect to illegal entrants: mandatory detention pursuant to section 1225(b)(2)(A) or contiguous-territory return pursuant to section 1225(b)(2)(C). 554 F. Supp. 3d 818, 852. Because the Government was unable to meet its mandatory detention obligations under section 1225(b)(2)(A) due to resource constraints, the court reasoned, terminating MPP would necessarily lead to the systemic violation of section 1225 as illegal entrants were released into the United States. Second, the District Court concluded that the June 1 Memorandum was arbitrary and capricious in violation of the APA. The District Court vacated the June 1 Memorandum and remanded to DHS. It also imposed a nationwide injunction ordering the Government to ‚Äúenforce and implement MPP in good faith until such a time as it has been lawfully rescinded in compliance with the APA and until such a time as the federal government has sufficient detention capacity to detain all aliens subject to mandatory detention under [section 1225] without releasing any aliens because of a lack of detention resources.‚Äù Id., at 857 (emphasis in original). While the Government‚Äôs appeal was pending, the Secretary released the October 29 Memoranda, which again announced the termination of MPP and explained anew his reasons for doing so. The Government then moved to vacate the injunction on the ground that the October 29 Memoranda had superseded the June 1 Memorandum. But the Court of Appeals denied the motion and instead affirmed the District Court‚Äôs judgment in full. With respect to the INA question, the Court of Appeals agreed with the District Court‚Äôs analysis that terminating the program would violate the INA, concluding that the return policy was mandatory so long as illegal entrants were being released into the United States. The Court of Appeals also held that ‚Äú[t]he October 29 Memoranda did not constitute a new and separately reviewable ‚Äòfinal agency action.‚Äô ‚Äù 20 F. 4th 928, 951.

Pursuant to the Trading with the Enemy Act, as amended by the First War Powers Act of 1941, and Executive Order 9095, as amended, the Alien Property Custodian issued an order vesting in himself title to certain shares of stock in petitioner, a Delaware corporation, and directing petitioner to cancel the certificates for such stock outstanding on its books and to issue new certificates to the Custodian. The order contained a finding that, although prior to August 31, 1939, the shares stood on the books of petitioner in the name of a Swiss corporation, they were held for the benefit of a German corporation, and constituted property belonging to a national of Germany. It was contended that the shares were pledged to certain Swiss banks as collateral for a loan.

An individual who confessed that he made false reports to the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) that his wife had been kidnapped, and also to the United States Secret Service that his wife was involved in a plot to kill the President, was charged in a two-count indictment with making false statements to the FBI and the Secret Service in violation of 18 USCS 1001, which makes it a crime to knowingly and willfully make a false statement "in any matter within the jurisdiction of any department or agency of the United States." The accused moved to dismiss the indictment on the grounds that the investigations conducted by the FBI and the Secret Service in connection with his false reports were not matters "within the jurisdiction" of the respective agencies, as that phrase is used in 1001. The District Court for the Western District of Missouri granted the motion, and the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit affirmed, adhering to its decision in a prior case that the phrase "within the jurisdiction" referred only to the "power to make final or binding determinations" (706 F2d 854).

The plaintiff brought the present action under the Federal Employers' Liability Act in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York to recover damages for an industrial disease he allegedly contracted in 1952 while working for the defendant. The action was brought after the statutory 3-year period of limitation ( 6 of the act) had lapsed, but plaintiff claimed that defendant was estopped from raising this limitation because it had induced the delay by representing to him that he had 7 years in which to sue. The District Court dismissed the action on the ground that the defense of estoppel is not available against the statute of limitations contained in the Federal Employers' Liability Act, the statutory provision being an integral part of a new cause of action created by that act. (154 F Supp 863.) The Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit affirmed. (253 F2d 957.)

A group of participants in the Foreign Service retirement system brought an action in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, alleging that 632 of the Foreign Service Act of 1946 (22 USCS 1002), which mandates the retirement at age 60 of participants in the Foreign Service retirement system, violates the equal protection component of the due process clause of the Fifth Amendment. The three-judge District Court held that the distinction between retirement for federal employees covered by the Foreign Service retirement system and that for federal employees generally--who, under the Civil Service retirement system, do not have to retire at age 60--was invalid (436 F Supp 134).

A state prisoner who had been convicted of murder in a New Jersey trial court sought a writ of habeas corpus in the United States District Court for the District of New Jersey, alleging that his confession to the murder was not voluntary. The District Court dismissed the petition without an evidentiary hearing. The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit affirmed, holding that the voluntariness of a confession is a "factual issue" within the meaning of 28 USCS 2254(d), which provides that state-court findings of fact, with certain exceptions, "shall be presumed to be correct" in a federal habeas corpus proceedings, and that accordingly federal review of the New Jersey Supreme Court's determination that the prisoner's confession was voluntary was limited to whether that court applied the proper legal test and whether its factual conclusions were supported by the record. Under this standard, the Court of Appeals concluded that the District Court's denial of the habeas corpus petition was proper (741 F2d 1456).

Petitioners are primarily nonprofit organizations that provide health insurance to their employees. Federal regulations require petitioners to cover certain contraceptives as part of their health plans, unless petitioners submit a form either to their insurer or to the Federal Government, stating that they object on religious grounds to providing contraceptive coverage. Petitioners allege that submitting this notice substantially burdens the exercise of their religion, in violation of the Religious Freedom Restoration Act of 1993, 107 Stat. 1488, 42 U. S. C. ¬ß2000bb et seq. Following oral argument, the Court requested supplemental briefing from the parties addressing "whether contraceptive coverage could be provided to petitioners' employees, through petitioners' insurance companies, without any such notice from petitioners." Post, p. Both petitioners and the Government now confirm that such an option is feasible. Petitioners have clarified that their religious exercise is not infringed where they "need to do nothing more than contract for a plan that does not include coverage for some or all forms of contraception," even if their employees receive cost-free contraceptive coverage from the same insurance company. Supplemental Brief for Petitioners 4. The Government has confirmed that the challenged procedures "for employers with insured plans could be modified to operate in the manner posited in the Court's order while still ensuring that the affected women receive contraceptive coverage seamlessly, together with the rest of their health coverage."

At his trial in a Kentucky state court on various criminal charges, the defendant did not testify. At the close of testimony, the defendant's counsel requested that an admonition be given to the jury that no emphasis be given to the defendant's failure to testify. This request was denied and the defendant was convicted. On appeal, the Kentucky Supreme Court conceded that under Carter v Kentucky (1981) 450 US 288, 67 L Ed 2d 241, 101 S Ct 1112, the defendant was entitled to an instruction that the jury should not draw an adverse inference from the defendant's failure to testify, but it held that since the defendant did not ask for such an instruction, and since there was a vast difference between an instruction and an admonition, the trial court properly denied the request for an admonition (647 SW2d 794).

The district court enhanced a lodestar award by 75%. The case presented the question whether the calculation of an attorney's fee, under federal fee-shifting statutes, based on the lodestar could have been increased due to superior performance and results. There was a strong presumption that the lodestar figure was reasonable, but that presumption could have been overcome in those rare circumstances in which the lodestar did not adequately take into account a factor that properly may have been considered in determining a reasonable fee. The Supreme Court found that there were a few circumstances in which superior attorney performance was not adequately taken into account in the lodestar calculation, but these circumstances were rare and exceptional, and required specific evidence that the lodestar fee would not have been adequate to attract competent counsel. For example, an enhancement could have been appropriate where the method used in determining the hourly rate employed in the lodestar calculation did not adequately measure the attorney's true market value. The district court did not provide proper justification for the large enhancement that it awarded.

In 1984, a collision between a car and a truck occurred in Ashtabula County, Ohio. More than 3 years later, a passenger of the car who had been injured in the collision brought a negligence action in the Ashtabula County Court of Common Pleas against the truck driver and its owner. The truck driver was a resident of Pennsylvania, and the owner was a Pennsylvania corporation which was not licensed to do business in Ohio. At the time of the collision, the limitations period for personal injury actions was 2 years; however, an Ohio statute tolled the running of such period for claims against out-of-state defendants. While the passenger's action was pending, the United States Supreme Court held in Bendix Autolite Corp. v Midwesco Enterprises, Inc. (1988) 486 US 888, 100 L Ed 2d 896, 108 S Ct 2218, that the Ohio tolling provision placed an unconstitutional burden upon interstate commerce. Thereafter, the Court of Common Pleas, dismissing the passenger's action as untimely, held that in light of Bendix Autolite Corp. v Midwesco Enterprises, Inc., the tolling provision could not constitutionally be applied. On appeal, the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh Appellate District, affirmed the dismissal (1992 Ohio App LEXIS 3453). Allowing a motion to certify the record, the Supreme Court of Ohio, reversing, expressed the view that Bendix Autolite Corp. v Midwesco Enterprises, Inc. could not retroactively be applied to bar claims in state courts which had accrued prior to the announcement of that decision (68 Ohio St 3d 240, 626 NE2d 75).

In 1966, police officers, after arresting for possession of narcotics two men who were driving the defendant's car, found in the car some property which had been stolen in a recent robbery. The two men admitted taking part in the robbery, implicated the defendant, told the police where the defendant's apartment was, and stated that some stolen property and the guns used in the robbery were in the apartment. Some officers, having received a description of the defendant and having gone to the apartment to arrest him, knocked on the door, and it was opened by a man who met the defendant's description. The officers arrested this man, but he denied that he was the defendant, and he produced identification showing who he was. Nevertheless, the officers, mistakenly believing that the arrestee was the defendant, proceeded to search the entire apartment and found a revolver and masks, property stolen in the robbery, and two pages of the defendant's diary containing a full confession of his participation in the robbery. The evidence found in the apartment was admitted at the defendant's trial in a California state court, the trial judge concluding that the officers had believed in good faith that the arrestee was the defendant. The defendant was convicted of robbery, and the California Supreme Court, affirming the conviction, held that the arrest at the apartment was valid, and that neither the defendant's absence nor the arrestee's lack of control of the premises vitiated the search, since the officers had a reasonable and good-faith belief that the arrestee was the defendant and that the arrestee controlled the premises (69 Cal 2d 550, 72 Cal Rptr 641, 446 P2d 521).

A 17-year-old, who was accused of brutally beating and stabbing to death his physically impaired cousin and foster mother while robbing her of $ 15, was tried as an adult and convicted in a Missouri court on a charge of capital murder. At a conference preceding the penalty phase of the trial, one of the accused's attorneys (1) moved for an order prohibiting the prosecution from cross-examining defense witnesses with regard to the accused's juvenile record; and (2) requested that the jury be instructed on the statutory mitigating circumstance that the accused had no significant history of prior criminal activity, even though the attorney also stated that she would not try to show that the accused lacked a criminal past. The trial judge never expressly ruled on the first motion, but did rule that the accused would not be entitled to the requested instruction without supporting evidence, and refused to give the instruction when no such evidence was submitted by either side. The accused was sentenced to death. In affirming the accused's conviction and sentence on direct review, the Supreme Court of Missouri held that, in the absence of evidence to support the statutory mitigating circumstance, the trial court had correctly refused the requested instruction (667 SW2d 712). Subsequently, the accused filed a petition for a writ of habeas corpus in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri and alleged in part that the trial judge's failure to give the requested instruction violated due process. The District Court ruled that the accused's conviction and sentence were not invalid under the Federal Constitution. On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit reversed with respect to the accused's sentence and remanded with instructions to grant the writ unless the state timely commenced resentencing proceedings, as the Court of Appeals ruled that the trial judge had violated the Constitution's Eighth Amendment by refusing to give the requested instruction (957 F2d 1495).

An association of Florida nursing homes brought an action in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida against the Department of Health, Education, and Welfare and the Florida Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services, arguing that a delay in enforcement until January 1, 1978 of an amendment to the Medicaid Act (42 USCS 1396a(a)(13)(E)) requiring participating states to reimburse nursing facilities on a cost-related basis was inconsistent with the statutory directive that such reimbursements begin on July 1, 1976, and seeking retroactive relief in the form of payments by the state of the difference between the reimbursement they had received and the amounts they would have received under a cost-related system. The District Court held invalid the HEW regulations creating the delay and, after consolidating the case with another one before it, held that retroactive relief was barred by the Eleventh Amendment. On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit affirmed the ruling that the regulations were invalid, but reversed the District Court's determination that retroactive relief was barred, finding the requisite state consent to retroactive monetary relief against it in a federal court in a state statute providing that the Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services is a "body corporate" with the capacity to "sue and be sued" and in an agreement under the Medicaid Act in which the state agency agreed to "recognize and abide by all State and Federal Laws, Regulations, and Guidelines applicable to participation in, and administration of, the Title XIX Medicaid Program" (616 F2d 1355).

Pre-1988 Medicaid eligibility rules for married applicants often required both spouses to deplete their combined resources before a spouse who was institutionalized, as in a nursing home, became eligible for benefits. In order to prevent the pauperization of the "community spouse"--that is, the spouse remaining at home--the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act of 1988 (MCCA) (42 USCS 1396r-5 et seq.) (1) directed that, in any month in which one spouse was institutionalized, no income of the community spouse was to be deemed available to the institutionalized spouse ( 1396r-5(b)(1)); (2) required states to set a "minimum monthly maintenance needs allowance" (MMMNA) for the community spouse ( 1396r-5(d)(3)); and (3) prescribed that, if the community spouse's posteligibility income was insufficient to yield income equal to or above the MMMNA, the shortfall--called the "community spouse monthly income allowance" (CSMIA)--could be deducted from the institutionalized spouse's income and paid to the community spouse ( 1396r-5(d)(1)(B)). In determining the institutionalized spouse's Medicaid eligibility, a portion of the couple's resources--called the "community spouse resource allowance" (CSRA)--was to be reserved for the benefit of the community spouse ( 1396r-5(c)(2)). Under 1396r-5(e)(2)(C), a couple could obtain a higher CSRA by establishing that the standard CSRA was inadequate to raise "the community spouse's income" to the MMMNA. An administrative hearing for such a purpose was authorized by 1396r-5(e)(2)(A)(v). To calculate the CSRA at such a hearing, some states used an "income-first" method, under which the state considered whether the community spouse's income, including potential CSMIA transfers from the institutionalized spouse, would suffice to enable the community spouse to meet monthly needs once the institutionalized spouse qualified for Medicaid. Other states used a "resources-first" method that excluded such potential income transfers from consideration. After entering a Wisconsin nursing home, a wife applied for Medicaid. The Green County, Wisconsin, department of human services (1) determined (using figures as subsequently corrected somewhat) that the wife and her husband could retain $ 74,822 in assets--$ 72,822 as the husband's standard CSRA and $ 2,000 as the wife's personal allowance; (2) found that, as of the date of the application, the couple possessed resources exceeding their $ 74,822 limit by $ 14,513; and (3) concluded that the wife would not be eligible for Medicaid until the couple's spending reduced their resources by the $ 14,513 amount. The wife sought a hearing before Wisconsin's department of health and family services in order to obtain a higher CSRA for the husband, on the grounds that the husband's monthly income fell below the applicable MMMNA. The hearing examiner, applying a Wisconsin statute that adopted the income-first rule, concluded that he lacked authority to increase the CSRA. Wisconsin's Department of Industry, Labor and Human Relations affirmed the hearing examiner's decision, and the Circuit Court for Green County affirmed. However, the Wisconsin Court of Appeals--in reversing the Circuit Court's order and in directing a remand--concluded that (1) the MCCA mandated the resources-first method, and (2) Wisconsin's income-first statute thus conflicted with the MCCA (2000 WI App 150, 237 Wis 2d 810, 615 NW2d 647).

Certain individuals who were originally indicted in the Eastern District of Kentucky on two counts for violations of 18 USCS 371 and 545 obtained a change of venue to the Central District of California. In the latter district the government secured a superseding indictment charging four new substantive counts of making false statements to Customs officers in violation of 18 USCS 542, in addition to the two original counts. The government then obtained a voluntary dismissal of the original conspiracy count and two of the false statement counts. The defendants moved to dismiss the remaining counts on the ground that the superseding indictment manifested prosecutorial vindictiveness. The United States District Court for the Central District of California denied the defendants' motion, but stayed the commencement of the trial to permit an appeal. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, ruling that the denial of a motion to dismiss based on the ground of vindictive prosecution is immediately appealable as a final decision under 28 USCS 1291, held that the defendants established a case of prosecutorial vindictiveness requiring dismissal of the superseding indictment (646 F2d 384).

A local board of education in Illinois agreed to the giving of religious instruction in the schools under a "released time" arrangement whereby pupils whose parents signed "request cards" were permitted to attend religious-instruction classes conducted during regular school hours in the school building by outside teachers furnished by a religious council representing the various faiths, subject to the approval and supervision of the superintendent of schools. Attendance records were kept and reported to the school authorities in same way as for other classes; and pupils not attending the religious instruction classes were required to continue their regular secular studies.

An accused--who had (1) begun serving a life sentence after a Georgia conviction for murder, (2) escaped from prison, and (3) committed another murder--was apprehended, convicted of the second murder, and sentenced to a second life term. At the time the accused committed his second offense, the state's board of pardons and paroles required reconsiderations of parole to take place every 3 years following an initial consideration after 7 years. After the accused had begun serving his second life sentence, the parole board, acting under statutory authority, amended its rules to provide that reconsideration of those inmates serving life sentences who have been denied parole would take place at least every 8 years. The parole board (1) considered the accused for parole 7 years after the second conviction, (2) denied release, and (3) consistent with the amended rule, set reconsideration for 8 years later. The United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit, in another case, held that retroactive application of the amended rule violated the prohibition on ex post facto laws contained in Art I, 10, cl 1 of the Federal Constitution. In compliance with that decision, the parole board reconsidered the accused's case in 3-year intervals, with parole being denied each time. Subsequently, the parole board (1) determined that the United States Supreme Court's decision in California Dep't of Corrections v Morales (1995) 514 US 499, 131 L Ed 2d 588, 115 S Ct 1597, had rejected the rationale underlying the Court of Appeals decision in the other case, and (2) set the accused's next consideration for 8 years after his most recent review. The accused brought an action in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Georgia against individual members of the parole board, which action claimed that the amended rule violated the Constitution's ex post facto law prohibition. The District Court (1) denied the accused's motion for leave to conduct discovery to support his claim, (2) entered summary judgment for the defendants, and (3) expressed the view that the amendment to the parole board rule changed only the timing between reconsideration hearings for inmates sentenced to life in prison, thereby relieving the board of the necessity of holding parole hearings for prisoners who had no reasonable chance of being released. The Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit reversed the judgment of the District Court and expressed the view that (1) the amended rule's retroactive application was necessarily an ex post facto violation, and (2) a parole board policy which permitted inmates, upon a showing of a change in "their circumstance" or where the board received new information, to receive expedited reconsideration for parole was insufficient (164 F.3d 589).

Defendants were indicted in 1950 for offenses involving fraud against the United States committed in 1947, more than three years before the indictment was returned. Under the three-year statute of limitations (18 USC 3282) prosecution was barred, unless the statute was tolled by the Wartime Suspension of Limitations Act of 1942, as amended (former title 18 USC 590a), which suspended the running of the statute of limitations until three years after the termination of hostilities in World War II (December 31, 1946).

This case involves a Selective Service registrant whose local board denied him a conscientious objector exemption. In order to secure aid for his appeal, the registrant met with a Government appeals agent. The agent made out a report which was placed in the registrant's file, and which was before the appeal board when it considered petitioner's claim. The report was unfavorable, and the Solicitor General so concedes. The Solicitor General also concedes that because of the appeal agent's special position in the Selective Service System, his views probably carried substantial weight with the appeal board. Yet, this crucial report was not shown to the registrant, so that he might have attempted to rebut the unfavorable statements contained therein.

The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Ab- duction (Hague Convention or Convention), implemented in the United States by the International Child Abduction Remedies Act, 22 U. S. C. §9001 et seq., provides that a child wrongfully removed from her country of “habitual residence” ordinarily must be returned to that country.
Petitioner Monasky, a U. S. citizen, asserts that her Italian hus- band, respondent Taglieri, became abusive after the couple moved to Italy from the United States. Two months after the birth of the cou- ple’s daughter, A. M. T., in Italy, Monasky fled with the infant to Ohio. Taglieri petitioned the U. S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio for A. M. T.’s return to Italy under the Convention, pursuant to 22 U. S. C. §9003(b), on the ground that the child had been wrongfully removed from her country of “habitual residence.” The District Court granted Taglieri’s petition, concluding that the parents’ shared intent was for their daughter to live in Italy. Then two-year-old A. M. T. was returned to Italy. The en banc Sixth Circuit affirmed. Under its prec- edent, the court first noted, an infant’s habitual residence depends on the parents’ shared intent. It then reviewed the District Court’s habitual-residence determination for clear error and found none. In doing so, the court rejected Monasky’s argument that Italy could not qualify as A. M. T.’s “habitual residence” in the absence of an actual agreement by her parents to raise her there.

Each of the two petitioners, one a permanent and the other a temporary county employee, were ordered by a California county board of supervisors to answer any questions asked by a subcommittee of the House Un-American Activities Committee relating to his subversive activities; moreover 1028.1 of the Government Code of California made it the duty of any public employee to give testimony relating to such activity on pain of discharge. Petitioners, nevertheless, refused to answer questions of this kind before the subcommittee, relying upon their federal privilege against self- incrimination. Thereafter the county discharged petitioners on the ground of insubordination, the permanent worker after a hearing before the county civil service commission, and the temporary employee without a hearing. Each of the petitioners then filed the present petitions for mandates in the Superior Court, Los Angeles County, California, seeking reinstatement, contending that the California statute and their discharges violated the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment. The Superior Court rendered judgments against the petitioners. The discharge of the permanent employee was affirmed by the District Court of Appeals (163 Cal App 2d 607, 329 P2d 978), and the summary dismissal of the temporary employee was likewise affirmed (163 Cal App 2d 595, 329 P2d 971). A petition for review in each of the cases was denied without opinion by the Supreme Court of California, three judges dissenting.

Petitioner's husband was killed as a result of a jeep accident outside a defense base at which he was employed, the accident taking place when he and other employees were returning from a nearby town. The Deputy Commissioner awarded death benefits to the petitioner, and in support of the award, found that although petitioner's husband had completed his day's work, he was subject to call for emergencies while off duty and was returning from reasonable recreation when the accident occurred. The District Court for the Southern District of Florida set aside the Deputy Commissioner's order, and the Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit affirmed. (299 F2d 74.)

A finding by the jury that defendant corporations had conspired to fix maximum resale prices in violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act is authorized by evidence tending to show that one of the defendants refused to sell to plaintiff and others unless the purchasers agreed to the maximum resale price fixed by it, and that a co-defendant was at first willing to sell without this restrictive condition, but subsequently informed plaintiff that the arrangements made to that end would not be carried out because the first defendant refused to co-operate, and that, after conferences held by officials of the defendants, both, on identical terms as to the fixing of retail prices, resumed sales to other wholesalers in plaintiff's territory who agreed to abide by such conditions, but no shipments were made to the plaintiff, and this is so even though there is other testimony in the record indicating that the price policies of the two defendants were arrived at independently.

Some physicians who had contracted with some managed-health-care organizations to provide health-care services to patients covered by the organizations' health insurance plans brought, in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida, an action alleging that the organizations had violated, among other federal and state laws, the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO) (18 USCS 1961 et seq.) by failing to pay the physicians for their services. The organizations, on the basis of arbitration clauses in the contracts in question, moved to compel arbitration. The District Court, in refusing this request for the RICO claims, concluded that the arbitration clauses were unenforceable because (1) the clauses prohibited awards of "punitive damages," and (2) thus, the physicians might not have been able obtain meaningful relief in arbitration, since 18 USCS 1964(c) authorized treble damages under RICO (132 F Supp 2d 989). The United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit affirmed for the reasons set forth in the District Court's opinion (285 F3d 971).

The Chemehuevi Indian Tribe brought an action in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California requesting a declaratory judgment that California's cigarette tax could not lawfully be applied to cigarettes sold by the Tribe on its reservation to non-Indian purchasers, and also requesting injunctive relief to prevent the California State Board of Equalization from enforcing the cigarette tax law against the Tribe. In response, the Board counterclaimed for damages in the amount of back taxes claimed to be owed by the Tribe. The District Court held that the counterclaim was barred by sovereign immunity (492 F Supp 55), but that California could lawfully require the tribe to collect cigarette excise taxes on cigarettes that it sold to non-Indians. On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit affirmed the first determination, but reversed the second (757 F2d 1047).

Plaintiffs are enlisted men in the United States Army who were captured during the hostilities in Korea in 1950 and 1951, were disloyal to their comrades and to their country, refused repatriation after the Korean Armistice in 1953 and went to Communist China, were dishonorably discharged from the Army in 1954, and returned to the United States in 1955. After their claims for accrued pay and allowances had been denied by the Department of the Army, they brought suit against the United States in the Court of Claims for pay and allowances from the time of their capture to the date of their discharge from the Army. The Court of Claims denied their claims. (____ Ct Cl ____, 181 F Supp 668.)

The state of Arizona levied a 2 percent tax on a trading post company's gross proceeds of sales, or gross income, derived from a retail trading business with reservation Indians on a Navajo Indian Reservation under a license granted by the United States Indian Commissioner, pursuant to federal statute. Although the company claimed that the tax was invalid on the ground of inconsistency with a comprehensive congressional plan to regulate Indian trade and traders and to have Indian tribes on reservations govern themselves, the Arizona Supreme Court upheld the tax, one justice dissenting. (95 Ariz 110, 387 P2d 809.)

The main channel of the Missouri River, the middle of which forms the Missouri-Nebraska boundary line, shifted so that certain bottom land, once an island in the river, was on the Missouri side rather than on the Nebraska side of the boundary. Two Nebraska citizens, who claimed the land by virtue of a Nebraska sheriff's tax foreclosure deed, brought suit in a Nebraska state court against a Missouri citizen who claimed the land by virtue of a Missouri swampland patent. A principal issue litigated was whether the shift in the river's course resulted from avulsion, so that under Nebraska law the land remained a part of Nebraska, or from accretion, so that under Nebraska law the land became a part of Missouri. The Nebraska court found that the shift in the river's course resulted from avulsion, that it had jurisdiction of the parties and of the subject matter, and that the land was in Nebraska, and it quieted title in the Nebraska citizens. The Supreme Court of Nebraska affirmed, and the Missouri citizen did not seek review in the Supreme Court of the United States. Instead, the Missouri citizen brought a similar action against the Nebraska citizens in a Missouri state court, from whence it was removed to the United States District Court for the Western District of Missouri, which dismissed the suit on the ground that the Nebraska judgment was res judicata and binding on the court. The United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit reversed, holding that the District Court was not required to give full faith and credit to the Nebraska judgment, that normal res judicata principles were inapplicable because the controversy involved land, and that a Missouri court was free to retry the issue of the Nebraska court's jurisdiction over the subject matter. (308 F2d 209.)

A resident and citizen of Mississippi brought an action based on diversity of citizenship in the Federal District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana against a partnership and its individual members who were residents of the Western District of Louisiana and a Texas corporation which had qualified to do business in Louisiana and made itself amenable to suit in the federal courts for either the Eastern or Western District of that State.

More than 30 years ago, Vernon Madison crept up behind police officer Julius Schulte and shot him twice in the head at close range. An Alabama jury found Madison guilty of *11 capital murder. The trial court sentenced him to death. See Ex parte Madison, 718 So.2d 104, 105‚Äì106 (1998).
In 2016, as Madison's execution neared, he petitioned the trial court for a suspension of his death sentence. He argued that, due to several recent strokes, he has become incompetent to be executed. The court held a hearing to receive testimony from two psychologists who had examined Madison and prepared reports concerning his competence. The court's appointed psychologist, Dr. Karl Kirkland, reported that, although Madison may have ‚Äúsuffered a significant decline post-stroke, ... [he] understands the exact posture of his case at this point,‚Äù and appears to have a ‚Äúrational understanding of ... the results or effects‚Äù of his death sentence. App. to Pet. for Cert. 75a (internal quotation marks omitted); Madison v. Commissioner, Ala. Dept. of Corrections, 851 F.3d 1173, 1193 (C.A.11 2017) (internal quotation marks omitted). Asked at the hearing whether Madison understands that Alabama is seeking retribution against him for his criminal act, Dr. Kirkland answered, ‚ÄúCertainly.‚Äù Id., at 1180 (internal quotation marks omitted).
Dr. John Goff, a psychologist hired by Madison's counsel, reported that Madison's strokes have rendered him unable to remember ‚Äúnumerous events that have occurred over the past thirty years or more.‚Äù App. to Pet. for Cert. 77a. Nevertheless, Dr. Goff found that Madison ‚Äúis able to understand the nature of the pending proceeding and he has an understanding of what he was tried for‚Äù; that he knows he is ‚Äúin prison ... because of ‚Äòmurder‚Äô ‚Äù; that he ‚Äúunderstands that ... [Alabama is] seeking retribution‚Äù for that crime; and that he ‚Äúunderstands the sentence, specifically the meaning of a death sentence.‚Äù **11 Id., at 76a‚Äì78a (some internal quotation marks omitted). In Dr. Goff's opinion, however, Madison does not ‚Äúunderstan[d] the act that ... he is being punished for‚Äù because he cannot recall ‚Äúthe sequence of events from the offense to his arrest to the trial or any of those *12 details‚Äù and believes that he ‚Äúnever went around killing folks.‚Äù Ibid. (internal quotation marks omitted).
The trial court denied Madison's petition. It held that, under this Court's decisions in Ford v. Wainwright, 477 U.S. 399, 106 S.Ct. 2595, 91 L.Ed.2d 335 (1986), and Panetti v. Quarterman, 551 U.S. 930, 127 S.Ct. 2842, 168 L.Ed.2d 662 (2007), Madison was entitled to relief if he could show that he ‚Äúsuffers from a mental illness which deprives [him] of the mental capacity to rationally understand that he is being executed as a punishment for a crime.‚Äù App. to Pet. for Cert. 74a. The court concluded that Madison had failed to make that showing. Specifically, it found that Madison understands ‚Äúthat he is going to be executed because of the murder he committed[,] ... that the State is seeking retribution[,] and that he will die when he is executed.‚Äù Id., at 82a.
1
Madison then filed a petition for a writ of habeas corpus in Federal District Court. As a state prisoner, Madison is entitled to federal habeas relief under the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996 (AEDPA) only if the state trial court's adjudication of his incompetence claim ‚Äúwas contrary to, or involved an unreasonable application of, clearly established Federal law, as determined by‚Äù this Court, or else was ‚Äúbased on an unreasonable determination of the facts in light of the evidence presented‚Äù in state court. 28 U.S.C. ¬ß 2254(d). A habeas petitioner meets this demanding standard only when he shows that the state court's decision was ‚Äúso lacking in justification that there was an error well understood and comprehended in existing law beyond any possibility for fairminded disagreement.‚Äù Harrington v. Richter, 562 U.S. 86, 103, 131 S.Ct. 770, 178 L.Ed.2d 624 (2011). The District Court denied Madison's petition after concluding that the state court ‚Äúcorrectly applied Ford and Panetti ‚Äù and did not make an ‚Äúunreasonable determination of the facts in light of the evidence.‚Äù App. to Pet. for Cert. 67a.
The Eleventh Circuit granted a certificate of appealability and, on appeal, reversed over Judge Jordan's dissent. In the majority's view, given the undisputed fact that Madison ‚Äúhas *13 no memory of his capital offense,‚Äù it inescapably follows that he ‚Äúdoes not rationally understand the connection between his crime and his execution.‚Äù 851 F.3d, at 1185‚Äì1186. On that basis, the Eleventh Circuit held that the trial court's conclusion that Madison is competent to be executed was ‚Äúplainly unreasonable‚Äù and ‚Äúcannot be reconciled with any reasonable application of Panetti.‚Äù Id., at 1187‚Äì1188 (internal quotation marks omitted).

A New Jersey municipal ordinance which forbids carrying on the business of storing goods for hire without payment of an annual license tax does not violate the Commerce Clause of the Constitution when applied (in the circumstances of this case) to a warehouse in which coal shipped from another state is stored within the municipality under a "transit" privilege, pending a decision by the owner whether to ship it to another state or to another point in the same state -- even though most of the coal actually is shipped to other states.

Under 26 USCS 6321, a federal lien attaches to all property and rights to property belonging to any taxpayer who fails to pay federal taxes owed by the taxpayer. When a husband failed to pay income tax liabilities assessed against him by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS), the Federal Government filed a lien that sought to attach, under 6321, the husband's properties that included a piece of real property in Michigan that the husband and his wife held under Michigan law as tenants by the entireties. After the notice of the lien was filed, the husband and wife executed a quitclaim deed that purported to transfer to the wife the husband's interest in the real property. Subsequently, when the wife was attempting to sell the property, the IRS agreed to release the lien with a stipulation that half of the net proceeds of the sale be held in escrow, pending determination of the Federal Government's interest in the property. In an action by the wife to quiet title to the escrowed proceeds, the United States District Court for the Western District of Michigan, granting the government's motion for summary judgment, held that the lien entitled the government to half of the property's value. On appeal by both parties, the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, remanding to the District Court to consider an alternative claim by the government, expressed the view that the lien did not attach to the property because under Michigan law, the husband had no separate interest in property held as a tenant by the entirety (140 F3d 638). After the District Court, on remand, awarded the IRS a share of the proceeds of the sale (65 F Supp 2d 651), both parties again appealed, with the government again asserting that its lien attached to the husband's interest in the entireties property. The Court of Appeals, affirming the District Court's decision concerning the government's alternative claim, held that the Court of Appeals' earlier decision in the instant case was the law of the case on the issue of whether the lien under 6321 attached (233 F3d 358).

The plaintiff, with others, instituted an action in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Georgia, seeking a declaratory judgment under the Federal Declaratory Judgment Act (28 USCS 2201, 2202) that the Georgia criminal trespass statute was being applied in violation of the plaintiff's First and Fourteenth Amendment rights, and also seeking an injunction restraining certain county officials and the owner and manager of a certain shopping center, from interfering with the plaintiff's right to distribute handbills at the shopping center protesting American involvement in Viet Nam. On two occasions, the plaintiff had stopped distributing handbills on an exterior sidewalk at the shopping center when warned by police that he would be arrested if he refused to stop or if he resumed handbilling, one of the plaintiff's companions having been arrested and charged with violating the state statute when she continued handbilling. The District Court denied relief for lack of an active controversy, since there was no showing that the state was acting in bad faith (334 F Supp 1386). On the plaintiff's appeal from the denial of declaratory relief only, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit affirmed the District Court's judgment denying declaratory relief, holding that the principles of Younger v Harris, 401 US 37, 27 L Ed 2d 669, 91 S Ct 746, and Samuels v Mackell, 401 US 66, 27 L Ed 2d 688, 91 S Ct 764--which required that bad faith enforcement or other special circumstances must be established in order to obtain either declaratory or injunctive relief in a federal court against a pending state court criminal prosecution under a challenged state criminal statute--were also applicable when a state prosecution was threatened but not pending (459 F2d 919).

A judgment of the Supreme Court of Utah, holding that the imposition of the Utah sales tax was unconstitutional (13 Utah 2d 113, 369 P2d 123), was reversed by the Supreme Court of the United States in a per curiam opinion, for the reason stated in the headnote below.

The Equal Access to Justice Act (EAJA) directs a court to award fees and other expenses to private parties who prevail in litigation against the United States, if, among other conditions, the position of the United States was not "substantially justified" (28 USCS 2412(d)(1)(A)). After protracted litigation on the merits of a challenge to the Immigration and Naturalization Service's actions with respect to Haitian immigrants, the United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida, in determining that the plaintiffs in the case were entitled to a fee award under the EAJA, expressly found that (1) the plaintiffs were the prevailing parties within the meaning of the EAJA; (2) the Federal Government's position was not substantially justified; and (3) there were no other special circumstances that would make an award unjust (624 F Supp 836). Subsequently, the District Court held that the plaintiffs were entitled to an award for the fees, costs, and expenses incurred during the litigation as to the proper EAJA fee (646 F Supp 1300). On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit, although deciding that certain errors required that the case be remanded for recalculation of attorney's fees and expenses, (1) upheld the three District Court findings with respect to the plaintiffs' entitlement to an EAJA award; and (2) expressed the view that the District Court did not err in awarding attorney's fees for the EAJA fee litigation, even though the District Court had made no determination that the Federal Government's position in the fee litigation itself was without substantial justification (863 F2d 759).

Petitioner veteran prevailed in an action for disability benefits against respondent Secretary of Veterans Affairs, and the veteran applied for an award of attorney fees and costs pursuant to the Equal Access to Justice Act (EAJA). Upon the grant of a writ of certiorari, the veteran appealed the judgment of the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit which upheld the dismissal of the application as defective in content. The veteran's EAJA application failed to include the statutorily required allegation that the Secretary's position was not substantially justified, and the veteran's amendment of the application to include the allegation was not accomplished prior to expiration of the statutory period for filing the application. The veteran contended that the amendment cured the defect in the otherwise timely application, but the Secretary argued that no proper application was filed within the required time. The United States Supreme Court held that the curative amendment was permissible after the filing period expired and the veteran's application, as amended, qualified for consideration and determination on the merits.
