A railroad worker, who had been exposed on his job to insulation dust that contained asbestos but had suffered from no asbestos-related disease and had exhibited no physical symptom of exposure to asbestos, brought against his employer under the Federal Employers' Liability Act (FELA) (45 USCS 51-60) an action seeking damages (1) for negligently inflicted emotional distress, and (2) to cover the costs of future medical checkups for cancer and asbestosis. The employer conceded negligence. The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, dismissing the action, (1) expressed the view that the FELA did not permit recovery for the alleged emotional distress, because the worker had suffered no physical impact, and (2) did not discuss the claim for medical monitoring costs. The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, reversing the District Court judgment, expressed the view that (1) the worker's contact with the insulation dust constituted a physical impact, and (2) the worker could recover medical monitoring costs under the FELA (79 F3d 1337).

In each of these cases, an employer and employee entered into a contract providing for individualized arbitration proceedings to resolve employment disputes between the parties. Each employee nonetheless sought to litigate Fair Labor Standards Act and related state law claims through class or collective actions in federal court. Although the Federal Arbitration Act generally requires courts to enforce arbitration agreements as written, the employees argued that its ‚Äúsaving clause‚Äù removes this obligation if an arbitration agreement violates some other federal law and that, by requiring individualized proceedings, the agreements here violated the National Labor Relations Act. The employers countered that the Arbitration Act protects agreements requiring arbitration from judicial interference and that neither the saving clause nor the NLRA demands a different conclusion. Until recently, courts as well as the National Labor Relations Board's general counsel agreed that such arbitration agreements are enforceable. In 2012, however, the Board ruled that the NLRA effectively nullifies the Arbitration Act in cases like these, and since then other courts have either agreed with or deferred to the Board's position.

On the same day that the United States District Court for the District of Nevada unsealed an indictment against a property owner for distributing marijuana, laundering money, and related crimes, the District Court unsealed a civil complaint, that had been brought under 21 USCS 881(a)(6) and 881(a)(7) against the owner by the United States, seeking forfeiture of the owner's properties that were located in the United States and allegedly had been purchased with proceeds of the owner's illegal drug sales or had been used to facilitate the sales. The owner, who was a citizen of the United States and Switzerland, and who had moved to Switzerland with his family before the indictment and the forfeiture complaint were unsealed, did not return to face the criminal charges and could not be extradited. While remaining outside the United States, the owner filed an answer contesting the forfeiture. The District Court--expressing the view that the owner was not entitled to be heard in the civil forfeiture action because he remained outside the country, unamenable to criminal prosecution--granted the government's motion to strike the owner's claims and entered summary judgment against the owner (755 F Supp 308). Subsequently, after dealing with procedural matters largely involving attempts by the owner's wife to contest the forfeiture, the District Court entered a final order vesting title to the properties in the United States. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in affirming, expressed the view that the District Court had properly dismissed, under the fugitive disentitlement doctrine, the owner's claims to the properties (47 F3d 1511).

A state prisoner who had been convicted in a Kentucky court on a charge of first-degree manslaughter, and whose conviction had been sustained on direct appeal by the Supreme Court of Kentucky (544 SW2d 228), unsuccessfully sought habeas corpus relief in the United States District Court for the Western District of Kentucky. With respect to the prisoner's Fourteenth Amendment due process claim that his conviction rested on insufficient evidence, the District Court denied habeas corpus relief on the ground that under the "no evidence" test the case was not devoid of an evidentiary basis for the prisoner's conviction. The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit affirmed, also relying on the "no evidence" test as the basis for the denial of habeas corpus relief (593 F2d 264).

An employer that maintained, was the sole source of funding for, and was the administrator and fiduciary of its employees' termination pay plan, retirement plan, and stock purchase plan, all of which were governed by the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, as amended (ERISA) (29 USCS 1001 et seq.), sold one of its divisions. Salaried nonunion divisional employees who were rehired by the division purchaser sought (1) severance benefits under the termination pay plan, which provided for termination pay in the event of a workforce reduction, and (2) information about their benefits under all three plans pursuant to 29 USCS 1024(b)(4). The employer denied the request for severance benefits on the ground that the sale of the division did not constitute a workforce reduction, within the meaning of the termination pay plan, and denied the requests for information on the ground that the employees were no longer plan "participants" entitled to the information. Subsequently, the employees brought an action seeking to recover severance benefits under 29 USCS 1132(a)(1)(B), and to recover damages, under 29 USCS 1132(c)(1)(B), for the employer's failure to disclose the requested information. The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, granting the employer's summary judgment motion, held that (1) the employer had satisfied its fiduciary duty under ERISA, because its decision not to pay the severance benefits was not arbitrary or capricious, and (2) the employer had no duty to provide the requested information to the employees, because they were not plan "participants" or "beneficiaries" when they requested the information (640 F Supp 519). On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, reversing the granting of summary judgment on both counts, and remanding the case to the District Court, held that (1) where an employer is the fiduciary and administrator of its employees' unfunded benefit plan, its decision to deny plan benefits should be subject to de novo judicial review, rather than to the arbitrary and capricious standard of review, and (2) the right to receive information about an employee benefit plan extends both to people entitled to a benefit under the plan and to people who claim to be, but are not, entitled to a plan benefit (828 F2d 134).

In a suit brought in the New York Supreme Court, Rockland County, to compel the Rockland County Board of Supervisors to reapportion in accordance with constitutional requirements, the court approved a plan creating a county legislature with districts corresponding to the county's five towns, one legislator being assigned to the smallest town and the number of legislators for each other town being the number of times its population exceeded that of the smallest town. Rounding off fractions to the nearest integer caused variations of 11,577 population-per-legislator in one town to 13,020 population-per-legislator in another town, with consequent 4.8 percent overrepresentation of one town and 7.1 percent underrepresentation of another, for a total voting inequality of 11.9 percent. The Appellate Division affirmed (33 App Div 2d 660, 305 NYS2d 102), and the Court of Appeals affirmed. (25 NY2d 309, 253 NE2d 189.)

The present actions were brought under the Jones Act in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia to recover damages for injuries sustained by one seaman, and for the death of another, as a result of an automobile accident which occurred when the seamen, after falling ill at a foreign port, were being taken to a United States consul by a local taxicab procured by the ship's master, and due to the negligence of its driver, the cab collided with a truck. The District Court entered judgment on a verdict for the plaintiffs, but the Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit reversed. (351 F2d 415.)

The Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims initially dismissed the veteran's appeal of a benefits denial as untimely under ¬¨√ü 7266(a), but upon reconsideration revoked the dismissal. While appeal was pending, the U.S. Supreme Court issued Bowles v. Russell, which held that the statutory limitation for an extension of time to file a notice of appeal in an ordinary civil case was jurisdictional and could not be excused based on equitable factors. Citing Bowles, the Veterans Court dismissed the veteran's appeal. In reversing the appellate court's affirmance, the U.S. Supreme Court held that the reasoning of Bowles did not apply to review of a denial of veterans' benefits, which was similar to judicial review of an administrative denial of Social Security disability benefits, particularly as the case involved review by a U.S. Const. art. I tribunal that was part of a unique administrative scheme. In holding that the ¬¨√ü 7266(a) deadline was not jurisdictional, the Court noted that the plain language of the statute and its placement within the statutory framework, as well as Congressional solicitude for veterans, indicated the 120 day limit of ¬¨√ü 7266(a) was not intended to be jurisdictional.

The present suit was instituted by plaintiffs in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois for a refund of excise taxes collected, under 3405(c) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1939, on the sales of two self-contained air-conditioning units. The District Court construed pertinent revenue rulings to the effect that the statute taxed units having "a total motor horsepower of less than 1 horsepower," as referring to actual, not nominal or rated, horsepower, and found that each of the two units involved had an actual horsepower in excess of one horsepower. From a judgment entered in favor of the plaintiff, the defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit reversed, holding void the revenue rulings, in so far as they referred to horsepower. (266 F2d 58, reh den 267 F2d 802.)

The Securities and Exchange Commission instituted the present action in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York to obtain an injunction compelling a registered investment adviser to disclose to his clients a practice of purchasing shares of security for his own account shortly before recommending that security for long-term investment and then immediately selling the shares at a profit upon the rise in the market price following the recommendation. The action was based on 206(2) of the Investment Advisers Act (15 USC 80b-6(2)), prohibiting an investment adviser from engaging in any practice which "operates as a fraud or deceit upon any client or prospective client." The District Court denied the request for a preliminary injunction, holding that the words "fraud" and "deceit" are used in 206 in their technical sense and that the Commission had failed to show an intent to injure clients or an actual loss of money to clients. (191 F Supp 897.) Accepting the District Court's limited construction of "fraud" and "deceit," the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, sitting en banc, by a 5-to-4 vote affirmed. (306 F2d 606).

With respect to a motor common carrier, the Interstate Commerce Act (ICA) (1) requires, under 49 USCS 10701, the adoption of reasonable rates and practices; (2) requires, under 49 USCS 10741, that such rates not be discriminatory; (3) requires, under 49 USCS 10762(a)(1), that a carrier publish and file with the Interstate Commerce Commission (ICC) tariffs containing the rates for the transportation the carrier may provide; and (4) prohibits, in 49 USCS 10761(a), a carrier from providing services at any rate other than the filed rate, also known as the tariff rate. The requirement to adhere to the filed rate has become known as the filed rate doctrine. Beginning in 1986, however, the ICC--citing changes in the motor carrier industry--adopted a negotiated rates policy according to which a shipper, under certain circumstances, was relieved of the obligation of paying the filed rate when the shipper and a motor common carrier had privately negotiated a lower rate. From 1981 to 1983, a motor common carrier which was a subsidiary of a parent company (1) privately negotiated rates with a shipper that were lower than the carrier's rates on file with the ICC, and (2) never filed the negotiated rates with the ICC. In 1983, the carrier's parent company filed for bankruptcy. After the shipper had refused to pay agents of the bankrupt estate for the alleged undercharges resulting from the prior billing of the shipper at the negotiated rather than the filed rate, the estate brought suit in the United States District Court for the Western District of Missouri against the shipper for the difference between the filed rates and the negotiated rates. The District Court, finding certain matters to be within the primary jurisdiction of the ICC, stayed the proceedings and referred the case to the ICC, which, ruling in favor of the shipper under the negotiated rates policy, expressed the view that (1) 10701 authorized the ICC to consider all the circumstances surrounding an undercharge suit to determine whether collection of the filed rate would constitute an unreasonable practice; and (2) the carrier was not entitled to recover the filed rates in the case at hand, where (a) the carrier and the shipper had negotiated rates other than the tariff rates, (b) the shipper had relied on the carrier to file the rates with the ICC, (c) the shipper had reasonably believed that the amounts quoted and billed by the carrier were the correct total charges for the transportation services performed, and (d) the shipper had made full payment. The case then returned to the District Court, which granted summary judgment for the shipper and expressed the view that (1) the ICC's policy was based on a permissible construction of the ICA, and (2) the ICC's finding that the carrier had engaged in an unreasonable practice was supported by substantial evidence (705 F Supp 1401). On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, in affirming, expressed the view that the ICC's approach (1) was consistent with the ICA, and (2) did not abolish the filed rate doctrine, but (3) merely allowed the ICC to consider all the circumstances, including equitable defenses, to determine if strict adherence to the filed rate doctrine would constitute an unreasonable practice (879 F2d 400).

Deficiencies in a taxpayer's income taxes were assessed by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue within the period specified in waivers of the statute of limitations which were executed by the taxpayer more than 3 years but less than 5 years after the taxpayer's returns for the years in question were filed. Although 275(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1939 limits the assessment of tax deficiencies to 3 years from the date on which the taxpayer filed his return, the Commissioner, in proceedings in the Tax Court in which it was sought to collect the deficiencies, contended that the taxpayer was within the special 5-year period of limitations which, under 275(c) of the Code, applies when a taxpayer "omits from gross income an amount properly includible therein" which is in excess of 25 per cent of the amount of gross income stated in the return. The Commissioner argued that there was such an omission from gross income by the taxpayer, who had understated his gross income as a consequence of miscalculating profits from the sale of realty by erroneously including an excessive item of cost. The Tax Court sustained the Commissioner's contention (26 T Ct 30) and the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit affirmed (244 F2d 75).

An investor, who was a veteran of two unsuccessful oil and gas investment ventures, invested approximately $ 310,000 with an oil and gas producer in a drilling venture involving leaseholds acquired by and held in the name of the producer. The investor then contacted a number of friends, family members, and business associates about the venture, all of whom, because of the investor's involvement, decided to invest about $ 7,500 in the venture, although most of them had not met or spoken to the producer or personally toured the leaseholds. The investor helped each of his contacts complete a subscription-agreement form which the producer had prepared. Each form stated that the venture interests were being sold without benefit of registration under the Securities Act of 1933 (15 USCS 77a et seq.), in reliance on a Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) rule then in effect, and the interests were never registered with the SEC. The contacts' investment checks were made payable to the producer's company, and the investor received no commission in connection with the purchases. When the drilling venture failed and the investment interests proved to be worthless, the investor and the contacts brought suit against the producer in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Texas, seeking rescission of their investment agreements on grounds that such agreements constituted the unlawful sale of unregistered securities under 12(1) of the Securities Act of 1933 (15 USCS 77l(1)). The producer, in response, (1) asserted that the investor's claim was barred by the equitable defense of in pari delicto, and (2) moved to realign the investor as a third-party defendant, on grounds that the investor was a "seller" of the venture interests to the contacts within the meaning of 12(1). The District Court denied the producer's motion to realign and, after a bench trial, granted judgment for the investor and the contacts on their 12(1) rescission claims, making no specific mention of the producer's in pari delicto defense against the investor. On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit affirmed, holding that (1) the in pari delicto defense was not available in an action under 12(1), since that section created a strict liability offense rather than liability based on intentional misconduct, and (2) the investor was not a "seller" under 12(1), since there was no evidence that the investor sought or received any financial benefit in return for his advice to the contacts (787 F2d 985). The Court of Appeals denied rehearing en banc (794 F2d 1016).

An Indiana state reformatory inmate filed a complaint under 42 USCS 1983 in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Indiana, alleging that (1) a reformatory doctor, the administrator of the reformatory infirmary, and other correctional officials had violated the inmate's rights under the Federal Constitution's Eighth Amendment by refusing to treat a small brain tumor that affected his equilibrium, and (2) correctional officials had violated the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by transferring him to a less desirable cellhouse without a hearing. Along with the complaint, the inmate filed a motion to proceed in forma pauperis pursuant to 28 USCS 1915(a). The District Court, invoking 28 USCS 1915(d)--which authorizes a federal court, in a proceeding in forma pauperis, to dismiss the case if the court is satisfied that the action is frivolous--dismissed the complaint sua sponte as frivolous on the grounds that the inmate had failed to state a claim upon which relief could be granted for the purpose of Rule 12(b)(6) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. The District Court said that the pleadings did not state a claim under (1) the Eighth Amendment, because there was no allegation of deliberate indifference to serious medical needs, or (2) the due process clause, because a prisoner has no constitutionally protected interest in being incarcerated in a particular institution or wing. Subsequently the District Court denied the inmate's motion to vacate the judgment and amend his pleadings. The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, affirming in part and reversing in part, held that (1) the District Court had wrongly equated the standard for frivolousness of a complaint under 1915(d) with the standard for failure to state a claim under Rule 12(b)(6), and (2) the Eighth Amendment claims against the infirmary doctor and administrator had been wrongly dismissed, because it was not certain that the inmate was unable to make any rational argument in law or fact to support those claims. Accordingly, the Court of Appeals remanded those claims to the District Court. However, the Court of Appeals also held that the due process claims had been properly dismissed as frivolous, because it was clear that the inmate could make no rational argument in law or fact to support those claims (837 F2d 304).

At a statutory rape trial in a Texas state criminal court, the accused's four prior convictions were used to impeach his credibility as a witness. He was convicted and sentenced to a 50-year prison term. Thereafter, he brought a habeas corpus proceeding in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas, alleging that the prior convictions were constitutionally invalid because he was denied the assistance of counsel. His sworn testimony at the habeas corpus hearing was that at the time of the prior convictions, he was unrepresented by counsel, could not afford to hire counsel, and was not advised of his right to counsel. The District Court denied relief, declaring that it placed little or no credence in his testimony and that the question did not rise to constitutional stature. The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit affirmed on the ground that no issue of constitutional proportions required reversal (440 F2d 934).

A female employee filed suit against her former employer, alleging that she had been discharged because of her age in violation of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 (29 USCS 621 et seq.). Seeking reinstatement, lost wages, liquidated damages, attorney's fees, and costs, the employee demanded a jury trial on all issues of fact, and her employer moved to strike the demand. The United States District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina granted the motion, but certified the issue for interlocutory appeal (69 FRD 576). The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit allowed the appeal, and held that both the Age Discrimination in Employment Act and the Seventh Amendment afforded the employee the right to jury trial on her claim for lost wages (549 F2d 950).

Labor unions picketed a construction project because some of the subcontractors employed nonunion help. Although the picketing was peaceful, Virginia courts enjoined it on the ground that it was carried on for purposes in conflict with the Virginia "Right to Work" statute, which prohibited any agreement between an employer and a labor union whereby persons not members of such union would be denied the right to work for the employer, or whereby union membership was made a condition of employment or continuation of employment. The defendant labor unions contended that the record did not justify the finding as to the purposes of the picketing, and that, even if the finding was justified, the injunction was inconsistent with the Fourteenth Amendment.

To avoid a disproportionate sales of the tax liens, each party bidding was required to certify that it did not use agents to submit simultaneous bids on the same parcel, and the bidders alleged that the competitors' certifications were false. The bidders contended that the competitors engaged in a pattern of racketeering based on mail fraud, through mailed notices to property owners, but the competitors argued that bidders did not rely on the alleged misrepresentations to support the RICO. The U.S. Supreme Court unanimously held that the bidders, in asserting the RICO claim predicated on mail fraud, were not required to show, either as an element of their claim or as a prerequisite to establishing proximate causation, that the bidders relied on the competitors' alleged misrepresentations. A RICO claim based on predicate acts of mail fraud only required use of the mails as a significant part of the alleged pattern of misrepresentations, and reliance by the county was sufficient to support the RICO claim. Further, the bidders could be injured by the pattern of mail fraud through loss of valuable tax liens even if they did not rely on the misrepresentations.

New Mexico's emergency school tax and its gross receipts tax were levied on the total proceeds received by a domestic corporation under certain contracts entered into outside the state with out-of-state clients for the creation and design of instructional programs. Under such contracts, the taxpayer created within the state a finished product--generally consisting of reproducible originals of books, films, and magnetic audio tapes--and then delivered such finished product to its out-of-state clients. The taxpayer appealed the assessment to the Court of Appeals of New Mexico, which ruled that although the taxes were imposed on the proceeds of out-of-state sales of tangible personal property, rather than on receipts from sales of services performed within New Mexico, nevertheless such taxes were not an unconstitutional burden on interstate commerce (81 NM 724, 472 P2d 987), and the Supreme Court of New Mexico declined to review the judgment. On initial application for certiorari, the United States Supreme Court vacated the judgment and remanded the case to the Court of Appeals of New Mexico for reconsideration in light of the State Attorney General's concession that the state could not validly tax the receipts from sales of tangible personal property outside the state (402 US 969, 29 L Ed 2d 134, 91 S Ct 1655). On remand, the Court of Appeals of New Mexico reinstated and reaffirmed its prior opinion that such receipts could be validly taxed (83 NM 110, 488 P2d 1214), and the Supreme Court of New Mexico declined to review the case.

Petitioner claimant sued respondent United States Department of Labor, alleging violations of the Privacy Act of 1974. The district court granted summary judgment in favor of the claimant and awarded $ 1,000 in statutory damages under 5 U.S.C.S. _ 552a(g)(4). The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit reversed, finding that the claimant failed to raise a triable issue of fact about damages. The claimant petitioned for review. When the claimant filed for black lung benefits, the Government disclosed the claimant's Social Security number beyond the limits set by 5 U.S.C.S. _ 552a of the Privacy Act of 1974. The claimant provided no proof of actual damages; the claimant submitted no corroboration for his claim of emotional distress. The claimant argued that 5 U.S.C.S. _ 552a(g)(4)(A) entitled any plaintiff adversely affected by an intentional or willful violation to the $ 1,000 minimum on proof of nothing more than a statutory violation. The Supreme Court disagreed with the claimant and determined that plaintiffs needed to prove some actual damages to qualify for a minimum statutory award of $ 1,000. The Court found that the "entitlement to recovery" necessary to qualify for the $ 1,000 minimum was not shown merely by an intentional or willful violation of the Act producing some adverse effect, and the statute guaranteed $ 1,000 only to plaintiffs who suffered some actual damages.

To stem the flow of commuter traffic from commercial and industrial districts into adjoining residential neighborhoods, and to reduce air pollution and other environmental effects of automobile commuting, Arlington County, Virginia, adopted a zoning ordinance which provides for the issuance of parking permits to residents of designated residential areas and to certain other persons, and which prohibits the parking of an automobile without a permit in the designated areas between 8 a.m. and 5 p.m. on weekdays. Commuters who had regularly parked in one of the designated residential areas filed suit in the Circuit Court of Arlington County, seeking to enjoin enforcement of the ordinance on state and federal constitutional grounds. The Circuit Court entered judgment for the plaintiffs, and the Supreme Court of Virginia affirmed, holding that the ordinance violated the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment (217 Va 645, 231 SE2d 231).

A provision of the District of Columbia Code made it unlawful (1) to display within 500 feet of a foreign embassy any sign tending to bring a foreign government into public odium or public disrepute (the "display" clause), or (2) to congregate within 500 feet of any foreign embassy and to refuse to disperse after having been ordered so to do by the police (the "congregation" clause). However, a proviso stated that nothing in the provision was to be construed to prohibit picketing as a result of bona fide labor disputes regarding the alteration, repair, or construction of embassy buildings or premises. The provision was originally enacted not by the District of Columbia Council but by Congress, pursuant to its authority under the Federal Constitution (Art I, 8, cl 10) to define and punish offenses against the law of nations, in order to implement the United States' obligation under international law to protect foreign emissaries. Three individuals wished to display signs critical of the governments of the Soviet Union and Nicaragua on the public sidewalks, and to congregate with other persons, within 500 feet of the embassies of those governments in Washington, D.C. These individuals and a political activist brought suit in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia against the Mayor of the District of Columbia and other law enforcement officials, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief on the ground that the provision violated the Federal Constitution's First and Fourteenth Amendments. The District Court granted summary judgment to the District of Columbia officials, saying that the provision served a compelling state interest. The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit affirmed. Considering the provision's two clauses separately, the Court of Appeals held that (1) the display clause was justified by a compelling governmental interest in complying with the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations--which obligates the United States to protect the "dignity" of foreign missions--and was narrowly tailored to serve that interest, (2) the congregation clause should be construed to permit dispersal only of congregations that are directed against the nearby embassy, and only when the police reasonably believe that a threat to the security or peace of the embassy is present, and (3) so narrowed, the congregation clause survived First Amendment scrutiny (798 F2d 1450).

Under the False Claims Act (FCA) (31 USCS 3729-3733), a private person--known as a "relator"--was empowered to bring a qui tam civil action, on behalf of the relator and on behalf of the Federal Government, in the name of the government against any person who allegedly knowingly presented, or caused to be presented, a false or fraudulent claim for payment or approval to an officer or employee of the Federal Government. When such an action was initiated, the government had 60 days to intervene and to assume primary responsibility for prosecuting the action. If the government declined to intervene, then the relator had the exclusive right to conduct the action. Also, regardless of whether the government intervened, the relator would receive a share of any proceeds from the action, plus attorneys' fees and costs. An individual brought such a qui tam action as a relator in the United States District Court for the District of Vermont against the relator's former employer--the state of Vermont's agency of natural resources--which action alleged that the state agency had submitted false claims to the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) in connection with various federal grant programs administered by the EPA by overstating the amount of time spent by the state agency's employees on the federally funded projects. The United States declined to intervene in the action. The state agency then moved to dismiss the action and argued that (1) a state or a state agency was not a "person" subject to liability under the FCA, and (2) a qui tam action in federal court against a state was barred by the Federal Constitution's Eleventh Amendment. The District Court denied the motion. The state agency then filed an interlocutory appeal in the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit and the District Court stayed the proceedings pending the outcome of the state's appeal. The Court of Appeals affirmed the District Court's denial of the state's motion to dismiss the action (162 F3d 195).

After a trial in the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts, the defendants were convicted of bank robbery. The conviction was affirmed by the Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, but on certiorari the Supreme Court of the United States, in Campbell v United States (1961) 365 US 85, 5 L ed 2d 428, 81 S Ct 421, vacated the Court of Appeals' judgment while allowing the conviction to stand pending a redetermination of the defendants' motion for the production of an FBI interview report under the Jencks Act (18 USC 3500), which requires the production of a written statement of a government witness when signed or otherwise adopted or approved by him after the witness has been called by the United States and has testified on direct examination. The District Court held that the FBI interview report was not producible (206 F Supp 213), and the Court of Appeals for the First Circuit agreed but remanded for further findings. (296 F2d 527.) At the second hearing, before a different judge, the District Court concluded that the report was producible, finding that an FBI agent questioned the witness, recited back to the witness the substance of the witness' account, referring to the agent's notes of the interview, received the witness' assurance that he had got it straight, and 7 hours later dictated the report in question primarily from his notes but also from memory. (199 F Supp 905.) The Court of Appeals accepted the second judge's findings but held that the report was not producible. (303 F2d 747.)

In an effort to "close [a] dangerous loophole" in the gun control laws, United States v. Castleman, 572 U. S. _,__, Congress extended the federal prohibition on firearms possession by convicted felons to persons convicted of a "misdemeanor crime of domestic violence," 18 U. S. C. ¬ß922(g)(9). Section 921(a)(33)(A) defines that phrase to include a misdemeanor under federal, state, or tribal law, committed against a domestic relation that necessarily involves the "use ... of physical force." In Castleman, this Court held that a knowing or mntentional assault qualifies as such a crime, but left open whether the same was true of a reckless assault. Petitioner Stephen Voisine pleaded guilty to assaulting his girlfriend in violation of ¬ß207 of the Maine Criminal Code, which makes it a misdemeanor to "intentionally, knowingly or recklessly cause[ ] bodily injury" to another. When law enforcement officials later investigated Voisine for killing a bald eagle, they learned that he owned a rifle. After a background check turned up Voisine's prior conviction under ¬ß207, the Government charged him with violating ¬ß922(g)(9). Petitioner William Armstrong pleaded guilty to assaulting his wife in violation of a Maine domestic violence law making it a misdemeanor to commit an assault prohibited by ¬ß207 against a family or household member. While searching Armstrong's home as part of a narcotics investigation a few years later, law enforcement officers discovered six guns and a large quantity of ammunition. Armstrong was also charged under ¬ß922(g)(9). Both men argued that they were not subject to ¬ß922(g)(9)'s prohibition because their prior convictions could have been based on reckless, rather than knowing or intentional, conduct and thus did not quality as misdemeanor crimes of domestic violence. The District Court rejected those claims, and each petitioner pleaded guilty. The First Circuit affirmed, holding that "an offense with a mens rea of recklessness may qualify as a 'misdemeanor crime of violence' under ¬ß922(g)(9)." Voisine and Armstrong ified a joint petition for certiorari, and their case was remanded for further consideration in light of Castleman. The First Circuit again upheld the convictions on the same ground.

The plaintiffs in the two instant cases purchased house trailers in Nebraska, executing and delivering a note and lien instruments to the local dealer, who in turn negotiated them to one of the defendants, a national bank located in Michigan. Alleging violations of the Nebraska Installment Loan Act, including usury, the plaintiffs brought suit in a Nebraska state court, challenging the validity of the transactions and of the documents executed in connection therewith. The defendant bank claimed that it could not be sued in Nebraska because of 12 USC 94, providing that suits against a national bank may be had in any state or county court in the county in which the bank is located having jurisdiction in similar cases. This contention was rejected by the state courts and judgment was rendered for the plaintiffs. Upon the bank's appeal the Supreme Court of Nebraska affirmed. (172 Neb 385, 109 NW2d 716; 172 Neb 370, 109 NW2d 739.)

Following jury verdicts finding the defendant guilty of making a false statement to a federal agency (18 USCS 1001) and willfully failing to report that he was carrying more than $ 5,000 into the United States (31 USCS 1058, 1101) (recodified at 31 USCS 5322(a), 5316), the trial court sentenced him to a prison term on the false statement count, a felony, and a consecutive term of probation on the currency reporting count, a misdemeanor. Both convictions were based on the defendant's having falsely answered "no" to a question on a Customs form asking whether he was carrying more than $ 5,000 upon his arrival into the country. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit reversed the conviction for making a false statement (726 F2d 1320), concluding that the false statement felony was a lesser included offense of the currency reporting misdemeanor and that Congress presumably intended someone in the defendant's position to be punished only for the currency reporting misdemeanor.

Goods destined for export by rail to Mexico were shipped from the point of origin over a series of connecting carriers under a bill of lading issued by the initial carrier and covering the shipment to the point of export on the Mexican border, the transportation charges being prepaid to that point. The last connecting carrier in the United States issued a new bill of lading which purported to cover the shipment to its ultimate destination in Mexico, but received no payment for transporting the goods other than its share of that paid to the initial carrier under the original bill of lading.

A motorist was stopped by a police officer on suspicion of driving while intoxicated, performed poorly on a series of sobriety tests, and stated to the officer that he had failed the tests because he had been drinking, whereupon the officer arrested the motorist and took him to a booking center. Officers at the booking center, following the usual practice with drunk-driving suspects, videotaped the booking proceedings, during which the motorist, who was informed of the videotaping, (1) responded to questions as to his name, address, height, weight, eye color, date of birth, and current age, stumbling over his address and age; (2) responded to a question whether he knew the date of his sixth birthday, first with an inaudible reply and subsequently by saying, "No, I don't"; (3) repeated the sobriety tests, in which he again performed poorly, and during which he (a) failed to complete requested verbal counts, (b) attempted to explain his difficulties in performing the tests, and (c) often requested clarification of his instructions; and (4) refused to take a breathalyzer test, after asking a number of questions about the law and commenting in the process on his state of inebriation. The motorist was then advised of his Miranda rights for the first time, signed a statement waiving those rights, and admitted under questioning that he had been driving while intoxicated. Both the video and audio portions of the videotape were admitted into evidence at the motorist's bench trial before the Court of Common Pleas of Cumberland County, Pennsylvania, which trial resulted in the motorist's conviction for driving under the influence of alcohol. The motorist moved for a new trial, partly on the ground that the videotape should have been suppressed because it was incriminating and had been completed before the motorist received a Miranda warning. The Court of Common Pleas denied the motion, but the Superior Court of Pennsylvania reversed, as it held that the admission of the videotape had violated the motorist's privilege against self-incrimination under the Federal Constitution's Fifth Amendment, and that the audio portion of the tape should have been suppressed in its entirety (377 Pa Super 382, 547 A2d 419). The Supreme Court of Pennsylvania denied the prosecution's application for review (522 Pa 575, 559 A2d 36).

A lessee of coal mining rights in Federal lands sought to prevent the Secretary of Interior from leasing similar rights in other near-by Federal lands to a competing company, which, after applying for such a lease, had established mines on partially exhausted state-owned lands and desired the Federal lands to prolong its business. The lessee alleged that the proposed lease was in violation of a regulation of the Secretary which instructed the General Land Office to make favorable recommendation on new leases only in cases where there has been furnished a satisfactory showing that an additional coal mine is needed and that there is an actual need for coal which cannot otherwise be reasonably met. The Secretary, however, took the view that the regulation prevented a lease only to a newcomer, but not to an existing mine for the purpose of enabling it to continue an established business.

After a union levied fines on several of its members for strikebreaking, and filed state court suits against nine individual employees to collect the fines, the employer filed a charge against the union, and a complaint was issued alleging that the attempted court enforcement of the fines violated 8(b)(1)(A) of the amended National Labor Relations Act. The NLRB ruled that (1) the union violated 8(b)(1)(A) by imposing disciplinary fines on employees for acts committed after the employees had resigned from the union, (2) the union did not violate 8(b)(1)(A) by fining employees for acts committed before they resigned from the union, and (3) the validly- levied fines would not be examined to determine whether they were impermissibly excessive (185 NLRB No. 23). The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit remanded the case to the NLRB with directions to consider questions relating to the reasonableness of the fines (148 App DC 119, 459 F2d 1143).

Respondent Valencia Gonzales, a death row inmate in Arizona, sought federal habeas relief. His counsel moved to stay the proceedings, contending that Gonzales' mental incompetence prevented him from rationally communicating with or assisting counsel, and that Gonzales was thus entitled to a stay because, under the Ninth Circuit's Rohan decision, what is now 18 U. S. C. ¬ß3599(a)(2) requires a stay when a petitioner is adjudged incompetent. The District Court denied a stay, finding that the claims before it were record based or resolvable as a matter of law and thus would not benefit from Gonzales' input. Gonzales thereafter sought a writ of mandamus in the Ninth Circuit. Applying Rohan and its recent decision in Nash-which gave habeas petitioners a right to competence even on record-based appeals-the court granted the writ, concluding that ¬ß3599 gave Gonzales the right to a stay pending a competency determination. Respondent Sean Carter, a death row inmate in Ohio, initiated federal habeas proceedings but eventually moved for a competency determination and stay of the proceedings. The District Court granted the motion and found Carter incompetent to assist counsel. Applying the Ninth Circuit's Rohan test, it determined that Carter's assistance was required to develop four of his exhausted claims. It thus dismissed his habeas petition without prejudice and prospectively tolled the statute of limitations. On appeal, the Sixth Circuit, relying in part on Rees v. Peyton, 384 U. S. 312 (Rees 1), located a statutory right to competence in 18 U. S. C. ¬ß4241, and found that a court could employ that provision whenever a capital habeas petitioner seeks to forgo his petition. It thus ordered that Carter's petition be stayed indefinitely with respect to any claims requiring his assistance.

Respondent, an integrated supplier-retailer of gasoline, granted a price cut to one of its many independently owned retail station customers in order to enable that customer to meet the competition of a gas station engaged solely in retail operations. The Federal Trade Commission filed a complaint charging respondent with price discrimination violative of 2(a) of the Clayton Act, as amended by the Robinson-Patman Act (15 USC 13(a)). Respondent defended on the ground that its price cut fell within the protection afforded by 2(b) of the act to price cuts made "in good faith to meet an equally low price of a competitor" (15 USC 13(b)). The Commission rejected this defense and held that a violation of 2(a) was established. (55 FTC 955.) The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit reversed, concluding that respondent was entitled to assert the 2(b) defense. (294 F2d 465.)

The attorneys contended that, in providing legal advice and services to clients, the attorneys were not debt relief agencies and thus were not precluded from advising clients to incur more debt in contemplation of filing for bankruptcy. The attorneys argued that they were also not subject to the disclosure requirements applicable to debt relief agencies which curtailed the attorneys' freedom of speech. The U.S. Supreme Court unanimously held that the attorneys were debt relief agencies. In providing bankruptcy assistance, which was defined as including services commonly provided by attorneys, the attorneys were clearly within the definition of a debt relief agency, even though attorneys were not expressly included in such definition. Further, the attorneys were not precluded under 11 U.S.C.S. ¬¨√ü 526(a)(4) from advising clients to incur more debt for valid purposes, and were only precluded from providing such advice when contemplation of bankruptcy was the impelling reason for the advice. Also, the disclosure requirements of 11 U.S.C.S. ¬¨√ü 528 were not unconstitutional since the requirements were reasonably related to the government's interest in preventing consumer deception.

The defendant was convicted of second degree murder upon trial in a Connecticut state court, and the conviction was affirmed by the Supreme Court of Connecticut. (155 Conn 124, 230 A2d 573.) The trial court admitted a confession and evidence as to the defendant's partial re-enactment of the crime at the request of the police, which confession and re-enactment had been made on the third day of interrogation after the defendant's arrest on a coroner's warrant, and had been preceded by two earlier confessions that the trial judge excluded from evidence as not having been voluntarily made. During the 30 to 48 hours that the defendant was held for interrogation by the police, the defendant's attorneys had made numerous unsuccessful attempts to communicate with the defendant or the officer in charge, even obtaining a writ of habeas corpus issued by a state judge, which proved fruitless when the sheriff could not locate the officer in charge or the coroner, and the defendant had been denied permission to communicate with the outside world on three separate occasions.

An employee injured while working for an employer in Texas filed a claim with the Texas Industrial Accident Board for $ 14,035, the maximum recovery allowable under Texas law. The board awarded him only $ 1,050. The employer's insurance carrier then filed a diversity suit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Texas to set aside the award, alleging that the employee had claimed, was claiming, and would claim $ 14,035, but denying that the employee was entitled to recover anything under Texas law. Relying on 28 USC 1332, which limits federal diversity jurisdiction to actions involving an amount in controversy in excess of $ 10,000, the District Court dismissed the action on the theory that the amount in controversy in the present case was only the amount of the award ($ 1,050). The Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit reversed. (275 F2d 148.)

A city and county in Michigan each assessed a tax against a subcontractor under a government contract. The tax was based, in part, on the value of materials and work in process in the subcontractors's possession to which the United States held legal title under the terms of the subcontract. The subcontractor paid this part of each tax under protest and then sued in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan for a refund. It contended that full title to the property was in the United States and that the taxes infringed the federal government's immunity from state taxation to the extent they were based on such property. The government intervened on the subcontractor's behalf. On motion for summary judgment the District Court entered judgment for the subcontractor (132 F Supp 899) and the Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit affirmed (235 F2d 380).

Petitioner was arrested during a traffic stop by a New Jersey state trooper who checked a statewide computer database and found a bench warrant issued for petitioner's arrest after he failed to appear at a hearing to enforce a fine. He was initially detained in the Burlington County Detention Center and later in the Essex County Correctional Facility, but was released once it was determined that the fine had been paid. At the first jail, petitioner, like every incoming detainee, had to shower with a delousing agent and was checked for scars, marks, gang tattoos, and contraband as he disrobed. Petitioner claims that he also had to open his mouth, lift his tongue, hold out his arms, turn around, and lift his genitals. At the second jail, petitioner, like other arriving detainees, had to remove his clothing while an officer looked for body markings, wounds, and contraband; had an officer look at his ears, nose, mouth, hair, scalp, fingers, hands, armpits, and other body openings; had a mandatory shower; and had his clothes examined. Petitioner claims that he was also required to lift his genitals, turn around, and cough while squatting. He filed a 42 U. S. C. ¬ß1983 action in the Federal District Court against the government entities that ran the jails and other defendants, alleging Fourth and Fourteenth Amendment violations, and arguing that persons arrested for minor offenses cannot be subjected to invasive searches unless prison officials have reason to suspect concealment of weapons, drugs, or other contraband. The court granted him summary judgment, ruling that "strip-searching" nonindictable offenders without reasonable suspicion violates the Fourth Amendment. The Third Circuit reversed.

The motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis, the motion for leave to supplement the petition for certiorari and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is reversed. Russell v. United States, 369 U.S. 749; Silber v. United States, ante, p. 717.

In a suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Texas, certain voters in a tax bond election for Fort Worth, Texas, challenged the constitutionality of provisions of the state constitution, state statutes, and the city's charter limiting the right to vote in city bond elections to persons who have rendered (listed with tax authorities) some real, mixed, or personal property for local taxation. A three-judge District Court held that the challenged laws violated the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment (377 F Supp 1016).

Respondent Hyatt claims that he moved from California to Nevada in 1991, but petitioner Franchise Tax Board of California, a state agency, claims that he actually moved in 1992 and thus owes California millions in taxes, penalties, and interest. Hyatt ified suit in Nevada state court, which had jurisdiction over California under Nevada v. Hall, 440 U. 5. 410, seeking damages for California's alleged abusive audit and investigation practices. After this Court armed the Nevada Supreme Court's ruling that Nevada courts, as a matter of comity, would immunize California to the same extent that Nevada law would immunize its own agencies and officials, see Franchise Tax Rd. of Cal. v. Hyatt, 538 U. 5. 488, 499, the case went to trial, where Hyatt was awarded almost $500 million in damages and fees. On appeal, California argued that the Constitution's Full Faith and Credit Clause, Art. IV, ¬ß 1, required Nevada to limit damages to $50,000, the maximum that Nevada law would permit in a similar suit against its own officials. The Nevada Supreme Court, however, affirmed $1 million of the award and ordered a retrial on another damages issue, stating that the $50,000 maximum would not apply on remand.

A federally chartered, federally insured savings association in New Jersey went into receivership, with the Resolution Trust Corporation (RTC)--subsequently replaced by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC)--as receiver. The RTC, as receiver, brought an action in the United States District Court for the District of New Jersey against several of the savings association's officers and directors, in which action it was alleged that various acts or omissions on the part of the defendants (1) had led the savings association to make bad loans; and (2) amounted to gross negligence, simple negligence, and breaches of fiduciary duty for purposes of federal common law. The defendants moved to dismiss under 12 USCS 1821(k), which (1) provided that a director or officer of a federally insured depository institution could be held personally liable for monetary damages for "gross negligence" or conduct demonstrating a greater disregard of a duty of care than gross negligence; and (2) contained a savings clause to the effect that nothing in 1821(k) would impair or affect any right of the RTC under "other applicable law." The District Court, in dismissing all but the gross negligence claims, expressed the view that 1821(k), by authorizing actions for gross negligence or more seriously culpable conduct, intended to forbid actions based upon less seriously culpable conduct, such as simple negligence. The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, in reversing in pertinent part on interlocutory appeal, concluded that the receiver could pursue any claims for negligence or breach of fiduciary duty available as a matter of federal common law, as (1) 1821(k) simply offered a safeguard against state legislation that had watered down applicable state standards of care below a gross negligence benchmark; (2) 1821(k), as so interpreted, did not prohibit actions resting upon stricter standard of care rules originating in state law or federal common law; and (3) federal common law was applicable to federally chartered depository institutions such as the savings association in question (57 F.3d 1231).

Upon remand by the United States Supreme Court for further proceedings consistent with the Supreme Court's opinion (386 US 237, 18 L Ed 2d 18, 87 S Ct 1003), the Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit held that a formula developed by the Federal Power Commission required that in determining gas rates for a natural-gas transmission company, the consolidated return tax savings coming to the company must be first allocated to the company's nonjurisdictional income. (388 F2d 385.)

In 1973, students in the Columbus, Ohio, school system brought an action in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Ohio, claiming that the Columbus Board of Education and its officials had pursued and were pursuing a course of conduct having the purpose and effect of causing and perpetuating racial segregation in the public schools in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment. A trial was held in 1976 in which the District Court found that (1) in 1954, when the United States Supreme Court had ruled that the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment prohibits states from maintaining racially segregated schools, the Board had not been operating a racially neutral, unitary school system, but had been operating separate, black schools in one area of the city, such racial separation being the direct result of cognitive acts or omissions of the school board administrators and members who had originally intentionally caused and later perpetuated the racial isolation, (2) the Board had been under a continuous constitutional obligation to disestablish the dual school system in existence in 1954 and had failed to discharge its duty, and (3) in the intervening years since 1954 the Board's actions and practices could not reasonably be explained without reference to racial concerns that intentionally aggravated, rather than alleviated, racial separation in the schools, such matters including the practice of assigning black teachers only to those schools with substantial black student populations, the use of optional attendance zones, discontiguous attendance zones and boundary changes, and the selection of sites for new school construction that had the foreseeable and anticipated effect of maintaining the racial separation of schools. The District Court concluded that at the time of trial, segregation of the races in the Columbus school system had directly resulted from the Board's intentional segregative acts and omissions in violation of equal protection under the Fourteenth Amendment. It enjoined continuing discrimination on the basis of race and ordered submission of a systemwide desegregation plan (429 F Supp 229). The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit affirmed on appeal, examining the extensive record in the case on its own and concluding that the District Court's findings of fact were not clearly erroneous and that the District Court had not misunderstood or misapplied the Fourteenth Amendment and relevant cases construing it (583 F2d 787).

An employee of the Federal Government--charged with theft of government funds, making false claims against the government, and attempted tax evasion--pleaded guilty pursuant to an agreement which stated the parties' expectation that the employee would be sentenced within a range identified by the Guidelines of the United States Sentencing Commission (18 USCS Appx) as corresponding to a particular offense level and criminal history category. The probation officer's presentence report (1) confirmed this expectation, (2) found the applicable sentencing range to be 30 to 37 months' imprisonment, and (3) concluded that there were no factors that would warrant departure from the guideline sentence. The United States District Court for the District of Columbia, however, announced at the conclusion of the sentencing hearing that the court would depart from the Guidelines' sentencing range and sentence the employee to 60 months' imprisonment, based on (1) the extensive duration of the employee's criminal conduct, (2) the disruption to governmental functions caused by the employee's criminal conduct, and (3) the employee's use of tax evasion to conceal his other offenses. On appeal, the employee argued that Rule 32 of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure--which provides in part that counsel for each side must be provided an opportunity, at the sentencing hearing, to comment on the probation officer's determination and on "other matters relating to the appropriate sentence"--required the District Court to furnish advance notice of its intent to depart from the Guidelines. In affirming the sentence, the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit pointed out that Rule 32 contained no express language requiring a Federal District Court to notify the parties of its intent to depart from the Guidelines on its own motion (282 App DC 194, 893 F2d 1343).

A vertically integrated poultry business refused to bargain with a union representing truck drivers employed by the business to transport poultry feed from the business' feedmill to independently owned farms which contracted to raise the business' chickens. The business contended that the drivers were agricultural laborers under 2(3) of the National Labor Relations Act (29 USCS 152(3)), which provides that agricultural laborers are not "employees" within the coverage of the Act, and under the related definition of "agriculture" in 3(f) of the Fair Labor Standards Act (29 USCS 203(f)). Sustaining the union's unfair labor practice charge against the employer, the National Labor Relations Board held that the drivers were not "agricultural laborers" and ordered the employer to bargain with the union (216 NLRB 502). The United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit sustained the Board's order (527 F2d 436).

The plaintiffs, having been indicted in a New York state court on charges of criminal anarchy, requested the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York to grant injunctive relief and a declaratory judgment to the effect that the New York criminal anarchy statutes were unconstitutional under the First and Fourteenth Amendments. The plaintiffs alleged that the state criminal proceedings would harass them and cause them to suffer irreparable injury. A three-judge District Court, dismissing the plaintiffs' complaint, held that the New York criminal anarchy statutes were constitutional (288 F Supp 348).

An individual was an Alabama-licensed agent for two insurance companies which were distinct and nonaffiliated entities. The first company wrote life insurance, but not group health insurance for municipalities; the second company wrote such group health insurance. The individual, presenting himself as an agent of the first company, (1) solicited an Alabama city for both life and health insurance for the city's employees; (2) prepared separate applications for (a) life insurance with the first company, and (b) health insurance with the second company; and (3) submitted the initial premium payments to the insurers with the applications. Later health premium payments were supposed to be effected through payroll deductions and the city clerk's issuance of checks to the individual, but the individual allegedly misappropriated most of the payments. The second company then sent notices of lapsed health coverage to city employees in care of the individual and of another person who was in charge of an Alabama office of the first company, but those notices were not forwarded to the employees. Several city employees eventually (1) filed suit in the Circuit Court for Jefferson County, Alabama against the first company and the individual, but not against the second company; (2) alleged that the individual had collected premiums but failed to remit them, so that the employees' health insurance policies had supposedly lapsed without their knowledge; and (3) claimed damages for fraud. The trial court found that the employees did not know that their health policies had been canceled, and the case against the first company was submitted to the jury under (1) a theory of respondeat superior; and (2) instructions to the effect that if the jury determined that there was liability for fraud, then the jury could award punitive damages. The jury returned general verdicts for the employees against both the first insurance company and the individual. The largest such award--$ 1,040,000 in favor of one employee--may have contained a punitive damages component of not less than $ 840,000. On appeal by the first company, the Supreme Court of Alabama, in affirming, expressed the view that (1) punitive damages were recoverable in Alabama for deceit or willful fraud; (2) on the evidence in the case at hand, the jury could not have concluded that the individual's misrepresentations were made either innocently or mistakenly; and (3) the punitive damages award did not violate the due process clause of the Federal Constitution's Fourteenth Amendment (553 So 2d 537). The first company then petitioned for certiorari.

At retirement an employee was not credited under his company's pension plan for a 30-month break in his employment service covering the time he spent in the military. With the assistance of the United States Attorney, he brought suit against his employer in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Alabama, claiming that under 9 of the Military Selective Service Act (38 USCS 2021), requiring an employer to restore an employee returning from military service to his former position or "to a position of like seniority, status, or pay," he was entitled to credit toward his pension for his period of military service. The District Court held that the employee was entitled to credit for the time of his military service (383 F Supp 880), and, on appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit affirmed (542 F2d 650).

In a prosecution in the United States District Court for the Central District of California, on a charge of violating 18 USCS 1708 by possessing United States Treasury checks stolen from the mails, knowing them to be stolen, the trial court instructed the jury that ordinarily it would be justified in inferring, from the defendant's unexplained possession of recently stolen mail, that he possessed the mail with knowledge that it was stolen. The jury found the accused guilty, the District Court sentenced him, and the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit affirmed (466 F2d 1361).

Where a court of appeals has originally held that an order of the National Labor Relations Board was vitiated by the examiner's bias, and, after reversal by the Supreme Court, again refuses to enforce the Board's order, this time on the ground of lack of substantial evidence to support it, the Supreme Court, in reviewing the latter judgment, will take care that the court of appeals, on reconsidering the record, has not been influenced by its former holding. However, no such influence is shown where the new opinion was written by a different judge, and the court was differently constituted and painstakingly reviewed the record.

This case presented the question whether attorney's fees incurred by a plaintiff subsequent to an offer of settlement under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 68, providing that a plaintiff who rejects a defendant's formal settlement offer must pay the costs incurred after the making of the offer if he fails to obtain a judgment more favorable than the offer, must be paid by the defendant under 42 USCS 1988, allowing attorney's fees as costs to prevailing parties in civil rights actions, when the plaintiff recovers a judgment less than the offer. A father brought an action in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois under 42 USCS 1983 and state tort law against three police officers for the wrongful killing of the father's adult son. Prior to trial, the police officers made a timely offer of settlement under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 68 for "a sum, including costs now accrued and attorney fees, of $ 100,000," but the father did not accept the offer. The case went to trial and the father was awarded $ 5,000 on the state law wrongful death claim, $ 52,000 for the violation of 42 USCS 1983, and $ 3,000 in punitive damages. The father requested $ 171,692.47 in costs, including attorney's fees. This amount included costs incurred after the settlement offer. The District Court declined to award costs incurred after the offer of judgment, and the parties agreed that $ 32,000 fairly represented the allowable costs, including attorney's fees, accrued prior to the offer of settlement (547 F Supp 542). The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit reversed (720 F2d 474).

Arizona prisoners may raise claims of ineffective assistance of trial counsel only in state collateral proceedings, not on direct review. In petitioner Martinez's first state collateral proceeding, his counsel did not raise such a claim. On federal habeas review with new counsel, Martinez argued that he received ineffective assistance both at trial and in his first state collateral proceeding. He also claimed that he had a constitutional right to an effective attorney in the collateral proceeding because it was the first place to raise his claim of ineffective assistance at trial. The District Court denied the petition, finding that Arizona's preclusion rule was an adequate and independent state-law ground barring federal review, and that under Coleman v. Thompson, 501 U. S. 722, the attorney's errors in the postconviction proceeding did not qualify as cause to excuse the procedural default. The Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit affirmed.

At the close of the defendant's nonjury criminal trial in the Supreme Court of Richmond County, New York, the defense counsel's request to make a summation of the evidence before the rendition of the judgment was denied by the trial judge in reliance upon a New York statute which conferred upon the court in such a trial discretion to permit the parties to deliver summations. The Appellate Division of the New York Supreme Court, Second Department, affirmed the conviction without opinion (43 App Div 2d 816, 351 NYS2d 368), and the New York Court of Appeals denied leave to appeal.

The defendant was convicted after a trial in the California Superior Court, Los Angeles County, at which there was introduced in evidence a transcript of the preliminary hearing testimony of the victim, who at the time of the trial was in another state but who was not subpoenaed although his relatives and employer were contacted and telegrams were allegedly received from him. On appeal, the California Court of Appeal for the Second District affirmed, holding that this procedure did not deny the defendant his Sixth Amendment right to be confronted with witnesses against him. (258 Cal App 2d 622, 66 Cal Rptr 213.) The California Supreme Court denied the defendant a hearing. Nineteen days later the United States Supreme Court in Barber v Page, 390 US 719, 20 L Ed 2d 255, 88 S Ct 1318, held that the absence of a witness from the jurisdiction does not justify the use at trial of preliminary hearing testimony unless the state has made a good-faith effort to secure the witness' presence.

The use in a federal criminal case of testimony as to damaging admissions by the accused in a conversation on the premises of the accused which the witness, outside such premises, was enabled to overhear by a radio transmitter concealed on the person of the other party to the conversation, was held by five members of the Court, in an opinion by Jackson, J., not to violate the constitutional immunity of the accused from unreasonable searches and seizures, not to be within the prohibition of the Federal Wire Tapping Act, and not to be inconsistent with fair play in federal law enforcement.

The present cases concern the constitutionality of nondiscriminatory state net income tax laws (No. 12 involving a Minnesota statute and No. 33 a Georgia statute) levying taxes on that portion of a foreign corporation's net income earned from and fairly apportioned to business activities within the taxing state when those activities are exclusively in furtherance of interstate commerce. In No. 12, upon the corporation's refusal to pay taxes, the state brought an action in the Hennepin County District Court for recovery of income taxes allegedly owed for 1933 through 1948. The court, sustaining the tax, entered judgment for the state, which, on appeal, was affirmed by the Supreme Court of Minnesota. (250 Minn 32, 84 NW2d 373.) The corporation appealed to the United States Supreme Court. In No. 33, the taxpayer, after paying the taxes, brought a suit for refund in the Superior Court, Fulton County. The trial court sustained the tax. On appeal, the Supreme Court of Georgia held that the statute, as applied, violated the commerce clause of the Federal Constitution and reversed the judgment. (213 Ga 713, 101 SE2d 197.) The United States Supreme Court granted the state's petition for certiorari.

Petitioner obtained a divorce from her husband in an Illinois state court with a judgment for monthly instalments of alimony until remarriage. Subsequently she married in Nevada a person who had on the same day obtained a Nevada divorce from his wife, a New York resident, who had not been served in Nevada nor appeared in the divorce proceedings. After this Nevada divorce decree had been declared void by a New York court having jurisdiction of the parties, petitioner obtained a valid New York decree against her second husband annulling her Nevada marriage and then married a third man. In the present case she invoked the diversity jurisdiction of a federal district court in Illinois in an action against her first husband for unpaid instalments of alimony for the period from her Nevada marriage to her New York marriage.

A District Court appointed an equity receiver for a corporation and suspended payment of its debts. The equity receivership was succeeded by reorganization proceedings under _ 77B of the Bankruptcy Act and later by a Chapter X proceeding. The District Court held the first mortgage bondholders entitled to interest on interest accruing after the receivership, on the theory that the validity of the covenant therefor was determined by New York law and that it was valid thereunder.

Five years after the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) first approved metoclopramide, a drug commonly used to treat digestive tract problems, under the brand name Reglan, generic manufacturers such as petitioners also began producing the drug. Because of accumulating evidence that long-term metoclopramide use can cause tardive dyskinesia, a severe neurological disorder, warning labels for the drug have been strengthened and clarified several times, most recently in 2009. Respondents were prescribed Reglan in 2001 and 2002, but both received the generic drug from their pharmacists. After taking the drug as prescribed for several years, both developed tardive dyskinesia. In separate state-court tort actions, they sued petitioners, the generic drug manufacturers that produced the metoclopramide they took (Manufacturers). Each respondent alleged, inter alia, that longterm metoclopramide use caused her disorder and that the Manufacturers were liable under state tort law for failing to provide adequate warning labels. In both suits, the Manufacturers urged that federal statutes and FDA regulations pre-empted the state tort claims by requiring the same safety and efficacy labeling for generic metoclopramide as was mandated at the time for Reglan. The Fifth and Eighth Circuits rejected these arguments, holding that respondents‚Äô claims were not pre-empted.

If one of the federal agencies covered by the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) (5 USCS 552) denies a request for information, the FOIA, in 552(a)(4)(B), confers jurisdiction on the Federal District Courts "to order the production of any agency records improperly withheld." The Tax Division of the United States Department of Justice, as the representative of the Federal Government in nearly all civil tax cases in the Federal District Courts, receives copies of all opinions and orders issued by those courts in such cases. The Division sends the originals to official Department files and makes copies for Division use. An organization published (1) a weekly magazine including summaries of recent federal court decisions on tax issues, and (2) a daily electronic data base including summaries and full texts of recent federal court tax decisions. After the organization, in 1979, first filed with the Department a FOIA request for the Division's copies of District Court tax opinions, a compromise was arranged, whereby the request was withdrawn, while the organization obtained access to the Division's weekly log of tax cases. The organization then directly requested copies of the decisions noted on the log from the respective District Court clerks and from participating attorneys. However, the organization, frustrated by alleged delays and gaps in the process, initiated, in 1984-1985, a new, approximately weekly series of FOIA requests, in each of which the organization asked the Department to provide to make available copies of all District Court tax opinions and final orders identified in the Division's weekly logs. The Department denied the requests, and the organization's administrative appeal was unsuccessful. The organization then filed suit in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia and sought, under the FOIA, to compel the Department to provide the organization with access to such decisions, but the District Court granted the Department's motion to dismiss the complaint, on the ground that the decisions had not been "improperly withheld," under 552(a)(4)(B), because the decisions were already available on the public record from their primary sources, the District Courts (643 F Supp 740). On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, reversing, expressed the view that (1) the District Court decisions had been "improperly withheld," even though the decisions were available elsewhere; (2) the decisions were "agency records," even though the decisions had originated in a part of the Federal Government not covered by the FOIA; and (3) on remand, the District Court was to enter an order directing the Department to provide some reasonable form of access to the decisions (269 App DC 315, 845 F2d 1060).

After the plaintiff had been sentenced to death by a court-martial for murder under Article 118 of the Uniform Code of Military Justice (10 USCS 918), the President, in 1960, commuted the sentence to life imprisonment, subject to the condition that the plaintiff would not thereafter be eligible for parole. In 1971 the plaintiff filed suit in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia to require the members of the United States Board of Parole to consider him for parole.
