The trial court dismissed the action on the ground that the arrangement did not violate the Florida right-to-work law. (41 L.R.R.M. 2300.) The Florida Supreme Court reversed, holding that state law forbids, and that the state courts could deal with, the agency shop clause involved (141 So 2d 269).

An attorney who was representing the plaintiff in a copyright infringement action filed in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York joined with another attorney to form a law partnership during pretrial litigation in such action. Subsequent to the formation of the partnership, all court papers in the case were signed both with the law partnership's name and by the plaintiff's original attorney as "a member of the firm." At trial, the court granted the defendants' motion for a directed verdict on the plaintiff's claim that documents purporting to grant the defendants an option to develop the plaintiff's copyrighted work commercially had been forged by one of the defendants; the jury returned a verdict against the plaintiff on all remaining claims. The defendants thereafter moved for sanctions, against the plaintiff's law firm and against both members of the firm individually, under Rule 11 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure--which provides, among other things, that a court shall impose an appropriate sanction upon the "person who signed" a pleading, motion, or other paper which was not "well grounded in fact"--on the ground that the forgery claim had no basis in fact and had not been investigated sufficiently by counsel. The District Court granted the motion and imposed a monetary sanction under Rule 11 against the law firm (111 FRD 637). Two weeks later, the law firm was dissolved, and the attorney who had not signed any of the court papers moved in the District Court to relieve the firm of the sanction. The District Court granted the motion in part and denied it in part, ruling that (1) half of the sanction would be shifted from the firm to the signing attorney, since the firm did not exist during a portion of the litigation and was thus not fully responsible for the Rule 11 violations, but (2) the remaining half of the sanction could be imposed, pursuant to Rule 11, on both the individual attorney and the law firm on whose behalf he signed the papers (650 F Supp 684). On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, affirming, expressed the view that nothing in the language of Rule 11 prohibited the imposition of sanctions on a signer's law firm, as well as on the individual attorney who signed an offending paper (854 F2d 1452).

A Virginia statute imposed upon a railway express company, doing exclusively interstate business in Virginia, a franchise tax in lieu of taxes upon all of its other intangible property and in lieu of property taxes on its rolling stock, measured by gross receipts derived from the transportation within Virginia of "express transported through, into, or out of this State." The taxpayer contended that the statute was a "privilege tax" and, like the statute invalidated in Railway Express Agency v Virginia, 347 US 359, 98 L ed 757, 74 S Ct 558, violated the commerce clause of the Federal Constitution; and that in any event the assessment under it was calculated in such a manner as to deprive taxpayer of its property without due process of law in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment. The Supreme Court of Appeals of Virginia sustained the statute and assessment against these attacks. (199 Va 589, 100 SE2d 785.)

The plaintiff, a New York corporation doing business in Texas, purchased insurance agreements covering risks connected with property located in Texas from Lloyds of London, England, and the Institute of London Underwriters. Taxes on the premiums paid under these policies were exacted from the plaintiff under a Texas statute providing that if any person shall purchase from an insurer not licensed in Texas a policy of insurance covering risks within the state in a manner other than through an insurance agent licensed in Texas, such person shall pay a tax of 5 percent of the amount of the gross premiums paid by the insured. The present action was instituted by the insured in a Texas state court to recover the taxes paid under protest. Judgment for the plaintiff was affirmed by the Court of Civil Appeals of Texas (340 SW2d 339) and an application for writ of error was refused by the Supreme Court of Texas (162 Tex 8, 343 SW2d 241).

While a railroad employee's action against his employer, alleging wrongful discharge and denial of a fair hearing, was pending in a Utah state court, the United States Supreme Court decided Andrews v Louisville & Nashville R. Co. (1972) 406 US 320, 32 L Ed 2d 95, 92 S Ct 1562, holding that a railroad employee alleging a violation of a collective bargaining agreement must submit such a dispute to the National Railroad Adjustment Board for resolution in accordance with the provisions of the Railway Labor Act (45 USCS 151-188). By stipulation of the parties, the state court action was dismissed, and the employee instituted a proceeding before the Adjustment Board. The Board dismissed the employee's action for failure to comply with the time limits prescribed by the collective bargaining agreement, holding that the agreement's time requirements were not tolled during the pendency of the state court action. The employee then instituted an action in the United States District Court for the District of Utah, seeking an order directing the Board to hear the merits of his case, but the District Court affirmed the Board's order and held that the employee had failed to establish any of the grounds for reversal of Board orders specified in the Act (45 USCS 153 First (q)) (423 F Supp 324). The United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit reversed, remanding the case to the Board (576 F2d 854).

The defendant was convicted in the United States District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania for (1) wilful failure to pay the excise tax imposed on wagering by 26 USC 4401, (2) wilful failure to pay the occupational tax imposed by 26 USC 4411 for engaging in the business of accepting wagers, and (3) conspiracy to defraud the United States by evading payment of these taxes. The District Court rejected the defendant's contention that requiring him to pay the excise tax would violate his constitutional privilege against self-incrimination. The Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit affirmed the defendant's convictions. (358 F2d 154).

Under a contract with the Federal Government, an engineering company managed oil drilling operations at a federal petroleum reserve in California. The contractor received an annual fixed fee plus reimbursement for costs including state sales and use taxes. For the years 1975 through 1981, California--in two deficiency notices issued in July 1978 and December 1982--assessed approximately $ 14 million in sales and use taxes against the contractor. At the direction of the Federal Government, the contractor, arguing that California had misapplied its own tax law, applied to the California board of equalization for an administrative redetermination of the assessments. With minor exceptions, the board denied each of the contractor's reassessment claims. Thereafter, the contractor paid the assessments under protest, using funds provided by the Federal Government. The contractor then filed timely actions on both claims against California in California state court. In January 1988, California and the contractor stipulated to (1) a $ 3 million refund for erroneous assessments on property purchased by the contractors and installed by the Federal Government; and (2) dismissal of both actions without prejudice. In May 1988, the Federal Government, seeking a refund of the remaining $ 11 million in sales and use taxes paid by the contractor, plus interest, filed suit against California in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of California. The Federal Government, which initially sought a declaratory judgment that California had erroneously taxed the contractor under California law, contended in the course of the suit that it was entitled to recovery based on the federal common-law cause of action for money had and received. Rejecting both grounds for recovery, the District Court granted summary judgment for California. On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, affirming, expressed the view that (1) the Federal Government could not maintain a federal quasi-contract action for money had and received because the facts did not support a claim of unjust enrichment; (2) the Federal Government had failed to satisfy the conditions precedent under California law to a state cause of action for a tax refund, which conditions included the filing of a court action within 90 days of an administrative denial; and (3) the 6-year statute of limitations under 28 USCS 2415(a) for quasi-contract actions did not apply, since the Federal Government had never acquired a cause of action (932 F2d 1346).

A defendant, claiming that he had become insane after conviction and sentence of death, asked the governor of the state to postpone execution on that ground. Under a statute which conferred upon the governor exclusive authority to pass upon this request, without, however, requiring a hearing or permitting judicial review of his findings, the governor denied the claim, after three physicians appointed by him had examined the defendant and declared him sane. The defendant's petition for habeas corpus was denied in the state courts.

The Communications Act of 1934, as amended, requires state or local governments to act on siting applications for wireless facilities "within a reasonable period of time after the request is duly filed." 47 U. S. C. ¬ß332(c)(7)(B)(ii). Relying on its broad authority to implement the Communications Act, see 47 U. S. C. ¬ß201(b), the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) issued a Declaratory Ruling concluding that the phrase "reasonable period of time" is presumptively (but rebuttably) 90 days to process an application to place a new antenna on an existing tower and 150 days to process all other applications. The cities of Arlington and San Antonio, Texas, sought review of the Declaratory Ruling in the Fifth Circuit. They argued that the Commission lacked authority to interpret ¬ß332(c)(7)(B)'s limitations. The Court of Appeals, relying on Circuit precedent holding that Chevron U. S. A. Inc. v. Natural Resources Defense Council, Inc., 467 U. S. 837, applies to an agency's interpretation of its own statutory jurisdiction, applied Chevron to that question. Finding the statute ambiguous, it upheld as a permissible construction of the statute the FCC's view that ¬ß201(b)'s broad grant of regulatory authority empowered it to administer ¬ß332(c)(7)(B).

The United States Supreme Court has developed a doctrine of qualified immunity that--as applied to damages actions, under provisions such as 42 USCS 1983, charging public officials with violation of a federal right--shields public officials from such damages actions unless the officials' conduct was unreasonable in light of clearly established law. In 1987, some police officers in Idaho made a warrantless arrest of a suspect by surrounding the house in which he resided and ordering him to come out. As the suspect came out, he had an epileptic seizure, fell on a concrete walk, and was seriously injured. The suspect--alleging that the warrantless arrest had violated his right under the Federal Constitution's Fourth Amendment to be secure against unreasonable seizure--sued the arresting officers in the United States District Court for the District of Idaho for damages under 1983. The District Court, however, in granting summary judgment for the officers on qualified immunity grounds, expressed the view that (1) it was not clear that the warrant requirement applied when officers surrounded a house and requested an individual inside to come out and surrender; and (2) there was "no controlling ... Ninth Circuit case law" (751 F Supp 858). On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in affirming, (1) noted that a 1985 Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit decision in another case might have alerted a reasonable officer to the constitutional implications of putting a suspect under arrest after the suspect had come outside his house pursuant to an order to exit; but (2) expressed the view that the suspect in question could not benefit from the 1985 decision, as a plaintiff could not benefit on appeal from precedent which neither the plaintiff nor the District Court had mentioned in the first instance (975 F2d 1388).

A railroad employee sought recovery under the Federal Employers' Liability Act for injuries sustained by him in the following manner: while engaged in burning weeds from the railroad tracks with a hand torch the employee noted the approach of a train and, in compliance with his employer's instructions, ran off the track to a point near a culvert in order to observe the passing train for hotboxes; the passing train fanned flames from the burning weeds, and the employee, in retreating from the place in which he was standing in order to avoid the flames, fell from the top of the culvert. At the trial in the Circuit Court of the City of St. Louis, Missouri, judgment was entered on a jury verdict in favor of the employee.

A group of debtors made a payment on a bona fide debt by delivering a check to a creditor on November 18, 1985, which check was dated November 19 and was honored by the drawee bank on November 20. On February 18, 1986, the debtors filed petitions for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code (11 USCS 1101-1174), which petitions were consolidated into a single bankruptcy proceeding. The trustee for the bankruptcy estate filed an adversary proceeding against the creditor in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the District of New Mexico, which proceeding claimed that the check payment was avoidable under 11 USCS 547(b)(4)(A) as a "transfer" made within 90 days before the date of the filing of the bankruptcy petition, as the trustee asserted that the "transfer" occurred for purposes of 547(b) on the date the check was honored by the drawee bank, which date, as the parties agreed, was the 90th day before the bankruptcy filing. The Bankruptcy Court held that the transfer occurred on the date the check was delivered to the creditor, and accordingly dismissed the trustee's claim (97 BR 69). The United States District Court for the District of New Mexico affirmed (111 BR 337). However, the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit, holding that a payment by check is deemed to have occurred for purposes of 547(b) when the check is honored by the drawee bank, reversed the judgment of the District Court and remanded the case for further proceedings (931 F2d 689).

Under rent regulations promulgated pursuant to the Emergency Price Control Act, the Price Administrator issued an order granting to landlords of residential properties special certificates authorizing eviction proceedings.

The investors alleged that the underwriters, during initial public offerings, unlawfully agreed with one another that they would not sell shares of a popular new issue to an investor unless that investor committed (1) to buy additional shares of that security later at escalating prices ("laddering"), (2) to pay unusually high commissions on subsequent security purchases from the underwriters, or (3) to purchase from the underwriters other less desirable securities ("tying"). The Court determined that the securities laws implicitly precluded the application of the antitrust laws to the conduct alleged because the securities laws were "clearly incompatible" with the application of the antitrust laws in this context since (1) the conduct was squarely within the heartland of securities regulations, (2) the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) had a clear and adequate authority to regulate the conduct, (3) the SEC actively enforced the rules and regulations regarding the conduct, and (4) there was a serious conflict between the antitrust and regulatory regimes. An antitrust action in this context would be accompanied by a substantial risk of injury to the securities markets.

An attorney representing a state prisoner who had been convicted of murder and sentenced to death in a Texas court filed a petition for certiorari in the United States Supreme Court seeking review with respect to the prisoner's death sentence, notwithstanding that the prisoner had informed the attorney that he did not wish to pursue any further appeal in his case after his conviction and sentence had been affirmed by the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas (578 SW2d 699). Thereafter, the prisoner, acting pro se, moved for dismissal of the petition.

Corning Glass Works, which operates plants both in New York and in Pennsylvania, paid its night inspectors, who were all male, significantly higher wages than its day inspectors, who were all female and performed the same tasks. The employer continued this practice after the effective date (June 11, 1964) of the Equal Pay Act of 1963 (29 USCS 206(d)(1)), which prohibits sex discrimination by an employer in the payment of wages for equal work. Beginning in June 1966, the employer started to open up jobs on the night shift to women. Previously separate male and female seniority lists were consolidated and women became eligible to exercise their seniority, on the same basis as men, to bid for the higher paid night inspection jobs as vacancies occurred. On January 20, 1969, a new collective bargaining agreement went into effect, establishing a new "job evaluation" system for setting wage rates; the agreement abolished for the future the separate base wages for day and night shift inspectors and imposed a uniform base wage for inspectors exceeding the wage rate for the night shift previously in effect. All inspectors hired after January 20, 1969, were to receive the same base wage, whatever their sex or shift. The collective bargaining agreement further provided for a higher "red circle" rate for employees hired prior to the date of the agreement, when working as inspectors on the night shift; this "red circle" rate served essentially to perpetuate the differential in base wages between day and night inspectors.

Petitioner Gerald Groff is an Evangelical Christian who believes for religious reasons that Sunday should be devoted to worship and rest. In 2012, Groff took a mail delivery job with the United States Postal Service. Groff‚Äôs position generally did not involve Sunday work, but that changed after USPS agreed to begin facilitating Sunday deliveries for Amazon. To avoid the requirement to work Sundays on a rotating basis, Groff transferred to a rural USPS station that did not make Sunday deliveries. After Amazon deliveries began at that station as well, Groff remained unwilling to work Sundays, and USPS redistributed Groff‚Äôs Sunday deliveries to other USPS staff. Groff received ‚Äúprogressive discipline‚Äù for failing to work on Sundays, and he eventually resigned. Groff sued under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, asserting that USPS could have accommodated his Sunday Sabbath practice ‚Äúwithout undue hardship on the conduct of [USPS‚Äôs] business.‚Äù 42 U. S. C. ¬ß2000e(j). The District Court granted summary judgment to USPS. The Third Circuit affirmed based on this Court‚Äôs decision in Trans World Airlines, Inc. v. Hardison, 432 U. S. 63, which it construed to mean ‚Äúthat requiring an employer ‚Äòto bear more than a de minimis cost‚Äô to provide a religious accommodation is an undue hardship.‚Äù 35 F. 4th 162, 174, n. 18 (quoting 432 U. S., at 84). The Third Circuit found the de minimis cost standard met here, concluding that exempting Groff from Sunday work had ‚Äúimposed on his coworkers, disrupted the workplace and workflow, and diminished employee morale.‚Äù 35 F. 4th, at 175.

The plaintiffs, by profession engaged in the motion-picture industry, filed, in the Superior Court of Los Angeles County, a complaint alleging that the defendants, motion-picture producers and distributors, agreed with each other to exclude from employment all persons, including the plaintiffs, who refused, on the grounds of the Fifth Amendment, to answer questions concerning their political associations and beliefs put by the Un-American Activities Committee of the House of Representatives. The complaint was dismissed on the ground that the plaintiffs failed to allege that but for defendants' alleged interference any one of the plaintiffs would, or even probably or possibly would, have been employed in the industry. The District Court of Appeals, Second District, affirmed (142 Cal App2d 183, 298 P2d 152). The United States Supreme Court granted the plaintiffs' petition for a writ of certiorari (352 US 980, 1 L ed 2d 364, 77 S Ct 381).

The Federal Trade Commission filed a complaint against Scott Tucker and his companies alleging deceptive payday lending practices in violation of ¬ß5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act. The District Court granted the Commission‚Äôs request pursuant to ¬ß13(b) of the Act for a permanent injunction to prevent Tucker from committing future violations of the Act, and relied on the same authority to direct Tucker to pay $1.27 billion in restitution and disgorgement. On appeal, the Ninth Circuit rejected Tucker‚Äôs argument that ¬ß13(b) does not authorize the award of equitable monetary relief.

Defendant was arraigned in a Louisiana state court on charges of armed robbery, kidnapping, and murder. His lawyers promptly filed a motion for a change of venue, based on the ground that defendant would be deprived of rights guaranteed to him by the United States Constitution if he were forced to trial in Calcasieu Parish after his televised interview in the jail with the parish sheriff, consisting in interrogation by the sheriff and admissions by the defendant that he had perpetrated the crimes with which he was later charged. The motion for change of venue was denied, and defendant was accordingly convicted and sentenced to death on the murder charge in the Calcasieu Parish trial court. The judgment of conviction was affirmed by the Supreme Court of Louisiana. (242 La 431, 137 So 2d 283.)

An employee filed unfair labor practice charges against a restaurant after she was fired. The restaurant owners filed a suit in an Arizona state court, alleging that the employee and other demonstrators had engaged in mass picketing, harassed customers, blocked access to the restaurant, created a threat to public safety, and libeled the owners by false statements. The employee then filed a second charge with the National Labor Relations Board, alleging that the owners had filed the state suit in retaliation for the employees' protected, concerted activities and because unfair labor practice charges had been filed. An administrative law judge held that the prosecution of the state suit was retaliatory and violated 8(a)(1) and (4) of the National Labor Relations Act (29 USCS 158(a)(1) and (4)). The National Labor Relations Board adopted, with minor exceptions, the administrative law judge's findings and ordered the owners to withdraw their state court complaint. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit enforced the Board's order (660 F2d 1335).

A corporation owned two patents for an improved magnetic rodless cylinder, which was a piston-driven device that relied on magnets to move objects in a conveying system. During the patent prosecution proceedings, the application for the first patent was amended after the patent examiner rejected the initial application, on the grounds that the exact method of operation was unclear and that some claims had been made in an impermissible way. The second patent was also amended during a re-examination proceeding. Both amended applications added some references to prior art. Both amended patents added a new limitation, to the effect that the inventions contained a pair of sealing rings. The amended second patent added a further limitation as to the composition of the outer shell or "sleeve" of the device. After the corporation began selling the rodless cylinder, a competitor entered the market with a similar device, except that (1) the competitor's device employed a single sealing ring, and (2) the competitor's sleeve was made of a different material. Although the competitor's device did not fall within the literal claims of either of the corporation's patents, the corporation contended that the device was so similar that it infringed the patents under the doctrine of equivalents, which allows a patentee to claim insubstantial alterations that were not captured in drafting the original patent claim but which could be created through trivial changes. The corporation brought suit against the competitor in the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts. Prior to trial, the District Court granted the corporation partial summary judgment, having found infringement on one of the patents under the doctrine of equivalents. The remaining issues were tried to a jury, which found infringement on the other patent claim and assessed damages.

Two residents of a Montana ranch filed a Federal District Court suit which asserted claims against some federal officials--special agents of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service and an assistant United States attorney--for damages under Bivens v Six Unknown Named Agents of Federal Bureau of Narcotics (1971) 403 US 388, 29 L Ed 2d 619, 91 S Ct 1999. The residents' complaint included allegations to the effect that the officials had violated the residents' rights under the Federal Constitution's Fourth Amendment, in that allegedly (1) in 1993, a magistrate judge had issued a warrant authorizing the search of the ranch with appurtenant structures, excluding the residence, for evidence of the taking of wildlife in violation of federal laws; (2) about a week later, a multiple-vehicle caravan consisting of government agents and a crew of photographers and reporters from a cable news network had proceeded to a point near the ranch; (3) the agents had executed the warrant; (4) the agents later explained that over the course of the day, "the officers" had searched the ranch and its outbuildings pursuant to the authority conferred by the warrant; and (5) the agents further explained that the media crew had accompanied and observed the officers and had recorded the officers' conduct in executing the warrant. However, the District Court, in granting summary judgment in favor of the federal officials, ruled that the officials were entitled to qualified immunity, as the court expressed the view that at the time of the alleged incident, there was no clearly established law protecting individuals from the commercial recording of a search of their premises. On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in reversing in pertinent part and in ordering a remand, expressed the view that--viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the residents for purposes of decision--(1) the search of the ranch violated the Fourth Amendment, and (2) the federal officials were not entitled to qualified immunity (129 F3d 505, 1997 US App LEXIS 31848).

Banks in Texas and Pennsylvania applied to the Comptroller of the Currency for approval of bank mergers in those states pursuant to the Bank Merger Act of 1966. Although the Attorney General and the Federal Reserve System both submitted adverse reports as to the mergers, the Comptroller approved them. The United States filed civil suits under 7 of the Clayton Act in the United States District Courts for the Southern District of Texas and for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, seeking to prevent the mergers. The Comptroller intervened and the District Courts dismissed the complaints. (262 F Supp 397.)

In separate incidents, two students were suspended from a public elementary school and a public secondary school without being given an adjudicatory hearing. The students filed suits against school officials in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois under 42 USCS 1983, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief, together with actual and punitive damages. After granting the students preliminary injunctions, the two cases were combined for trial. The District Court held that the students had been suspended without the procedural due process required by the Fourteenth Amendment and that they were entitled to declaratory relief, but that their claims for damages failed for complete lack of proof. On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit reversed, holding that the students were entitled to recover substantial nonpunitive damages even if the suspensions were justified, and even if they did not prove that any other actual injury was caused by the denial of procedural due process (545 F2d 30).

A general agent employed by the United States under the terms of the war-time standard form of general agency agreement to manage certain phases of the business of a ship owned by the United States and operated by the War Shipping Administration is not liable under _ 33 of the Merchant Marine Act of 1920, known as the Jones Act, to a member of the crew of the ship who suffered physical injury through the negligence of its master and officers, when the injury occurred after March 24, 1943, the date of enactment of the War Shipping Administration Act, known as the Clarification Act.

After the 1962 amendments to the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act of 1938, prohibiting the introduction into commerce of a "new drug" not generally recognized by experts as safe and effective for its intended uses, the Commissioner of Food and Drugs withdrew approval of the new drug application for Lutrexin for which its manufacturer had been granted approval in 1952, and denied the manufacturer's request for a hearing, on the ground that Lutrexin was not exempt under the grandfather clause of the 1962 amendments, and that the manufacturer had not submitted adequate evidence that Lutrexin is not a "new drug" or is effective. The evidence consisted of a list of literature references, a copy of an unpublished study, a representative sample testimonial letter on behalf of Lutrexin, and additional data. The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit reversed on the ground that while Lutrexin is not exempt under the grandfather clause of the 1962 amendments, the manufacturer was entitled to a hearing as to the effectiveness of Lutrexin (461 F2d 215). The court did not discuss the Commissioner's ruling that Lutrexin currently is not a "new drug."

A black and a white tenant of a San Francisco apartment complex sued the apartment owner-operator in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California, alleging that the owner-operator was engaged in discriminatory housing practices, in violation of the Civil Rights Act of 1968, by maintaining a "white ghetto" and depriving the plaintiffs of their right to live in a racially integrated community. The District Court dismissed the complaint on the ground that the tenants lacked standing to sue (322 F Supp 352), and the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit affirmed on the ground that only those who are the objects of discriminatory housing practices have standing to sue to challenge them (446 F2d 1158).

Inquiries as to thefts of property of a corporation were conducted by the head of a detective agency, together with two of its employees and a member of the state police force detailed to assist in the investigation, in which they obtained confessions from suspects by physical force and violence. Thereupon they were indicted for violations of 19 and 20 of the Criminal Code (now 18 USC 241, 242). The pertinent provisions of 19 prohibit a conspiracy to injure a citizen in the free enjoyment of any right or privilege secured to him by the Federal Constitution, and those of 20 penalize a person who under color of state law wilfully subjects any inhabitant of a state to the deprivation of any rights, privileges, or immunities so secured or protected. As to the charges under 20, the head of the agency was convicted and the other defendants were acquitted. As to all defendants a mistrial was declared under 19, the jury being unable to agree on a verdict. Upon a new indictment under 19 all the defendants were convicted, but on appeal the judgment was reversed by the Court of Appeals.

The Internal Revenue Service summoned a corporate taxpayer's president in 1963 to give testimony and produce records relating to the taxpayer's 1958 and 1959 returns, but the president refused to produce the records because the 3-year statute of limitations barred assessment of deficiencies for those years except in cases of fraud, and the Service indicated no grounds for its belief that a fraud had been committed. In a subsequent proceeding brought pursuant to 7604(b) of the 1954 Internal Revenue Code for enforcement of the administrative summons, the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania ruled that an internal revenue agent be given one hour to re-examine the taxpayer's records. The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit reversed on the ground that the examination was an "unnecessary examination," barred by 7605(b), unless the Service had information which might cause a reasonable man to suspect that there had been fraud in the returns for the closed years, and that whether this was established was to be decided in an adversary proceeding. (325 F2d 914.)

In 1970, the National Labor Relations Board certified a union as the collective bargaining agent for an employer's production and maintenance employees. In 1979, a collective bargaining agreement between the union and the employer expired, and after negotiations toward a new agreement failed, the union commenced an economic strike. Five employees immediately crossed the picket line and reported for work. During the strike, the employer hired 29 permanent replacement employees to replace the 22 striking employees. The union subsequently ended the strike, offering to accept unconditionally the employer's last contract offer. The employer informed the union that the offer was no longer open. At that time, the bargaining unit consisted of 19 strikers, 25 permanent replacements, and the 5 employees who had crossed the picket line. The employer withdrew recognition from the union and refused to bargain further, expressing doubt that the union was supported by a majority of the bargaining unit. The employer also refused to provide the union with information concerning the total number of bargaining-unit employees on the payroll and the job classification and seniority of each employee. The union filed an unfair labor practice charge with the Board. After an investigation, the General Counsel issued a complaint, alleging that the employer's withdrawal of recognition, its refusal to execute a contract embodying the terms of its last offer, and its failure to provide the union with employee information violated 8(a)(1) and 8(a)(5) of the National Labor Relations Act (29 USCS 158(a)(1), 158(a)(5)). The employer defended its conduct by asserting that it had a reasonably based, good-faith doubt of the union's majority status. The administrative law judge found for the employer and dismissed the complaint. The Board reversed, holding that the employer offered insufficient evidence to rebut the presumption of the union's continuing majority status; regarding the hiring of striker replacements, the Board refused to presume that the replacements opposed the union. The Board determined that the employer had violated 8(a)(1) and 8(a)(5) and ordered the employer to bargain with the union upon request, provide employee information, execute a collective bargaining agreement, and make the bargaining-unit employees whole for whatever losses they had suffered as a result of the employer's failure to execute a contract (287 NLRB No. 35). The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit refused to enforce the Board's order; holding that the employer was justified in doubting the union's majority status, the Court of Appeals rejected the Board's decision not to presume that striker replacements opposed the union (859 F2d 362).

By a treaty of 1868 between the United States and the Ute Indians, a reservation was established for the Indians in Colorado. Subsequently, an erroneous survey showed the northern boundary to be south of the true boundary and as excluding the White River Valley lands which actually were in the reservation. Believing the survey to be accurate and desiring to preserve these lands for the use of the Indians, the President, by an Executive Order of 1875, withdrew from sale and "set apart for the use of the . . . Ute Indians, as an addition to the present reservation in said Territory" a strip of land north "of the present Ute Indian Reservation." Later, in order to punish the Indians for a massacre, dispossess them of the reservation, and remove them from Colorado, Congress passed the Act of June 15, 1880, 21 Stat. 199, which ratified and embodied an agreement by their leaders to cede to the United States all territory of "the present Ute Reservation," and provided that all lands so ceded and not allotted specifically to individual Indians would be restored to the public domain for sale as public lands and that, subject to certain conditions, the proceeds of their sale should be distributed to the Indians. An Executive Order of 1882 declared that the lands "set apart for the use of the . . . Ute Indians" by the Executive Order of 1875 is "hereby restored to the public domain." The Indians brought this suit under the Act of June 28, 1938, 52 Stat. 1209, as amended, 55 Stat. 593, to obtain compensation for the lands north of the original reservation made available to them by the Executive Order of 1875.

The district court's order, that had not resolved a demand for an injunction, was not final, thus, the governor's appeal was timely. For _ 1973cpurposes, the invalidated law never gained "force or effect." Thus, the reversion to the prior practice of gubernatorial appointment of a county commission vacancy was not a "change" requiring preclearance. Since the invalidated state law was never "in force or effect," the baseline practice for filling vacancies was the prior gubernatorial appointment practice. Reinstating that practice thus did not constitute a change requiring preclearance. The invalidated state law was a temporary misapplication of state law, on the books for just over three years and applied once. It was challenged in state court at first opportunity and ultimately invalidated and thus properly regarded as null and void ab initio, incapable of effecting any change for _ 1973c purposes. Practically, the district court's decision gave controlling effect to the erroneous trial court decision and rendered the Alabama Supreme Court's corrections inoperative. Nothing inherent in gubernatorial appointments violated theFifteenth Amendment or the Voting Rights Act.

After petitioner Thompson‚Äôs fianc√©e, Miriam Regalado, filed a sex discrimination charge with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) against their employer, respondent North American Stainless (NAS), NAS fired Thompson. He filed his own charge and a subsequent suit under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act, claiming that NAS fired him to retaliate against Regalado for filing her charge. The District Court granted NAS summary judgment on the ground that third-party retaliation claims were not permitted by Title VII, which prohibits discrimination against an employee ‚Äúbecause he has made a [Title VII] charge,‚Äù 42 U. S. C. ¬ß2000e‚Äì3(a), and which permits, inter alia, a ‚Äúperson claiming to be aggrieved . . . by [an] alleged employment practice‚Äù to file a civil action, ¬ß2000e‚Äì5(f)(1). The en banc Sixth Circuit affirmed, reasoning that Thompson was not entitled to sue NAS for retaliation because he had not engaged in any activity protected by the statute.

The Arkansas Public Service Commission (PSC) entered an order asserting jurisdiction over the wholesale rates charged by a rural power cooperative to its member retail distributors. The PSC held that state regulation was neither forbidden by the commerce clause of the United States Constitution (Art I, 8, cl 3) nor pre-empted by the Federal Power Act (16 USCS 791a et seq.) and the Rural Electrification Act (7 USCS 901 et seq.). On review, the Pulaski County Circuit Court set aside the PSC's order. The Arkansas Supreme Court reversed and upheld the jurisdiction of the PSC (273 Ark 170, 618 SW2d 151).

The Chicago and North Western Railway Company sued the United Transportation Union in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, seeking injunctive relief against the union's threatened strike, on the ground that the union had failed to perform its obligation under 2 First of the Railway Labor Act to exert every reasonable effort to make and maintain agreements concerning rates of pay, rules, and working conditions. The trial court concluded that the question was not justiciable, and that the Norris-LaGuardia Act deprived it of jurisdiction to enjoin the strike. The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit affirmed. (422 F2d 979.)

Under Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (42 USCS 2000d et seq.), 601 of the 1964 Act (42 USCS 2000d) prohibits discrimination based on race, color, or national origin in covered programs and activities. Also, 602 of the 1964 Act (42 USCS 2000d-1) authorizes federal agencies to effectuate 601 by issuing regulations. The United States Department of Justice (DOJ), in an exercise of this authority, promulgated a regulation forbidding federal funding recipients to utilize criteria or administrative methods having the effect of subjecting individuals to discrimination based on the prohibited grounds ( 28 CFR 42.104(b)(2)). Alabama's department of public safety accepted grants of federal financial assistance and thus was subject to the restrictions of Title VI. The state of Alabama amended its constitution to make English the official language of Alabama. The department, in response to this amendment and allegedly as a matter of public safety, required that all state driver's license tests be administered in English. An Alabama resident--representing a class of all Alabama residents who were otherwise qualified to obtain a private vehicle driver's license but could not do so because they were not sufficiently fluent in English--filed a class action suit against the department and its director in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Alabama. The District Court, in granting summary judgment for the class, (1) rejected the argument that Title VI did not provide a private cause of action to enforce the DOJ regulation, (2) concluded that the English-only policy subjected non-English speakers to discrimination based on their national origin, (3) enjoined the policy as violative of the DOJ regulation, and (4) ordered the department to accommodate non-English speakers. The United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit affirmed (197 F3d 484).

Two individuals, who were the officers and part owners of a company which was a lessor of office copiers, sold the company's interest in the income stream from a number of lease contracts to several banks in order to raise cash. The government alleged that the individuals conspired to, and did, violate 18 USCS 1014--making it a crime to make a false statement to a federally insured bank--in that (1) the leases presented to the banks contained secret side agreements, regarding service obligations, which the individuals concealed in order to avoid tying up cash in reserve accounts, which the banks might have required had the existence of the service agreements been known to them, and (2) the individuals had given a bank forgeries of their wives' signatures on personal guarantees designed to enable the bank to pursue the wives' assets in the event of the company's default. At the end of the trial, a Federal District Court instructed the jury, at the government's behest, that (1) withholding a material fact made a statement or representation false, and (2) materiality was an issue for the judge to determine. The jury convicted the individuals, the court treated the statements as material, and the individuals appealed. While the appeal was pending, the United States Supreme Court decided United States v Gaudin (1995) 515 US    , 132 L Ed 2d 444, 115 S Ct 2310, in which it was held that the element of materiality under 18 USCS 1001 (also dealing with false statements) was to be determined by the jury. The United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit in the case at hand--following supplemental briefing on the Gaudin decision's applicability, in which briefing the government argued for the first time that materiality was not an element under 1014--(1) expressed the view that under 1014 materiality was an element upon which the individuals were entitled to a jury's determination, and (2) vacated the convictions and remanded for a new trial (63 F.3d 745).

Three defendants, among them the petitioner in the instant habeas corpus proceedings, were convicted in a New York state court of a felony murder, the sole evidence against each defendant being his signed confession. The petitioner did not, but the other defendants did, appeal their convictions. While these appeals were unsuccessful, subsequent legal proceedings in the state courts resulted in the releases of the other defendants on findings that their confessions had been coerced. Petitioner instituted the present habeas corpus proceeding in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, in which the coercive nature of his confession was conceded. Relief was denied on the ground that because of his failure to appeal he had not exhausted the remedies available in the state courts. (183 F Supp 222.) The Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit reversed and ordered that petitioner's conviction be set aside and that he be discharged from custody unless given a new trial forthwith. (300 F2d 345.)

Under the standard of New York Times Co. v Sullivan (1964) 376 US 254, 11 L Ed 2d 686, 84 S Ct 710, proof of actual malice, which is defined as publication of a statement with knowledge of its falsity or reckless disregard as to its truth or falsity, is required, by the Federal Constitution's First Amendment, for recovery by a public figure in a defamation action. A psychoanalyst was terminated from his position as projects director of archives containing materials about Sigmund Freud, including his writings, letters, and personal library, after the psychoanalyst, having become disillusioned with Freudian psychology, advanced his theories of Freud in a lecture before a psychoanalytical society. Subsequently, an author, after tape recording a series of interviews with the psychoanalyst, wrote an article on his relationship with the archives for a magazine. After the article, which contained lengthy passages that were in quotation marks and were attributed to the psychoanalyst, was published in the magazine, a book publisher, with knowledge of at least the allegation by the psychoanalyst, who alleged that there were errors in some of the quoted passages, that the article contained defamatory material, published the article as a book, which portrayed the psychoanalyst in an unflattering light. The psychoanalyst brought an action for libel under California law in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California against the author, the magazine, and the book publisher. With respect to each of six quotations attributed to the psychoanalyst in the article, no identical statement appeared in the more than 40 hours of the author's taped interviews with the psychoanalyst. However, the author alleged that not all of her discussions with the psychoanalyst were recorded on tape. The District Court, finding that the allegedly fabricated quotations were either substantially true or were rational interpretations of ambiguous conversations, granted summary judgment for the author, magazine, and book publisher, where the parties had agreed that the psychoanalyst was a public figure and so could escape summary judgment only if the evidence in the record would permit a reasonable finder of fact, by clear and convincing evidence, to conclude that the article contained defamatory material that was published with actual malice (686 F Supp 1396). On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, affirming the District Court judgment, concluded that one of the quotations was not defamatory, and that, under the incremental harm doctrine--under which the incremental reputational harm inflicted by allegedly defamatory statements beyond the harm imposed by the nonactionable remainder of the publication containing the statements is measured to determine whether the incremental harm is sufficient to be actionable--the quotation would not be actionable (895 F2d 1536).

Under the Aid to Families with Dependent Children (AFDC) program, the Federal Government partially reimburses states that provide financial assistance to families with needy dependent children, as long as the states administer their assistance plans in conformity with federal statutes (42 USCS 601-615) and United States Department of Health and Human Services' (HHS) regulations. Although the federal statute defines neither term, it requires the consideration of a family's "income" and "resources" when determining whether the family is needy (42 USCS 602(a)(7)(A)), and prohibits the providing of AFDC benefits for any month in which either income or resources exceed state-prescribed limits (42 USCS 602(a)(7)(B)). Because income eligibility and resources eligibility are separately computed, and because state limits for the two generally differ, whether, and for how long, a family that acquired a sum of money was rendered ineligible for ADFC benefits at times depended on whether the sum was classified as income or as a resource. Under an amendment to the AFDC statute (42 USCS 602(a)(17)), if a given sum of money was treated as a resource, a family would be ineligible only until it spent enough of the sum to bring the amount down to the state's resource limit, but if the money was treated as income, a family would remain ineligible, no matter how much was spent, for the statutory period. In response to the AFDC amendment, the Virginia Department of Social Services revised its regulations to treat various lump-sum payments, including personal injury awards, as income rather than as resources, although the regulations continued to treat property damage awards as resources. Personal injury award recipients, who were disqualified from Virginia's AFDC program pursuant to the revised state regulations, filed a class-action suit in the United States District Court for the District of Western Virginia against the Secretary of HHS and the Commissioner of the Virginia Department of Social Services, alleging that the treatment of personal injury awards as income was inconsistent with the AFDC statute. The District Court granted summary judgment in the class' favor, holding that the common meaning of the term "income" precluded application of that term to personal injury awards, and that it was irrational to treat personal injury awards as income while treating awards for property loss as resources. The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit affirmed in all respects (774 F2d 1270).

After a corporation filed a petition for relief under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code (11 USCS 1101-1174), an officer and shareholder of the corporation drew a $ 26,000 check on the corporate account and used $ 20,000 of that money to obtain a cashier's check payable to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). As directed, the IRS applied these funds against the officer's individual tax liability. The bankruptcy trustee appointed for the corporation subsequently commenced an adversary proceeding in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Northern District of Ohio, which proceeding sought to recover, among other transfers, the $ 20,000 paid by the officer to the IRS. Determining that the officer's unauthorized postpetition transfer could be avoided under 11 USCS 549(a) and recovered from the IRS under 11 USCS 550(a), the Bankruptcy Court entered judgment against the IRS in the amount of $ 20,000. The United States District Court for the Northern District of Ohio affirmed. The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in affirming, rejected a defense, raised for the first time on appeal, that sovereign immunity barred the judgment entered against the government, as the court found that the sovereign immunity of the United States had been waived by 11 USCS 106(c)--which states that notwithstanding any assertion of sovereign immunity, (1) any provision of the Bankruptcy Code which contains the terms "creditor," "entity," or "governmental unit" applies to governmental units, and (2) a determination by the court of an issue arising under a Code provision binds governmental units (915 F2d 1049).

Under Ohio law, sales of natural gas by state-regulated local public utilities were exempt from the state's general sales and use taxes that were applied to sales of natural gas by other in-state and out-of-state sellers. After the application by the state tax commissioner of the use tax to a company's natural gas purchases from independent out-of-state marketers for the company's plants in the state was sustained by the state board of tax appeals, the company appealed to the Supreme Court of Ohio on, among other contentions, the grounds that the state tax regime facially violated the Federal Constitution's commerce clause (Art I, 8, cl 3) and violated the equal protection clause of the Constitution's Fourteenth Amendment. After initially concluding that the tax regime did not violate the commerce clause, the Supreme Court of Ohio (1) stepped back to rule that because the company was not an out-of-state vendor of natural gas, the company lacked standing to bring the commerce clause challenge, and (2) dismissed the company's equal protection claim as submerged in its commerce clause argument (73 Ohio St 3d 29, 63 N.E.2d 188).

A coal company owning several deep shaft mines in the midwestern United States was a member of a national multiemployer group which--with respect to the midwestern mines--bargained with a union representing its employees. Through its collective bargaining contract with the union, the coal company, along with the other members of the multiemployer group, agreed to contribute to the union's national pension and welfare trust fund established under 302(c)(5) of the Labor Management Relations Act (29 USCS 186(c)(5)). In accord with 302(c)(5), the trust funds were administered by three trustees, one selected by the union, one by the members of the multiemployer group, and one by the other two. Subsequently, the coal company opened a surface mine in Wyoming, but did not join the national multiemployer group with respect to that mine. Eventually, the union struck the mine and other western mines, attempting to compel the mine owners to establish a multiemployer bargaining unit and to agree to a new contract under which members of the new employer unit would contribute to the national trust funds. The union began separate negotiations with the coal company, but these negotiations came to an impasse while the union continued its strike at the surface mine. The coal company then filed unfair labor practice charges against the union with the National Labor Relations Board, charging that the union had attempted to coerce it illegally in the selection of its collective bargaining representative in violation of 8(b)(1)(B) of the National Labor Relations Act (29 USCS 158(b)(1)(B)), which makes it an unfair labor practice for a union "to restrain or coerce ... an employer in the selection of his representatives for the purposes of collective bargaining or the adjustment of grievances." The coal company took the view that any management-appointed trustee of a 302(c)(5) trust fund was a collective bargaining "representative" of the employer within the meaning of 8(b)(1)(B). The coal company reasoned that, since the management trustee of the national trust fund had already been selected by the multiemployer group, the union's insistence that it participate in the national trust fund with regard to the surface mine's employees constituted illegal coercion under 8(b)(1)(B). The Board concluded that the union had acted legally in bargaining to impasse and striking to obtain the coal company's participation in the national trust funds for the surface mine's employees, but the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit reversed, holding that management-appointed trustees of a 302(c)(5) trust fund act as both fiduciaries of the employee-beneficiaries and as agents of the appointing employers, and that the union had acted in violation of 8(b)(1)(B) in exerting its economic power to induce the coal company to participate in the national trust funds with respect to the surface mine's employees (614 F2d 872).

A petition for certiorari was filed on December 14, 1978, some 17 months out of time as a conventional petition for certiorari under Rule 22(2) of the Rules of the United States Supreme Court, by a pro se petitioner whose convictions in a Federal District Court on criminal charges had been affirmed on June 9, 1977, by the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. The petitioner, whose petition presented a single question--"What remedy is available for petitioner when court-appointed attorney failed and refused to file timely petition for writ of certiorari in defiance of the petitioner's written request that same be done?"--alleged that he had asked the court-appointed lawyer representing him at the time to file a timely petition for certiorari after the Court of Appeals' decision, that in September of 1977 he had received an assurance from the lawyer that such request had been honored, that in July of 1978, he had learned from the Clerk of the United States Supreme Court that no petition had been filed, and that subsequent letters to the attorney were never answered.

Three months after an accused had been convicted of second-degree murder in a jury trial in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, defense counsel moved for a new trial. Defense counsel asserted that (1) the murder victim had a prior criminal record that would have further evidenced the victim's violent character, thus supporting the defense argument that the accused had acted in self-defense, (2) the prosecutor had failed to disclose the victim's record to the defense, and (3) there was recent authority that such evidence was admissible even if not known to the defendant. The District Court denied the new trial motion, but rejected the government's argument that there was no duty to tender the victim's criminal record to the defense in the absence of an appropriate request, holding that even if it were assumed that the evidence was admissible, nevertheless it was not sufficiently material. The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia reversed (167 App DC 28, 510 F2d 1249).

During a trial in the 108th Judicial District Court, Potter County, Texas, which trial resulted in a conviction for knowingly attempting to pass a forged instrument, the trial court admitted in evidence certain checks that had been seized during a warrantless search of the defendant's car at the police station after the defendant had been arrested at a bank, and after a police officer had driven the defendant's car to the station house. The trial judge expressly found probable cause for the search of the car either at the scene of the arrest or at the station house. However, the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas reversed the defendant's conviction on the ground that the checks had been obtained in violation of the defendant's Fourth Amendment rights (521 SW2d 255).

In a 1962 murder trial in the Superior Court of Effingham County, Georgia, the jury, without reference to the charge of murder, returned a verdict of guilty to the lesser-included crime of voluntary manslaughter and fixed the sentence at 10 to 15 years in the state penitentiary. The Court of Appeals of Georgia reversed the conviction because of an erroneous jury instruction and ordered a new trial (108 Ga App 581, 133 SE2d 916). In 1967, the accused was again placed on trial for murder under the original indictment. The trial judge, rejecting a double jeopardy claim, included instructions on the offense of murder in his charge to the jury, so that the jury could have rendered a verdict of guilty on that offense. That jury, like the first, found the accused guilty of voluntary manslaughter and fixed the penalty at 10 years' imprisonment. The accused sought direct review of his second conviction in the Supreme Court of Georgia, but that court transferred the case to the Court of Appeals of Georgia (224 Ga 306, 161 SE2d 825). The Court of Appeals affirmed the second conviction, rejecting the double jeopardy argument on the ground that the case of Brantley v State, 132 Ga 573, 64 SE 676, affd 217 US 284, 54 L Ed 768, 30 S Ct 514, was controlling (118 Ga App 207, 163 SE2d 243). On rehearing, the Court of Appeals rejected the contention that the Brantley Case was no longer controlling. The Georgia Supreme Court denied certiorari.

Regulations governing eligibility for disability benefits under Titles II and XVI of the Social Security Act (42 USCS 401-431, 1381-1383c) establish a "sequential evaluation" process. Eligibility is initially determined by a state agency acting under the authority and control of the Secretary of Health and Human Services, and the agency's decisions are reviewable by the Social Security Administration (SSA), which may return a case to the agency for correction. A disappointed claimant is then afforded a three-stage administrative review process, the completion of which results in the exhaustion of the claimant's administrative remedies, and the claimant may then seek judicial review within 60 days of notice of the action taken, as provided in 42 USCS 405(g). A class action was brought in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York against the Secretary and the SSA Commissioner by named individuals, seeking relief on behalf of all individuals residing in New York who had applied for or received disability benefits, who had been found to have a severe mental impairment, and who had been denied disability benefits or whose benefits had been terminated, pursuant to an allegedly unpublished and unlawful policy of the Secretary. The plaintiffs claimed that the failure to make the policy known to claimants denied the individual plaintiffs and class members due process of law. Holding that the policy in question was illegal, the District Court also (1) held that the class included claimants who had not exhausted administrative remedies as well as those who had not complied with the 60-day requirement for judicial review, (2) ordered the Secretary to reopen the decisions denying or terminating benefits and to redetermine eligibility, and (3) awarded interim relief (578 F Supp 1109). The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit affirmed, holding that the District Court had jurisdiction over the claims of class members who had failed to exhaust their administrative remedies and the claims of those who failed to seek judicial review within the 60-day period (742 F2d 729, rehearing denied 755 F2d 331).

In a declaratory judgment action, the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court held that a national bank was not exempt from Massachusetts sales and use taxes on its purchases of tangible personal property. (229 NE2d 245.)

A longshoremen's union and an employer's association, upon disagreeing as to the interpretation of "set-back" provisions of the collective bargaining agreement relating to compensation of longshoremen who are told after they report for duty that they will not be needed until the afternoon, submitted the dispute to an arbitrator, who upheld the association's interpretation of the contract provisions in an award setting forth an abstract conclusion of law. After work stoppages resulted from disputes under the contract "set- back" provisions which the union contended were not controlled by the arbitrator's award, the employers' association instituted an action in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, seeking to enforce the arbitrator's award. The District Court entered a decree merely requiring that the arbitrator's award "be specifically enforced," and ordering the union "to comply with and to abide by" the award, refusing to explain such decree to counsel for the union. After subsequent "set-back" disputes resulted in further work stoppage, the District Court held the union in contempt, refusing to specify what acts by the union had violated the enforcement order. The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit affirmed both the original enforcement decree (365 F2d 295) and the subsequent contempt order (368 F2d 932).

In an action brought by a railroad policeman against his employer under the Federal Employers' Liability Act (FELA) (45 USCS 51 et seq.), to recover for injuries sustained in the course of his employment, the Circuit Court of the city of St. Louis, Missouri, denied the employer's request to instruct the jury that any award for loss of future earnings should reflect the present value of such losses, and entered judgment on a verdict in favor of the policeman. The Circuit Court refused to submit such an instruction because it was not among those promulgated by the Supreme Court of Missouri for use in FELA cases. The Missouri Court of Appeals affirmed (674 SW2d 165).

Under the one-person, one-vote principle, jurisdictions must design legislative districts with equal populations. See Wesberry v. Sanders, 376 U. 5. 1, 7-8, Reynolds v. Sims, 377 U. 5. 533, 568. In the context of state and local legislative districting, States may deviate somewhat from perfect population equality to accommodate traditional districting objectives. Where the maximum population deviation between the largest and smalest district is less than 10%, a state or local legislative map presumptively complies with the one-person, onevote rule. Texas, like al other States, uses total-population numbers from the decennial census when drawing legislative districts. After the 2010 census, Texas adopted a State Senate map that has a maximum total-population deviation of 8.04%, safely within the presumptively permissible 10% range. However, measured by a voter-population baseline-eligible voters or registered voters-the map's maximum population deviation exceeds 40%. Appellants, who live in Texas Senate districts with particularly large eligible- and registered-voter populations, ified suit against the Texas Governor and Secretary of State. Basing apportionment on total population, appellants contended, dilutes their votes in relation to voters in other Senate districts, in violation of the one-person, one-vote principle of the Equal Protection Clause. Appellants sought an injunction barring use of the existing Senate map in favor of a map that would equalize the voter population in each district. A three-judge District Court dismissed the complaint for failure to state a claim on which relief could be granted.

An indictment charged the defendant with engaging in the business of accepting wagers without first filing Internal Revenue Service form 11-C, the special return and registration application required by 4412 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1954, and without first paying the occupational tax imposed by 4411 of the Code. The indictment further charged that when the defendant did file such a form, he knowingly and wilfully understated the number of employees accepting wagers on his behalf--in violation of 18 USC 1001, the general criminal provision punishing the making of fraudulent statements to the government. In the United States District Court for the Western District of Texas, the defendant moved to dismiss the indictment, asserting that the wagering tax laws that required him to file the special return had been held invalid by the United States Supreme Court. The government did not pursue the charges under 4411 and 4412, but argued that the alleged invalidity of the wagering tax laws was "largely irrelevant" to the 1001 charge. The District Court dismissed the indictment, reasoning that the defendant could not be prosecuted for his "failure to answer the wagering form correctly," since his Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination would have prevented prosecution for "failure to answer the form in any respect" (unreported memorandum; 298 F Supp 1260).

At defendant's express request, defendant's biological mother and ex-wife refused to testify in mitigation at sentencing that the mother used drugs and alcohol during her pregnancy with defendant and that defendant was a good father. Defendant also stated to the sentencing court that he did not wish to present any mitigating evidence, and defendant repeatedly interrupted counsel's efforts to raise matters in mitigation. The U.S. Supreme Court held that it was well within the lower court's discretion to determine that, even with the benefit of an evidentiary hearing, defendant could not develop a factual record that would entitle him to habeas relief. Defendant could not show prejudice from any failure of counsel to investigate additional mitigating evidence, since the record indicated that defendant would have interrupted and refused to allow his counsel to present any such evidence. Further, the record also showed that defendant understood the consequences of refusing to allow evidence in mitigation, and the facts which defendant sought to prove in an evidentiary hearing constituted weak evidence in mitigation and would not have changed the result.

A federal employee was charged with violating 18 USC 281 by agreeing to receive compensation from the petitioner, a subcontractor on various government projects for equipping air force survival kits, for services to be rendered by the employee in regard to purchase requests concerning goggles for such kits. Petitioner was charged with inducing the federal employee to accept such outside compensation.

Michelle Cochran and Axon Enterprise, Inc.‚Äîrespondents in separate enforcement actions initiated in the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and the Federal Trade Commission (FTC)‚Äîeach filed suit in federal district court challenging the constitutionality of the agency proceedings against them. When, as in the enforcement actions against Cochran and Axon, a Commission elects to institute administrative proceedings to address statutory violations, it typically delegates the initial adjudication to an Administrative Law Judge (ALJ) with authority to resolve motions, hold a hearing, and then issue a decision. As prescribed by statute, a party objecting to the Commission proceedings makes its claims first within the Commission itself, and then (if needed) in a federal court of appeals. But the parties here sidestepped that review scheme and brought their claims in district court, seeking to enjoin the administrative proceedings. Cochran and Axon asserted that the tenure protections of the agencies‚Äô ALJs render them insufficiently accountable to the President, in violation of separation-of-powers principles. Axon also attacked as unconstitutional the combination of prosecutorial and adjudicatory functions in the FTC. Each suit premised jurisdiction on district courts‚Äô ordinary federal-question authority to resolve ‚Äúcivil actions arising under the Constitution, laws, or treaties of the United States.‚Äù 28 U. S. C. ¬ß1331. Cochran‚Äôs and Axon‚Äôs suits initially met the same fate: dismissal for lack of jurisdiction. The district court in Cochran‚Äôs case held that the review scheme specified in the Securities Exchange Act‚Äî‚Äúadministrative review followed by judicial review in a federal court of appeals‚Äù‚Äî ‚Äúimplicitly divest[s] district courts of jurisdiction‚Äù over ‚Äúchallenges to SEC proceedings,‚Äù including Cochran‚Äôs constitutional ones. Likewise, the district court in Axon‚Äôs case found that the FTC Act‚Äôs comparable review scheme displaces ¬ß1331 jurisdiction for claims concerning the FTC‚Äôs adjudications. On appeal, the Ninth Circuit affirmed the district court‚Äôs dismissal of Axon‚Äôs constitutional challenges to the FTC proceeding, concluding that the claims were the type that fell within the FTC Act‚Äôs review scheme. But the en banc Fifth Circuit disagreed as to the equivalent SEC question, finding that Cochran‚Äôs claim would not receive ‚Äúmeaningful judicial review‚Äù in a court of appeals; that the claim was ‚Äúwholly collateral to the Exchange Act‚Äôs statutory-review scheme‚Äù; and that the claim fell ‚Äúoutside the SEC‚Äôs expertise.‚Äù

During a criminal prosecution in the United States District Court for the Western District of Texas, the case was called, both sides announced ready, and a jury was selected and sworn and instructed to return that afternoon, when the prosecution asked that the jury be discharged because its key witness had not yet been found. Over the accused's objection, the court discharged the jury and 2 days later impaneled a second jury, which found the accused guilty. The Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit affirmed on the grounds that the trial court did not abuse its discretion in discharging the first jury, and that the impaneling of the second jury did not subject the accused to double jeopardy. (300 F2d 137.)

A company that manufactured asphalt kept its books, and prepared its 1974 federal income tax return, on a cash-receipts-and-disbursements basis. However, the company's 1974 year-end inventories and accounts receivable were substantially higher than in prior years, and these changes were not fully reflected in the tax return. The company also claimed a deduction of $ 1,103.04 for the expense of transporting two trucks that had been used by the company's shareholders in their individual capacities. The Commissioner of Internal Revenue (1) determined that the company had underpayed its taxes in the amount of $ 154,332.16, (2) determined that the company's failure to use an accrual method of accounting and its deduction of the truck transportation expenses constituted negligence, and (3) assessed a penalty of $ 7,716.61, or 5% of the full alleged underpayment, pursuant to 26 USCS 6653(a)(1), which provides that if any part of an underpayment of certain federal taxes is due to negligence, a penalty of 5% of the underpayment shall be added to the tax. The United States Tax Court (1) held that although the Commissioner did not abuse his discretion in requiring the company to use accrual accounting, the company's use of cash-basis accounting was not negligent, (2) affirmed the finding of negligence with respect to the truck transportation deduction, and (3) recalculated the underpayment as $ 133,248.69 and the negligence penalty as $ 6,943.37. The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, reversing the Tax Court's imposition of the negligence penalty on the full amount of the underpayment, (1) held that the penalty should be applied only to that portion of the underpayment attributable to the disallowed deduction, (2) affirmed the finding that the deduction for truck transportation expenses was negligent, and (3) affirmed the determination that the company was required to use accrual accounting (796 F2d 843).

A "Bivens action" or "Bivens claim"--based on the United States Supreme Court's decision in Bivens v Six Unknown Named Agents of Federal Bureau of Narcotics (1971) 403 US 388, 29 L Ed 2d 619, 91 S Ct 1999--generally (1) purports to be brought under a federal constitutional provision; and (2) alleges that a defendant such as a federal official violated that provision. The Supreme Court, however, has generally recognized a defense of qualified immunity to a Bivens action or claim, where the defendant's alleged acts did not violate a clearly established constitutional right. Allegedly, after a clinical psychologist had resigned from a federal hospital in Washington, D.C., the psychologist began working at a United States Army hospital in Bremerhaven, West Germany, and, in order to satisfy an Army requirement, signed a "Credential Information Request Form" asking the Washington hospital to provide information on the psychologist's prior job performance. A former supervisor of the psychologist supposedly replied with a negative letter to the effect that the psychologist had been inept, unethical, and untrustworthy, after which, allegedly, (1) an Army committee denied the psychologist credentials; (2) the psychologist was turned down for a position at another Army hospital; and (3) although the psychologist temporarily worked at the Bremerhaven hospital under provisional credentials, his federal service employment was terminated after his administrative appeal of the denial of full credentials was unsuccessful. The psychologist then filed a suit for damages against the supervisor in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, and included a Bivens claim that the supervisor, by writing and sending the letter, had caused an infringement of the psychologist's alleged liberty interests under the due process clause of the Federal Constitution's Fifth Amendment, through the supervisor's alleged publication, maliciously and in bad faith, of a defamatory per se statement. The supervisor, in filing a motion to dismiss or in the alternative for summary judgment, asserted the defense of qualified immunity to the Bivens claim. The District Court initially declined to decide the qualified immunity issue and ordered a limited amount of discovery. Upon the supervisor's motion for reconsideration and for a stay of discovery pending disposition of the qualified immunity issue, the District Court denied the motion and expressed the view that the psychologist's factual allegations were sufficient to state violations of a clearly established constitutional right (692 F Supp 1406).
